Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The following ordinances, arranged in chapters, articles, divisions, and sections, be and the same shall constitute and be designated and cited as the "City Code of Melbourne, Florida." 
(Code 1980, § 1-1; Code 1984, § 1-1) 
Charter reference- Codification requirement and authority, § 2.12. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and the ordinances of the city, the following rules shall be observed, and the following definitions of words and phrases apply, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    Charter. The term "Charter" means the Charter of the City of Melbourne, Florida. 
    City. The term "city" means the City of Melbourne, Florida, except as otherwise provided. 
    City council. The term "city council" or "council" means the city council of the City of Melbourne, Florida. 
    Code. The term "Code" means the City Code of Melbourne, Florida. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall be excluded in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall be included. Whenever any act required to be done pursuant to the provisions of this Code falls on a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, that act shall be performed on the next succeeding business day. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Florida Rules of Civil Procedure, § 1.090(a), Florida Rules of Judicial administration, Rule 2.514. 
    County. The term "county" means the County of Brevard in the State of Florida. 
State Law reference- Boundaries of Brevard County, F.S. § 7.05. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever, by the provisions of this Code, any officer of the city is assigned any duty or empowered to perform any act or duty, reference to such officer shall mean and include such officer or his deputy or authorized subordinate. 
    F.S. The abbreviation "F.S." means the latest edition or supplement of the Florida Statutes. 
    Gender. A term importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    Officer, employee, board, committee, commission. Whenever any officer, employee, board, committee, or commission is referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Melbourne, Florida." 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and" and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" may extend and be applied to bodies politic and corporate as well as individuals, partnerships, firms, associations, societies and institutions. 
    Property. The term "property" shall include real and personal property. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall. The term "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory, unless the context of use indicates otherwise. 
    Signature. The term "signature" includes a mark when the person cannot write, his name being written near it and witnessed by a person who writes his own name as witness. 
    Singular and plural. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; and a word importing the plural number only may extend and be applied to one person or thing, as well as to several persons or things. 
    State. The term "state" shall be construed to mean the State of Florida. 
    Street. The term "street" includes public avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the approaches thereto, parkways, freeways, turnpikes, and all other public thoroughfares in the city, and shall mean the entire width thereof between abutting property lines. It shall be construed to mean and include a sidewalk or footpath unless the contrary is expressed or unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council. 
    Tenant, occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," when applied to a building or land, include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the present or past tense shall include future as well as the present and past. 
    Writing. The term "writing" includes typewriting and printing. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1980, § 1-2; Code 1984, § 1-2; Ord. No. 2000-31, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
State Law reference- Statutory definitions, F.S. § 1.01. 
Sec. 1-3. - Section catchlines. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in bold type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles to such sections, nor as any part of such sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any such section, including the catchline, is amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1980, § 1-3; Code 1984, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
(Code 1984, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - References to chapters or sections. 
    All references in this Code to chapters, articles, divisions or sections are to the chapters, articles, divisions, and sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. 
Sec. 1-6. - References and editor's notes. 
    References and editor's notes following certain sections of this Code are inserted as an aid and guide to the reader and are not controlling or meant to have any legal effect. 
Sec. 1-7. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of the City Code of Melbourne, 1984, and of ordinances existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-8. - Code does not affect prior offenses, penalties, contracts, rights. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
State Law reference- No bill of attainder, ex post facto law, or any law impairing the obligation of contracts shall ever be passed, Fla. Const., art. I, § 10. 
Sec. 1-9. - Continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances existing prior to the adoption of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. When any ordinance which has repealed another shall itself be repealed, the previous ordinance shall not be revived without express words to that effect, unless the ordinance repealing it is passed during the same session of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 1-4; Code 1984, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-10. - When former ordinance repealed. 
    A new ordinance shall not be construed to repeal a former ordinance, as to any offense committed against the former ordinance, any act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred, or any right accrued, or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense or act so committed or done, or any penalty, forfeiture, or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued, or claim arising before the new ordinance takes effect. 
(Code 1980, § 1-5; Code 1984, § 1-6) 
State Law reference- No bill of attainder, ex post facto law, nor any law impairing the obligation of contract shall ever be passed, Fla. Const., Declaration of Rights, art. I, § 10. 
Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city, or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  Any administrative ordinances; 
(3)  Any right or franchise, permit or other right granted by any ordinance; 
(4)  Any ordinance establishing positions, classifying positions and setting salaries of city officers or employees; 
(5)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, alley or other public way in the city; 
(6)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades in the city; 
(7)  Any personnel regulations; 
(8)  Any land use, zoning or airport zoning ordinance; 
(9)  Any ordinance annexing territory or excluding territory from the city or redefining the boundaries of the city; 
(10)  Any appropriation ordinance or any ordinance levying or imposing taxes; 
(11)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(12)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city; 
(13)  Any ordinance establishing the official plat of the city, the zoning map or any amendments thereof not included herein; 
(14)  Any ordinance prescribing traffic and parking regulations for specific streets and locations; 
(15)  Any land development code, land development regulations, comprehensive plan or zoning ordinances or amendments, all terms as defined in F.S. § 163.3164; 
(16)  Any temporary or special ordinance; 
(17)  Any provisions of Laws of Fla. ch. 69-879, as amended by special law or otherwise, which have been converted to ordinances by F.S. ch. 166, and have not been amended by referendum, superseded or repealed; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1984, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-12. - Repeal of conflicting ordinances. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with ordinances appearing in this Code, but only such ordinances or parts of ordinances as are in conflict herewith, are hereby repealed; however, nothing herein contained shall be construed or taken as repealing or amending any of the provisions of any ordinance heretofore adopted as to any offense committed against the provisions of the ordinance, or as to any act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred under or by reason of the ordinance, prior to the time this Code takes effect, except as provided herein. 
(Code 1980, § 1-7; Code 1984, § 1-8) 
Sec. 1-13. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, illegal or otherwise void by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, illegality, or other declaration shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 1-6; Code 1984, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-14. - Penalty for violation of Code. 
    Whenever in this Code, or in any ordinance of the city, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or a violation of a municipal ordinance, or whenever in this Code, or in any ordinance of the city, the doing of any act is required or the failure to do an act is declared to be unlawful or a violation of a municipal ordinance, the violator of any such provision, section, or chapter of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of a court. Each day any violation of any provision, section or chapter of this Code shall continue or be omitted, if required and neglected, shall constitute a separate offense, and subject such violator to a separate fine or imprisonment, or both, for each such separate offense. 
(Code 1980, § 1-8; Code 1984, § 1-10) 
State Law reference- Penalty for violation of municipal ordinances, F.S. § 162.22. 
Sec. 1-15. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code which amend, repeal, or in any way affect the same may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection, or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section _____ of the City Code of Melbourne, Florida, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions should then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language is suggested: "That the City Code of Melbourne, Florida, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _____, which said section reads as follows:...." The new section should then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1980, § 1-9; Code 1984, § 1-11) 
Sec. 1-16. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code, and shall also include all amendments to the Charter during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ through _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1984, § 1-12) 
Sec. 1-17. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be an offense against the city for any person to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1980, § 1-10; Code 1984, § 1-13) 
State Law reference- Falsifying public records, F.S. § 839.13. 
Sec. 1-18. - Ordinances regulating firearms and ammunition. 
(a)  As established by F.S. § 790.33, including amendments thereto enacted by Laws of Fla. ch. 2011-109, except as expressly provided by the state constitution or by general law, the state legislature is occupying the entire field of regulation of firearms and ammunition, including the purchase, sale, transfer, taxation, manufacture, ownership, possession, storage and transportation thereof, to the exclusion of all existing and future county, city, town or municipal ordinances and any administrative regulations or rules adopted by local or state government relating thereto. Accordingly, all ordinances, regulations and rules set forth in or contemplated by this Code which in any manner regulate firearms or ammunition to the extent that the subject matter thereof has been properly occupied by, reserved to, or preempted by the state legislature are hereby declared to be null and void and shall not be interpreted, construed, implemented, enforced or the like in any manner so as to conflict with, be inconsistent with, or violate F.S. § 790.33, including any subsequent amendments thereto. 
(b)  The city acknowledges that the entire field of regulation of firearms and ammunition, including any components thereof, has been preempted by the state legislature and that, except as expressly provided by the state constitution or by general law, the city is preempted from adopting, enacting, implementing, or enforcing any ordinances, regulations and rules pertaining thereto to the extent that the subject matter thereof has been preempted by the state legislature. Accordingly, as a rule of construction and interpretation applicable to all provisions of this Code, it is hereby directed that no provision of this Code shall be deemed or interpreted in any manner to violate state law, including F.S. § 790.33; rather, the provisions of this Code shall be interpreted and constructed in a manner so as to not cause or result in a violation of state law, including F.S. § 790.33. 
(Code 1984, § 1-14; Ord. No. 2011-46, § 1, 9-20-2011) 
State Law reference- Regulation of firearms and ammunition preempted by the state, F.S. § 790.33.

(a)  The following symbol is hereby designated to be the official seal of the city: 

(b)  In accordance with state statutes, the manufacture, use, display, or other employment or any facsimile or reproduction of the municipal seal, except by municipal officials or employees in the performance of their official duties, without the express approval of the city manager, is a second-degree misdemeanor, punishable as provided in F.S. § 775.082 or 775.083. 
(Code 1984, § 2-2; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
State Law reference- Use of city seal restricted, penalty, F.S. § 165.043.

(a)  The following symbols are hereby designated to be the official logos for the city:

ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- City council, art. II; elections, art. V. 
State Law reference- Code of ethics for public officers and employees, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; public meetings, F.S. § 286.011; public records, F.S. ch. 119. 

Sec. 2-23. - Salary of mayor and city council; expense allowance. 
(a)  The annual salary of the mayor and council members shall be determined by a computation of the average salary of like positions derived from at least ten cities within the state that have a similar population and form of government. The salary shall be fixed by vote of the city council and shall be reviewed through updated survey information every five years. 
(b)  There shall also be paid to the mayor a $415.00 per month expense allowance, and there shall be paid to each council member a $255.00 per month expense allowance. In addition thereto, the mayor and council members shall be reimbursed in accordance with section 2-484 for their actual and necessary expenses incurred in travel outside of the county. 
(Code 1984, § 2-16; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2005-109, § 1, 9-27-2005) 
Charter reference- City council compensation, § 2.05. 
Sec. 2-24. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings. City council shall hold regular meetings on the second and fourth Tuesday of each month in the council chamber of the city or such other place within the city as the city council may from time to time designate. City council may alter the meeting schedule as a result of special circumstances. Any change in meeting schedule shall require the adoption of a resolution. City council shall, by policy, establish the starting time for regular city council meetings. 
(b)  Special meetings. Pursuant to section 2.09 of the Charter, the mayor or city manager may call special meetings of the city council whenever the public business may require it or at the express written request of any three members of the city council. 
(c)  Attendance by city officials. All regular and special city council meetings as provided for in this section shall be attended by the mayor, council members, city manager, city clerk, and the city attorney. If any such official cannot attend a meeting, the official shall notify the city clerk prior to the meeting of the reason for non-attendance, which reason shall be included in the minutes of the meeting. In cases of emergency, the official may notify the city clerk after the meeting for inclusion in the minutes. If the city manager, city clerk, or city attorney is unable to attend the meeting, the official shall make prior arrangements for attendance by their respective assistants at the meeting. 
(d)  Cancellation of meeting. If there is no business or a paucity of business (as determined by the mayor or, in the mayor's absence, the vice-mayor) to be transacted at a regular meeting, or if it appears that a quorum is likely not to be obtained at said meeting, the mayor or, in the mayor's absence, the vice-mayor may cancel the meeting; provided that no more than one regular meeting in any month may be cancelled. Any special meeting may be cancelled by the individual calling the meeting. 
(Code 1984, § 2-17; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 1, 5-23-2006) 
Charter reference- City council meetings, § 2.09. 
Sec. 2-25. - Presiding officer; duties. 
    Pursuant to section 2.04 of the Charter, the presiding officer of the city council shall be the mayor or, in the mayor's absence, the vice-mayor. The presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at all regular and special meetings of the city council. The presiding officer must state every question coming before the city council before a vote is taken, announce the decision of the city council on all subjects and decide all questions of order, subject, however, to an appeal to the city council, in which event a majority vote of the city council shall govern and conclusively determine such question of order. The presiding officer must vote on all questions, said presiding officer's name being called last, unless the presiding officer has a conflict of interest or is otherwise excused from voting. The presiding officer must sign all ordinances and resolutions adopted by the city council during said individual's presence. In the event of the absence of the mayor, the presiding officer shall sign ordinances or resolutions as then adopted. 
(Code 1984, § 2-18; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Charter reference- Mayor is presiding officer, § 2.04. 
Sec. 2-26. - Call to order; temporary presiding officer. 
    The mayor or, in his absence, the vice-mayor, shall call the city council to order at the time prescribed in the agenda for that meeting. In the absence of the mayor and vice-mayor, the city clerk, or the city clerk's assistant, shall call the city council to order, whereupon a temporary chair shall be elected by the members of the city council present. Upon the arrival of the mayor or vice-mayor, the temporary chair shall immediately relinquish the chair upon the conclusion of the item immediately before the city council. 
(Code 1984, § 2-19; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-27. - Roll call. 
    Before proceeding with the business of the city council, the city clerk or assistant city clerk shall call the roll of the members, and the name of those present and absent shall be entered in the minutes. 
(Code 1984, § 2-20; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-28. - Quorum. 
    A majority of all members of the city council shall constitute a quorum, but a lesser number may adjourn from day to day and compel the attendance of absent members. 
(Code 1984, § 2-21; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-29. - Order of business. 
    Unless an exemption is provided by state law, meetings of the city council shall be open to the public. During regular meetings, the business of the city council shall be taken up for consideration in generally the following order: 
(1)  Invocation. 
(2)  Pledge of Allegiance. 
(3)  Roll call. 
(4)  Proclamations and presentations. 
(5)  Approval of minutes of previous meeting. 
(6)  City manager's report. 
(7)  Public comments. (The time limit provision in section 2-32 does not apply to this item.) 
(8)  Unfinished business. 
(9)  New business, with engineering or construction contracts in excess of $50,000.00 appearing first and the consent agenda appearing second. 
(10)  Petitions, remonstrances and communications. 
(11)  Adjournment. 
(Code 1984, § 2-22; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-30. - Reading of minutes. 
    Unless a reading of the minutes of a city council meeting is requested by a majority of the city council, such minutes may be approved without reading if the clerk has previously furnished each member with a copy. 
(Code 1984, § 2-23; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-31. - Rules of debate. 
(a)  Presiding officer may debate and vote. The mayor or such other member of the city council as may be presiding may move, second and debate from the chair, subject only to such limitations of debate as are imposed by these rules on all members and shall not be deprived of any of the rights and privileges of a council member by reason of his acting as the presiding officer. 
(b)  Getting the floor; improper references to be avoided. Every member desiring to speak must address the chair and, upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall confine comments to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. 
(c)  Interruptions. A member, once recognized, must not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call said member to order, or as herein otherwise provided. If a member, while speaking, is called to order, the member will cease speaking until the question of order is determined and, if in order, the member will be permitted to proceed. 
(d)  Privilege of closing debate. The council member moving the adoption of an ordinance or resolution has the privilege of closing the debate. 
(e)  Motion to reconsider. A motion to reconsider any action taken by the city council may be made only on the day such action was taken. It may be made either immediately during the same session or at a recessed or adjourned session thereof. Such motion must be made by a council member on the prevailing side but may be seconded by any member, and may be made at any time and have precedence over all other motions or while a member has the floor; such motion shall be debatable. A member on the prevailing side may also make a motion to reconsider and leave pending, which motion to reconsider and leave pending will then be considered at the next regular meeting. Any member may second a motion to reconsider and leave pending. 
(f)  Remarks of council member; when entered in minutes. A council member may request, through the presiding officer, the privilege of having an abstract of said council member's statement on any subject under consideration by the city council entered in the minutes. If the city council consents thereto, such statement shall be entered in the minutes. 
(g)  Synopsis of debate; when entered in minutes. The clerk may be directed by the presiding officer, with consent of the city council, to enter in the minutes a synopsis of the discussion on any question coming regularly before the city council. 
(h)  Rules of order. Meetings will be conducted substantially in accordance with Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. The mayor shall enforce parliamentary rules for the government of the city council when in session. Modifications of such rules may be adopted by vote of the city council from time to time. No alterations of a rule or adoption of a new rule shall take place without the consent of four-sevenths of the members of the city council and upon one month's notice prior to the vote. Any rule of procedure may be suspended by the unanimous vote of the city council for the meeting then in session. 
(Code 1984, § 2-24; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-32. - Addressing the city council-Time limit. 
(a)  Each person who wishes to address the city council during a city council meeting should complete a form located at the entrance to the council chamber. After the presiding officer has recognized a speaker, the speaker must use the microphone at the public lectern and state his name for the record; indicate his address in terms of a specific city or unincorporated county; address his remarks to the city council as a body rather than individual members; and direct all questions through the presiding officer. 
(b)  Unless a speaker is making comments under the agenda item reserved for public comments or petitions, remonstrances, and communications, the comments must be germane to the agenda item being considered by the city council. 
(c)  Speakers may not borrow time from or assign time to others. Groups are encouraged to appoint a representative. City council may consider granting additional time to a person functioning as a representative of a group. The following time limits will apply: 
(1)  Public comments: up to three minutes. 
(2)  Public hearing items: up to five minutes. 
(3)  Petitions, remonstrances, and communications: up to five minutes. 
(4)  All other items on the agenda, including the consent agenda: up to three minutes. 
(d)  The speaking times set forth in subsection (c) of this section apply to quasi-judicial matters being heard by the city council. However, an applicant, person in opposition or who otherwise has legal standing to support or oppose a quasi-judicial matter in a court of law, or representative of either of the foregoing on a quasi-judicial item, as defined in appendix D, chapter 1, article II, or as determined by judicial precedent, will be permitted sufficient time, as reasonably determined by the city council, to create a record before the city council. During the hearing of quasi-judicial matters, the city council will be acting as judge and concepts of due process and fair trial will apply, but the formal courtroom rules of evidence may not necessarily apply. Any person who seeks additional time beyond that time set forth in subsection (c) of this section to make a presentation on a quasi-judicial matter before the city council, as part of a record for appellate purposes, should carefully organize any comments or presentation of witness testimony prior to the quasi-judicial hearing. 
(e)  At the discretion of the presiding officer with concurrence of the city council, the speaking times in subsection (c) of this section may be varied. 
(f)  The city council is not required to allow public speaking on the following items: 
(1)  Any official act that must be taken to deal with an emergency situation affecting the public health, safety, and welfare when allowing public input would cause an unreasonable delay in the ability of the city council to act. 
(2)  Ministerial items, such as invocation, pledge of allegiance, roll call, approval of minutes and adjournment. 
(3)  Meetings that are exempt from the Sunshine Law. 
(Code 1984, § 2-25; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2013-49, § 1(2-25), 8-27-2013) 
Sec. 2-33. - Same-After motion made. 
    After a motion is made by the city council, no person shall address the city council without first securing the permission of the city council to do so. 
(Code 1984, § 2-26; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-34. - Voting. 
    The yeas and nays may be called for on any question and shall be ordered whenever demanded by any member of the city council present. Whenever the yeas and nays are ordered, the city clerk shall call the roll of council members and record the vote of each member. 
(Code 1984, § 2-28; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-35. - Minutes. 
    The city clerk shall keep a journal of the proceedings of the city council, and, except when journal records are exempt from disclosure by law or otherwise confidential, the journal shall be open to public inspection during normal business hours. 
(Code 1984, § 2-29; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-36. - Standards of decorum. 
(a)  By council members. While the city council is in session, the members must preserve order and decorum, and a member shall not, by conversation or otherwise, delay or interrupt the proceedings or the peace of the city council or disturb any member while speaking or refuse to obey the orders of the city council or its presiding officer. 
(b)  By other persons. Any person who makes personal, impertinent, or slanderous remarks or who becomes boisterous while addressing the city council may be ordered to leave the council chamber by the presiding officer unless permission to continue is granted by a majority vote of the city council. 
(Code 1984, § 2-30; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-37. - Enforcement of decorum. 
    The chief of police, or such member of the police department as he may designate, shall be sergeant-at-arms of the city council meetings. He shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the city council meeting. 
(Code 1984, § 2-31; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-38. - Members may file protests against city council action. 
    Any member shall have the right to have the reasons for his dissent from, or protest against, any action of the city council entered on the minutes. 
(Code 1984, § 2-32; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-39. - Resolution of claims and lawsuits against the city to be considered. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City attorney means the city attorney for the City of Melbourne, or said city attorney's designee. 
    Court means and refers to: 
(1)  A judicial tribunal created by Article V of the Florida Constitution of 1968; 
(2)  A judicial tribunal created by Part I, Title 28, United States Code (28 USC 1-482); 
(3)  A trial or appellate court or administrative law tribunal of any state or territory of the United States of America other than Florida; 
(4)  An action pending before an administrative law judge appointed pursuant to F.S. § 120.65; or 
(5)  An action pending before a federal administrative law judge appointed pursuant to 5 USC 3105. 
    Major claim means and refers to the following types of claims against the city, whether or not the claim has matured into a lawsuit filed in court, the settlement of which claim would: 
(1)  Require the payment, of in excess of $200,000.00 to any one person, or which when totaled with all other claims or judgments paid by or for the benefit of the city, arising out of the same incident or occurrence, exceeds the sum of $300,000.00, by the city, an insurance carrier utilized by the city which carrier is making payment pursuant to an insurance policy issued to the city, or a third party acting on behalf of the city; 
(2)  Require the payment of any claim for which the city is not fully insured (other than payment of an insurance deductible); 
(3)  Require the taking of, or refraining from the taking of, any action by the city which the city manager does not have authority to undertake; or 
(4)  Result in the issuance of a development order, as defined in F.S. § 163.3164. 
Workers' compensation claims pursuant to F.S. ch. 440 shall not be construed to be a major claim. 
    Minor claim means and refers to the following types of claims against the city whether or not the claim has matured into a lawsuit filed with an administrative or judicial tribunal, the settlement of which claim, or payment of a judgment for said claim: 
(1)  Requires payment (excluding insurance policy deductible amounts) of not more than $200,000.00 to any one person, or which when totaled with all other claims or judgments paid by or for the benefit of the city, arising out of the same incident or occurrence, does not exceed $300,000.00, by an insurance carrier utilized by the city which carrier is making payment pursuant to an insurance policy issued to the city, or a third party acting on behalf of the city and which will not require the taking of, or refraining from the taking of, any action by the city which the city manager has not been previously delegated authority to undertake; 
(2)  Results in payment by the city of any amount equal to or less than the amount of a city insurance policy deductible amount and which will not require the taking of, or refraining from the taking of, any action by the city which the city manager has not been previously delegated authority to undertake; 
(3)  A claim for workers' compensation benefits, pursuant to F.S. ch. 440; or 
(4)  A claim the settlement of which is consistent with authority to settle previously delegated to the city manager or his designee. 
(b)  Lawsuit settlement requiring city council approval. Except for any claim for damages or other compensation (excluding insurance policy deductible amounts) that the city's insurance carrier, or other third party, has agreed to be responsible for the payment of as a result of a settlement, no major claim for damages, compensation, or other relief shall be the subject of a pre-litigation settlement or an out-of-court or court-approved settlement without the approval of the city council. With regard to the settlement of any lawsuit or other claim against the city, other than for compensation or damages, that requires action or an omission to act that can only be agreed to by the city council, no settlement may occur without the approval of the city council. 
(c)  Lawsuit settlements not requiring city council approval. A minor claim for damages, compensation, or other relief may be the subject of a pre-litigation settlement or an out-of-court or court-approved settlement without the approval of the city council but only upon the approval of the city manager or his designee. The settlement by the city manager, or his designee, of any minor claim or workers' compensation action shall bind the city to the same extent as if the city council had approved the same, and authority to effectuate resolution of minor claims is hereby delegated to the city manager, or the city manager's designee. 
(d)  Settlement negotiations and mediation. The city attorney has the full power and authority to negotiate or mediate a settlement of any claim for damages, or other relief, on behalf of the city. The city attorney has the full power and authority to recommend a settlement to the city council of any major claim or other pending or threatened lawsuit seeking to have actions taken by the city or seeking to have the city to refrain from taking actions. The city attorney has the full power and authority to recommend a settlement to the manager, or said city manager's designee, of any minor claim. One of the chief purposes of this delegation of authority is to comply with the requirements of Rule 1.720(d), Florida Rules of Civil Procedure. In negotiating or mediating claims, the city attorney will coordinate any negotiations or settlement with the city's risk manager and insurance carrier, if any. 
(Code 1984, § 2-33; Ord. No. 2000-30, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
State Law reference- Tort claims, F.S. § 768.28. 
Sec. 2-40. - Ordinances, resolutions, motions and contracts. 
(a)  Preparation of ordinances. No ordinance shall be prepared for presentation to the city council unless ordered by a majority vote of the city council, or requested by the city manager, or prepared by the city attorney on his own initiative. 
(b)  Prior approval by administrative staff. All ordinances, resolutions and contract documents, before presentation to the city council, shall have been approved as to form and legality by the city attorney or said city attorney's authorized representative, and shall have been examined and approved for administration by the city manager or said city manager's authorized representative, where there are substantive matters of administration involved. All such instruments first shall have been referred to the head of the department under whose jurisdiction the administration of the subject matter of the ordinance, resolution or contract document would devolve and shall have been approved by such department head; however, if approval is not given, then the same shall be returned to the city manager with a written memorandum of the reasons why such approval is withheld. If the questioned instrument is not redrafted to meet a department head's objection, or if the objection is not withdrawn and approval in writing given, then the city manager shall so advise the city council and give the reasons advanced by the department head for withholding approval. 
(c)  Introducing for passage or approval. 
(1)  Ordinances must be introduced and read by the city attorney. Ordinances shall be read by title only; however, at the discretion of the city council, an individual ordinance may be read in full. Resolutions need not be read by title; however, at the discretion of the presiding officer, an individual resolution may be read in full or by title only. 
(2)  Each ordinance or resolution shall be introduced in writing and shall embrace but one subject matter and matters properly connected therewith. The subject shall be clearly stated in the title. No ordinance shall be revised or amended by reference to its title only. Ordinances to revise or amend shall set out in full the revised or amended act or section or subsection or paragraph of a section or subsection. 
(3)  a.  Except as provided in F.S. § 166.041(3)(c), a proposed ordinance may be read by title, or in full, on at least two separate days and shall, at least ten days prior to adoption, be noticed in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice of proposed enactment shall state the date, time and place of the meeting; the titles of proposed ordinances and the places within the city where such proposed ordinances may be inspected by the public. The notice shall also advise that interested parties may appear at the meeting and be heard with respect to the proposed ordinance. 
b.  The city council may, by a two-thirds vote, enact an emergency ordinance without complying with the requirements of subsection (c)(3)a of this section. However, no emergency ordinance shall be enacted which enacts or amends a land use plan or which rezones private real property or that changes the actual list of permitted, conditional, or prohibited uses within a zoning category. Emergency enactment procedures for land use plans adopted pursuant to F.S. ch. 163, part II shall be pursuant to that part. 
(4)  Pursuant to section 2.10 of the Charter, a majority of the total number of members of the city council constitutes a quorum. An affirmative vote of a majority of city council (four votes) is necessary to enact any ordinance or adopt any resolution; except that two-thirds of the total membership of the city council is required to enact an emergency ordinance. 
(5)  On final passage, the vote of each member of the city council voting shall be entered on the official record of the meeting. Pursuant to section 2.11 of the Charter, all ordinances and resolutions shall become effective upon passage or as otherwise provided therein. 
(6)  Any resolution providing for the appropriation of money shall designate the particular fund from which the appropriation is to be made. 
(7)  Every ordinance or resolution must, upon its final passage, be recorded in a book kept for that purpose and shall be signed by the mayor or presiding officer and the city clerk. 
(Code 1984, § 2-34; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Charter reference- Legislative procedure, § 2.10; ordinances and resolutions, § 2.11. 
State Law reference- Minimum procedure for adoption of ordinances and resolutions, F.S. § 166.041. 
Sec. 2-41. - Adjournment. 
    A motion to adjourn is always in order and decided without debate. 
(Code 1984, § 2-35; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Secs. 2-42-2-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- City administration, art. III. 
State Law reference- Code of Ethics for public officers and employees, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; unemployment compensation, F.S. ch. 443; workers' compensation, F.S. ch. 440. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-71. - Bond. 
    The city council and city manager may require official bonds for the faithful performance of duties of such city officials and employees as the city council or city manager may deem necessary, in such amounts as may be required. All such official bonds shall be filed with the risk management division. 
(Code 1984, § 2-52; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Secs. 2-72-2-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OFFICERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Offices and departments of the city, art. III; recreation department, § 3.22. 

Sec. 2-101. - City clerk; appointment and duties. 
    As provided in section 3.09 of the Charter, the city manager shall appoint an officer of the city who shall have the title of city clerk and serve as custodian of all city records. 
(Code 1984, § 2-61; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Charter reference- Office of the city clerk, § 3.09. 
State Law reference- Custodian designated, F.S. § 119.021. 
Sec. 2-102. - Financial services department-Director, assistant; appointment; duties. 
    The financial services department shall be headed by the director of finance. An assistant finance director shall serve in the absence of the director of finance. The director of finance shall act as city comptroller, treasurer, tax collector, and chief financial officer of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 2-62; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Charter reference- Department of fiscal affairs, § 3.13. 
Sec. 2-103. - Same-Receipts, disbursements and reports. 
    The director of finance shall pay out city monies in accordance with systems prescribed or approved by the city manager. The director shall make an annual financial and statistical report of receipts, disbursements and financial condition of the city to the city manager and shall make such special interim reports as may be required. 
(Code 1984, § 2-63; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
State Law reference- Annual audit required, F.S. § 218.32. 
Secs. 2-104-2-134. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMITTEES, AND AUTHORITIES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Civil defense, rescue and disaster relief committee, § 3.23; advisory boards, § 3.24; airport authority, § 3.25; zoning commission, § 8.04(5); board of adjustment, § 8.04(6)-(14). 
State Law reference- Suspension, removal of certain municipal board members, F.S. § 112.501. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-135. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ad hoc committee means any committee established by city council to consider a specific issue. 
    Board means any city board, authority, committee, ad hoc committee or commission established or created by the City Charter, City Code, city council action, or the general laws of the state. 
    Department means the department in the city responsible for providing support to a board. 
    Subcommittee means any committee formed from a board. 
(Code 1984, § 2-75; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-136. - Qualifications of persons to be appointed to any municipal board, authority or committee. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided by statute or this Code, a board member must be a resident of the city for 180 consecutive days immediately prior to the time of appointment, must be a registered elector of the city, and must not hold any public office or serve on any other board, authority or committee of the city or hold any other position in the city. Following appointment to any city board, a person must continue his city residency during the prescribed term in order to remain qualified, unless otherwise provided for in this Code or state statutes. 
(b)  Appointments to any subcommittee or ad hoc committee are not subject to the residency provisions of subsection (a) of this section; however, such members must be registered to vote in the state. 
(Code 1984, § 2-76; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-137. - Vacancies; appointment of members. 
    A vacancy shall occur on a board upon the death, resignation, removal from office of the member as authorized by law, or forfeiture of office by the member whenever a member ceases to possess the prescribed qualifications. When such vacancy occurs, the city council shall select, by the affirmative vote of not less than a majority of the total membership of the city council, a person to fill the vacancy. Such person must meet the qualifications for board member specified in this chapter or this Code or the state statutes and shall serve the unexpired term. 
(Code 1984, § 2-76.1; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-138. - Board members; suspension; removal. 
    A board member may be suspended or removed from office in accordance with the provisions of F.S. §§ 112.501 and 112.51. 
(Code 1984, § 2-76.2; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
State Law reference- Suspension or removal of municipal board members, F.S. § 112.501; suspension or removal of municipal officers, F.S. § 112.51. 
Sec. 2-139. - Election and term of chair and vice-chair. 
(a)  Each board shall annually elect a member to serve as chair and vice-chair from its membership of regular members. The term of the chair and vice-chair shall be for a period of one year, or until a successor is selected, whichever event occurs second in time. The board may re-elect members as chair or as vice-chair. 
(b)  Each board is encouraged to provide an opportunity to all its members who desire to serve as chair. 
(c)  The city clerk shall coordinate with staff assigned to each board to provide periodic training on topics such as parliamentary procedures, sunshine law, voting conflict of interest law, public input, decorum, and relevant City Code sections. 
(Code 1984, § 2-76.3; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2016-16, § 1, 3-8-2016) 
Sec. 2-140. - Rules of procedure. 
(a)  Meetings will be conducted substantially in accordance with Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, most recent edition. The presiding officer shall enforce parliamentary rules when meetings are in session. Modifications of such rules may be adopted by vote of the board from time to time. Any rule of procedure may be suspended by the unanimous vote of the board for the meeting then in session. 
(b)  The presiding officer may make motions, second motions and debate from the chair, subject only to such limitations of debate as are imposed on all members and shall not be deprived of any rights and privileges of a board member by reason of his acting as the presiding officer. 
(c)  Every member desiring to speak shall address the presiding officer and, upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall confine any comments or inquiries to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and language lacking propriety or good taste. 
(Code 1984, § 2-76.4; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-141. - Meetings; records. 
(a)  Each board shall meet upon the call of the chair, the vice-chair, the city manager or said city manager's designee, or pursuant to a motion adopted at a meeting of the board. The board may hold regular, special, or workshop meetings. All meetings of the board shall be held at a public facility and shall be open to the public. The time and place of meetings and the order of business and procedure to be followed at meetings shall be as prescribed by the board. 
(b)  Public comments. 
(1)  Each board will allow public comments on agenda items. Boards may adopt rules of procedure relating to the amount of time that will be granted to a speaker to comment on an agenda item, such as three to five minutes. 
(2)  At the discretion of the presiding officer and with concurrence of the board members, the speaking times adopted in a rule or procedure may be varied. 
(3)  Boards are not required to allow public speaking on the following items: any official act that must be taken to deal with an emergency situation affecting the public health, safety, and welfare when allowing public input would cause an unreasonable delay in the ability of the board to act; ministerial items, such as invocation, pledge of allegiance, roll call, approval of minutes and adjournment; and any meeting that is exempt from the Sunshine Law. 
(4)  Quasi-judicial boards that have adopted rules of procedure on quasi-judicial items will continue to follow those procedures. At a minimum, an applicant, person in opposition or who otherwise has legal standing to support or oppose a quasi-judicial matter in a court of law, or representative of either of the foregoing on a quasi-judicial item, as defined in appendix D, chapter 1, article II, or as determined by judicial precedent will be permitted sufficient time, as reasonably determined by a city board, to create a record before the city board. 
During the hearing of quasi-judicial matters, the city board will be acting as judge and concepts of due process and fair trial will apply, but the formal courtroom rules of evidence may not necessarily apply. Any person who seeks additional time to make a presentation on a quasi-judicial matter before a city board, as part of a record for appellate purposes, should carefully organize any comments or presentation of witness testimony prior to the quasi-judicial hearing. 
(c)  Minutes of the board shall be kept, shall be filed in the department and office of city clerk, shall be open for public inspection during regular city business hours, and shall be distributed to the city council. 
(Code 1984, § 2-76.5; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2013-49, § 3(2-76.5), 8-27-2013) 
Sec. 2-142. - Funding; staff support; compensation. 
(a)  The city council may from time to time appropriate such funds as it deems necessary to assist a board in performing its duties and services. 
(b)  Provided funding is available, the city manager and department shall provide from city staff such clerical, technical and other resources as the board may reasonably require for the effective and efficient execution of its duties. An individual from city staff shall serve as recording secretary to the board and that individual shall be charged with the responsibility of maintaining board records. 
(c)  Board members shall not receive any pay or compensation for service rendered as a member of a board. 
(Code 1984, § 2-76.6; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-143. - Board member attendance requirements. 
(a)  Any person appointed by the city council to serve on a board, authority or committee who is in violation of such organization's attendance requirements and who has been recommended to the city council for removal by that organization shall be notified by the city council of such failure to attend and shall have an opportunity to be heard on that issue. The city council may then suspend or remove from office that board member in accordance with the provisions of F.S. § 112.501. 
(b)  In the absence of organization-established attendance requirements, the following attendance standard shall apply: Any person appointed by the city council to serve on a board, authority or committee shall be in violation of the city's attendance requirements if said member fails to attend three consecutive regular meetings or any three of five consecutive regular meetings, unless the member has been excused by the chair of the organization for good cause. 
(c)  The chair of any board, authority or committee whose members are appointed by the city council shall provide written notification to the city council when a member has violated the attendance requirements of that organization or the city, unless such absences are excused by the chair of that organization. 
(Code 1984, § 2-77; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Secs. 2-144-2-169. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AFFORDABLE HOUSING ADVISORY COMMITTEE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Affordable housing property, F.S. § 166.0451; affordable housing, F.S. § 420.601 et seq.; state housing initiatives partnership, F.S. § 420.907 et seq. 

Sec. 2-170. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and established an affordable housing advisory committee designated as the "affordable housing advisory committee." 
(Code 1984, § 2-78; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-171. - Composition; terms of office. 
(a)  The affordable housing advisory committee consists of nine members. The committee must consist of one representative from at least six of the following 11 categories; a citizen who is actively engaged in the residential home building industry in connection with affordable housing; a citizen who is actively engaged in the banking or mortgage banking industry in connection with affordable housing; a citizen who is a representative of those areas of labor actively engaged in home building in connection with affordable housing; a citizen who is actively engaged as an advocate for low-income persons in connection with affordable housing; a citizen who is actively engaged as a for-profit provider of affordable housing; a citizen who is actively engaged as a not-for-profit provider of affordable housing; a citizen who is actively engaged as a real estate professional in connection with affordable housing; a citizen who actively serves on the planning and zoning board/local planning agency pursuant to F.S. § 163.3174; a citizen who is a resident of the city; a citizen who represents employers within the city; and a citizen who represents essential services personnel, as defined in the local housing assistance plan (any person employed by educational, governmental and human service agencies; health care personnel; public safety personnel; and any skilled building trades personnel and food service personnel). Except as provided, members shall not be subject to the residency requirement established in section 2-136. If the city council, due to reasonable factors, is unable to appoint a citizen actively engaged in these activities in connection with affordable housing, a citizen engaged in the activity without regard to affordable housing may be appointed. 
(b)  All members shall serve five-year terms. 
(Code 1984, § 2-79; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2018-15, § 1, 4-24-2018) 
Sec. 2-172. - Meetings; authority. 
(a)  The approval by the committee of its local housing incentive strategies and its review of local implementation of previously recommended strategies must be made by affirmative vote of five members of the committee taken at a public hearing. 
(b)  The presence at a meeting of five members of the committee constitutes a quorum. With the exception of action identified in subsection (a) of this section, the affirmative vote of a majority of the members present and voting is necessary for the adoption of any motion. 
(c)  Notice of the time, date, and place of the public hearing of the committee to recommend adoption of final local housing incentive strategies must be published in a newspaper of general paid circulation in the county. The notice must contain a short and concise summary of the local housing incentives strategies to be considered by the committee. The notice must state the public place where a copy of the tentative strategies recommended by the committee can be obtained. 
(d)  No recommendations of the committee are binding on the city council, city staff, or other city boards, and the city council retains final authority and power to make binding decisions concerning the adoption, repeal, alteration or amendment of the various ordinances, resolutions, policies and procedures, and other actions, which the committee has reviewed or recommended. 
(Code 1984, § 2-80; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2018-15, § 1, 4-24-2018) 
Sec. 2-173. - Duties, goals and objectives. 
(a)  Triennially, the committee shall review the established policies and procedures, ordinances, land development regulations, and the adopted city comprehensive plan and shall recommend specific actions or initiatives to encourage or facilitate affordable housing while protecting the ability of the property to appreciate in value. Recommendations may include the modification or repeal of existing policies, procedures, ordinances, regulations, or plan provisions; the creation of exceptions applicable to affordable housing; or the adoption of new policies, procedures, regulations, ordinances, or plan provisions, including recommendations to amend the comprehensive plan and corresponding regulations, ordinances, and other policies. 
(1)  At a minimum, the committee must submit a report to the city council that includes recommendations on the implementation of affordable housing incentives in the following areas: 
a.  Expedited processing of approvals of development orders or permits, as defined in F.S. § 163.3177(6)(f)3, for affordable housing projects. 
b.  The modification of impact fee requirements, including reduction or waiver of fees and alternative methods of fee payment for affordable housing. 
c.  The allowance of flexibility in densities for affordable housing. 
d.  The reservation of infrastructure capacity for housing of very low-income persons, low-income persons, and moderate-income persons. 
e.  The allowance of affordable accessory residential units in residential zoning districts. 
f.  The reduction of parking and setback requirements for affordable housing. 
g.  The allowance of flexible lot configurations, including zero lot line configurations for affordable housing. 
h.  The modification of street requirements for affordable housing. 
i.  The establishment of a process by which the city considers, before adoption, the effect of policies, procedures, ordinances, regulations, or plan provisions that increase the cost of housing. 
j.  The preparation of a printed inventory of locally owned public lands suitable for affordable housing. 
k.  The support of development near transportation hubs and major employment centers and mixed-use development. 
(2)  Thereafter, the committee shall evaluate the implementation of these incentives. 
(b)  The committee may perform other duties at the request of the city council, including: 
(1)  The provision of mentoring services to affordable housing partners including developers, banking institutions, employers, and others in order to identify available incentives, to assist with applications for funding requests, and to develop partnerships between various parties. 
(2)  The creation of best practices standards for the development of affordable housing in the community. 
(Code 1984, § 2-81; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2018-15, § 1, 4-24-2018) 
Sec. 2-174. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-15, § 1, adopted April 24, 2018, repealed former § 2-174 which pertained to support staff and derived from the 1984 Code, § 2-82; and Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, adopted March 25, 2008. 
Secs. 2-175-2-201. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BEAUTIFICATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY BOARD[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, adopted Oct. 24, 2017, changed the title of Div. 3 from "Beautification and Environmental Advisory Committee" to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 2-202. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and established the "Melbourne Beautification and Energy Efficiency Board". 
(Code 1984, § 2-96; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, 10-24-2017) 
Sec. 2-203. - Composition. 
(a)  The beautification and energy efficiency board shall consist of five regular members and two alternate members appointed by the city council. At least two of the regular or alternate members must be business owners in the city. To the greatest extent possible, members shall have the following backgrounds: economic development or business; environmental protection, natural resources management, or sustainability practices; social services or community health; urban planning or transportation planning; education; environmental law; science; horticulture; marine industry; or retired military personnel. 
(b)  The two business owners are not required to be city residents. 
(c)  Alternate members may participate in the discussion of every item. An alternate member may only vote in the absence of a regular member. In the event that four regular members are present and voting and two alternate members are present, the first alternate member may vote and make motions with regard to agenda items. 
(Code 1984, § 2-97; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, 10-24-2017) 
Sec. 2-204. - Terms of members. 
    The members of the beautification and energy efficiency board shall initially serve staggered terms. Three regular members shall serve for three years; two regular members shall serve for two years; and two alternate members shall serve for one year. Thereafter, the members shall serve three-year terms. 
(Code 1984, § 2-98; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, 10-24-2017) 
Sec. 2-205. - Quorum; meetings. 
(a)  The presence at a meeting of three regular or alternate members of the board constitutes a quorum. The affirmative vote of three regular or alternate members shall be necessary for the adoption of any motion. 
(b)  The board shall meet monthly at city hall on a regular schedule as determined by the board. If there is no business to conduct, a meeting shall not be held. 
(Code 1984, § 2-100; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, 10-24-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, adopted Oct. 24, 2017, changed the title of § 2-205 from "Quorum; authority" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 2-206. - Authority. 
    The beautification and energy efficiency board shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city council. No recommendations of the board shall be binding on the city council, city staff, or other city boards, and the city council shall retain the final authority and power to make binding decisions concerning the adoption, repeal, alteration or amendment of ordinances, resolutions, policies and procedures, and other actions, which the board has reviewed or recommended. 
(Code 1984, § 2-101; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, 10-24-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, adopted Oct. 24, 2017, changed the title of § 2-206 from "Duties, objectives, and goals" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 2-207. - Duties and purpose. 
(a)  The beautification and energy efficiency board shall identify and make recommendations to the city council concerning affordable strategies associated with conservation, renewable energy, and energy efficiency. Duties of the board shall include: 
(1)  Develop an environmental sustainability plan for city operations with a goal of achieving 100 percent clean energy by 2035 in city operations. 
(2)  Develop an assessment plan to track activities and implementation of the city's environmental sustainability plan. Provide an annual report to the city council on activities and implementation of the plan. 
(3)  Review ordinances and policies that have an environmental impact on the city and make recommendations to city council. Such topics may include standards for recycling, environmental standards, preservation and landscape design, and floodplain management. 
(b)  Initiatives of the board may include: 
(1)  Research, identify, and recommend to the public affordable strategies associated with conservation, renewable energy, and energy efficiency. 
(2)  Research and recommend to the public financial initiatives and resources that are available to offset costs associated with renewable energy initiatives. 
(3)  Recognize the efforts of others who contribute to the beautification, environmental protection, and enhancement of the city. 
(c)  The board shall perform such additional duties and services as may from time to time be assigned by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2017-49, § 2, 10-24-2017) 
Secs. 2-208-2-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITIZENS' ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-236. - Created, composition, appointment, and terms of members. 
    There is hereby created and established a citizens' advisory board designated as the Melbourne Citizens' Advisory Board consisting of seven members and two alternate members who are appointed by the city council, each for a term of three years. Alternate members may attend complete board meetings regardless of whether a quorum of regular members is seated. Alternate members may always participate in board deliberations and debate, but they may make motions and vote only in the absence or voting disqualification of a regular member or the vacancy in a regular member's seat. 
(Code 1984, § 2-116; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-237. - Quorum; authority. 
(a)  The presence at a meeting of four regular or alternate members of the board constitutes a quorum. The affirmative vote of a majority of the regular and alternate board members present and voting is necessary for the adoption of any motion. 
(b)  No recommendations of the board are binding on the city council, city staff, or other city boards and committees, and the city council retains final authority and power to make binding decisions concerning the adoption, repeal, alteration or amendment of the various ordinances, resolutions, policies and procedures, and other actions, which the board has reviewed or recommended. 
(Code 1984, § 2-118; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-238. - Duties, goals and objectives. 
    The citizens' advisory board shall provide and perform such duties and services as may from time to time be assigned to the board by the city council. The specified goals and objectives of the Melbourne Citizens' Advisory Board are as follows: 
(1)  To serve as the formal means through which active citizen participation is provided to aid in the planning, oversight and evaluation of federal- and state-funded housing and community development programs that benefit and improve low- and moderate-income persons and neighborhoods in the city. 
(2)  To recommend priorities for allocation of housing and community development program funds for projects, which benefit low- and moderate-income persons, to aid in the elimination or prevention of slums and blight. 
(3)  To conduct public hearings to obtain citizen views and to respond to proposals and questions at the various stages of the Community Development Block Grant, HOME Investment Partnership and State Housing Initiatives Partnership programs and other related grant programs from program planning through program evaluation. 
(Code 1984, § 2-120; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008)
