DIVISION 8. - PLANNING AND ZONING BOARD/LOCAL PLANNING AGENCY[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Charter reference- Zoning commission, § 8.04(5). 
State Law reference- Local planning agency, F.S. § 163.3174. 

Sec. 2-326. - Creation of planning and zoning board. 
(a)  A planning and zoning board is hereby established consisting of seven members who are appointed by the city council and one non-voting member appointed by the county school board. In addition, the city council may appoint not more than two alternate members, designating them as such. Alternate members may attend complete board meetings regardless of whether a quorum of regular members is seated. Alternate members may always participate in board deliberations and debate, but they may make motions and vote only in the absence or voting disqualification of a regular member or the vacancy in a regular member's seat. 
(b)  In the event that six regular members are present and voting and two alternate members are present, the alternate member who may vote and make motions with regard to an agenda item shall be the alternate member who has served on the board for the longest period of time, regardless of whether said service is interrupted. Any non-voting member may participate in discussions; however, shall not make motions and may not be used to constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1984, § 2-157; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-327. - Organization and members. 
(a)  The member appointed by the county school board is not required to be a resident of the city or a registered elector. 
(b)  Terms of office; vacancies. Each member, each alternate member, and non-voting member shall serve a term of three years. Any vacancy occurring during the unexpired term of office of any non-voting member shall be filled by appointment of the county school board for the remainder of the term. 
(Code 1984, § 2-158; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2015-45, § 1, 9-8-2015) 
Sec. 2-328. - Quorum; records. 
(a)  The presence at a meeting of four regular or alternate members of the board constitutes a quorum. The affirmative vote of a majority of the regular and alternate board members present and voting shall be necessary for the adoption of any motion. However, in modifying a decision of the building official, the affirmative vote of at least five members shall be required. 
(b)  A written record of the proceedings of the board must be kept, showing its action on each question considered. Such record shall be filed in the community development department office and shall be open for public inspection during regular city business hours. The individual charged with the responsibility of maintaining board records is the board secretary. The community development department director, or said director's designee, shall serve as secretary of the board. 
(Code 1984, § 2-159; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2015-45, § 1, 9-8-2015) 
Sec. 2-329. - Authority and duties of the planning and zoning board. 
    The planning and zoning board has the following authority and duties: 
(1)  To act in an advisory capacity to the city council on questions relating to zoning, comprehensive planning, and land use and to conduct investigations on matters or proposals to change land use, zoning, land development regulations, and to report its findings and recommendations on such proposals to the city council. 
(2)  To recommend to the city council such amendments to this division and appendices A, B, and D as the board may deem to be in the promotion of the public health, safety, welfare, economic order, or aesthetics or necessary to clarify or to carry into effect the purposes of this Code or the comprehensive plan. 
(3)  To hear applications and submit recommendations to the city council on the following: 
a.  Proposed change of the permitted use of any specifically designated property. 
b.  Applications for conditional uses. 
c.  Proposed amendment to the zoning code. 
d.  Proposed subdivision plats and subdivision variances. 
e.  Review annexation requests. 
f.  Site plan review. 
g.  Vested rights petitions. 
h.  Adoption of and amendments to the city's comprehensive plan. 
In connection with any recommendation by the planning and zoning board, the board shall include any conditions, requirements, or limitations which the board may believe to be necessary or desirable to protect adjacent properties and the surrounding neighborhood, or to promote the public health, safety, welfare, economic order, or aesthetics. 
(4)  To hear and approve specific site plans as authorized in the table outlined in appendix B, article IX, section 6(B), zoning code. 
(5)  To hear appeals of decisions and interpretations of the building official and consider variances of the technical codes as specifically authorized in Code. 
(6)  To hear appeals of decisions made by the architectural review board in its decision on an application in the Melbourne Downtown Community Redevelopment Area and the Olde Eau Gallie Riverfront Community Redevelopment Area. 
(7)  Upon receipt from the historic preservation board, to consider recommendations made by the historic preservation board for variances of individually designated historic resources. 
(8)  To act as the fire prevention board of adjustment and appeals. 
(9)  To consider and grant variances to specific provisions of the City of Melbourne Stormwater Management Ordinance. 
(10)  To hear appeals of decisions made by the city engineer as specifically authorized in Code. 
(Code 1984, § 2-160; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008; Ord. No. 2015-45, § 1, 9-8-2015) 
Sec. 2-330. - Planning and zoning board to be local planning agency. 
(a)  Authority. This section is enacted pursuant to and in accordance with provisions of the Community Planning Act, F.S. § 163.3161 et seq. 
(b)  Designation and establishment of local land planning agency. Pursuant to and in accordance with the Community Planning Act, F.S. § 163.3174, the planning and zoning board is hereby designated and established as the local planning agency as referenced in the Community Planning Act, F.S. § 163.3164(25), all for the incorporated territory of the city and to the extent that such jurisdiction may be provided for by any interlocal agreement and for any area of unincorporated territory subject to the jurisdiction of the city. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities of the local planning agency. The local planning agency, in accordance with the Community Planning Act, shall: 
(1)  Coordinate the comprehensive plan or elements or portions thereof with the comprehensive plan or elements of appropriate local governments, and the strategic regional policy plan of the East Central Florida Regional Planning Council, and the state's comprehensive plan as adopted by F.S. § 187.201. 
(2)  Be the agency responsible for the preparation of the comprehensive plan or plan amendment and shall make recommendations to the city council regarding the adoption or amendment of such plan. The city council in cooperation with the local planning agency may designate any agency, committee, department, or person to prepare the comprehensive plan or plan amendment, but final recommendation of the adoption of such plan or plan amendment to the city council shall be the responsibility of the local planning agency. 
(3)  Monitor and oversee the effectiveness and status of the comprehensive plan and recommend to the governing body such changes in the comprehensive plan as may from time to time be required, including the periodic evaluation and appraisal of the comprehensive plan required by F.S. § 163.3191. 
(4)  Review proposed land development regulations, land development codes, or amendments thereto, and make recommendations to the city council as to the consistency of the proposal with the adopted comprehensive plan, or element, or portion thereof, when the local planning agency is serving as the land development regulation commission or the local government requires review by both the local planning agency and the land development regulation commission. 
(5)  Perform any other functions, duties, and responsibilities assigned to it by the city council or by general or special law. 
(d)  Funds. The city council shall appropriate funds at its discretion to support the local planning agency in the conduct of its work. The city council may expend all sums so appropriated and other sums made available for use from fees, gifts, state or federal grants, state or federal loans and other sources in order to assist the local planning agency in accomplishing the purposes and activities required by the Community Planning Act. 
(Code 1984, § 2-161; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
State Law reference- Local planning agency, appointment, powers and duties, F.S. § 163.3174. 
Sec. 2-331. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person who desires to appeal a final decision made by the planning and zoning board may file a written notice of appeal within 30 days of the final order being rendered and filed in the records of the community development department. Such appeal must specify the grounds for the appeal. The city council shall make a determination on the appeal within 30 days of such application/petition. 
(b)  The following procedures shall apply to the appeal process outlined above as used in this section, the term "rendition" means the issuance of a written order by the planning and zoning board effective upon the date that a signed original is filed in the records of the secretary/clerk to the planning and zoning board. A copy of said written order must be hand delivered or mailed, postage prepaid by U.S. certified mail, to the person requesting the order. The letter must be mailed or hand delivered on the date of filing in the records of the secretary/clerk to the planning and zoning board. 
(1)  The notice of appeal shall be filed with the city clerk with a copy to the planning and zoning board secretary within 30 days of the rendition of the planning and zoning board's decision. The city clerk shall stamp the date of filing on the notice of appeal so that compliance with the 30-day filing requirement can be quickly and easily ascertained. 
(2)  If the date of rendition of the planning and zoning board's decision and the date of appeal are within 30 days of each other, a determination shall be made that the appeal has been timely filed. If the two documents were not filed within 30 days of each other, the appeal was not timely filed. The city council shall then issue an order dismissing the appeal, and no further action is required. 
(3)  Within 30 days after the filing of the notice of appeal, the appellant shall be required to have a court stenographer prepare a verbatim transcript of the planning and zoning board hearing at which the final order being appealed was issued. The preparation of the verbatim transcript is the responsibility of the appellant and will be at the expense of the appellant. Within 30 days after the filing of the notice of appeal, the appellant may also file a written argument explaining why the planning and zoning board's decision should be reversed. Within 30 days after the filing of any written argument by the appellant, the community development director may file a written argument with the city clerk for the city council. 
(4)  The planning and zoning board secretary shall assemble all documents from the planning and zoning board's hearing, together with a copy of the board's final order, which constitutes the record. The transcript shall be forwarded to the city council at the same time the record is forwarded to the city council. The city council shall not rehear the entire matter, although oral arguments with regard to the appeal may be heard by the city council. The city council will determine whether the planning and zoning board made a decision inconsistent with the law or this Code; whether the board's decision is supported by substantial, competent evidence; and whether due process was afforded to the parties. If the planning and zoning board's decision is inconsistent with the law or the Code; if the planning and zoning board's decision is not supported by substantial, competent evidence; or if procedural due process was not afforded to the parties, then the city council may reverse the decision and return the matter to the planning and zoning board for further action consistent with the city council's action. If the planning and zoning board made a decision consistent with the essential requirements of the law and the code supported by substantial, competent evidence and procedural due process was afforded to the parties, even if the decision is not the best or more desirable decision, the city council shall affirm the board's decision. 
(Code 1984, § 2-162; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Secs. 2-332-2-350. - Reserved.

DIVISION 10. - MELBOURNE ECONOMIC ENHANCEMENT DISTRICT ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-382. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and established a committee designated as the "Melbourne Economic Enhancement District Advisory Committee." 
(Code 1984, § 2-172.9; Ord. No. 2009-24, § 1, 6-23-2009) 
Sec. 2-383. - Establishment of district boundaries; intent. 
(a)  Resolution No. 3017, on file with the community development department, establishes the Melbourne Economic Enhancement District (MEED). The MEED was established to enhance the overall quality of life within the city by encouraging economic and redevelopment opportunities, which create new jobs, improve the environment, and revitalize neighborhoods. 
(b)  The committee shall also be responsible for considering requests for Brownfield area designation on property located outside of the MEED. 
(Code 1984, § 2-172.10; Ord. No. 2009-24, § 1, 6-23-2009) 
Sec. 2-384. - Composition; terms of office. 
(a)  The Melbourne Economic Enhancement District Advisory Committee consists of seven members. One member shall be a current member of and shall be appointed by the Melbourne Downtown Community Redevelopment Agency Advisory Committee, one member shall be a current member of and shall be appointed by the Olde Eau Gallie Riverfront Community Redevelopment Agency Advisory Committee, one member shall be a current member of and shall be appointed by the Babcock Street Community Redevelopment Agency Advisory Committee, one member shall be appointed by the Melbourne Airport Authority, one member shall be appointed by the Economic Development Commission of Florida's Space Coast, one member shall be appointed by the community development department, and one member who either resides within, or is engaged in business in, or owns property within, the Melbourne Economic Enhancement District, shall be appointed by the city council. Members are not subject to the residency requirement established in section 2-136. The member appointed by the Melbourne Airport Authority and the member appointed by the community development department may be a city employee. 
(b)  The member appointed by city council shall serve for a period of three years. The remaining members shall serve until their successors are appointed. 
(Code 1984, § 2-172.11; Ord. No. 2009-24, § 1, 6-23-2009) 
Sec. 2-385. - Meetings; authority. 
(a)  The presence at a meeting of four members of the Melbourne Economic Enhancement District Advisory Committee constitutes a quorum. The affirmative vote of a majority of the members present and voting shall be necessary for the adoption of any motion. 
(b)  No recommendations of the committee shall be binding on the city council, city staff, other city boards, or governmental agencies. 
(Code 1984, § 2-172.12; Ord. No. 2009-24, § 1, 6-23-2009) 
Sec. 2-386. - Purpose, powers and responsibilities. 
    The purpose of the Melbourne Economic Enhancement District Advisory Committee is to improve public participation and receive public comments on rehabilitation and redevelopment of the MEED, and to consider additional areas for Brownfield site rehabilitation and designation located outside of the MEED. The committee has the following powers and responsibilities: 
(1)  Economic and redevelopment opportunities through Enterprise Florida. A person responsible for an economic development or redevelopment project applying for incentives offered by Enterprise Florida through the Governor's Office of Tourism, Trade and Economic Development shall provide the committee with a copy of the application and supporting documents. Following review and public comment, the committee shall make a recommendation to the city council on whether to adopt a resolution of support, which is a program requirement. 
(2)  Incentives through the Florida Department of Environmental Protection. A person responsible for a Brownfield site rehabilitation must notify the advisory committee of said person's intent to rehabilitate and redevelop the site before executing the Brownfield site rehabilitation agreement, and provide the committee with a copy of the draft plan for site rehabilitation, which addresses elements required by F.S. § 376.80(5), as amended from time to time. The advisory committee shall review any proposed redevelopment agreements prepared pursuant to F.S. § 376.80(5)(i), as amended from time to time, and provide comments, if appropriate, to the city council. When a person responsible for a Brownfield site rehabilitation submits a site assessment report or the technical document containing the proposed course of action following site assessment to the appropriate state agency for review, said person must attend a regularly scheduled meeting of the committee to inform the committee of the findings and recommendations in the site assessment report or the technical document. 
(3)  Other duties. The committee may perform other duties at the request of the city council, including review of proposals for future land use, local employment opportunities, community safety and environmental justice within the MEED. 
(Code 1984, § 2-172.13; Ord. No. 2009-24, § 1, 6-23-2009) 
Sec. 2-387. - Support staff. 
    The Melbourne Economic Enhancement District Advisory Committee shall be staffed by the community development department. 
(Code 1984, § 2-172.14; Ord. No. 2009-24, § 1, 6-23-2009) 
Secs. 2-388-2-417. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - ZONING BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Charter reference- Board of adjustment, § 8.04(6)-(14). 

Sec. 2-418. - Creation and composition. 
    A board of adjustment is hereby established and consists of seven members. Members of the board of adjustment are appointed by the city council. In addition, the city council may appoint not more than two alternate members, designating them as such. Such alternate members may act in the temporary absence or disability of any regular member, or may act when a regular member is otherwise disqualified from voting in a particular case that may be presented to the board. The chair of the planning and zoning board shall be an ex officio member (nonvoting member) of the board of adjustment. 
(1)  Terms of office. Each member and alternate member shall serve a term of three years. 
(2)  Fees. The city council is authorized to establish a schedule of fees to be charged by the board of adjustment. 
(Code 1984, § 2-173; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-419. - Duties and powers. 
    The board of adjustment has the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Administrative review. To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged that there is an error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the community development director, city engineer, or the building official in the interpretation or enforcement of chapter 50 and appendices A, B, and D, excepting chapter 13 of appendix D. 
(2)  Variances. Unless prohibited by Code, to authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variance from the terms of appendices A, B, and D, excepting chapter 13 of appendix D, as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this division could result in unnecessary hardship. 
(Code 1984, § 2-173.1; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Sec. 2-420. - Duties of administrative official, board of adjustment, city council on matters of appeal. 
(a)  It is the intent of this Code that matters relating to code enforcement shall be presented to the building official. 
(b)  All questions of interpretation of appendices A, B, and D of the land development code (excepting chapter 10 relating to impact fees and chapter 13 relating to buildings and building regulations) shall be first presented to the community development director. In interpreting appendices A, B, or D of the land development code (excepting chapter 10 relating to impact fees and chapter 13 relating to buildings and building regulations), the community development director shall be guided first by the plain meaning of the words and terms in the Code and second by the intent expressed therein. The community development director shall make interpretations by interpreting the Code as a whole and not by taking specific words or clauses in isolation. In interpreting whether a particular use is allowed either as a principal, conditional or accessory use, the community development director shall be guided first by the specific uses delineated in particular zoning districts, and if the specific use sought is not delineated, the community development director shall be guided by the delineated uses to determine whether uses similar thereto are permitted and by examination of the intent of the zoning district. The letter of final determination must include in it instructions to the addressee with regard to how and when the addressee or other substantially affected party may appeal the determination. Thereafter, the board of adjustment shall have the authority to hear and decide appeals from the decision of the community development director where it is alleged that there is error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the community development director in interpreting appendices A, B, or D (excluding chapter 10 relating to impact fees and chapter 13 relating to buildings and building regulations). 
(1)  Hearings; appeals; notice. An appeal of any decision of the community development director in the interpretation of any portion of appendices A, B, or D of the land development code may be initiated by any person aggrieved and substantially affected greater in degree or differently than the community at large, or by the city manager. Such appeal shall be filed no later than 30 days following the date of rendition of the interpretation by the community development director. The term "rendition" shall be defined as the issuance of a written determination of interpretation by the community development director effective upon the date that a signed original is filed in the records of the secretary/clerk to the community development director. A copy of said letter of determination must be hand delivered or mailed, postage prepaid by U.S. certified mail, to the person requesting the determination. The letter must be mailed or hand delivered on the date of filing in the record of the secretary/clerk to the community development director. An appeal is initiated by filing with the community development director and with the secretary to the board of adjustment, a notice of appeal specifying the interpretation appealed from and a description of the reasons why the interpretation is in error. The secretary to the board of adjustment shall, within 15 days thereafter, transmit to the board all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. A fee may be charged for said appeal, said fee being an amount fixed from time to time by resolution of the city council. The secretary of the board after receipt of the record shall fix a time for hearing of the appeal and give public notice thereof at least 15 days in advance of the public hearing as well as notice to the parties in interest. At the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or attorney. 
(2)  Stay of proceeding. An appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the community development director certifies to the board of adjustment, after the notice of appeal is filed, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would, in the community development director's opinion, cause imminent peril to life and property. In such cases, proceedings shall not be stayed other than by a restraining order, which may be granted by the board of adjustment or by a court of record on application. 
(c)  It is further the intent of this section that the duties of the city council in connection with this Code shall not include hearing and deciding questions of interpretation or enforcement that may arise. The procedure for deciding questions shall be as stated in this section and this Code. Under this Code, the city council shall have only the duties: 
(1)  Of considering and adopting or rejecting proposed amendments or the repeal of this code, as provided by law; 
(2)  Of establishing a schedule of fees and charges; and 
(3)  To hear and decide applications for conditional uses as provided for in herein. 
(Code 1984, § 2-173.3; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 3-25-2008) 
Secs. 2-421-2-427. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - HISTORIC AND ARCHITECTURAL REVIEW BOARD 

Sec. 2-428. - Established. 
    An historic and architectural review board is hereby established and designated as the historic and architectural review board. 
(Ord. No. 2016-22, § 1, 4-26-2016) 
Sec. 2-429. - Organization and membership. 
(a)  The historic and architectural review board shall consist of seven members and two alternates, appointed by the city council. 
(b)  Alternate members may attend complete board meetings regardless of whether a quorum of regular members is seated. Alternate members may always participate in board deliberations and debate, but they may make motions and vote only in the absence or voting disqualification of a regular member or the vacancy in a regular member's seat. In the event that six regular members are present and voting and two alternate members are present, the alternate member who may vote and make motions is the alternate member who has served on the board for the longest period of time, regardless of whether said service is interrupted. 
(c)  As a participant in the Florida certified local government program as declared by the Florida Department of State, Division of Historical Resources, appointments to the historic and architectural review board shall be made based upon a reasonable effort to appoint members who are residents of the city from the disciplines of architecture, history, architectural history, planning, prehistoric and historic archaeology, landscape architecture, real estate, general contracting or building contracting. Lay persons who are residents, owners of property located within the city and individuals engaged in business within the city may make up the balance of the membership in the event that there are not enough qualified and eligible residents, provided the individual has demonstrated special interest, experience or knowledge in history, architecture, or a related discipline. The term "engaged in business" shall mean owning a business or serving as an officer or director of a corporation or other business entity so engaged. 
(d)  To the extent reasonably possible, each community redevelopment district shall be represented on the historic and architectural review board by at least one member. The representative of a district may be a regular or alternate member. 
(e)  To the extent reasonably possible, the historic and architectural review board shall include one member who is an architect and one member who is a contractor, which individuals may be regular or alternate members. 
(f)  Terms. In soliciting applications for the initial appointees, four of the seven regular member positions shall be for a three-year term and the remaining three regular member positions shall be for a two-year term. One of the alternate positions shall be for a two-year term and the other alternate position shall be for a one-year term. Members shall be eligible for reappointment. All appointments after the historic and architectural review board is first established shall be for a three-year term. 
(g)  Compensation. The members of the historic and architectural review board shall serve without compensation or honorarium; however, the members may be entitled to receive reimbursement fees pertaining to workshops, memberships, publications and/or conferences upon approval by the city manager and/or in accordance with the city's travel policy. 
(Ord. No. 2016-22, § 1, 4-26-2016) 
Sec. 2-430. - Quorum; meetings; records. 
(a)  The presence at a meeting of four regular or alternate members of the historic and architectural review board constitutes a quorum. The affirmative vote of a majority of the regular and alternate board members present and voting is necessary for the adoption of any motion. In all instances, seven members of the historic and architectural review board must be present at the hearing of an historic district designation, and a positive recommendation will require the affirmative vote of six members. 
(b)  The historic and architectural review board shall schedule a minimum of four regular meetings per year. 
(c)  An individual from city staff shall serve as recording secretary to the board and that individual shall be charged with maintaining board records in accordance with established city policies. 
(d)  An individual from city staff shall be appointed by the city manager to serve as staff liaison to the board. 
(e)  An individual shall be appointed by the city manager to serve as historic preservation officer to the board on behalf of the city, as prescribed by chapter 20, article VIII. 
(Ord. No. 2016-22, § 1, 4-26-2016) 
Sec. 2-431. - Powers and authority. 
(a)  In its capacity as the designated historic preservation board, the historic and architectural review board is hereby vested with the power, authority and jurisdiction on a city-wide basis to recommend local historic designations, regulate and administer historical, cultural, archaeological and architectural resources in the city as prescribed by chapter 20, article VIII under the direct jurisdiction and legislative control of the city council. 
(b)  In its capacity as the designated architectural review board, the historic and architectural review board is hereby vested with the power, authority and jurisdiction within the city redevelopment districts to consider material changes in the exterior appearance of buildings and signs as prescribed by chapter 20, article IV under the direct jurisdiction and legislative control of the city council. The historic and architectural review board is also hereby vested with the power, authority and jurisdiction to consider applications for murals as prescribed by chapter 20, article IV and appendix D, chapter 11. 
(Ord. No. 2016-22, § 1, 4-26-2016; Ord. No. 2016-61, § 1, 9-15-2016) 
Secs. 2-432-2-438. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - BUDGET[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference- Budgets and amendments, F.S. § 166.241. 

Sec. 2-462. - Preparation of manager's budget. 
    The city manager shall present to the city council each year a budget for all phases and operation of city government for the next fiscal year. The budget shall contain a complete financial plan for the fiscal year, a detailed estimate of anticipated revenues, a detailed description of proposed expenditures, and a capital improvement program for the fiscal year and the next four ensuing fiscal years. By message which shall accompany the budget, the manager shall describe important features of the budget plan and explain any major changes proposed in fiscal policy. 
(Code 1984, § 2-186; Laws of Fla., ch. 70-807, § 6.02; Ord. No. 79-45, § 1, 8-14-1979; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
State Law reference- Adoption of budgets and millage rates, F.S. § 200.065; financial matters, F.S. § 218.01 et seq. 
Sec. 2-463. - Form and content of budget. 
    Other than as provided in the Charter, the form and content of the budget and budget message shall be prescribed by the city council by resolution. Principal sources of anticipated revenue shall be itemized. 
(Laws of Fla., Ch. 69-879, § 6.03) 
State Law reference- Content and adoption of the budget, F.S. § 200.065. 
Sec. 2-464. - Public hearing. 
    Prior to adoption, the city council shall hold a public hearing on the proposed budget as provided by general law. 
(Code 1984, § 2-187; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
State Law reference- Budget and budget amendments, F.S. § 166.241; adopting budget and fixing millage, F.S. § 200.065. 
Sec. 2-465. - Adoption. 
    After the public hearing, the city council shall adopt by resolution by vote of at least a majority of the city council membership a final budget for the city. In adopting the final budget, the city council may amend the proposed budget by adding, increasing, deleting or decreasing any programs or amounts, other than expenditures required by law or for debt service. The form and content of the final budget shall be the same as that required for the manager's budget. Total proposed expenditures in the final budget shall not exceed total anticipated revenues. 
(Code 1984, § 2-188; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
State Law reference- Budget and budget amendments, F.S. § 166.241; adopting budget and fixing millage, F.S. § 200.065. 
Secs. 2-466-2-483. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRAVEL AND PER DIEM[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference- Per diem and travel expenses, F.S. § 112.061. 

Sec. 2-484. - Per diem and traveling expenses for city council, employees and authorized persons. 
    The intent of this section is to provide for the reimbursement of reasonable travel expenses for city councilmembers, city board members and city employees traveling in the course of official business. It also applies to certain third parties who are authorized by contract to receive reimbursement for travel expenses. As requested by the Melbourne Airport Authority, this section is also intended to apply to board members of the airport authority traveling in the course of airport-related official business and to third parties who are authorized to travel based upon a contract with the airport authority and traveling in the course of airport-related official business. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Airport authority means the Melbourne Airport Authority governing board. 
Airport director means the executive director of aviation of the airport. 
Authorized person means a person who is authorized to incur travel expenses in the performance of official business and (i) who is authorized by the city manager or the airport director, as the case may be, to incur travel expenses in the performance of his official duties, or (ii) is a person who is called upon by the city council or the Melbourne Airport Authority to contribute time and services as consultant or advisor or (iii) is a person who is a candidate for an executive or professional position, except that the term excludes city council members, city board members, airport authority board members and all employees. 
City manager means the city manager of the city. 
Common carrier means train, bus, or commercial airline operating scheduled flights. 
Travel expense, traveling expenses, necessary expenses while traveling, or words of similar nature, means usual, ordinary and incidental expenditures necessarily incurred by a traveler. 
Traveler means any city council member, city board member, employee, member of the airport authority governing board, or authorized person traveling on city business. 
(b)  Authority to incur traveling expense. 
(1)  Travel for all persons except members of the city council or board members of the airport authority must be authorized and approved by the city manager for non-airport related business or the airport director for airport-related business, as the case may be. All travel by members of the city council must be approved by the city council and reimbursement then requested from the city manager. All travel by board members of the airport authority must be approved by the airport authority and reimbursement then requested from the airport director. The city manager or the airport director, as the case may be, must not authorize or approve any request for travel reimbursement unless it is accompanied by a signed statement by the traveler's supervisor stating such travel is or was on the official business of the city and also stating the purpose of such travel. In the case of a member of the city council, the request for travel reimbursement is required to also have been approved by the city council. In the case of a member of the airport authority board or a city council member serving on the airport authority board and traveling on airport business, the request for travel reimbursement is required to also comply with section 12-141. 
(2)  Traveling expenses for travelers is limited to those expenses necessarily incurred by them in the performance of a public purpose authorized by law to be performed by the city and must be within the limitations prescribed by this section. Determination of whether the travel expense is incurred in the performance of official business shall be as follows: 
a.  For employees, by city manager for non-airport related business or airport director for airport-related business, as the case may be. 
b.  For city council members, by city council. 
c.  For board members of airport authority, by the airport authority. 
d.  For board members of other city boards, by city manager. 
e.  For authorized persons, pursuant to a valid and approved contract. 
(c)  Rates of subsistence allowance for travel within the United States of America. 
(1)  All travelers will be reimbursed for actual lodging expenses at the single occupancy rate to be substantiated by paid receipts. 
(2)  All travelers will be reimbursed for expenses, including tips, for meals up to the following amounts: 
a.  Breakfast ..... $ 8.00 
b.  Lunch ..... 11.00 
c.  Dinner ..... 19.00 
In the alternative to the meal allowance rates set forth in this subsection (c)(2), subject to the approval of the city manager or the airport director, as the case may be, a traveler will be reimbursed for actual expenses, including tips, for meals consistent with (meaning not to exceed) the U.S. General Services Administration ("GSA") per diem rates for the city and state in which travel occurs, as said rate is revised from time to time. Rates may be found on the worldwide web at http://www.gsa.gov. 
(4)  When a traveler attends an event on the city's behalf and the fixed price of the meal exceeds the per meal allowance, the traveler will be reimbursed the actual cost of the meal as authorized by the city manager or the airport director, as the case may be, and the remaining meals will be reimbursed either at the individual meal allowance rates or at a proportional meal rate for the GSA rates, as applicable. 
(5)  No traveler will be reimbursed for meals gratuitously provided by another party. 
(6)  No traveler will be reimbursed for meals when travel is confined to the county, except as authorized by the city manager or the airport director, as the case may be. 
(d)  Rates of subsistence allowance for international travel. 
(1)  This subsection (d) applies to travel outside the United State of America. All travelers will be reimbursed for actual lodging expenses at the single occupancy rate to be substantiated by paid receipts. 
(2)  All travelers will be reimbursed for actual expenses, including tips, for meals consistent with the U.S. Department of State foreign per diem rates for the city and country in which travel occurs, as said rate is revised from time to time. Rates may be found on the worldwide web at http://aoprals.state.gov. 
(3)  When a traveler attends an event on the city's behalf or that of the airport authority and the fixed price of the meals exceeds the allowance as set forth in subsection (d)(2) of this section, the traveler will be reimbursed the actual cost as authorized by the city manager or the airport director, as the case may be, and the remaining meals will be reimbursed at a proportional meal rate. 
(4)  No traveler will be reimbursed for meals gratuitously provided by another party. 
(e)  Transportation. 
(1)  All travel must be by a usually traveled route. In case a person travels by an indirect route for his own convenience, any extra costs shall be borne by the traveler and reimbursement for expenses shall be based only on such charges as would have been incurred by a usually traveled route. The city manager or airport director, as the case may be, shall designate the most economical method of travel for each trip, keeping in mind the following conditions: 
a.  The nature of the business. 
b.  The most efficient and economical means of travel (considering time of the traveler, cost of transportation and subsistence required). 
c.  The number of persons making the trip, and the amount of equipment or material to be transported. 
(2)  Common carrier. Transportation by common carrier, when traveling on official business and paid for personally by the traveler, will be substantiated by a receipt. Travelers will endeavor to obtain the most economical class of travel. Generally, the most economical class of travel for transportation common carrier shall be coach class. In the event travel time by common carrier airlines will exceed ten consecutive hours (including connections and plane changes), then business class fare may be designated as the most economical class of travel, subject to the approval of the city manager or the airport director, as the case may be. Charges in excess of the most economical class will be refunded by the traveler to the city. 
(3)  Privately owned vehicles. 
a.  The use of privately owned vehicles for official travel in lieu of public-owned vehicles or common carrier may be authorized by the city if a public-owned vehicle is not available. The traveler shall provide the risk manager of the city with proof of adequate insurance upon request of the risk manager of the city. 
b.  Whenever travel is by privately owned vehicles, the traveler will be entitled to (i) a mileage allowance at a fixed rate not to exceed the current rate allowable under the Internal Revenue Regulations § 1.274-5 or (ii) the most applicable common carrier fare for such travel. Determination of whether the reimbursement shall be based on the mileage allowance or the fare shall be made by the city manager or airport director, as the case may be. Reimbursement for expenditures related to the operation, maintenance and ownership of a vehicle will not be allowed when privately owned vehicles are used on public business and reimbursement is made pursuant to this subsection (e)(3), except as provided in subsection (f) of this section. 
c.  All mileage shall be shown from point of origin to point of destination based on the odometer reading. 
(4)  Privately owned aircraft. No traveler shall be reimbursed for the use of a privately owned aircraft for travel in the performance of official business of the city. 
(5)  Rental cars. Transportation by rental car must be substantiated by a receipt. Car rental shall be from an established rental car firm. Approved car rental shall be obtained at the most economical size and rate, consistent with the travel needs. Charges in excess of the most economical size and rate will be refunded by the traveler to the city. 
(6)  Charters. Transportation by chartered vehicles or chartered aircraft when traveling on official business may be authorized by the city manager or the airport director, as the case may be, when necessary or where it is to the advantage of the city, provided the cost of such transportation does not exceed the cost of transportation by privately owned vehicles and common carrier. The chartered vehicle or aircraft shall be from an established charter operator commercial business. No traveler shall own, in whole or in part, the chartered vehicle or aircraft or the commercial business. Transportation by chartered vehicles or aircraft must be substantiated by a receipt. Nothing herein is intended to limit the city or the airport authority from entering into a contract for services to charter transportation. 
(7)  No traveler will be allowed either mileage or transportation expense when he is gratuitously transported by another person, or when he is transported by another traveler who is entitled to mileage or transportation expense. 
(f)  Other expenses. The following incidental traveling expenses of the traveler may be reimbursed: 
(1)  Taxi fare. 
(2)  Ferry fares; and bridge, road and tunnel tolls. 
(3)  Storage or parking fees. 
(4)  Telecommunication expense, when directly related to city business. 
(5)  Tips, other than meals. 
(6)  Convention registration fee while attending a convention or conference which will serve a direct public purpose with relation to the city served by the person attending such meetings. However, any meals or lodging included in the registration fee will be deducted from the allowances provided in this section. 
(7)  Taxes from which the city is eligible for exemption shall not be reimbursed. 
(g)  Advancements. Notwithstanding any of the foregoing restrictions and limitations, the city manager or the airport director, as the case may be, may make, or authorize the making of, advances to cover anticipated costs of travel to travelers. Such advancements may include the costs of subsistence and travel of the traveler in the performance of his official duties. Advancements shall not be available to authorized persons (third-parties). 
(h)  Unusual situations. In rare instances, unusual situations may occur in which travel not covered in this section is required. In such instances, the city manager or the airport director, as the case may be, is authorized to approve the necessary travel expenses to accomplish the city's objectives. 
(i)  Rules and regulations. The city will prescribe such forms and procedures as may be necessary to effectuate the purpose of this section. 
(Code 1984, § 2-201; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1, 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 2003-48, § 1, 7-22-2003; Ord. No. 2006-66, § 1, 7-11-2006; Ord. No. 2008-46, § 1, 8-12-2008; Ord. No. 2013-03, § 1(2-201), 1-22-2013; Ord. No. 2018-60, § 1, 12-11-2018) 
Secs. 2-485-2-506. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FEES 

Sec. 2-507. - Schedule of miscellaneous fees. 
(a)  The schedule of fees to be paid at the time of application for rezoning, conditional use, variance, annexation, construction plan review, project inspection, project re-inspection, plat, development plan, comprehensive plan amendment, concurrency evaluation, right-of-way use permit, vacating right-of-way, site plan approval, sign variance, or other types of development permits as that term is defined in F.S. § 163.3164 and police escort fee shall be set by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(b)  No permit or certificate shall be issued and no inspection, public notice or other action shall be instituted until after such fees, costs and charges have been paid. When, in accordance with provisions of this section, a fee is paid and application is filed, there shall be no return or rebate of any funds so received, regardless of the city's determination in the matter involved. All fees, costs and charges shall be, upon collection, deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 2-216; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Secs. 2-508-2-537. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - PURCHASING[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Editor's note- Within this article, the terms "purchasing division" and "purchasing manager" have been replaced with "procurement division" and "procurement manager," at the request of the city. 
Charter reference- Central purchasing and competitive bidding, § 3.18. 
State Law reference- Consultants' Competitive Negotiation Act, F.S. § 287.055. 

Sec. 2-570. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Professional services means any service performed by a professional. A professional is one performing any vocation requiring at least a four-year college degree as a prerequisite to licensing by the state. The four-year degree is not required to be in the field of study specifically related to the vocation in question. A professional service includes, but is not limited to, services performed by a certified public accountant, an attorney, or a doctor. The positions of city manager, financial advisor, consultant, or bond underwriter shall also be included within this definition. 
    Procurement manager means the purchasing agent as provided for in the Charter. 
    Services means the furnishing of labor, time, or effort by a contractor. 
    Supplies means and include all supplies, materials and equipment. 
    Using agency means any department or division, agency, commission, board, bureau, committee, institution, authority, or other establishment or official of this city, which utilizes any supplies, services, or any other item procured under this Code. 
(Code 1984, § 2-231; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 1, 11-11-2014) 
Sec. 2-571. - Establishment of a division of central purchasing; general purpose. 
(a)  In accordance with the Charter, there is hereby established a central purchasing program to be located in the division of purchasing. The central purchasing program shall be administered by a procurement manager who shall function as the city's purchasing agent. The purpose of the division of purchasing is to promote efficiency and economy; to effect coordination in the purchase of commodities for the city; and to provide overall direction of contractual services, procurement policies, rules, and procedures. 
(b)  The procurement manager shall develop and maintain a purchasing manual which shall provide for rules, regulations, and procedures for the internal management and operation of the division of purchasing and such rules and regulations as shall be prescribed by the city manager and the city council. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided in the Code, the procurement manager shall supervise the procurement of all supplies, services, or other items as needed by the city; exercise supervision and control over inventories of supply belonging to the city; sell, trade, donate, destroy, transfer or otherwise dispose of surplus property belonging to the city; establish and maintain programs for the inspection, testing, and acceptance of supplies and services; establish and maintain a program for the development and usage of standard specifications for supplies and services; and determine the lowest or highest responsible and responsive bidder/proposer, as the case may be. 
(Code 1984, § 2-232; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-572. - Jurisdiction on public improvement or professional service contracts. 
(a)  The solicitation and award of contracts involving public works or public construction and improvements shall be administered by the engineering department. Public works and public construction and improvement contract solicitation and award shall be specifically subject to the procedures set forth in sections 2-574 through 2-588, and subject to F.S. § 255.20, as amended from time to time, and to the extent that the public work or construction and improvement meets the cost thresholds in those statutes. The solicitation and award of contracts involving public works or public construction and improvements are otherwise exempt from this article. Notwithstanding that the foregoing code provisions make reference to certain tasks being accomplished by the procurement division, in the case of the solicitation and award of contracts involving public works or public construction and improvements, said tasks shall be accomplished by the engineering department. 
(b)  The solicitation and consummation of contracts involving leases by the city for all grounds, buildings, or other space required by using city agencies shall be administered by the city manager or his designee. Contract consummation of leases by the city for all grounds, buildings, or other space required by using city agencies shall be specifically subject to the procedures set forth in sections 2-574, 2-578 and 2-580-2-582. The solicitation and consummation of contracts involving leases by the city for all grounds, buildings, or other space required by using city agencies shall be otherwise exempt from this article. Notwithstanding that the foregoing provisions may make reference to certain tasks being accomplished by the procurement division, said tasks shall be accomplished by the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  Contracts for professional services shall be exempt from this article relating to purchasing. The purchase of professional services subject to the Consultants' Competitive Negotiation Act, F.S. § 287.055, shall be awarded pursuant to the provisions of that enactment, as amended from time to time. The purchase of professional services, subject to F.S. § 11.45, shall be awarded pursuant to the provisions of that enactment, as amended from time to time. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the purchase of professional services up to and including $25,000.00 may be awarded by the city manager. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the purchase of professional services for in excess of $25,000.00 shall be awarded by the city council. 
(Code 1984, § 2-233; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
State Law reference- Local bids and contracts for public construction, F.S. § 255.20. 
Sec. 2-573. - Unauthorized purchases. 
    Except as herein provided, it shall be unlawful for any using agency to order the purchase of any services, supplies, or commodities within the purview of this article other than through the procurement division. The city shall not approve and shall not be bound by any purchase order or contract made contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 2-234; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-574. - Encumbrance of funds. 
    Except in cases of emergency, neither the procurement manager nor a using agency shall issue any purchase order for delivery if it has been determined that there is an insufficient unencumbered appropriation balance, in excess of unpaid obligations, to defray the amount of such order in the account of the using agency. 
(Code 1984, § 2-235; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-575. - Formal bids. 
(a)  Generally. All supplies and services, except as otherwise provided herein, when the estimated cost shall exceed $35,000.00, shall be purchased after competitive formal bidding (sealed bids) and awarded to the lowest and best responsible and responsive bidder. City council shall have authority to waive formal bid procedures in cases where it deems it advisable to do so, under the terms and conditions provided for in this article. 
(b)  Notice inviting bids. Invitations to bid shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Newspaper. The notice inviting bids shall be published once in the legal section of a newspaper of general circulation in the city and at least five calendar days preceding the last day set for the receipt of proposals. The notice shall include a general description of the supplies to be purchased or sold or services to be performed and shall state where bid invitations and specifications may be secured and the time and place for opening bids. 
(2)  Electronic bid posting. Sealed bids and formal proposals shall be made available simultaneously to all prospective suppliers. Bids and formal proposals are classified by commodities and posted online for the purpose of inviting sealed bids and quotations. 
(3)  Bulletin board. All pending purchases or sales shall also be advertised by a notice posted on a public bulletin board in city hall. 
(c)  Bid deposits. When deemed necessary by the procurement division, a bid deposit (surety) and/or performance bond may be prescribed in an invitation to bid; however, a performance bond may be required by the city council in any case where the contract price exceeds $35,000.00. Unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to a return of surety where the city has required such. A successful bidder shall forfeit any required surety upon failure on his part to enter into a contract after city approval or to meet other requirements as set forth in the invitation to bid. 
(d)  Bid-opening. 
(1)  Sealed. Bids shall be submitted sealed to the procurement division and shall be identified as a bid on the envelope. 
(2)  Opening. Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notice. 
(3)  Tabulation. A tabulation of all bids received shall be available for public inspection. 
(e)  Award. The provisions of section 2-583 shall apply. 
(f)  Rejection of bids. The city shall reserve the right to reject all bids or parts of all bids for one or more supplies or services included in the proposed specifications. A statement of the reason for the rejection shall be prepared and made a part of the record. 
(g)  Correction or withdrawal of bids; cancellation of awards. Correction before bid opening or withdrawal of inadvertently erroneous bids before or after bid opening or cancellation of awards or contracts based on bid mistakes may be permitted. Mistakes discovered before bid opening may be modified or withdrawn by written notice from the bidder and received in the office designated in the invitation to bid prior to the time set for bid opening. After bid opening, corrections or clarifications in bids shall be permitted only to the extent that the corrections do not materially affect the terms, conditions and specifications and may be subject to the approval of the city attorney. 
(h)  Late bids. Bids received and clocked in after the hour and date specified in the proposal form will not be opened. 
(i)  Contracts. Supplies and services to be provided over a period of time may be a subject of a formal contract signed by the successful bidder, the procurement manager, and/or the city manager. 
(Code 1984, § 2-236; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2011-15, § 1, 5-10-2011; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 2, 11-11-2014) 
Sec. 2-576. - Waiver of formal bid requirements. 
    When the estimated cost of supplies and/or services exceeds $35,000.00, a contract for same may be awarded to the lowest and best responsible bidder without formal contract and without formal bidding, as specifically provided below: 
(1)  Purchase from governmental entity. The city may buy from another governmental entity contracts or bids whereby such contract or formal bid followed formal bid procedures of sealed written bids, public opening, and legal advertising. 
(2)  Sole source procurement. A contract may be made without competition when the using agency certifies to the procurement manager in writing that, after conducting a good faith review of available sources, there is only one source for the required item or service, and that the item or service is the only item or service that can meet the city's need, or by negotiation where the procurement by competitive procedure is not feasible or practicable. 
(3)  Surplus property. The city manager may authorize the procurement manager to purchase surplus property as donated by the state department of general services, division of surplus property, as authorized by state statutes. 
(Code 1984, § 2-237; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2011-15, § 2, 5-10-2011; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 3, 11-11-2014) 
Sec. 2-577. - Formal proposals. 
    When the city manager determines that the use of competitive sealed bidding is either not practicable or advantageous to the city, an award or a contract may be entered into by use of the competitive sealed proposals method. 
(1)  Request for proposals. Proposals shall be solicited through a request for proposals (RFP). 
(2)  Public notice. Adequate public notice of the request for proposals shall be given in the same manner as provided in this article. 
(3)  Proposed fees. The city shall require interested persons to submit a quotation of their proposed fees or prices for the performance or delivery of their proposed services or goods, unless such interested persons are prohibited by law. 
(4)  Evaluation factors. The request for proposals shall state the relative importance of price and other evaluation factors. 
(5)  Discussion with responsible offerors; revisions to proposals. For the purpose of clarification and to ensure a full understanding of and conformance to the solicitation requirements, discussions shall be conducted with at least three of the best qualified responsible offerors, who submit proposals, who are determined to be reasonably successful in being selected for award. Offerors shall be provided an opportunity to discuss and revise proposals. Revisions may be permitted through negotiations after submission and prior to award for the purpose of obtaining the best and final offer. 
(6)  Award. Award shall be made to the responsible offeror whose proposal is determined in writing to be the most advantageous to the city taking into consideration price and the evaluation factors set forth in the request for proposals. Approval of final award will be governed by the total estimated cost and provisions set forth in this article. No other factors or criteria shall be used in the evaluation. 
(Code 1984, § 2-238; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 4, 11-11-2014) 
Sec. 2-578. - Contracts. 
(a)  All contracts for purchase of commodities or performance of services for the city which exceed $35,000.00, except for contracts governed by the Consultant's Competitive Negotiations Act (CCNA) and contractual services and commodities that are not subject to the competitive-solicitation requirements of F.S. § 287.057. F.S. § 287.055, shall be awarded in accordance with the provisions of the formal bids and formal proposals. All contracts which do not exceed $35,000.00 may be approved by the procurement manager without competitive bidding or negotiation. If the city has an existing contract for the performance of such services, the contract may be renewed annually, provided that the services rendered have been satisfactory. 
(b)  Contracts in the amount up to and including $15,000.00 shall be approved by the appropriate department director and the procurement manager. Contracts in the amount of $15,000.01 to $35,000.00 shall be approved by the appropriate department director and city manager. 
(Code 1984, § 2-239; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2011-15, § 3, 5-10-2011; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 5, 11-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Consultants Competitive Negotiations Act, F.S. § 287.055. 
Sec. 2-579. - Cooperative purchasing. 
    The procurement manager shall have the authority to join with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interest of the city would be served. 
(Code 1984, § 2-240; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-580. - Open market (informal) purchases. 
    Purchases of supplies and/or services with a value of $35,000.00 or less shall be made without observing the provisions prescribed for formal bids or formal proposals. Competitive informal bids (quotes) shall be obtained as provided below: 
(1)  Small purchases. Purchases which do not exceed $5,000.00 may be procured without competitive bids, when it best serves the interests of the city. 
(2)  Purchases between $5,000.01 and $15,00.00. Purchases of supplies and/or services, except in case of emergency or as otherwise provided herein, between $5,000.00 and $15,000.00 shall require a minimum of three competitive written quotes. 
(3)  Purchases between $15,000.01 and $35,000.00. Purchases of supplies and/or services, except in case of emergency or as otherwise provided herein, between $15,000.01 and $35,000.00 shall require formal quotation processing by the procurement division. 
(Code 1984, § 2-241; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2011-15, § 4, 5-10-2011; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 6, 11-11-2014) 
Sec. 2-581. - Purchasing awards thresholds. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, the authority for awards of contracts or purchases shall be made as follows: 
(1)  Procurement manager. Amounts up to and including $15,000.00. 
(2)  City manager. Amounts exceeding $15,000.00 up to and including $35,000.00. 
(3)  City council. Amounts in excess of $35,000.00. 
(Code 1984, § 2-242; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2011-15, § 5, 5-10-2011; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 7, 11-11-2014) 
Sec. 2-582. - Prohibition against subdivision. 
    No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 2-243; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-583. - Award to lowest responsible bidder. 
    Awards of contracts or purchases shall be to the lowest most responsive and responsible bidder. In determining the lowest responsive and responsible bidder, the following, in addition to price, shall be considered: 
(1)  Responsibility. 
a.  The ability, capacity, and skill of the bidder to perform under the terms of the bid documents. 
b.  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the materials or service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference. 
c.  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience, and efficiency of the bidder. 
d.  The quality of performance of previous contracts and the providing of materials and/or services. 
e.  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract, or the providing of materials or services. 
f.  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the materials or services. 
g.  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies, equipment, or contractual services to the particular use required. 
h.  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract. 
i.  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid. 
(2)  Responsiveness. 
a.  Whether the bid conforms to the material elements of an invitation for bid or request for proposal. 
b.  Whether the bid conforms substantially to specifications and does not contain a material variance. 
(Code 1984, § 2-244; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 8, 11-11-2014) 
Sec. 2-584. - Award to other than lowest responsive and responsible bidder. 
    When the award is not given to the lowest responsive and responsible bidder, a statement of the reason for placing the order elsewhere shall be prepared and made a part of the record when bids are taken by formal method. 
(Code 1984, § 2-245; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 9, 11-11-2014) 
Sec. 2-585. - Tie bids. 
    Whenever identical bids are received, preference shall be given to the bid certifying a drug-free workplace has been implemented. If two or more, or none, of the equal responses are received certifying that a drug-free workplace has been implemented, the contract shall be awarded to a local responsible bidder. Local bidder is defined to be a bidder whose business office is located within the incorporated limits of the city. If there are no local bidders, then the contract shall be awarded to a bidder whose business office is located within the county. Should all or none of the bidders meet the preferences stated above, the procurement manager shall award the contract to one of the bidders by drawing lots in public. 
(Code 1984, § 2-246; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-586. - Negotiations. 
(a)  When only one bid is received under competitive bidding, negotiation is permitted in order to obtain a fair and reasonable price, or if the low responsive bid is considered by the procurement manager to be high, he shall have the authority to negotiate a lower price with the lowest responsible bidder. 
(b)  The procurement manager may negotiate for used equipment when deemed to be in the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 2-247; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-587. - Emergency purchases. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the city manager may make or authorize the procurement manager or others to make emergency procurement of supplies or services when there exists a threat to public health, safety, or welfare; provided that such emergency procurement shall be made with such competition as is practicable under the circumstances. A written determination of the basis for the emergency and for the selection of the particular contractor shall be submitted to the procurement manager by the using agency and shall be included as part of the contract and filed with the city manager. 
(Code 1984, § 2-248; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-588. - Appeals and remedies. 
(a)  Right to protest. Any actual or prospective bidder or proposer who is aggrieved in connection with a solicitation or award of a bid or contract may protest to the procurement manager in accordance with established procedures detailed in the purchasing manual. 
(b)  Remedy. The procurement manager is authorized to settle any protest regarding the solicitation or award of a city contract any claim arising out of the performance of a city contract, prior to an appeal to the city manager or city council, or the commencement of an action in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  Stay of procurement. In the event of a timely protest properly filed, the procurement manager shall not proceed further with the solicitation or award of the contract until all administrative remedies have been exhausted or until the city manager or city council, as appropriate, makes a determination on the record that the award of a contract without delay is necessary to protect substantial interests of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 2-249; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 2-589. - Local vendor preference policy. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Formal bid means a solicitation (invitation to bid (ITB)) of supplies and/or services in excess of $35,000.00. 
    Formal quote means a solicitation of supplies and/or services between $15,000.01 and $35,000.00, processed by the procurement division. 
    Local business means the vendor is either a local-city or local-county business. 
    Local-city business means the vendor has: 
(1)  A valid business tax receipt issued by the city at least one year prior to the solicitation of a formal quote/bid for which the business may seek local vendor preference; and 
(2)  A physical business address located within the city, in an area zoned for the conduct of such business, from which the vendor is operating or performing its business, and at which it maintains full-time employees. 
    Local-county business means the vendor has: 
(1)  A valid business tax receipt, issued by the county at least one year prior to the solicitation of a formal quote/bid for which the business may seek local vendor preference; and 
(2)  A physical business address located within the county from which the vendor is operating or performing its business, and at which it maintains full-time employees. 
    Non-local business means any vendor that does not meet either the definition of local-city business or local-county business as defined in this section. 
(b)  Establishment as local business. To establish that a vendor is a local business, a vendor shall provide written documentation of compliance with the definitions for each such local business as defined in subsection (a) of this section, at the time of submitting a formal quote/bid. Post office boxes are not verifiable and shall not be used for the purpose of establishing the required physical business address. A vendor that misrepresents the local preference status of its firm in a formal quote/bid submitted to the city shall lose the privilege to claim local preference status for a period of two years. 
(c)  Local preference in purchasing and contracting. The city shall give award preference to a local business in the purchase of commodities, personal property, general services, professional services, and the purchase of or contract for construction or renovation of public works or other public improvements by means of formal quote or competitive bid in the following manner: 
(1)  Competitive quote/bid. Each formal competitive quote/bid solicitation shall clearly identify how the price order of the quotes/bids received will be evaluated and determined. 
(2)  Local award. If the initial lowest quote/bid is submitted by a qualified and responsive local business, there is no further local preference given. 
(3)  Local-city preference. 
a.  Under a competitive quote/bid solicitation, when a qualified responsive, responsible non-local business submits the lowest price quote/bid, and a quote/bid submitted by one or more responsive, responsible local-city businesses is within five percent of the price submitted by the non-local business, then each of the responsive, responsible local businesses within five percent shall have the opportunity to submit an offer to match the price submitted by the non-local bidder. A price match document must be received within five business days after issuance. 
b.  If the initial lowest local-city business submits an offer that matches the lowest non-local quote/bid, and the two vendors are similarly qualified and responsive bidders, then the award shall be made to the local-city business. 
c.  If the initial lowest local-city business declines or is unable to match the lowest non-local quote/bid, then the option to do so moves to the next initial lowest local-city business, and so on, that is a similarly qualified and responsive bidder. 
(4)  Local-county preference. 
a.  At such time that there is no local-city business within five percent of the lowest bid, or all eligible local-city bidders decline the option to match the lowest quote/bid, then the offer to match the lowest non-local bid shall go to each of the similarly qualified and responsive local-county businesses whose submitted bid is within two percent of the lowest bid. A price match document must be received within five business days after issuance. 
b.  If the initial lowest local-county business submits an offer that matches the lowest non-local quote/bid, and the two vendors are similarly qualified and responsive bidders, then the award shall be made to the local-county business. 
c.  If the initial lowest local-county business declines or is unable to match the lowest non-local quote/bid, then the option to do so moves to the next initial lowest local-county business, and so on, that is a similarly qualified and responsive bidder. 
(5)  No local award. Should none of the local bidders be willing to price match the lowest non-local quote/bid, then the lowest non-local bid shall be awarded the purchase or contract. 
(6)  Unit pricing. If a local business accepts the opportunity to match the lowest non-local quote/bid, and that quote/bid is based on unit pricing and estimated quantities, then the unit prices for each or all quote/bid items must be matched against the non-local quote/bid pricing, in accordance with the quote/bid solicitation requirement. 
(7)  Tie quotes/bids. In the event of a tie between the initial quote/bid of two or more local businesses, the local business with the greatest number of full-time employees working in the city or county, respectively, shall be awarded the purchase or contract. 
(d)  Exception to local vendor preference policy. The local preference policy set forth herein shall not apply to any of the following purchases or contracts: 
(1)  Goods or services provided under a cooperative purchasing agreement or piggyback agreement; 
(2)  Purchases or contracts which are funded, in whole or part, by a governmental entity and the laws, regulations, or policies governing such funding prohibit application of that preference; 
(3)  Purchases made or contracts approved under emergency or noncompetitive situations, or for litigation related legal services, as described in the city's purchasing policies; 
(4)  Purchases or contracts with an estimated cost of $15,000.00 or less; 
(5)  Purchases or contracts where the difference between the amount of the low quote/bid submitted by a qualified and responsive non-local business and the lowest quote/bid submitted by a qualified and responsive local business is greater than $35,000.00; or 
(6)  Where all quotes/bids are rejected. 
(e)  Waiver of the application for local vendor preference policy. Any request for the waiver of local preference to any particular purchase or contract must be approved by either the city manager or the city council, depending upon approval threshold, prior to advertising the quote/bid. The city manager or city council, as the respective awarding authority, may approve the waiver of local preference upon review and at their discretion. 
(f)  Comparison and review of qualifications. The preferences established herein in no way prohibit the right of the city to compare and review the quality of materials proposed for purchase, and to compare and review the qualifications, character, responsibility, and fitness of all persons, firms or corporations submitting quotes/bids. Furthermore, the local preference established herein shall not prohibit the city from giving any other preference permitted by law in addition to the local preference contained herein. 
(g)  Administration of local preference policy. This policy shall apply to all departments under the purview of the city council. The engineering department shall be responsible for the administration of the local preference policy for bids involving public works or public construction and improvements. The procurement division of the financial services department shall be responsible for administration of the local preference policy for all other quotes/bids. 
(Code 1984, § 2-249.1; Ord. No. 2009-30, § 1, 8-11-2009; Ord. No. 2011-15, § 6, 5-10-2011; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 10, 11-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Preference to state businesses, F.S. § 287.084. 
Secs. 2-590-2-601. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SURPLUS CITY PROPERTY[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note- Within this article, the terms "purchasing division" and "purchasing manager" have been replaced with "procurement division" and "procurement manager," at the request of the city. 

Sec. 2-602. - Disposition of property.
