(a)  Reports. All using agencies shall submit to the procurement manager, at such times and in such forms as prescribed, reports showing stocks of all supplies, material, and equipment which are no longer used, or which have become obsolete, worn out, or scrapped. 
(b)  Transfer. The procurement manager, subject to approval of the city manager, shall have the authority to transfer surplus stock to other using agencies. 
(c)  Sale. The procurement manager shall have the authority to sell all surplus supplies which have become unsuitable for public use, or to exchange the same for or trade in the same on new supplies. 
(Code 1984, § 2-250; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Secs. 2-603-2-612. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HOMETOWN LABOR LAW 

Sec. 2-613. - Adopted. 
(a)  This section shall be known as the "Hometown Labor Law of the City of Melbourne, Florida." 
(b)  The city council's desire to provide employment opportunities for residents of the city shall be implemented through the following requirements applicable to all construction projects having a contract value of $100,000.00 or more and which are funded entirely by the city: 
(1)  Employment preference shall be given to qualified city residents, if available, for all new jobs created as a result of the awards of contracts for such projects. 
(2)  All contracts for such projects shall include a provision requiring the contractor to submit an employment plan describing his proposed actions to comply with subsection (b)(1) of this section. Such employment plan shall contain the following: 
a.  A listing of the number and types of new jobs to be created by the contractor, or his subcontractors, as a result of the contract. 
b.  A description of the actions to be taken by the contractor, or his subcontractors, to ensure the employment of qualified city residents, if available, for the new jobs created as a result of the contract. 
c.  An agreement to include status reports on the implementation of the employment plan with all pay requests. 
(3)  Employment plans shall become a part of the contract documents, and shall be enforced in the same manner as other provisions of the contract. 
(Code 1984, § 2-251; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000) 
Secs. 2-614-2-622. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - REAL PROPERTY[18] 
Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
State Law reference- Purchase of property, F.S. § 166.045. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-623-2-632. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ACQUISITION BY THE CITY 

Sec. 2-633. - Acquisition of real property by the city. 
    The city may acquire real property pursuant to the terms and conditions deemed most advantageous to the city, subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  City manager approval for limited purchases. If the proposed purchase price of real property to be acquired by the city is less than or equal to $25,000.00, then the city manager is hereby authorized to accept title to such real property and execute all documents necessary to effectuate the purchase of such real property. Regarding such acquisitions by the city, no written appraisal must be obtained or reviewed as part of the city's negotiation process. 
(2)  City council approval. 
a.  All purchases of real property by the city having a purchase price in excess of $25,000.00 shall be subject to the approval of the majority of the city council voting. City council shall be authorized to enter into any agreement for the purchase of specifically identified parcels of real property upon such terms and conditions as city council shall deem acceptable. 
b.  City council may require one or more appraisals of the real property by a state certified real estate appraiser who is a Member of the Appraisal Institute (MAI) to consider as part of the purchase process, but the city council need not obtain any appraisals if the city council deems the purchase price to be in the best interest of the city, based upon any other factors deemed appropriate by the city council. 
(3)  Other restrictions. All purchases of real property by the city shall comply with the requirements of applicable state and federal laws, including, but not limited to, the Uniform Act, 42 USC 4601 et seq., a federal law that establishes minimum standards for federally funded programs and projects that require the acquisition of real property. 
(4)  Optional procedures. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prohibit or limit the city from utilizing any other procedure for the purchase of real property which may be provided by state law, including, but not limited to, F.S. § 166.045, exempting certain appraisals and negotiations from public disclosure, and F.S. ch. 73, eminent domain proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 2014-57, § 1, 10-28-2014) 
Secs. 2-634-2-644. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISPOSITION[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-28, §§ 1, 2, adopted Aug. 11, 2015, repealed the former div. 3, §§ 2-645-2-660, and enacted a new div. 3 as set out herein. The former div. 3 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2014-57, § 1(2-252), adopted Oct. 28, 2014. 

Sec. 2-645. - Conveyance of title to real property. 
    The city council may approve a conveyance of the city's title of ownership to real property provided that the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The conveyance must be approved by resolution adopted by the city council, which resolution shall be recorded with the deed in the public records of Brevard County. 
(2)  The purchase price of the conveyance must equal or exceed the city's estimate of fair market value of the city property, except for good cause shown to serve a public purpose. 
(3)  For a conveyance reflecting an estimated fair market value of the city property in excess of $100,000.00, the resolution must be adopted at a public hearing proceeded by notice, which notice shall consist of an advertisement in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city and posting a copy of the advertisement upon the subject property and at city hall, all notice to be provided at least ten days prior to the public hearing. The conveyance of the property may not be divided for the purpose of evading the public hearing. 
(4)  The requirements of section 42-3, City Code shall apply to a conveyance of "park property" or "waterfront property" as identified therein. 
(5)  The conveyance must be in the best interests of the city. 
(6)  The terms of the conveyance must conform to the requirements of applicable state and federal laws. 
(Ord. No. 2015-28, § 2, 8-11-2015) 
Sec. 2-646. - Lease of real property. 
    The city council may approve a lease of real property owned by the city provided that the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The lease must be approved by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(2)  The rental price of the lease must equal or exceed the city's estimate of fair rental value of the city's property, except for good cause shown to serve a public purpose. 
(3)  For a lease reflecting a term of more than 50 years and reflecting an estimated total fair rental value of the city property in excess of $100,000.00, including renewal terms, the resolution must be adopted at a public hearing proceeded by notice, which notice shall consist of an advertisement in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city and posting a copy of the advertisement upon the subject property and at city hall, all notice to be provided at least ten days prior to the public hearing. The lease of the property may not be divided for the purpose of evading the public hearing. 
(4)  The requirements of section 42-3, City Code shall apply to a lease of "park property" or "waterfront property" as identified therein. 
(5)  The lease must be in the best interests of the city. 
(6)  The terms of the lease must conform the requirements of applicable state and federal laws. 
(Ord. No. 2015-28, § 2, 8-11-2015) 
Sec. 2-647. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, to the extent the following property interests qualify as conveyances of title to real property or leases in real property, such conveyances or leases, as applicable, are exempt from this division. 
(1)  The conveyance of real property pursuant to an agreement approved by the city council for the use of federal Community Development Block Grant funds to provide housing in the city is exempt from this division of City Code. 
(2)  The vacation of any right-of-way is exempt from this division and is subject to authorization by city council pursuant to chapter 52, article IV, City Code. 
(3)  The lease of real property subject to the jurisdiction of the City of Melbourne Airport Authority pursuant to section 12-142, City Code is exempt from this division. 
(4)  The sale of city property, lease of city property or other disposition of any other interest in real property authorized by the city council on or prior to July 28, 2015 is exempt from this division. 
(b)  As property interests that do not constitute conveyance of a fee simple title to real property or a lease of real property, the following property interests are not subject to this division: 
(1)  Easements. 
(2)  Licenses to use land. 
(3)  Sale or lease of personal property. 
(Ord. No. 2015-28, § 2, 8-11-2015) 
Secs. 2-648-2-667. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SPECIAL ACTIVITY PERMITS 

Sec. 2-668. - Purpose. 
    The intent of the city council in adopting this article is to recognize that there are certain special or unique activities not recognized in the Code, which provide for an economically viable community. Special activities, whether held on private property or public property, may require the provision of city services and/or a temporary waiver from this Code. This article provides the regulatory framework for the processing of special activity permits and authorizes the development of administrative policies and procedures to process such permits. 
    The city is committed to balancing the city's interests in protecting public health and safety through this article with the First Amendment rights of special activity permit applicants. It is the intent of the city council that the review of applications for special activity permits be limited to content-neutral time, place, and manner conditions and restrictions, and that the city clerk and relevant city departments coordinate with the city attorney to ensure that city policies and procedures in interpreting and applying this article are consistent with applicable First Amendment principles. 
(Code 1984, § 2-253; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-669. - Notice. 
    The application deadlines provided in this article provide the minimum number of days for processing of permit applications. An event is not considered approved until the city clerk has issued a special activity permit or the city manager and applicant have executed a permit agreement, depending on the type of event. 
(Code 1984, § 2-254; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 2-670. - Permit required. 
    An applicant for a special event held within the city is required to apply for and obtain a special activity permit, and comply with the provisions set forth in this article and the special activity permit or permit agreement. 
(Code 1984, § 2-255; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 2-671. - Proper zoning required; activity must relate to primary business. 
(a)  The site selected for a special event must be properly zoned for the proposed activity. For example, a commercial vehicle tent sale may not be conducted on an empty lot in a residentially zoned subdivision. 
(b)  An event conducted on private property, e.g., tent sale, banner, inflatable sign, temporary sign, business promotion, must relate to the primary activity conducted by the business on that site. For example, an applicant from a hair salon may not apply for a parking lot plant sale or tool sale. 
(Code 1984, § 2-256; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 2-672. - Authority. 
(a)  The city clerk, under the direction of the city manager, is hereby authorized and directed to administer the special activity permitting process. This includes the authority to grant temporary waivers to this Code for special activities and to impose conditions of approval, including the requirement of city services. 
(b)  Waivers may include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Section 6-7, open container ordinance. 
(2)  Placement of a tent, stage, banner, inflatable sign (air filled), temporary sign, portable restroom, or other temporary structure. 
(3)  Blocking a public roadway or right-of-way. 
(4)  Use of temporary electrical power. 
(5)  Use of Code-required parking areas. 
(c)  The city clerk may not approve or grant waivers to the following: 
(1)  Section 6-2, hours of operation of any place holding a license under the regulations of the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation, Division of Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco. 
(2)  Chapter 26, article II, noise and vibration control ordinance. 
(3)  Sections of this Code that provide for a regulatory scheme or permitting process separate from the special activity permitting process. Examples include sign permit, landscaping requirements, and various building permits. 
(4)  A condition of a conditional use ordinance adopted by the city council. 
(d)  The fire chief shall have the authority to review, approve, and/or deny applications for fireworks display and pyrotechnics display. 
(Code 1984, § 2-257; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 2-673. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Admission street event means an event held on city property where an admission is charged for access to the event area. 
    Annual permit means a special activity permit or permit agreement issued by the city clerk for qualified recurring special events that remains effective for up to a 12-month period identified in the permit or permit agreement at the time of issuance. 
    Block party means a non-commercial organized public gathering for the purpose of having a party or other social, recreational or similar assemblage composed substantially of neighbors in a predominantly residential area on a public right-of-way (street, sidewalk, or alley) where: no admission is charged for access to any portion of the event area; merchandise, food, and beverages are not offered in exchange for money; and city services, with the exception of traffic control devices, are not required. 
    Business promotion means an event that does not require city services held at a place of business on private property for the sole purpose of promoting the business located on the property. A promotion may include, but not be limited to, placement of a balloon, banner, inflatable sign, temporary sign, or tent; sales and/or distribution of food and beverages; and use of sound amplification. 
    City property means any public street, sidewalk, place, property, easement, right-of-way, structure or facility owned, dedicated, controlled or otherwise under the jurisdiction and control of the city. 
    City sponsored event means a community based, nonprofit event that is free to the public, and appeals to the broadest segment of the community. 
    Code compliance director means the city code compliance director or his designee. 
    Fire chief means the city fire chief or his designee. 
    Life safety management document means the written plan defined by NFPA 1 (National Fire Protection Association code) that is required with each application for an outdoor event that is fenced or gated, has open seating, and an expected peak attendance of 6,000 or more. 
    Outdoor seasonal sales means items associated with a season. Seasonal sales may include sparklers, pumpkins, Christmas trees, and holiday decorations. The term "outdoor seasonal sale" is narrowly defined and may not include a broad category, such as gifts, crafts, or household items. 
    Police chief means the city police chief or his designee. 
    Special activity or special event means a public or private event conducted outside that is characterized by its limited duration, infrequent occurrence, or seasonal nature and by the fact that permanent improvements are not made to the site; or an event where it can be anticipated that the number of persons attending the event will exceed the on-site parking available at the event area; or an event where it can be reasonably expected that services will be required beyond those that are regularly provided by the city, such as police services, traffic control, crowd control, code compliance, fire and/or emergency medical services, street closures, or other municipal services that may be necessary to service the event; or an event that involves displays or activities that will impinge on any adjacent area, including amplified sound, athletic events, carnivals, circuses, concerts, fireworks, high intensity lighting, musical groups, parades, runs, street events, and walk-a-thons. 
    Special activity application means the form provided by the city clerk for the purposes of processing a special activity. 
    Special activity application fee means the fee an applicant is required to pay before a special activity application can be processed. 
    Special activity permit means a permit that is issued by the city clerk for an event conducted on private property or public property not under city ownership or control. 
    Special activity permit agreement means an agreement that is issued by the city clerk and approved by the city manager for an event that is held on city property or an event where the cost of city services and equipment is estimated to be $5,000.00 or more. 
    Special activity permitting procedures means the administrative procedures prepared by the city clerk, as amended from time to time, pertaining to the issuance of a special activity permit or permit agreement. 
    Submittals means additional documents that are required as part of the special activity review process. Examples include, but are not limited to, site plan, tent form, mobile vending form, police department employment services request form, trash and recycling plan, parking plan, accessibility plan, security plan, lighting plan, life safety management document, copy of alcohol permit issued by the state, and certificate of insurance. 
    Temporary structure means any structure used during a special event with a primary purpose of protection from the elements, such as a tent, stage, platform, concession trailer, and similar items. Temporary structures do not include vehicles, tables, chairs, portable restrooms, and trash or garbage receptacles. 
    Traffic engineering means the city engineer or his designee. 
    Year means the period January 1 through December 31, inclusive. 
(Code 1984, § 2-258; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-674. - Application, deadlines, site plan, and submittals. 
(a)  Each applicant will be required to complete and submit a special activity application to the city clerk, along with the applicable fee. 
(1)  Applicants for special events for a business promotion are encouraged to apply at least ten business days prior to the event. Notwithstanding the foregoing, applicants must apply no later than one business day prior to an event. 
(2)  Applicants for special events with an expected attendance of 1,000 or less must make application a minimum of ten business days prior to the date of the event. If such an event involves a road closure or requires police services, applicants must apply a minimum of 30 days prior to the date of the event. 
(3)  Applicants for special events that are expected to attract 1,001 people or more must make application a minimum of 90 days prior to the date of the event. If such an event does not require city services, the city clerk has the authority to accept and process an application, provided there is sufficient time to process the application in accordance with this article. 
(b)  A site plan is required with each application and, depending on the type of event, submittals may also be required. The site plan and submittals must meet the requirements outlined in the special activity permitting procedures authorized by section 2-676 of this article. 
(c)  An application will not be processed if an applicant or the applicant's affiliate owes money to the city from a prior event until all past due amounts are paid in full. 
(d)  Applicants for business promotions may include the entire 30 days allowed in a calendar year (reference section 2-686 on frequency and duration of events) on one application and pay one application fee. For example, if six, five-day events are planned at various times throughout the year, all six events may be included on one application. 
(e)  An application may not be submitted more than 365 days prior to an event. 
(f)  The applicant for an event that is held annually will have the first option of making application for the same or similar event area for the following year, as long as a completed application is submitted to the city clerk during the first city business week following the event. It shall be the applicant's responsibility to submit the application during the first city business week following the annual event. 
(Code 1984, § 2-259; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, adopted Aug. 9, 2016, changed the title of § 2-674 from "Application" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 2-675. - Fees. 
(a)  The fee schedule for this article shall be adopted from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  All applicants, regardless of profit or non-profit status, will be required to pay the prescribed fees. 
(c)  The application fee shall be nonrefundable once the application has been circulated to departments for review. 
(Code 1984, § 2-260; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, adopted Aug. 9, 2016, changed the title of § 2-675 from "Application fee" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 2-676. - Special activity permitting procedures. 
    The city clerk is authorized to prepare administrative procedures for the special activity permitting process. The procedures may include, but not be limited to, requirements and standards for site plans and submittals, mobile vending, tents, portable toilets and trash receptacles, noise monitoring, lighting, parking, crowd management plan, and inflatable rides. 
(Code 1984, § 2-261; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-677. - Insurance requirements for special events held on city property. 
(a)  Liability insurance. The applicant, the individual or other legal entity holding the activity will provide and maintain at all times during the event, without cost or expense to the city, a commercial general liability (CGL) insurance policy. This policy of insurance will have a per occurrence coverage trigger and cover the applicant, the individual or other legal entity holding the activity and its or their employees for any and all claims, demands, and expenses whatsoever, including defense and causes for action for general damages, bodily injury and property damage arising out of or to the extent caused by negligent acts or omissions, intentional misconduct of the applicant, the individual or other legal entity holding the activity and its or their employees and volunteers. These insurance requirements shall not relieve or limit the liability of the applicant, the individual or other legal entity holding the activity. The following minimum insurance requirements shall be provided: 
(1)  Occurrence basis. All policies, except professional liability insurance and workers' compensation, shall be written on an occurrence and not a claims-made basis and, at a minimum, shall cover the applicant, organizers, sponsors, and all event volunteer workers and volunteer vendors. 
(2)  Coverage and deductible amounts. The coverage amount for the CGL policy shall not be less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence and in the aggregate and may be met by a combination of underlying and umbrella policies so long as, in combination, the limits equal or exceed those stated. The deductible amount for the CGL policy shall not be more than $3,000.00 per occurrence. 
(3)  Additional insured. The CGL policy shall be endorsed to add the City of Melbourne as an additional insured. 
(4)  Evidence of insurance. In addition to a certificate of insurance that lists the specific event that is being covered, the city requires proof that the policy has been endorsed by adding the city as additional insured for the duration of the special event. To satisfy this requirement, the applicant may provide a copy of the actual policy endorsement page or written communication from the insurance agent to the insurance company directing that the policy be endorsed by adding the city as additional insured. 
(5)  Insurance companies. All insurance shall be effected under valid and enforceable policies, issued by insurers qualified to do business in the state, or surplus line carriers on the state insurance commissioner's approved list of companies qualified to do business in the state. All insurance carriers and surplus line carriers shall be rated B+, with a financial size category of VII, or better by A.M. Best Company. 
(b)  Alcohol. In addition to the insurance requirements in subsection (a) of this section, additional insurance is required if alcohol will be sold, served, or consumed within the event area. Applicants or parties serving alcohol, who are in the business of manufacturing, distributing, selling, serving or furnishing alcoholic beverages must obtain or have full liquor liability insurance with a per occurrence and aggregate limit of not less than $1,000,000.00 with a deductible amount of not more than $3,000.00. Applicants or parties serving alcohol, who are not in the business of manufacturing, distributing, selling, serving or furnishing alcoholic beverages, must obtain or have host liquor liability insurance with a per occurrence and aggregate limit of not less than $1,000,000.00 with a deductible amount of not more than $3,000.00. An applicable liquor liability insurance policy must be maintained in full force, at all times during the event, without cost or expense to the city. This policy of insurance will be required to cover the applicant, the individual or other legal entity holding the activity and its or their employees or volunteers for any and all claims, demands, and expenses whatsoever, including defense and causes arising from or related to the furnishing, sale, consumption, or serving of alcoholic beverages of any type as defined in F.S. chs. 561-565. These insurance requirements will not relieve or limit the liability of the applicant, the individual or other legal entity holding the activity and allowing alcohol to be consumed, sold, or served. All entities licensed to serve alcohol within the event area shall provide proof of insurance to the city. 
(Code 1984, § 2-262; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, adopted Aug. 9, 2016, changed the title of § 2-677 from "Insurance requirements for events held on city property" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 2-678. - Application review process; types of permits. 
(a)  Generally. Upon receipt of a completed application, the city clerk will route the application to the reviewing city departments. City departments will review the application and return it to the city clerk with a recommendation for approval or denial. Special conditions of approval may be imposed by each department. 
(b)  Review procedures. Applications will be reviewed as follows: 
(1)  Admission street event. Applications will be processed in accordance with this article and the special activity permitting procedures adopted by the city clerk. A permit agreement executed by the applicant and the city manager will be required. At least five business days prior to the event, the applicant will be required to provide submittals/documents that are due, make required deposits or payments for city services, and execute a permit agreement. 
(2)  Special activity or special event-Private property. Applications will be processed in accordance with this article and the special activity permitting procedures adopted by the city clerk. A special activity permit executed by the city clerk will be required. At least five business days prior to the event, the applicant will be required to provide submittals/documents that are due and make deposits or payments for city services, if required. 
(3)  Special activity or special event-City property. Applications will be processed in accordance with this article and the special activity permitting procedures adopted by the city clerk. A permit agreement executed by the applicant and the city manager will be required. At least five business days prior to the event, the applicant will be required to provide submittals/documents that are due, make required deposits or payments for city services, and execute a permit agreement. 
(4)  Special activity or special event-Private property or public property not under city ownership or control with expected attendance of 1,001 or more. Applications will be processed in accordance with this article and the special activity permitting procedures adopted by the city clerk. A permit agreement executed by the applicant and the city manager will be required if the cost for providing city services and equipment is estimated to be $5,000.00 or more. At least five business days prior to the event, the applicant will be required to provide submittals/documents that are due, make deposits or payments for city services, and execute a permit agreement. 
(c)  Pre-event planning participation. An applicant for a new event or an event with an expected attendance of 1,001 or more may be required to participate in a pre-event planning meeting with city staff. 
(d)  Special event permit. An event or activity will not be considered approved until the city clerk has issued a permit. The city clerk will make the final decision on issuance of a special activity permit. 
(e)  Annual permit. The city clerk may issue an annual permit to an applicant for a qualified recurring special activity or special event. A recurring special activity or special event will qualify for an annual permit upon the city clerk's determination that the special activity or special event satisfies the requirements of this article, and that the parameters of the special activity or special event will remain substantially unchanged for any recurrences during the effective period of the annual permit. Annual permits are subject to all other rules and regulations established by this article. 
(Code 1984, § 2-263; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-679. - Alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  If an event includes the sale, consumption, or service of alcoholic beverages, the applicant is responsible for: 
(1)  Complying with all state and local laws related to alcoholic beverages; 
(2)  Providing the city clerk with a copy of the temporary license issued by the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation, Division of Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco; 
(b)  Events held on city property. 
(1)  For special events held on city property, it is the city council's intent that alcohol sales and distribution end the earlier of either (i) the end of an event, or (ii) 1:00 a.m. 
For special events held on city property where the city clerk has waived open container pursuant to section 2-672 of this article, the waiver shall not apply beyond the earlier of either (i) one hour after the end of the event, or (ii) the closing hours for sale of alcoholic beverages in chapter 6-2 of the City Code. 
(c)  An event being held on private property, at the same time an event is being held on city property in the immediate area, must end at the same time as the event being held on city property. 
(Code 1984, § 2-264; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2013-54, § 1(2-264), 10-8-2013; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-680. - City services. 
(a)  Unless otherwise prohibited by law, the city shall recover its costs for services, equipment, and materials on the following basis and in accordance with the fee resolution adopted by city council: i) any direct expenses to the city shall be paid in full by applicants. Direct expenses include, but are not limited to, the rate of pay paid to employees assigned to work the event, traffic or pedestrian control devices ordered from a contractor, and materials used during an event. ii) Any indirect expenses to the city shall be partially paid by applicants. Indirect expenses include, but are not limited to, employee time to process applications (recognized in the application fees), participate in pre-event planning meetings, and draft permit agreements; clean-up of an event site or area impacted by an event when an applicant has not returned the site to its pre-event condition; use of city equipment; custom map or site plan requested by an applicant; parking lot rental; and employee time to obtain permit from another agency or order equipment from an outside source. To the greatest extent possible, the intent is that the current level of municipal services in the city is not reduced as a result of a special event being conducted. 
(b)  The provision of city services will be based on: 
(1)  Size (area), location, duration, and type of event; 
(2)  Previous experience with a similar event, and the applicant's ability to demonstrate organization and management of an event; 
(3)  Type of entertainment or proposed activities; 
(4)  Whether alcohol will be available during the event; 
(5)  Information contained in the completed application, including estimated attendance at event; 
(6)  Potential for illegal use of alcohol or drugs; 
(7)  Potential for unrest or injury to attendees; 
(8)  Traffic conditions; and 
(9)  Fire conditions. 
(c)  Police services. 
(1)  The police chief shall review each special activity application and make a determination on the type and amount of police coverage and equipment needed for an event. The police chief reserves the authority to approve police services being provided by private security or another law enforcement agency. 
(2)  Police services may be required for carnivals, circuses, concerts, crowd control, events with an anticipated attendance of 1,001 or more, events that involve alcohol, events that may require traffic control, festivals, parades, runs, street closures, street events, walk-a-thons, and other events requiring police services to address security and safety issues. 
(3)  The ranking police officer working during an event shall have the authority to increase or decrease the amount of police services based on actual event conditions. 
(d)  Code compliance services. 
(1)  The code compliance director shall review each special activity application and make a determination on the type and amount of building inspection and code enforcement coverage needed for an event. 
(2)  Code compliance services may be required for carnivals, circuses, concerts, events with an anticipated attendance of 1,001 or more, festivals, fireworks, open flame, pyrotechnics, sound amplification (monitoring of noise and vibration level), street events, temporary electrical, temporary structures and other events requiring code compliance services to address the building code and other life/safety issues. 
(3)  The ranking code compliance employee working during an event shall have the authority to increase or decrease the amount of services based on actual event conditions. 
(e)  Fire department services. 
(1)  The fire chief shall review each special activity application and make a determination on the type and amount of fire department services and equipment needed for an event. 
(2)  Fire department services may be required for athletic events, carnivals, circuses, concerts, events with an anticipated attendance of 1,001 or more, events that involve alcohol, festivals, fireworks, open flame, pyrotechnics, runs, street events, walk-a-thons, and other events requiring fire department services to address the fire code and other life/safety issues. 
(3)  The fire chief may waive the requirement for medical services for an event if such services are being provided by a private contractor or another jurisdiction. 
(4)  The ranking fire official working during an event shall have the authority to increase or decrease the amount of services based on actual event conditions. 
(f)  Traffic engineering services. 
(1)  Traffic engineering shall review each special activity application that would have an impact on roadways or traffic within the city. 
(2)  Traffic engineering services may be required for the following types of events or activities: events requiring temporary signage or use of variable message boards, and temporary road closures or detours. 
(3)  If the city is required to obtain traffic control devices from a private contractor, the applicant will be required to pay for the full cost. 
(g)  Electrical service. The facilities maintenance superintendent shall review each special activity application that makes a request for connection to the city's electrical service. 
(h)  All other services. All other municipal services that may be required for an event shall be reviewed by the appropriate department. The cost will be based on the actual cost of providing the service. 
(i)  If additional city services are required and provided during an event, the applicant will be responsible for payment of the additional cost. Additional services may be required as a result of the following: 
(1)  The applicant underestimated attendance. 
(2)  The applicant did not meet one or more of the conditions of the permit including, but not limited to, provision of security personnel, fencing, barricades, lighting, and parking management. 
(3)  The city incurred additional costs or fees in connection with an event for the protection of the life, safety and property of event attendees. 
(Code 1984, § 2-265; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-681. - Payment to city. 
    If an applicant has previously conducted an event in the city and has a positive payment history, a deposit equal to one-half of the estimated costs for city services shall be required. All other applicants shall be required to pay 100 percent of the anticipated costs for city services at least five business days prior to the event. 
(Code 1984, § 2-266; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-682. - Events conducted on city property. 
(a)  Applicants for events held on city property shall be required to: 
(1)  Enter into a hold harmless and indemnification agreement as part of the permit agreement in a format acceptable to the city attorney and risk manager. 
(2)  Perform a safety inspection of the event area prior to the event and report any findings in writing to the city clerk at least two weeks prior to the event. 
(3)  Provide written notification to each occupant within a proposed event area and the area impacted by the event if the event involves the barricading or closing of a public roadway. 
(4)  Provide proof of insurance as set forth in section 2-677 if the event involves the barricading or use of a roadway; placement of a temporary structure; sale, distribution or consumption of alcohol; fireworks or pyrotechnics; or athletic or contact sporting event. 
(5)  Provide adequate trash receptacles throughout the event area and return the event area to its pre-event condition following the event. Clean-up of the event area shall include the surrounding area along with public parking lots in the area that are impacted by the event. 
(b)  Applications shall be considered on a first come, first served basis. The applicant who has submitted a completed application, attached all required submittals, and paid the application fee shall have his application reviewed first. However, an applicant for an event that is held annually will have the first option of making application for the same or similar event area for the following year, as long as a completed application is submitted to the city clerk the first business week following the event. It shall be the applicant's responsibility to submit the application the first business week following the annual event. 
(c)  Admission street event. The following provisions shall apply to admission street events: 
(1)  Event area. As a condition to issuance of a permit, the applicant for an admission street event must demonstrate that the event area will be secured during an event and that access by event participants will be controlled through access gates. This security is intended to safely limit the maximum number of event participants within a confined area. In no event shall pedestrian access to adjacent property be obstructed by an admission street event. 
(2)  Hours. Events may be held from 6:00 p.m. until 1:00 a.m. The closure of a street adjacent to a business may not occur prior to 3:00 p.m. and the applicant may not begin charging admission prior to 6:00 p.m. 
(3)  Maximum number of participants. The maximum number of participants per event area will be based on the estimated usable square footage of the event area. Eight square feet per person will be used in making the calculation. The maximum number will be controlled through a wristband system. 
(4)  Frequency in community redevelopment areas. No more than six admission street events may be held per calendar year in one redevelopment area. Of that six, no more than two events may occur in a one-month period. 
(5)  Admission fee/payment to city. The application must indicate the amount of the admission fee. Within 30 calendar days following an event, the applicant must provide the city clerk with a report of the attendance and amount collected in admission fees for the event. A payment of 20 percent of the total admission fees collected must also be made to the city within 30 calendar days following an event. 
(6)  Use of admission proceeds. If an event is held in a redevelopment area, the city's portion of the admission fee shall be spent in that area. The community redevelopment agency advisory committee in the area where an event is held shall make a recommendation to the city council on use of the city's portion of the admission fee. For events held in all other areas, the city's portion of the admission fee shall be deposited into the city's general fund. 
(7)  Special promotion. The city's portion of the admission fee may be reduced if an applicant provides a special promotion with an event ticket, provided that the value assigned is agreed to between the applicant and the city prior to the event. For example, if the cost for a ticket to an event includes a food or beverage item, the city may reduce its portion of the admission fee to reflect up to the wholesale value of such food or beverage. 
(d)  Block party. The following provisions shall apply to block parties: 
(1)  An applicant for a block party must be: i) a representative of the owner or occupant of a non-residential property, or ii) a resident of the property abutting the right-of-way where the block party is being conducted, or iii) a representative of the applicable homeowners' or property owners' association. 
(2)  Applicants shall be exempt from the insurance requirements in section 2-677, unless the block party includes placement of a temporary structure on city property or alcohol will be distributed or consumed on the public street. 
(3)  Block parties may be conducted between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and midnight. 
(Code 1984, § 2-267; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-683. - City funding for events. 
    Decisions regarding funding for special events shall be made by the city council through the annual budget adoption process. 
(Code 1984, § 2-268; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2014-69, 11-25-2014; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, adopted Aug. 9, 2016, changed the title of § 2-683 from "City sponsored events" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 2-684. - Farmers' markets. 
    The following conditions shall apply to farmers' markets: 
(1)  Farmers' markets are permitted in the redevelopment areas on property zoned C-3 or I-1 and at Wickham Park. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  Banners and signage may be placed two days prior to an event and must be removed the day of the event. No permanent banners or signs will be allowed. 
(4)  A notice must be posted indicating the specific location of restroom facilities in the area. 
(Code 1984, § 2-269; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-685. - Outdoor seasonal sales. 
    The following conditions shall apply to outdoor seasonal sales: 
(1)  A special activity permit is required, and the applicant must obtain a business tax receipt prior to set-up. Written permission from the property owner must be submitted with the application. 
(2)  Adequate stabilized parking, including handicapped parking, must be provided within 100 feet of the sales/display area. Restrooms, including handicapped accessible restrooms, must be provided on site within 500 feet of the sales/display area. 
(3)  If parking and/or restroom facilities are provided by an adjacent business, the applicant must provide a copy of the written agreement. The business hours of the adjacent business must coincide with the operating hours of the special event. 
(4)  The sales/display area shall not be located within a required landscaped area and on-site vegetation shall not be disturbed. 
(Code 1984, § 2-270; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-686. - Frequency and duration of events on private property. 
(a)  The frequency and duration of events is calculated on a per building site basis. If a building site has multiple units, the frequency and duration shall apply to each unit. An applicant may conduct a special event for a total of 30 days per year. Events are permitted in five-day increments and the five-day period must be consecutive. (For example, an applicant could conduct up to six, five-day events per year.) There is no waiting period between events. 
(b)  An applicant may conduct an off-site event up to four times per year (a total of 20 days in one-year, five-day increments) for the sale of vehicles in a C-P zoning district. The off-site sale does not affect the frequency allowed at the applicant's primary business location. 
(c)  During the period that a business is directly affected by road construction or work in the right-of-way and one or more curb cuts are lost or access is restricted, a special activity may be conducted for an additional five-day period each month. 
(d)  Schools, colleges, universities, outdoor seasonal sales, and locations where off-site events are held shall be exempt from this section. 
(e)  An applicant is allowed a reasonable set-up and take-down period for an event, which is not included in the five-day increment. The period will be based on the type and complexity of the event. Placement of inflatable signs, banners, temporary signs, and flags will be allowed a one-day set-up and one-day take-down period. 
(Code 1984, § 2-271; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, adopted Aug. 9, 2016, changed the title of § 2-686 from "Frequency and duration of events" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 2-687. - Hours of event. 
(a)  Unless otherwise restricted by this article, special events held on city property may be conducted between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 1:00 a.m. 
(b)  Special events held on private property may be conducted during the regular business hours of the primary operation on site. 
(c)  An event being held on private property at the same time an event is being held on city property in the immediate area must end at the same time as the event being held on city property. 
(Code 1984, § 2-272; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2013-54, § 2(2-272), 10-8-2013; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-688. - Noise and vibration control. 
    The decibel level during a special event may not exceed the sound level prescribed in section 26-25. 
(Code 1984, § 2-273; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2013-04, § 1(2-273), 1-22-2013) 
Sec. 2-689. - Temporary signs. 
    Notwithstanding the signage regulations contained in appendix D, chapter 11, temporary signs may be used within an event area or along an event route for the day of the event only, subject to the conditions of the special event permit. The signs must be removed immediately following the event. 
(Code 1984, § 2-274; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-690. - Denial of a permit. 
(a)  The city clerk may deny a special activity application/permit for the following reasons: 
(1)  The application is not fully completed and executed, or the application does not include all required submittals, or the applicant did not comply with a deadline imposed by this article, the procedures adopted by the city clerk, or by the city during the application review process. 
(2)  The applicant or its affiliate did not provide the application fee, insurance as set forth in section 2-677, pay for city services, or execute the permit agreement within the time prescribed. 
(3)  The application contains a material falsehood or misrepresentation. 
(4)  The applicant is legally incompetent to contract or sue and be sued. 
(5)  The applicant has on prior occasions damaged property and not paid in full for damage or had other outstanding and unpaid debts to the city. 
(6)  A complete application for the same time and place has already been received from another applicant. 
(7)  The activity conflicts with a previously planned program. 
(8)  The activity is prohibited or inconsistent with the surrounding area in consideration of anticipated noise, crowd capacity, or available parking. 
(9)  The use or activity would present an unreasonable danger to the applicant, participants, or employees. 
(10)  The applicant has not or cannot comply with applicable licensure requirements, ordinances or regulations concerning sale or offering sale of any goods or services. 
(11)  The intended use or activity is prohibited by law, ordinance, or regulation. 
(12)  Preparation for the event or the event itself will unduly impede, obstruct, or interfere with the operation of emergency vehicles or equipment, or adversely affect the city's ability to perform municipal functions or provide city services in the vicinity of the event area. 
(13)  The proposed event is aimed at inciting or producing imminent lawless action and is likely to incite or produce such action. 
(14)  City resources necessary to support the activity are not available. 
(b)  If an application or permit is denied, the city clerk will notify the applicant in writing and include the reason for denial. 
(Code 1984, § 2-275; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-691. - Cancellation of event. 
    If an applicant decides to cancel, postpone, or reschedule an event, a minimum of 24 hours' notice must be provided. If less than 24 hours' notice is provided, the applicant will be responsible for the costs of any city services, materials, and equipment made available for the event that were not canceled in a timely manner. 
(Code 1984, § 2-276; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-692. - Interpretation; provisions declared to be minimum requirements. 
(a)  All questions of interpretation of the special activity permitting process shall first be presented to the city clerk. In interpreting this Code, the city clerk shall be first guided by the plain meaning of the words and terms in this Code and second by the intent expressed herein. The city clerk shall make an interpretation based on review of the code as a whole and not by taking specific words or clauses in isolation. 
(b)  The provisions of this article shall be held to be minimum requirements, adopted for the protection of the public health, safety, morals and general welfare. Whenever the requirements of this article conflict with the requirements of any other lawfully adopted rule, regulation, or ordinance, the most restrictive shall prevail. 
(Code 1984, § 2-277; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 2-693. - Appeals; city not responsible for costs. 
(a)  A person aggrieved by a decision of the city clerk in the denial of a special activity permit may appeal to the city manager. The appeal must be made in writing within not more than ten days following the denial. It shall include an explanation by the applicant as to any factual errors the city made in processing the application. 
(b)  If an application or permit is not approved, the city shall not be responsible for any costs incurred by the applicant or his affiliates. 
(Code 1984, § 2-278; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 2-694. - Authority to revoke permit. 
    After a special activity permit or permit agreement has been issued, the city may revoke the permit, either in whole or in part, or revoke authorization for certain permitted activities if the applicant does not meet the conditions of the permit or permit agreement. If a portion of the event is not in compliance, the city may close that portion of the event until compliance is achieved. 
(Code 1984, § 2-279; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-695. - Penalty. 
    A violation of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-14, or F.S. ch. 162. 
(Code 1984, § 2-280; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 3-27-2012) 
Chapter 4 - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT CODE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Purpose, findings, intent, and incorporation of recitals. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this chapter to regulate sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments in order to promote and protect the public health, safety, good order, morals and general welfare of the citizens of the city, to establish reasonable and uniform regulations of adult entertainment establishments and sexually oriented businesses within the city. The provisions of this chapter have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing an unreasonable limitation or restriction on the content of any lawful communicative materials, including sexually oriented materials. Similarly, it is not the intent nor effect of this chapter to unreasonably restrict or deny access by adults to sexually oriented materials protected by the First Amendment or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of sexually oriented entertainment protected by the First Amendment to their intended market. Neither is it the intent nor effect of this chapter to condone or legitimize the distribution of obscene or otherwise illegal material. 
(b)  Findings. Based on evidence concerning the adverse secondary effects of adult uses on the community presented in hearings and in reports made available to the city council, and on findings incorporated in the cases of City of Littleton, Colo. v. Z.J. Gifts D-4, L.L.C., 541 U.S. 774, 124 S. Ct. 2219, 159 L. Ed. 2d 84 (2004); City of Los Angeles v. Alameda Books, Inc., 535 U.S. 425, 122 So. Ct. 1728, 152 L. Ed. 670, 30 Media L. Rep. (BNA) 1969 (2002); City of Erie v. Pap's A.M., 529 U.S. 277, 120 S. Ct. 1382, 146 L. Ed. 2d 265, 28 Media L. Rep. (BNA) 1545 (2000); City of Renton v. Playtime Theatres, Inc., 475 U.S. 41, 106 S. Ct. 925, 89 L. Ed. 2d 29, 12 Media L. Rep. (BNA) 1721 (1986); Young v. American Mini Theatres, Inc., 427 U.S. 50, 96 S. Ct. 2440, 49 L. Ed 2d 310, 1 Media L. Rep. (BNA) 1151 (1976); Barnes v. Glen Theatre, Inc., 501 U.S. 560, 111 S. Ct. 2456, 115 L. Ed. 2d 504 (1991); California v. LaRue, 409 U.S. 109, 93 S. Ct. 390, 34 L. Ed. 2d 342 (1972); and DLS, Inc. v. City of Chattanooga, 107 F. 3d 403, 1997 FED App. 0066P (6th Cir. 1997); Brandywine, Inc. v. City of Richmond, Kentucky, 359 F. 3d 830, 2004 FED App. 0066P (6th Cir. 2004); Currence v. City of Cincinnati, 2002 U.S. App. LEXIS 1258; Broadway Books, Inc. v. Roberts, 642 F. Supp. 486 (E.D. Tenn. 1986); Bright Lights, Inc. v. City of Newport, 830 F. Supp. 378 (E.D. Ky. 1993); Richland Bookmart, Inc. v. Nichols, 137 F. 3d 435, 1998 RED App. 0070P (6th Cir. 1998); Richland Bookmart, Inc. v. Nichols, 278 F. 3d 570, 30 Media L. Rep. (BNA) 1309, 2002 FED App. 0030P (6th Cir. 2002); Center For Fair Public Policy v. Maricopa County, Arizona, 336 F. 3d 1153, 121 A.L.R. 5th 733 (9th Cit. 2003); Déjà vu v. Metro Government, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 535 (6th Cir. 1999); Bamon Corp. v. City of Dayton, 923 F.2d 470 (6th Cir. 1991); Triplett Grille, Inc. v. City of Akron, 40 F.3d 129, 1994 FED App. 0386P (6th Cir. 1994); O'Conner v. City of Denver, 894 F. 2d 1210 (10th Cir. 1990); Deja Vu of Nashville, Inc. v. Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County, Tennessee, 274 F.3d 377, 30 Media L. Rep. (BNA) 1257, 2001 FED App. 0415P (6th Cir. 2001); Z.J. Gifts D-2, L.L.C. v. City of Aurora, 136 F. 3d 683 (10th Cir. 1998); ILQ Investments, Inc. v. City of Rochester, 25 F.3d 1413 (8th Cir. 1994); Threesome Entertainment v. Strittmather, 4 F. Supp. 2d 710 (N.D. Ohio 1998); Bigg Wolf Discount Video Movie Sales, Inc. v. Montgomery County, Maryland, 256 F. Supp. 2d 385 (D. Md. 2003); Kentucky Restaurant Concepts, Inc. v. City of Louisville, Jefferson County, Ky., 209 F. Supp. 2d 672 (W.D. Ky. 2002); Restaurant Ventures, LLC v. Lexington-Fayette Urban County Government, 60 S.W. 3d 572 (Ky. Ct. App. 2001); World Wide Video of Washington, Inc. v. City of Spokane, 368 F.3d 1186 (9th Cir. 2004), as amended on denial of reh'g and reh'g en banc, (July 12, 2004); Ben's Bar, Inc. v. Village of Somerset, 316 F.3d 702 (7th Cir. 2003), on materials made of record relating to the St. Johns County Public Nudity Ordinance, and on the substance of and findings made or incorporated in studies accomplished in other communities and ordinances enacted in other communities, including, but not limited to, New York, New York; City of Houston Ordinance Number 97-75; Senate Bill Number 232, as passed by the Kansas State Legislature; Phoenix, Arizona; Tucson, Arizona; St. Paul, Minnesota; Minneapolis, Minnesota; Houston, Texas; Indianapolis, Indiana; Amarillo, Texas; Garden Grove, California; Los Angeles, California; Austin, Texas; Macon-Bibb County, Georgia; Palm Beach County, Florida; Manatee County, Florida; the findings of the Attorney General of the State of Minnesota; the report of United States Attorney General's Commission on Pornography (1986); Jacksonville, Florida; Detroit, Michigan; and "A Summary of a National Survey of Real Estate Appraisers Regarding the Effect of Adult Bookstores on Property Values," conducted by the Division of Planning, Department of Metropolitan Development, Indianapolis, January 1984; the publication entitled "Protecting Communities From Sexually Oriented Businesses" (Southwest Legal Press, Inc.); the publication entitled "Local Regulation of Adult Businesses" (Clark, Boardman and Callaghan); publications prepared by the Florida Family Association, Inc. (Tampa, Florida) relating to the regulation of sexually oriented businesses and adverse secondary effects of sexually oriented businesses; the "Report to: The American Center for Law and Justice on the Secondary Impacts of Sex Oriented Businesses," Peter R. Hecht, Ph.D. (1996); and the findings of fact relating to the Adult Entertainment Code of Orange County, Florida, and the findings of fact relating to the Sexually Oriented Business and Adult Entertainment Establishment Ordinance of Seminole County, Florida, matters and materials submitted at the public hearings relating to this chapter and other matters and documents relating to all of the above; the city council finds: 
(1)  Sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments lend themselves to ancillary unlawful and unhealthy activities that are presently uncontrolled or not adequately controlled by the operators of the establishments or businesses. Further, there are presently no mechanisms or inadequate mechanisms to make the owners of these businesses or establishments responsible for the activities that occur on their premises. 
(2)  Certain workers of certain sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments defined in this chapter engage in a higher incidence of certain types of illicit sexual behavior than workers of other business establishments. 
(3)  Sexual acts, including masturbation, and oral and anal sex, occur at sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments, especially those which provide private or semi-private areas, booths or cubicles for viewing films, videos, live sex shows and those having physical interaction between workers and customers. 
(4)  Offering and providing such private spaces encourages such previously mentioned activities, which create unhealthy conditions. 
(5)  Persons frequent certain adult theaters, adult arcades, and other sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments for the purpose of engaging in sex within the premises of such businesses and establishments. 
(6)  At least 50 communicable diseases may be spread by activities occurring in sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments, including, but not limited to, syphilis, gonorrhea, human immunodeficiency virus infection (HIV-AIDS), genital herpes, hepatitis B, Non A, Non B amebiasis, salmonella infections and shigella infections. 
(7)  Since 1981 and to the present, there has been an increasing cumulative number of reported cases of AIDS caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in the United States (600 in 1982, 2,200 in 1983, 4,600 in 1984, 8,555 in 1985 and 253,448 through December 31, 1992, and the number of people in the United States living with an AIDS diagnosis as of February, 2012 is 479,161). 
(8)  As of December 31, 1995, there have been 51,838 reported cases of AIDS in the state. 
(9)  From 1981 to June 1996, the number of living persons testing positive for the HIV antibody with AIDS symptoms has risen to 73,217 in the 28 states having confidential reporting requirements. 
(10)  The number of cases of early (less than one year) syphilis in the United States reported annually has risen, with 33,613 cases reported in 1982 and 45,200 through November of 1990. 
(11)  The number of cases of gonorrhea in the United States reported in 2011 was 321,849. 
(12)  The surgeon general of the United States, in his report of October 22, 1986, has advised the American public that AIDS and HIV infection may be transmitted through sexual contact, intravenous drug abuse, exposure to infected blood and blood components, and from an infected mother to her newborn. 
(13)  According to the best scientific evidence, AIDS and HIV infection, as well as syphilis and gonorrhea, are principally transmitted by sexual acts. 
(14)  Sanitary conditions in some sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments are unhealthy, in part, because the activities conducted there are unhealthy, and, in part, because of the unregulated nature of the activities and the failure of owners and operators of the facilities to self-regulate those activities and maintain those facilities. 
(15)  Numerous studies and reports have determined that semen is found in the areas of sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments where persons view adult oriented films. 
(16)  The findings noted in subsections (b)(1) through (15) of this section and as set forth hereinafter raise substantial governmental concerns. 
(17)  Sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments have operational characteristics that should be reasonably regulated in order to protect those substantial governmental concerns. 
(18)  A reasonable licensing procedure is an appropriate mechanism to place the burden of that reasonable regulation on the owners and the operators of the sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments. Further, such a licensing procedure will place a heretofore nonexistent incentive on the operators to see that the business or establishment is run in a manner consistent with the good order, health, safety and welfare of its patrons and workers, as well as the citizens of the city. It is appropriate to require reasonable assurances that the licensee is the actual operator of the business or establishment, fully in possession and control of the premises and activities occurring therein. 
(19)  Removal of doors on adult booths and requiring sufficient lighting on premises with adult booths advances a substantial governmental interest in curbing the illegal and unsanitary sexual activity occurring in adult theaters. 
(20)  Requiring licensees of sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments to keep information regarding current workers and certain past workers will help reduce the incidence of certain types of criminal behavior by facilitating the identification of potential witnesses or suspects and by preventing minors from working at such businesses and establishments. 
(21)  The disclosure of certain information by those persons ultimately responsible for the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the sexually oriented business and adult entertainment establishments, where such information is substantially related to the significant governmental interest in the operation of such uses, will aid in preventing the spread of sexually transmitted diseases. 
(22)  It is desirable in the prevention of the spread of communicable diseases to obtain a limited amount of information regarding certain workers who may engage in the conduct which this chapter is designed to prevent or who are likely to be witnesses to such activity. 
(23)  The fact that an applicant for an adult entertainment establishment or sexually oriented business license has been convicted of a sexually related crime leads to the rational assumption that the applicant may engage in that conduct in contravention of this chapter. 
(24)  Commercial establishments exist or may exist within the city and other nearby cities and counties in central Florida where adult entertainment material is possessed, displayed, exhibited, distributed and/or sold for commercial purposes in the form of books, magazines, periodicals or other printed material, or photographs, films, motion pictures, prints, videotapes, slides, computer digital graphic recordings or other visual representations or recordings, or recordings or other audio matter, or instruments, novelties, devices, or paraphernalia which depict, illustrate, describe or relate to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
(25)  Commercial establishments exist or may exist within the city and other nearby cities or counties in the state where adult entertainment and sexually oriented commercial activities in the form of nude, semi-nude, or topless dancers, entertainers, performers, or other individuals, who, for commercial gain, perform or are presented while displaying or exposing specified anatomical areas, or engage in straddle dancing or touching with customers. 
(26)  Commercial sexually oriented businesses exist or operate or may exist or operate within the city or other nearby cities or counties in the state where sexually oriented services are offered for commercial or pecuniary gain in the form of commercial physical contact, escort services and other services providing sexual encounters. The workers of such sexually oriented businesses operating in the state engage in physical contact or touching with customers, including, but not limited to, acts of prostitution, or encourage or entice the customers to engage in lewdness. 
(27)  The activities occurring at sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments occur at establishments and businesses which operate primarily for the purpose of making a profit and, as such, are subject to regulation by the city in the interest of the good order, health, safety, economy, property values, morals and general welfare of the people, businesses and industries of the city. A major industry which is important to the community's economic welfare is tourism by persons seeking to bring children to visit the city who wish to stay in a community with a family atmosphere not dominated by commercialized sexual themes. 
(28)  When the activities occurring at sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments are present in establishments and businesses, other activities which are illegal, unsafe, or unhealthful tend to accompany them, concentrate around them, and be aggravated by them. Such other activities include, but are not limited to, prostitution, pandering, solicitation for prostitution, lewd and lascivious behavior, exposing minors to harmful materials, possession, distribution and transportation of obscene materials, sale or possession of controlled substances, and violent crimes against persons and property. 
(29)  When the activities occurring at sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments are competitively exploited in establishments and businesses, they tend to attract an undesirable number of transients, blight neighborhoods, adversely affect neighboring businesses, lower real property values, promote the particular crimes described above and, ultimately, lead residents and businesses to move to other locations. 
(30)  Sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments often have exterior signs or exterior appearance that lower the surrounding property values and contribute to urban decline. 
(31)  The activities occurring at sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments sometimes occur in establishments and businesses concurrent with the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages which concurrence leads to a further increase in criminal activity, unsafe activity, and disturbances of the peace and order of the surrounding community and creates additional hazards to the health and safety of customers and workers and further depreciates the value of adjoining real property harming the economic welfare of the surrounding community and adversely affecting the quality of life, commerce, and community environment. 
(32)  Physical contact or touching within sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments between workers exhibiting specified anatomical areas and customers poses a threat to the health of both and promotes the spread of communicable and social diseases. 
(33)  In order to preserve and safeguard the good order, health, morals, safety, and general welfare of the people of the city, it is necessary and advisable for the city to regulate the conduct of owners, managers, operators, agents, workers, entertainers, performers, and customers at sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments. 
(34)  The potential dangers to the good order, morals, health, safety, and general welfare of the people of the city posed by permitting a sexually oriented business or adult entertainment establishment to operate without first meeting the requirements for obtaining a license under this chapter are so great as to require the licensure of such establishments prior to their being permitted to operate. 
(35)  Requiring operators of sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments to keep records of information concerning workers and certain recent past workers as well as customer contracts and other matters and materials will help reduce the incidence of certain types of criminal behavior by facilitating the identification of potential witnesses or suspects and by making it difficult for minors to work at or be customers in such establishments. 
(36)  Prohibiting sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments from operating within set distances of educational institutions, religious institutions, residences, areas zoned or designated for residential use, and parks at which minors are customarily found, will serve to protect minors from the adverse affects of the activities that accompany such establishments and businesses. 
(37)  Straddle dancing, unregulated private performances, and enclosed adult booths in sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments have resulted in indiscriminate commercial sex between strangers and poses a threat to the health of the participants and promotes the spread of communicable sexually transmitted diseases. Straddle dancing is primarily conduct rather than communication or expression. 
(38)  Workers at sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments engage in a higher incidence of certain types of unhealthy or criminal behavior than workers of other establishments and businesses, including, but not limited to, a very high incidence of illegal prostitution or engaging in lewdness in violation of F.S. ch. 796, operation without business tax receipts and illegal and unlicensed massage. 
(39)  Physical contact or touching between workers of sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments and customers poses a threat to the health of both and promotes the spread of communicable and sexually transmissible diseases. 
(40)  The practice of not paying or underpaying workers at sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments and requiring them to earn their entire income from tips or gratuities from their customers who are predisposed to want sexual activity has resulted in a high incidence of prostitution and crimes related to lewdness by workers. 
(41)  Sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments involve some activities that are pure conduct engaged in for the purpose of making a profit, rather than speech or expressive activity and, therefore, are subject to and require increased regulation to protect the health, good order, morals, welfare and safety of the community. 
(42)  Requiring sexually oriented businesses to post a listing of services provided and restrict services to those listed as well as maintaining a customer contract and transaction record in a daily register will discourage incidents of criminal behavior such as lewdness and prostitution thereby further safeguarding the health of both workers and customers and will assist in facilitating the identification of potential witnesses or suspects if criminal acts do occur. 
(43)  The general welfare, health, good order, morals and safety of the citizens of the city will be promoted by the enactment of this chapter. 
(c)  Intent. It is the intent of this chapter to protect and preserve the good order, health, peace, morals, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city. This chapter regulates conduct and is not an ordinance that affects the use of land as contemplated by F.S. § 166.041. 
(d)  Authority. This chapter is enacted under the constitutionally derived home rule power of the city in the interest of the good order, health, morals, peace, safety, and general welfare of the people of the city. 
(e)  Recitals. It is the city council's further intention to accomplish those intents and purposes expressed by the city council in the recitals of the ordinance from which this section derives, each of which are incorporated by reference into this section. 
(f)  Speech protection. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit constitutionally protected expression or speech. This chapter is intended to reasonably regulate the adult entertainment industry and sexually oriented businesses which engage in commercial activities involving acts or services of a sexually explicit nature or which involve acts or services involving matters which are sexual in nature. 
(Code 1984, § 2.6-1; Ord. No. 2004-101, § 2, 1-11-2005; Ord. No. 2013-50, § 2(2.6-1), 8-27-2013) 
Sec. 4-2. - Construction. 
(a)  This chapter shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purpose of reasonably regulating sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments in order to reduce or eliminate adverse secondary effects of such businesses and establishments. Barnes v. Glen Theater, Inc., 510 U.S. 560, 111 S. Ct. 2456, 115 L.Ed. 2d 504 (1991), Cafe 207, Inc. v. St. Johns County, 856 F. Supp. 641 (M.D. Fla. 1994); affirmed, Cafe 207, Inc. v. St. Johns County, 66 F. 3d 272 (11th Cir. 1995); cert. denied, 134 L Ed. 2d.647 (U.S. April 22, 1996). This chapter shall not be construed to authorize any illegal act under federal law, state law or city ordinance. This chapter is intended to reasonably regulate such matters in order to reduce or eliminate the adverse secondary effects of commercial establishments and businesses. The regulation of alcoholic beverage establishments is also addressed in the Code and other provisions of law. 
(b)  Unless otherwise indicated, all provisions of this chapter shall apply equally to all persons, regardless of sex. Masculine pronouns, such as "he," "his," and "him," as employed in this chapter, shall also be construed to apply to feminine pronouns and neutral pronouns, unless the context suggests otherwise. Words used in the singular number shall include the plural number, unless the context suggests otherwise. 
(Code 1984, § 2.6-2; Ord. No. 2004-101, § 2, 1-11-2005) 
Sec. 4-3. - Obscenity/indecent exposure unlawful. 
    As a matter of state and federal law, obscenity is unlawful in the city. Likewise, state law prohibits indecent exposure. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to allow or permit the possession, distribution and transportation of obscene materials; to authorize the exposing of persons under 18 years of age to motion pictures, exhibitions, shows, representations and presentations of specified sexual activities or persons displaying or exhibiting specified anatomical areas; or the indecent exposure of a person as prohibited by state law. 
(Code 1984, § 2.6-3; Ord. No. 2004-101, § 2, 1-11-2005) 
State Law reference- Obscenity, F.S. § 847.001 et seq.; indecent exposure, F.S. § 800.02 et seq. 
Sec. 4-4. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult bookstore/adult video store means:
