The city may hire a third state CPA to review the audits previously conducted as to the records of the for-profit bingo organization and any other records deemed appropriate by such CPA firm, and the city council shall base the results of the appeal on the reports of the CPAs presented to the city. The cost of any and all audits conducted pursuant to this section shall be borne by the for-profit bingo organization. If the for-profit bingo organization wishes to appeal any determination by the city council under this section, it may appeal same to the court of appropriate jurisdiction in the county. All bookkeeping records of the for-profit bingo organization shall be available for inspection, auditing and copying by the city and by state and county law enforcement personnel or their designees at all times that the bingo hall is open for business, or upon request. 
(Code 1984, § 4-20; Ord. No. 94-47, § 5, 8-23-1994) 
Sec. 8-24. - Notices. 
    Each bingo hall must have prominently posted signs (no less than four square feet in size each), at all entrances to the bingo hall, and at no less than five additional places in the bingo hall, one of which must be within five feet of the caller, which state: 
"IF YOU DO NOT RECEIVE A RECEIPT FOR ANY PAYMENT MADE PLEASE NOTIFY THE MELBOURNE POLICE DEPARTMENT 608-6731" 
(Code 1984, § 4-21; Ord. No. 94-47, § 6, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2011-28, § 5, 7-26-2011) 
Sec. 8-25. - Regulatory permit required; application; investigation required; contents of application; fee. 
(a)  An annual permit shall be required for each for-profit bingo organization and for each charity operating bingo games or instant bingo in a bingo hall. No permit for an applicant shall be issued until an application is made to the city manager which shall cause an investigation to be made to determine whether the applicant has complied with this article and all other requirements of this Code and of the state statutes. Each application must be accompanied by a fee of $300.00 to cover the cost of investigation, administration and handling of the application. The application fee is nonrefundable, but shall be applied against the permit fee, as described herein. Each application must provide the following information under oath: 
(1)  Name, address and date of birth of all interested parties of the applicant, and if the city manager shall determine that fingerprinting is required to conduct a criminal history investigation, fingerprints as required by section 8-27. 
(2)  Statement as to whether any interested party of the applicant has been convicted within 15 years of the date of application of any specified criminal act and, if so, the name of such interested party, the date and place of conviction, and the nature of the crime for which the interested party was convicted. 
(3)  If the applicant is a charity, proof of exemption from federal income tax as an exempt organization under the provisions of Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, or Section 528 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation or limited liability company, a true and correct copy of its articles of incorporation, or articles of organization, and bylaws. 
(5)  If the applicant is a partnership, a true and correct copy of the of the partnership agreement. 
(6)  If the applicant is not a corporation or partnership, a true and correct copy of the agreement or document under which the applicant exists or conducts itself. 
(7)  A detailed description of the charitable, civic, community, benevolent, religious or scholastic works and/or other similar activities in which the charity is involved and the endeavors to which the proceeds from the bingo games or instant bingo shall be donated. 
(8)  The address of the premises in which the applicant performs, conducts and/or supervises bingo games or instant bingo, and the days of the week on which the operator performs, conducts and/or supervises bingo games or instant bingo. If the days are changed, a supplemental statement must be filed with the city prior to such change. 
(9)  A financial statement of the applicant, evidencing the amount and sources of its previous year's gross bingo or instant bingo revenue and the distributees with the amount of the previous year's distributions to each distributee. This statement must be certified as correct by an officer of the corporation, one of the partners, or one who controls the applicant, but need not be audited. The information supplied shall cover the period of the applicant's most recently concluded fiscal year. 
(b)  No application shall be processed by the city manager unless such application complies with all the requirements as stated hereunder. If an incomplete application, or an application not accompanied by the fee as herein required, is received by the city manager, the city manager shall send a notice of intent to deny the permit to the applicant with an explanation of the requirements necessary to make the application complete. Such notice shall include a statement that if a completed application and/or required fee is not submitted or if an appeal to the city council of the determination by the city manager that such application is incomplete is not submitted within ten days of receipt by the applicant of such notice, the application shall be finally denied. If the applicant does not return a properly completed application and/or required fee or does not file a notice of appeal as designated in such notice within ten days of receipt by applicant of notice therefore, the denial of the permit application by the city manager shall be deemed to be final. Permits issued pursuant to this article shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any business tax receipts or other permits or licenses required under this Code. In the event a permit hereunder is revoked, no permit fee having previously been paid hereunder shall be refunded to the permittee. 
(Code 1984, § 4-22; Ord. No. 94-47, § 7, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 1, 6-25-2002; Ord. No. 2006-121, § 1, 11-28-2006; Ord. No. 2011-28, § 6, 7-26-2011) 
Sec. 8-26. - Continuing duty to update application. 
    Applicants for a permit and any person, partnership, corporation, limited liability company, association or other entity which has been issued a permit under this article are under a continuing duty to update the information contained in the application submitted for a permit, and shall, within 30 days of any change in such information, notify the city manager in writing of such changes. 
(Code 1984, § 4-23; Ord. No. 94-47, § 8, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 1, 6-25-2002) 
Sec. 8-27. - Fingerprinting. 
(a)  If the city manager shall determine that fingerprinting is required to conduct a criminal history investigation, an application for a permit under this article shall not be complete until all interested parties of the applicant have submitted their fingerprints to the city police department with a certification of compliance with this subsection to the city manager. 
(b)  If the city manager shall determine that fingerprinting is required to conduct a criminal history investigation, a permittee shall not be deemed to have complied with the provisions of section 8-23 until and unless the fingerprints of any new interested parties of the permittee have been submitted to the city police department with a certification of compliance with this subsection to the city manager. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, fingerprints submitted to the city must be in a form approved by the city police department. Fingerprints made outside the presence of a fingerprint technician employed by the city shall not be acceptable. 
(Code 1984, § 4-24; Ord. No. 94-47, § 9, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 3, 6-25-2002; Ord. No. 2011-28, § 7, 7-26-2011) 
Sec. 8-28. - Permit not to be issued without specific authorization following conviction for certain crimes. 
    The city shall not grant, without specific authorization from the city council, a permit or a renewal of a permit under this article to any applicant if an interested party thereof has been convicted of a specified criminal act and such conviction is final whether or not such conviction is on appeal within 15 years of the date of application. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond upon a charge of a specified criminal act. 
(Code 1984, § 4-25; Ord. No. 94-47, § 10, 8-23-1994) 
Sec. 8-29. - Permit not to be issued without specific authorization to certain person, etc., after revocation. 
    The city manager shall not grant, without specific authorization from the city council, a permit or a renewal of a permit under this article to any applicant if an interested party of the applicant was a permittee or an interested party of a permittee at the time such permit was revoked under the provisions hereof. 
(Code 1984, § 4-26; Ord. No. 94-47, § 11, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 4, 6-25-2002) 
Sec. 8-30. - Issuance of permit; term; renewal. 
    If the city manager determines that the applicant is not ineligible to be issued a permit or a renewal of a permit, a permit shall be issued to be effective for one year from the date of issuance, upon payment of the annual permit fee of $500.00. In order for the city to grant a renewal of a permit, the application for renewal and the investigation thereon must show that the applicant is not ineligible under the provisions hereof for the issuance of a permit without specific authorization pursuant to sections 4-25 and 4-26. 
(Code 1984, § 4-27; Ord. No. 94-47, § 12, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 5, 6-25-2002) 
Sec. 8-31. - Appeal from action of the city manager. 
(a)  If the city manager determines that a permit shall not be issued to the applicant under the provisions of this article, without specific authorization pursuant to sections 8-28 and 8-29, or under the provisions of section 8-25 relating to incomplete applications or applications not accompanied by the required fee, the city manager shall notify the applicant by hand delivery or by certified mail of the city's intention to deny the permit. Such notice shall include a copy of this article and the reasons for the denial of the permit. The applicant shall have the right to appeal the city's determination to deny the permit to the city council by filing with the city clerk a notice of appeal within ten days of receipt by applicant of notice of intent to deny. If an applicant appeals a determination by the city manager to deny a permit based on failure to submit a properly completed application or for failure to submit the required fee, the city council shall hold a public hearing to determine whether such application is sufficiently complete to comply with the requirements of section 8-25 and/or the required fee was submitted with such application. If the city determines that such application is not sufficiently complete to comply with the requirements of section 8-25, or that the required fee was not submitted therewith, the city council shall direct the city to issue a notice of final denial of such application for permit; provided, however, if the city council finds that the defects in the application or the failure to pay the required fee were the result of excusable neglect or inadvertence on the part of the applicant, the city council may grant the applicant a specific time period in which to submit a properly completed application and/or submit the required fee. 
(b)  If an applicant appeals a determination by the city manager to deny a permit or a renewal of a permit based on any grounds other than an incomplete application or failure to submit the required fee, the city council shall hold a public hearing to determine whether issuance or renewal of the permit would be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare. In determining whether issuance or renewal of the permit would be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare, the city council shall consider whether the factors which caused the city manager to not issue a permit, without specific authorization pursuant to sections 8-28 and 8-29, are related to the instant bingo or bingo operation or bingo involvement by the applicant or an interested party thereof for which a permit application is made or the involvement with or operation by the applicant or an interested party thereof of any other bingo operation and if such factors evidence a disregard for the health, safety or welfare of such applicant's or permittee's patrons, charities or employees, or of persons residing or doing business nearby, or a disregard for or violation of the financial constraints of this article or of state law by either the charity or the for-profit bingo organization. If the city council determines that a factor which caused the city not to issue a permit, without specific authorization pursuant to sections 8-28 and 8-29, is related to the use or operation or involvement by the applicant or an interested party thereof of the bingo hall for which a permit application is made or the use or operation by the applicant or such interested party thereof of any other bingo hall and that such factor evidences a disregard for the health, safety or welfare of such bingo hall's patrons, charities, or employees, or of persons residing or doing business nearby, or a disregard for or violation of the financial constraints of this article or of state law by either the charity or the for-profit bingo organization, the city council shall direct the city to issue a notice of final denial of such application for permit or renewal of permit. In the event an application or renewal is finally denied, the applicant shall have the right to appeal such denial to the court having jurisdiction of such matters under the constitution and laws of the state. If the city council determines that none of the factors which caused the city not to issue a permit or renewal is related both to the use or operation or involvement, by the applicant or an interested party thereof, of the bingo hall for which a permit application is made or the use or operation by the applicant or an interested party thereof of any other establishment and that such factor does not evidence a disregard for the health, safety or welfare of such bingo hall's patrons, charities or employees, or of persons residing or doing business nearby, or a disregard for or violation of the financial constraints of this article or of state law by either the charity or the for-profit bingo organization, the city council shall direct the city to issue a permit to such applicant forthwith. 
(Code 1984, § 4-28; Ord. No. 94-47, § 13, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 6, 6-25-2002; Ord. No. 2011-28, § 8, 7-26-2011) 
Sec. 8-32. - Authority to revoke permits; grounds for revocation. 
    The city council, after a hearing as hereinafter provided, is authorized to revoke any permit issued under the provisions of this article of any permittee under any one or more of the following circumstances if the city council makes an affirmative finding that the continued operation of the permitted premises would be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare: 
(1)  The permittee, or any interested party of permittee, is convicted of a specified criminal act. 
(2)  The permittee fails to comply with the fire prevention ordinances of the city after reasonable notice shall have been given to the permittee to eliminate or correct any condition in violation of such ordinances on the permitted premises. 
(3)  The permittee or any interested party of permittee violates any state statute relating to bingo or instant bingo operations or gambling laws. 
(4)  The permittee fails to comply with any provision of this Code, including, but not limited to, the building code, the city electrical code, the city mechanical code, the city zoning code, the city sign code, or the city plumbing code after reasonable notice shall have been given to the permittee to eliminate or correct any condition in violation of such ordinances on the permitted premises. 
(5)  The permittee fails to comply with any provisions of this article after reasonable notice or correct any condition in violation of such article on the permitted premises. 
(6)  The permittee furnished incorrect or incomplete information on its application for permit or application for renewal of permit. 
(7)  The permittee fails to comply with the business tax receipts ordinances for the city after reasonable notice shall have been given to the permittee to eliminate or correct any condition in violation of such ordinances related to the permitted premises. 
(8)  The permittee fails to furnish notification of changes in application information within 30 days of change in such information as required by section 8-26. 
(9)  Any person who has been convicted of a specified criminal act within the last 15 years becomes an interested party of the permittee. 
(Code 1984, § 4-29; Ord. No. 94-47, § 14, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2006-121, § 1, 11-28-2006; Ord. No. 2011-28, § 9, 7-26-2011) 
Sec. 8-33. - Notice of hearing concerning permit revocation. 
    Whenever the city council shall find any of the conditions enumerated in section 8-32 to exist, it shall notify by certified mail or hand delivery to the applicant or permittee that the city council shall hold a public hearing to determine whether the continued operation of the permitted premises is detrimental to the public health, morals, safety and welfare. In determining whether the continued operation of the permitted premises is detrimental to the public health, morals, safety and welfare, the city council shall consider whether the conditions enumerated in section 8-32 which are found to exist are related to the use or operation by the permittee or an interested party thereof of the permitted premises and if such conditions evidences a disregard for the health, morals, safety or welfare of such permittee's patrons or employees, or of persons residing or doing business nearby. If the city council determines that a condition enumerated in section 8-32 does exist as to a permitted premises and that such condition relates to the use or operation by the permittee or of an interested party thereof of the permitted premises and that such condition evidences a disregard for the health, morals, safety or welfare of such permittee's patrons or employees or of persons residing or doing business nearby, the city council shall revoke the permit of the permittee. If the city council determines that no conditions enumerated in section 8-32 exist as to the permitted premises, or that no such existing condition relates to the use or operation of the permittee or an interested party thereof of the permitted premises, or that no such existing condition evidences a disregard for the health, morals, safety or welfare of such permittee's patrons or employees, or of persons residing or doing business nearby, the city council shall not revoke the permit of the permittee. Such hearing is to be held at a time and place to be specified in the notice and at a time not less than ten days from the date of service of the notice. Such notice shall also list with specificity the acts or occurrence concerning which the hearing will be held. 
(Code 1984, § 4-30; Ord. No. 94-47, § 15, 8-23-1994) 
Sec. 8-34. - Injunctive relief. 
    It is hereby found and declared that a violation of the provisions of this article constitutes an irreparable injury to the citizens of the city and the city may institute a civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction to seek injunctive relief to enforce compliance with this article; to enjoin any violation of this article; and to seek injunctive relief to prevent injury to the health, safety and general welfare caused or threatened by any violation. 
(Code 1984, § 4-31; Ord. No. 94-47, § 16, 8-23-1994) 
Sec. 8-35. - Operating bingo hall or conducting bingo games or instant bingo in bingo hall without permit; unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, association, corporation or any other entity to operate a bingo hall or to conduct bingo games or instant bingo in a bingo hall within the city unless such entity shall have a currently valid permit therefor. 
(Code 1984, § 4-32; Ord. No. 94-47, § 17, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2011-28, § 10, 7-26-2011) 
Sec. 8-36. - Bingo halls open for inspection. 
    Each bingo hall shall be open for inspection by city, county, state and federal representatives and any authorized inspection personnel during all hours such establishment is open for business, for the purpose of ensuring compliance with this article. 
(Code 1984, § 4-33; Ord. No. 94-47, § 18, 8-23-1994) 
Sec. 8-37. - Issuance of permit not to permit acts otherwise unlawful. 
    The issuance of a permit hereunder shall not be construed as permitting, licensing or allowing the commission of any act otherwise prohibited or made unlawful by valid city or county ordinances, or state or federal law. 
(Code 1984, § 4-34; Ord. No. 94-47, § 19, 8-23-1994) 
Sec. 8-38. - Federal, state, county and city enforcement of article. 
    The city manager and law enforcement officials of the city, state, county and the U.S. government are specifically authorized to enforce the provisions of this article, including, but not limited to, the ordering of audits hereunder, and are permitted to inspect bingo halls and records of for-profit bingo organizations and charities conducting bingo games in a bingo hall as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1984, § 4-35; Ord. No. 94-47, § 20, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 2011-28, § 11, 7-26-2011) 
Sec. 8-39. - Penalty. 
    Any person, partnership, association, or corporation committing an act which is prohibited or made unlawful by the provisions of any section of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-14 and, in addition, violations of this article shall be subject to enforcement by the code enforcement board of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 4-36; Ord. No. 94-47, § 21, 8-23-1994) 
Secs. 8-40-8-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RAVE CLUBS 

Sec. 8-67. - Legislative findings, intent, and purpose. 
(a)  The city hereby finds and determines, as a matter of fact, that the late night and all night rave clubs and similar forums of assembly, commonly referred to as "raves," are sites for the sale, possession and use of illicit drugs. 
(b)  The city also finds such raves expose drug activity to the uninitiated youth of our city, and such exposure to drug activity occurring at such raves is often found to result in drug addiction, overdose and death of both juveniles and adults. 
(c)  The city hereby finds raves provide an arena for predatory-type sexual crimes, thus, for the protection of our city's youth, juveniles should not congregate in such social settings with adults; additionally, regulation of raves is also necessary for the protection of adult victims of such crimes. 
(d)  The city hereby finds raves are oftentimes the sites for violent criminal activity, as well as street gang activity as defined in F.S. ch. 874. 
(e)  The city hereby finds that the dangerous criminal activity occurring at such raves occurs predominately in the late night/early morning hours. 
(f)  The city hereby finds that the actions of rave patrons entering and exiting rave club establishments has a deleterious effect on nearby residential and commercial properties in terms of excessive noise, traffic and debris, and such impacts are exacerbated by the fact that rave patrons enter and exit such raves at extraordinarily late night/early morning hours when citizens have a reasonable expectation of peace and quiet. 
(g)  The city finds that the above-referenced problems associated with raves are unique and specific to such rave club establishments and are not prevalent in other types of unregulated places of assembly. 
(h)  It is the intent of the city to address the unique problems associated with raves by implementing rave club regulations for both juvenile and adult rave clubs to prevent rave club contact between juveniles and adults so as to prevent and/or reduce illicit or undesirable juvenile involvement and exposure to illegal drugs and dangerous criminal activity, and further to protect both juveniles and adults from criminal activity that occurs at such raves. 
(i)  The city hereby asserts that the following purposes of the rave club regulations set forth herein are matters of legitimate, substantial and compelling governmental interests: 
(1)  To protect juveniles and adults from illegal drug activity, including use, sale and drug abuse such as overdoses and to reduce, if not eliminate, such activity from occurring in rave clubs. 
(2)  To protect juveniles and adults from violent criminal activity occurring in rave clubs. 
(3)  To protect juveniles and adult victims from predatory type sexual crimes occurring in rave clubs. 
(4)  To protect juveniles and adults from gang-related activity occurring in rave clubs. 
(5)  To reduce the amount of criminal activity occurring predominately in the late night/early morning hours. 
(6)  To prevent the deleterious impacts of noise, traffic and debris on adjacent residential and commercial property that occur in the late night/early morning hours. 
(Code 1984, § 4-40; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-68. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult rave club means any rave club whose patrons or admittees are 18 years of age or older. 
    Conviction or convicted means the finding of guilt for a violation of a municipal or county ordinance or state or federal law, adjudication withheld on such a finding of guilt, an adjudication of guilt on any plea of guilty, or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond or bail when charged with a violation of a municipal or county ordinance or state or federal law. 
    Juvenile rave club means any rave club whose patrons or admittees are 17 years of age or younger. 
    Knowingly means with actual knowledge of a specific fact, or with reasonable inquiry, a reasonable person should have known a specific fact. 
    Permit or rave club permit means a permit to operate a rave club. 
    Permittee means a person in whose name a permit to operate a rave club has been issued, as well as the individual listed as an applicant on the application for a rave club permit. 
    Person means an individual, partnership, corporation, association or legal entity. 
    Rave club. 
(1)  The term "rave club" means any place, area or property which is operated either as an ongoing enterprise or undertaking or as a one time event or a limited number of events, which is open to the public, and which: 
a.  Has music, either live or electronically produced or transmitted; 
b.  Has space available for dancing, or dancing is permitted, whether such dancing takes place or not; 
c.  Allows free admission or admission by payment of a direct or indirect charge, fee, donation, or any form of consideration, or by the purchase, possession or presentation of a ticket or token; and 
d.  Is not licensed or permitted to sell, serve or dispense alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption, or permit alcoholic beverages to be consumed on premises. 
(2)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, a "rave club," as defined herein, does not include: 
a.  An establishment with a license reviewed and approved by the state and county to sell, serve or dispense alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption; 
b.  A bona fide dance studio where students are taught the art of dancing or ballet; 
c.  A private residence or residential facility from which the general public is excluded; 
d.  A place owned and operated by the federal, state, or local government; 
e.  A public or private elementary school, secondary school, college, or university; 
f.  A place owned, leased or operated by a not-for-profit organization and sponsored by a bona fide law enforcement organization or federal, state, local government or school board; or 
g.  An adult use establishment (special cabaret or adult entertainment establishment), as defined in chapter 4, lawfully established, existing, permitted and licensed under the provisions of this article, during such hours of the day as said establishment is being lawfully and principally operated as an adult use. 
    Rave club regulations means the regulations set forth in this article. 
(Code 1984, § 4-41; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-69. - Permit required; application for permit. 
(a)  No person may operate a rave club without a permit. 
(b)  A notarized application for a permit shall be made on a form provided by the city manager or his designee. The applicant must be qualified according to the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The applicant shall indicate whether the application is for a juvenile rave club or adult rave club. 
(d)  A person who wishes to operate a rave club shall sign the application for a permit as applicant. If a person who wishes to operate a rave club is other than an individual, each individual who has a 20 percent or greater interest in the business must sign the application for a permit as an applicant. Each applicant must meet the requirements of section 8-70, and each applicant shall be considered a permittee if a permit is granted. 
(Code 1984, § 4-42; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-70. - Requirement for issuance of permit; posting. 
(a)  The city manager or his designee shall approve issuance of a rave club permit within 60 days after receipt of an application unless the city manager or designee finds one or more of the following to be true: 
(1)  An applicant is under 18 years of age. 
(2)  An applicant has failed to answer or falsely answered a question or request for information on the application provided. 
(3)  An applicant has been convicted of a violation of any rave club regulation within two years immediately preceding the application. 
(4)  An applicant has failed to obtain a certification from the fire marshal that the rave club complies with all applicable provisions of chapter 28, relative to places of assembly, including, but not limited to, maximum permitted occupancy load. 
(5)  An applicant has failed to obtain a certification from the zoning administrator that the rave club complies with all applicable provisions of the land development code, including, but not limited to, parking. 
(6)  An applicant has been convicted of a crime: 
a.  Involving: 
1.  Any felony; 
2.  Any misdemeanor offense of state statutes: F.S. ch. 784, assault; battery; culpable negligence; F.S. ch. 787, kidnapping; false imprisonment; luring or enticing a child; custody offenses; F.S. ch. 790, weapons and firearms; F.S. ch. 794, sexual battery; F.S. ch. 800, lewdness; indecent exposure; F.S. ch. 812, theft, robbery and related crimes; F.S. ch. 827, abuse of children; F.S. ch. 837, perjury; F.S. ch. 856, drunkenness; open house parties; loitering; prowling; desertion; F.S. ch. 562, selling, serving or giving alcoholic beverages to a minor; F.S. ch. 859, poisons; adulterated drugs; F.S. ch. 870, affrays; riots; routs; unlawful assemblies; F.S. ch. 874, street terrorism enforcement and prevention; F.S. ch. 877, miscellaneous crimes, and F.S. ch. 893, drug abuse prevention and control, as said chapters currently exist or may be amended from time to time; or 
3.  Any violation of rave club regulations of any other city, county, state or government; and 
b.  For which: 
1.  Less than two years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a misdemeanor offense; 
2.  Less than five years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a felony offense; or 
3.  Less than five years have elapsed since the date of the last conviction or the date of release from confinement for last conviction, whichever is the later date, if the convictions are of two or more misdemeanor offenses or combination of misdemeanor offenses occurring within any 24-month period. 
(b)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed has no effect on the disqualification of the applicant under subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  An applicant who has been convicted of an offense listed in subsection (a)(6)a of this section may qualify for a rave club permit only when the time period required by subsection (a)(6)b of this section has elapsed. 
(d)  The application shall be reviewed by the police department, the fire department and the city manager or his designee for compliance with the provisions of this section. Review shall be conducted by the police department and the fire department within 30 days from the receipt of the application by the city manager or designee, and their comments forwarded to the city manager or designee for consideration in issuance of the permit in accordance with the provisions hereof. 
(e)  The city manager or designee, upon approving issuance of a rave club permit, shall send to the applicant, by hand delivery or U.S. mail, written notice of that action and state where the applicant must pay the permit fee and obtain the permit. The city manager's approval of the issuance of the permit does not authorize the applicant to operate a rave club until the applicant has paid all fees required by this chapter and obtained possession of the permit. 
(f)  The permit shall state on its face the name of the person to whom it is granted, the expiration date, the address of the rave club, and whether it is issued for a juvenile rave club or adult rave club. 
(g)  The permit must be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance to the rave club so that it may be easily read at any time. 
(Code 1984, § 4-43; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-71. - Application and renewal fees. 
    The city council may, by resolution, establish nonrefundable fees for the city to review the contents of a rave club permit application and for each renewal permit issued under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 4-44; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-72. - Persons under 18 years of age prohibited in adult rave clubs. 
(a)  No person under the age of 18 years may enter an adult rave club unless accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(b)  No person shall falsely represent himself to be either a parent or guardian of another person under the age of 18 years for the purpose of gaining the other person's admission into an adult rave club. 
(c)  No permittee or employee of an adult rave club shall knowingly allow a person under the age of 18 years to enter or remain on the premises of an adult rave club. 
(d)  No permittee of an adult rave club shall maintain or operate the premises without posting a sign at each entrance to the business that reads: "It is unlawful for any person under 18 years of age to enter this premises without a parent or guardian." 
(Code 1984, § 4-45; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-73. - Persons age 18 years and over restricted in juvenile rave clubs. 
(a)  No person over 18 years of age and older may enter a juvenile rave club except: 
(1)  A permittee or employee of the rave club; 
(2)  A parent or guardian of a rave club patron inside the rave club; or 
(3)  A governmental employee in the performance of official duties. 
(b)  No person shall falsely represent himself to be under 18 years of age for the purpose of gaining admission to a juvenile rave club. 
(c)  No permittee or employee of a juvenile rave club shall knowingly allow a person 18 years of age or over to enter or remain on the premises of the juvenile rave club. 
(d)  No permittee of a juvenile rave club shall maintain or operate the premises without posting a conspicuous sign at the entrance to the business that reads: "It is unlawful for any person over 18 years of age or older to enter this premises." 
(Code 1984, § 4-46; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-74. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  No person shall operate a juvenile rave club during any hours other than 4:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, and from 4:00 p.m. on Friday to 12:01 a.m. of the following day, and from 1:00 p.m. Saturday to 12:01 a.m. of the following day. The establishment shall close and all customers or members shall vacate the premises when it is required to close until the time that the establishment may legally open for operation. 
(b)  No person shall operate an adult rave club during any hours other than 1:00 p.m. to 2:00 a.m. of the following day. The establishment shall close and all customers or members shall vacate the premises when it is required to close until the time that the establishment may legally open for operation. 
(Code 1984, § 4-47; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-75. - Security; paramedic. 
(a)  Whenever a rave club is open to the general public, the rave club permittee shall have on the premises, at the permittee's expense, the greater of either three off-duty sworn law enforcement officers, or three private security officers having either a Class D or Class MS license as set forth in F.S. ch. 493 or one off-duty sworn law enforcement officer, or one private security officer having a license described above, per 150 of the persons allowed under the maximum occupancy load for the structure in which the rave club is operated. The police chief may require a permittee to increase the number of off-duty law enforcement officers or licensed private security officers when a special event or limited engagement is scheduled to take place at a permitted rave club. Nothing in the subsection shall be construed to mean that the police chief must require law enforcement officers to serve in an off-duty capacity at a permitted rave club. 
(b)  Whenever a rave club is open to the general public, at least one certified and actively licensed paramedic, as set forth in F.S. ch. 401, shall be present, at the expense of the permittee. 
(Code 1984, § 4-48; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-76. - Land development code; fire prevention; offenses. 
    No person shall operate a rave club in violation of any applicable provisions of the land development code, appendix D, or chapter 28, or chapter 40, as those provisions may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1984, § 4-49; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-77. - Rave club supervisor. 
(a)  A person who operates a rave club shall designate a person as the rave club supervisor and shall register that supervisor's name with the city manager or his designee. 
(b)  The person designated as the rave club supervisor shall comply with the requirements set forth in section 8-70(a)(6)a and (a)(6)b for applicants. 
(c)  The person designated rave club supervisor shall remain on the premises of the rave club during all hours of operation and until 30 minutes after closing to ensure that the operation is conducted in accordance with all rave club regulations hereof. 
(Code 1984, § 4-50; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-78. - Inspection. 
(a)  Application for, and issuance of, any rave club permit shall constitute consent by the permittee for representatives of the city to enter and inspect the premises of the rave club at any time it is open for business or occupied for the purpose of verifying compliance with the law. 
(b)  No person who operates a rave club, or a person designated as the rave club supervisor, shall refuse to permit a lawful inspection of the premises of a rave club by a representative of the city at any time it is open for business or occupied. 
(Code 1984, § 4-51; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-79. - Expiration of permit. 
(a)  A permit for a rave club expires one year from the date of issuance. A permit may be renewed only by making application as provided in section 8-69. Application for renewal should be made at least 60 days before the expiration date, and when made less than 60 days before the expiration date, the expiration of the permit will not be affected by the pendency of the application. 
(b)  If the city manager or designee denies renewal of a permit, the applicant may not be issued any rave club permit for one year from the date denial becomes final. If, subsequent to denial, the city manager or designee finds that the basis for denial of the renewal permit has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a permit if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date denial becomes final. 
(Code 1984, § 4-52; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-80. - Suspension of permit. 
    The city manager or designee shall suspend a rave club permit for a period of time not to exceed 30 days if the city manager determines that a permittee, or an employee of a permittee, has committed any one or more of the following acts: 
(1)  Violated any provisions of the rave club regulations; 
(2)  Engaged in the use of alcoholic beverages on the rave club premises; 
(3)  Refused to allow an inspection of the rave club premises so authorized in this article; 
(4)  Knowingly permitted an intoxicated person to remain on the rave club premises; 
(5)  Knowingly permitted gambling by any person on the rave club premises; 
(6)  Knowingly permitted the possession, consumption or sale of an alcoholic beverage on the premises of a rave club; 
(7)  Knowingly permitted the possession, consumption or sale of any illegal drugs on the premises of the rave club; or 
(8)  Knowingly allowed performances or activity that violates chapter 4, which regulates adult entertainment. 
(Code 1984, § 4-53; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-81. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The city manager or designee shall revoke a permit if a cause of suspension under section 8-80 occurs, and the permit has been previously suspended within the preceding 12 months. 
(b)  The city manager or designee shall revoke a permit if the city manager determines that one or more of the following is true: 
(1)  A permittee has given false or misleading information in the material submitted to the city during the application or renewal process. 
(2)  A permittee or an employee has knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances, or any derivative thereof, on the premises. 
(3)  A permittee or an employee knowingly permitted dancing or a live performance during a period of time when the rave club permit was suspended. 
(4)  A permittee has been: 
a.  Convicted of an offense listed in section 4-70(a)(6)a for which the time period required in section 8-70(a)(6)b has not elapsed; or 
b.  Convicted of or is under indictment for any felony offense while holding a rave club permit. 
(5)  While an employee of the rave club, and while on the permitted premises, a person has committed an offense listed in section 8-70(a)(6)a, for which a conviction has been obtained, two or more times within a 12 month period. 
(c)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the revocation of the permit. 
(d)  When the city manager or designee revokes a permit, the revocation will continue for one year, and the permittee may not be issued any rave club permit for one year from the date revocation became final. If, subsequent to revocation, the city manager or designee finds that the basis for the revocation action has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a permit if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date the revocation became final. If the permit was revoked under subsection (b)(4) of this section, an applicant may not be granted another permit until the appropriate number of years required under section 8-70(a)(6)b has elapsed. 
(Code 1984, § 4-54; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-82. - Appeals. 
    If the city manager or designee denies the issuance or renewal of a permit, or suspends or revokes a permit, the city manager or designee shall send the applicant or permittee, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of the action and the right to an appeal. The aggrieved applicant or permittee may appeal the decision of the city manager to the city council in accordance with the following procedures. The filing of an appeal stays the action of the city manager or designee in suspending or revoking the permit until the city council makes a final decision on the appeal. 
(1)  The aggrieved party may, not later than ten calendar days after receiving notice of the denial, file with the city clerk a written request for a hearing before the city council. Such request shall constitute notice of appeal. 
(2)  If a written request is filed under subsection (1) of this section with the city clerk within the ten-day limit, the city council shall consider the request. The city clerk shall set a date for the hearing within 30 days from the date the written request is filed with the clerk. 
(3)  The city council shall hear and consider evidence offered by any interested person to determine whether the city manager or designee properly denied issuance or renewal of the permit, or properly suspended or revoked the permit in accordance with the provisions of this article. During such hearing, the formal rules of evidence shall not apply. 
(4)  By a proper vote, the city council shall either affirm or reverse the city manager's actions concerning the permit or application, in accordance with the provisions of this article. Any dispute of fact must be decided on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence. The decision of the city council is final. 
(5)  If the city council affirms the city manager's denial or suspension or revocation, the aggrieved party may not re-apply for a rave club permit until at least 12 months have elapsed since the date of the city council's action. 
(Code 1984, § 4-55; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-83. - Transfer of permit. 
    A permittee shall not transfer a permit to another person, nor shall a permittee operate a rave club under the authority of a permit at any place other than the address designated in the application. 
(Code 1984, § 4-56; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Sec. 8-84. - Penalties and remedies. 
    A person who operates or causes to be operated a rave club without a valid permit or in violation of any provision of this article, shall be subject to the following penalties and/or remedies: 
(1)  Suspension or revocation of the rave club permit. 
(2)  Violations of this article may be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(3)  Each day that any violation continues after receipt of written notice of such violation shall constitute a separate violation and a separate offense for purposes of the penalties and remedies specified herein. 
(4)  In addition to the penalties and remedies set forth in subsection (1) through (3) of this section, the city may institute any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent, restrain, correct or abate a violation of this article, as provided by law. 
(Code 1984, § 4-57; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 8-14-2001) 
Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Animals, F.S. ch. 828; livestock at large, F.S. § 588.12; damage by dogs, F.S. ch. 767. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Adoption. 
    The county animal control ordinance, as amended from time to time, shall be known as the "City of Melbourne Animal Control Code" and is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated herein, as if fully set out. 
(Code 1984, § 5-1; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-2. - Designation of city as wildlife sanctuary. 
    All lands and waters within the city are hereby declared to be and are designated as a wildlife sanctuary and, as such, it shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally kill or injure any bird, waterfowl or wild animal within said area. 
(Code 1984, § 5-2; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Secs. 10-3-10-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL PERMITS 

Sec. 10-23. - Purpose. 
    The intent of the city council in adopting this article is to recognize that the zoning code does not expressly permit nondomestic animals in certain zoning districts; however, within these districts, there are certain animals that may be kept as family pets. 
(Code 1984, § 5-13; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-24. - Authority. 
    The city clerk, under the direction of the city manager, is hereby authorized and directed to administer the animal permitting process. Permits may be issued for certain animals in accordance with this article that are maintained outside of a residence. 
(Code 1984, § 5-14; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-25. - Jurisdiction by state. 
    The city will not issue permits for animals regulated by the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission. Any person in the city who keeps an animal regulated by the state must possess the appropriate license and follow all applicable statutes, rules, and regulations. 
(Code 1984, § 5-15; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal permit means the permit that is issued by the city clerk. 
    Animal permit application means the form provided by the city clerk for the purposes of processing a request to keep certain animals. 
    Animal structure means any structure used to house an animal. The term "animal structure" includes, but is not limited to, coop, cage, and enclosure. 
(Code 1984, § 5-16; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-27. - Permit required for certain animals; conditions. 
(a)  A permit shall be required for animals (except domestic dogs and cats) that are kept outside of a residence. An applicant for an animal permit must complete a form provided by the city clerk and provide a hand-drawn diagram that includes the following: street name; location of house; and location of any structure used to house the animal. If an animal structure will be used, it must be in place prior to submitting the animal permit application. 
(b)  Animal structures must meet any setback requirements established in this Code. If an animal structure is larger than 100 square feet or higher than six feet, a building permit for an accessory structure will be required from the code compliance division. 
(c)  Code compliance personnel will conduct a physical inspection of the area where the animal is maintained and make a recommendation for approval or denial of the animal permit to the city clerk. 
(d)  The number of animals permitted will be based on the zoning district, lot size, and usable lot area as determined by a physical inspection of the site by the city. Animal permits will generally not be issued for roosters unless there is something unique about the property, such as zoning, acreage, and location. 
(e)  Animal feed that is stored outside must be in sealed containers to prevent access by rodents, insects, and wildlife. 
(f)  An applicant for an animal permit is responsible for complying with homeowners' association rules and regulations, if applicable, that pertain to keeping animals or animal enclosures outside of a residence. 
(g)  If the applicant is not the owner of the property, the applicant must obtain permission from the property owner to keep animals that require an animal permit from the city. 
(h)  An animal permit will be effective for two years from the date of issuance. In order to keep the animal permit in an active status, the applicant must submit a new animal permit application to the city clerk prior to the expiration date of the animal permit. 
(Code 1984, § 5-17; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-28. - Inspection of area. 
    Once an animal permit has been issued, the location will be subject to an annual inspection by code compliance personnel to ensure that the area is being maintained in a manner that is safe and sanitary for the animal. 
(Code 1984, § 5-18; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-29. - Maintenance of animals, reptiles, and fowl. 
    A person who has been issued an animal permit shall be required to maintain the area where the animal is kept in a sanitary manner. Complaints from surrounding neighbors and personal observation by code compliance personnel shall be considered in determining whether an area is being properly maintained. 
(Code 1984, § 5-19; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-30. - Permit revocation. 
    If any condition of an animal permit has been violated, the city clerk may revoke the permit. 
(Code 1984, § 5-20; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-31. - Appeals. 
    A person aggrieved by a decision of the city clerk in the issuance, denial or revocation of an animal permit may appeal to the city manager. The appeal must be submitted in writing within 20 days of the decision and state the basis for the appeal. A person aggrieved by a decision of the city manager may appeal to the city council. The appeal must be submitted in writing to the city clerk within 20 days of the decision and state the basis for the appeal. 
(Code 1984, § 5-21; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Secs. 10-32-10-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - APIARIES 

Sec. 10-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bees means a swarm, hive or apiary or any volume of bees. 
    Educational uses means public or private schools, vocational schools or colleges. 
    Hazard or nuisance means the creation of a circumstance or situation that would adversely affect the health, welfare and safety of or create an annoyance to persons or property. 
    Medical uses means use by any licensed member of the medical profession, including medical technicians and persons engaged in medical research. 
    Scientific purposes means use in research other than that stated above. 
(Code 1984, § 5-32; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 10-52. - Beekeeping prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an apiary or otherwise maintain bees within the city limits, except in an agricultural estate use (AEU) zoning district, or as may otherwise be provided in this article. 
(Code 1984, § 5-33; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001; Ord. No. 2004-37, § 5, 5-25-2004) 
Sec. 10-53. - Exceptions to section 10-52. 
(a)  Nothing contained in section 10-52 shall prohibit the maintenance of one hive of bees under the following conditions: 
(1)  Upon the premises of any public or private educational institution for use by students for educational purposes. 
(2)  Upon such premises as may be required for medical research or scientific purposes. 
(3)  Upon the premises of a building or residence, provided that the person seeking to maintain the hive upon the premises shall first make application for permit to maintain such hive. No application for permission to maintain such hive shall be granted unless the use for educational purposes is clearly established. 
(b)  The use of bees for educational, medical or scientific purposes, as provided for herein, shall be permitted so long as no hazard or nuisance, public or private, is created. 
(Code 1984, § 5-34; Ord. No. 2001-31, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Chapter 12 - AVIATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Airport authority, § 3.25. 
State Law reference- Aviation, F.S. chs. 329, 330, 331, 332, 333. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airport means the Melbourne International Airport. 
    Commercial activity means activity that the city has recognized as a commercial activity by the granting of leases, permits, franchises, licenses or other similar allowances, for the soliciting of customers, execution of contracts, sale, purchase or delivery of merchandise or services sold, leased, or rented. 
    Director of aviation means the manager of all aviation activities and facilities and shall be appointed by the Melbourne Airport Authority. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1; Code 1984, § 6-1; Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 1-28-1997) 
Sec. 12-2. - Liability of city for harm. 
    The city assumes no liability or responsibility for the loss, injury or damage to persons or property utilizing the facilities and services of the airport due to fire, theft, vandalism, wind, water, earthquake, collision or otherwise. 
(Code 1980, § 7-2; Code 1984, § 6-2) 
Sec. 12-3. - Penalties; enforcement. 
(a)  The director of aviation shall be charged with the enforcement of this chapter under the general police powers of the city. If, in the discretion of the director of aviation, violations of this chapter are of a minor enough nature to not warrant summons to court, then the director of aviation may, in his discretion, administratively suspend the violator from the use and privileges of the airport for a period not to exceed 30 days. The director of aviation may not suspend any violator for more than two such 30-day periods in any one year. 
(b)  Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of, this chapter shall be punished as provided by section 1-14. Each day that the violation is permitted to exist after notice will constitute a separate offense and will subject the violator to a separate fine and separate imprisonment for each such separate offense. 
(Code 1980, § 7-5; Code 1984, § 6-3) 
Sec. 12-4. - Authority required for commercial activity. 
    No person shall conduct any commercial activity at the airport, including terminal buildings, airfields, aprons, runways, parking areas, streets or any other airport property, unless he first obtains proper authority to do so from the city or the city airport authority, as the case may be. 
(Code 1980, § 7-3; Code 1984, § 6-4) 
Sec. 12-5. - Commercial aviation activity. 
(a)  No person shall engage in any commercial aviation activity from the airport except by virtue of written approval of the city. 
(b)  Requisites for obtaining written permission shall be that: 
(1)  The applicant has the necessary federal, state and local licenses. 
(2)  The applicant is financially sound and can make a proper showing of his financial ability to engage in the proposed activity. A current financial statement certified as true and correct by an acceptable certified public accountant shall be furnished. Credit reports from three areas in which the applicant has most recently resided and/or operated a business may be requested by the city at the expense of applicant. 
(3)  The proposed operation will be beneficial to the airport and the general flying public. This determination will be made by the airport authority at a regular meeting subsequent to the applicant's presenting his proposal to the airport authority seven days in advance of the regular meeting. 
(4)  The activity shall have suitable quarters and facilities on the flight line at the airport. Approval of location, quarters and facilities shall not be arbitrarily withheld. 
(Code 1980, § 7-4; Code 1984, § 6-5) 
Sec. 12-6. - Public ground transportation. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "vehicle for hire" shall mean any motor vehicle used by a commercial enterprise for the purpose of carrying its customers or clients, whether for a charge or without charge, including, but not limited to, taxicabs, limousines, buses and, including, but not limited to, courtesy vehicles operated by rental car agencies, hotels, motels, restaurants, travel agencies or tour guides. 
(b)  The authority shall designate an area proximate to the terminal building where vehicles for hire may pick up or discharge passengers at the airport. The authority shall establish, from time to time, fees for access to such designated area. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle for hire to stop, wait or park or pick up or discharge passengers at the airport except at such designated area and except upon payment of the fees established for access to such area. 
(c)  The authority shall, from time to time, establish rules and regulations for the safe and orderly operation of vehicles for hire at the Melbourne International Airport. The authority shall, from time to time, establish procedures for the issuance of permits to operate vehicles for hire at the Melbourne International Airport and may, from time to time, establish fees for the issuance of such permits and attach such conditions to the issuance of such permits as may be reasonably necessary to ensure the safe and orderly operation of such vehicles. It shall be unlawful for the owner or the operator of any vehicle for hire to operate a vehicle for hire at the Melbourne International Airport unless operated in conformity with the rules and regulations from time to time enacted by the authority and unless operated pursuant to a permit issued by authority under the conditions set forth in such permit. Such rules and regulations shall not conflict with the provisions of chapter 60. 
(d)  No person shall, within the boundary of the airport, solicit or invite or induce persons to ride in any vehicle for hire, either by acts or the utterance of words used or calculated to induce persons to hire or engage such vehicles, unless such person is authorized by the authority and acting pursuant to rules and regulations approved by the authority and the provisions of chapter 60. 
(e)  No person shall operate any vehicle for hire from the airport unless that person is the holder of a permit or contract with the city airport authority. 
(f)  No person shall solicit rental car business or transact rental car business on the airport premises unless he is the holder of a permit or contract issued by the authority. This section shall not be construed as to prevent delivery of rental cars for arriving passengers previously reserved by the customer at another point. Evidence as to such prior reservation may be requested by any law enforcement officer or authorized representative of the director of aviation. 
(Code 1980, § 7-6; Code 1984, § 6-6; Ord. No. 87-13, § 1, 3-10-1987; Ord. No. 97-2, § 2, 1-28-1997) 
Secs. 12-7-12-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIELD RULES 

Sec. 12-31. - Standard of conduct for aeronautical activities. 
    All aeronautical activities at the airport are to be conducted in conformance with the current and pertinent rules and regulations of the Federal Aviation Agency. 
(Code 1980, § 7-16; Code 1984, § 6-21) 
Sec. 12-32. - Airport users presumed to have knowledge of rules, regulations, ordinances. 
    It is assumed that all persons using the airport in any capacity are cognizant of the provisions of the local rules and regulations, current Federal Aviation Agency (FAA) rules and regulations and any specific ordinances enacted by the city for the use and operation of the airport. 
(Code 1980, § 7-17; Code 1984, § 6-22) 
Sec. 12-33. - Persons prohibited from restricted areas; exceptions. 
    All persons are prohibited from entering the runways, taxiways, ramp, apron, utility and service areas or other areas of the airport as may be designated as restricted, except: 
(1)  Persons assigned to duty therein. 
(2)  Bona fide airmen in the course of their business. 
(3)  Passengers, under appropriate supervision, enplaning or deplaning. 
(4)  Other persons as authorized by the director of aviation. 
(Code 1980, § 7-18; Code 1984, § 6-23) 
Sec. 12-34. - Motor vehicles prohibited from restricted areas; exceptions. 
    All automobiles or other vehicles are prohibited from entering the runways, taxiways, ramp, apron or other areas of the airport as may be designated as restricted, except: 
(1)  Service vehicles. 
(2)  Official vehicles. 
(3)  Other vehicles as authorized by the director of aviation. 
(Code 1980, § 7-19; Code 1984, § 6-24) 
Sec. 12-35. - Authorized automobiles to display flag while operating. 
    All authorized automobiles or vehicles not having two-way radio communications with the airport traffic control tower shall display a red flag, mast-mounted, of a minimum dimension of 36 inches by 36 inches at any time they are operating on the runways, taxiways, ramp, apron or other areas as may be designated restricted. Authorized vehicle traffic in the T-hangar area is exempt from this section. 
(Code 1980, § 7-20; Code 1984, § 6-25) 
Sec. 12-36. - Parking motor vehicles. 
    No automobiles or other vehicles will be parked on the airport except in those areas specifically designated as parking areas. 
(Code 1980, § 7-21; Code 1984, § 6-26) 
Sec. 12-37. - Parking aircraft. 
    No aircraft will be parked on the airport except in the designated parking areas. All aircraft shall be parked in an orderly manner and so as to leave adequate taxiing and maneuvering area for other aircraft. 
(Code 1980, § 7-22; Code 1984, § 6-27) 
Sec. 12-38. - Regulations governing activity between sunset and sunrise. 
    Between sunset and sunrise, no aircraft shall be left unattended on the airport ramp or apron, except when such aircraft is parked in the designated parking area and securely tied down or adequate brake locking devices are set. All aircraft in motion on the ground during these hours will have navigation lights turned on. Stationary aircraft parked in other than designated overnight parking areas will have navigation lights turned on. 
(Code 1980, § 7-23; Code 1984, § 6-28) 
Sec. 12-39. - Distance from hangar doors required for engines run-up. 
    Aircraft engines shall not be run up for power checks at any distance less than 150 feet from hangar doors. 
(Code 1980, § 7-24; Code 1984, § 6-29) 
Sec. 12-40. - Where aircraft are to be operated; takeoff and landing on taxiways. 
    All aircraft operations shall be confined to the hard-surfaced runways, taxiways, ramp, and apron, except as specifically authorized by the director of aviation. Takeoff or landing on taxiways is prohibited except that roto-craft may land and take off from the ramp or apron but must follow normal taxiway routes or as directed by the airport traffic control tower. 
(Code 1980, § 7-25; Code 1984, § 6-30) 
Sec. 12-41. - Smoking prohibited. 
    Smoking shall not be permitted on the airport apron, ramp, in any hangar or shop, service area, gasoline storage area or in any other area where specifically prohibited. 
(Code 1980, § 7-26; Code 1984, § 6-31) 
Sec. 12-42. - Fueling or defueling; smoking, open flame operations while fueling. 
    No aircraft will be fueled or defueled while any engine is running or while the aircraft is in a hangar or enclosed space. Smoking or open flame operations are not permitted within 100 feet of an aircraft during fueling or defueling operations. 
(Code 1980, § 7-27; Code 1984, § 6-32) 
Sec. 12-43. - Conducting open flame operation. 
    No person shall conduct any open flame operations in any hangar or on the airport property unless specifically authorized by the director of aviation. 
(Code 1980, § 7-28; Code 1984, § 6-33) 
Sec. 12-44. - Storage of gasoline, oil, solvents. 
    Gasoline, oil and solvents or the receptacles therefor shall not be stored on the apron or ramp in excess of amounts actually needed as current stock. Any material of this type that is kept in these areas will be kept enclosed and covered in housing and receptacles of a design and type as meets the approval of the director of aviation. 
(Code 1980, § 7-29; Code 1984, § 6-34) 
Sec. 12-45. - Draining fuels, oils, etc., into drains, ditches. 
    Fuels, oils, dopes, paints, solvents or other corrosive or volatile liquids will not be disposed of in drains, basins or ditches except in those areas approved by the director of aviation. 
(Code 1980, § 7-30; Code 1984, § 6-35) 
Secs. 12-46-12-63. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ENGINE OPERATION AND TAXIING RULES 

Sec. 12-64. - Visual inspection of area before taxiing, operating engine. 
    No person shall taxi an aircraft or operate an engine until he has ascertained by visual inspection that there will be no danger of collision with any person or damage to any object within the immediate area. 
(Code 1980, § 7-41; Code 1984, § 6-51) 
Sec. 12-65. - Taxiing speed. 
    All aircraft shall be taxied at a safe and reasonable speed with due regard to other aircraft, weather conditions, persons and property. A reasonable taxiing speed in congested areas is ten miles per hour and on open taxiways 20 miles per hour. 
(Code 1980, § 7-42; Code 1984, § 6-52) 
Sec. 12-66. - Qualified persons required at controls when starting, operating engine; wheel chocks. 
    No person will start or operate an engine in an aircraft unless a competent and qualified person is in the aircraft and at the engine controls. Wheel chocks shall be in place in front of wheels before starting the aircraft engine unless the aircraft is equipped with adequate and operating parking brakes. 
(Code 1980, § 7-43; Code 1984, § 6-53) 
Sec. 12-67. - Manner of running engine. 
    No person shall run an engine at any location on the airport in such a manner as to cause damage to, or in such a manner as to blow debris across aprons, ramps, taxiways or runways or to endanger property or the safety of operations on the airport. 
(Code 1980, § 7-44; Code 1984, § 6-54) 
Sec. 12-68. - Warmup to be completed prior to entering runway for takeoff. 
    All extensive engine warmups are to be completed prior to the aircraft entering the runway for takeoff position. 
(Code 1980, § 7-45; Code 1984, § 6-55) 
Sec. 12-69. - Position for aircraft awaiting takeoff. 
    Aircraft awaiting takeoff shall park at least 100 feet from the edge of the runway in use and in a position to observe all aircraft approaching the runway for landing. 
(Code 1980, § 7-46; Code 1984, § 6-56) 
Sec. 12-70. - Adherence to established traffic pattern required. 
    All aircraft shall adhere to the taxi patterns as set forth in the map on file in the office of the director of aviation. 
(Code 1980, § 7-47; Code 1984, § 6-57) 
Sec. 12-71. - Taxiing planes without adequate brakes near buildings, parked planes. 
    An aircraft not equipped with adequate and operational brakes will not be taxied near buildings or parked aircraft unless an attendant is at each wingtip of the aircraft to assist the pilot. 
(Code 1980, § 7-48; Code 1984, § 6-58) 
Secs. 12-72-12-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AIR TRAFFIC RULES 

Sec. 12-101. - Direction of air travel generally. 
    Except as otherwise directed by the airport traffic control tower, the direction of air traffic in the vicinity of the airport shall be counterclockwise, left-hand pattern, with landings and takeoffs on the runway nearest to the wind direction indicated by the wind direction indicator. 
(Code 1980, § 7-59; Code 1984, § 6-71) 
Sec. 12-102. - Turns after takeoff. 
    Except as otherwise directed by the airport traffic control tower, no turn shall be made after takeoff until the airport boundary has been reached, the aircraft has attained an altitude of at least 400 feet, and it has been ascertained that there will be no danger of collision with any other aircraft. 
(Code 1980, § 7-60; Code 1984, § 6-72) 
Sec. 12-103. - Departure from traffic pattern. 
    Except as otherwise directed by the airport traffic control tower, aircraft leaving the traffic pattern shall climb to an altitude of not less than 400 feet above the surface, make a 90-degree turn to the left and leave the traffic pattern by performing a 45-degree turn to the right. If aircraft characteristics make this procedure impractical, departure from the traffic pattern may be made in a straight climb after the takeoff, when it has been ascertained that there will be no danger of collision with any other aircraft. 
(Code 1980, § 7-61; Code 1984, § 6-73) 
Sec. 12-104. - Pattern for touch-and-go landings by fast or large aircraft from outer pattern. 
    All fast or large aircraft taking off intending to remain in the outer traffic pattern for a series of landings and takeoffs shall continue to climb to a traffic altitude of 1,500 feet above the surface after making a 90-degree turn to the left and shall thereafter follow the pattern as set forth in the map on file in the office of the director of aviation. 
(Code 1980, § 7-62; Code 1984, § 6-74) 
Sec. 12-105. - Light, slow aircraft performing touch-and-go landings in inner pattern. 
    All light or slow aircraft taking off intending to remain in the inner rectangular pattern for a series of takeoffs and landings shall continue to climb to 1,000 feet above the surface after making a 90-degree turn and then follow the inside pattern as set forth in the map. 
(Code 1980, § 7-63; Code 1984, § 6-75) 
Sec. 12-106. - Angle, altitude for entering inner rectangular traffic pattern. 
    Aircraft entering the inner rectangular traffic pattern inbound to the airport shall do so at an angle of 45 degrees midway on the downwind leg at an altitude of 1,000 feet above the surface. 
(Code 1980, § 7-64; Code 1984, § 6-76) 
Sec. 12-107. - Careful entry into traffic pattern required; passing prohibited in both patterns. 
    Aircraft entering the traffic pattern shall exercise extreme caution so as not to cause aircraft already in the pattern to deviate from their course. There shall be no passing of aircraft in either pattern. 
(Code 1980, § 7-65; Code 1984, § 6-77) 
Sec. 12-108. - Altitude for entering outer traffic pattern; procedure after entry. 
    Aircraft finding it impractical to enter and conform to the inner rectangular pattern may enter the outer pattern at any point at an altitude of 1,500 feet above the surface but shall fly at least a 90-degree segment of the circular pattern as a base leg before aligning the aircraft on the final approach. 
(Code 1980, § 7-66; Code 1984, § 6-78) 
Sec. 12-109. - Minimum altitude for departing multiengine aircraft. 
    All departing multiengine aircraft shall climb as quickly as possible subject to the provisions of this chapter to an altitude of not less than 1,500 feet to avoid unnecessary noise over the surrounding residential areas. 
(Code 1980, § 7-67; Code 1984, § 6-79) 
Sec. 12-110. - Minimum altitude for incoming multiengine aircraft. 
    All inbound multiengine aircraft shall remain above 1500 feet until starting a descent to enter the traffic pattern and will avoid unnecessary noise over the surrounding residential areas. 
(Code 1980, § 7-68; Code 1984, § 6-80) 
Sec. 12-111. - Touch-and-go landing planes to give way. 
    As a courtesy, aircraft within either traffic pattern making a series of touch-and-go landings shall give way to itinerant or multiengine aircraft in the interest of expeditious landing of these aircraft. 
(Code 1980, § 7-69; Code 1984, § 6-81) 
Sec. 12-112. - Roto-craft traffic pattern; operation near light aircraft. 
    Except as otherwise directed by the airport traffic control tower, roto-craft shall conform to the same traffic patterns as prescribed for conventional aircraft. Such aircraft will not be operated within 200 feet of any area where the light aircraft are parked or operating. 
(Code 1980, § 7-70; Code 1984, § 6-82) 
Secs. 12-113-12-137. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AIRPORT AUTHORITY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Airport authority, § 3.25. 

Sec. 12-138. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and constituted as an agency and instrumentality of the city, a special board to be named and known as "City of Melbourne Airport Authority," hereinafter referred to as the "airport authority." 
(Code 1980, § 7-81; Code 1984, § 6-96) 
Sec. 12-139. - Members; qualifications; term of office. 
(a)  Residence within the city shall not be a prerequisite to membership on the airport authority. An airport authority member may or may not be a member of the city council. 
(b)  The airport authority shall consist of seven members. Three of the members shall be members of the city council, appointed by the city council. One member shall be appointed by the chamber of commerce of the city, or such chamber body with which the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce may have merged or be a part. One member shall be appointed by the tenants of the Industrial Air Center of the airport and the sixth and seventh members shall be selected by the aforementioned members. 
(c)  In the absence of a chamber of commerce or tenants within the Industrial Air Center, or upon the failure of either of these bodies to so appoint within 60 days of the time the appointments could be made, the appointments shall be made by the city council. 
(d)  The term of office of each member shall be for a period of two years. The terms of any member of the city council who may be appointed to the airport authority shall terminate upon the member ceasing to be a council member or at the end of his two-year term, whichever shall occur first. 
(Code 1980, § 7-82; Code 1984, § 6-97) 
Sec. 12-140. - Quorum, voting, chair of the airport authority; public meetings. 
    Four members of the airport authority shall constitute a quorum. Matters requiring a vote by this airport authority shall be approved only by a favorable vote of a majority of the airport authority. The chair of the airport authority shall be elected annually by the airport authority members at the first meeting of the airport authority in December of each year. Meetings of the airport authority shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1980, § 7-84; Code 1984, § 6-98) 
Sec. 12-141. - Compensation and travel expense of airport authority members. 
    The members of this airport authority will serve without pay, but subject to section 2-484 members of the airport authority are allowed compensation for any travel expense while on or about the business of the airport authority away from the city. Such travel expense is limited to a reasonable amount which will be determined by the board. Any such travel expense will be approved by the airport authority before payment and such payment will be made from monies received from the operation of the airport. 
(Code 1980, § 7-83; Code 1984, § 6-99; Ord. No. 2013-03, § 2(6-99), 1-22-2013) 
Sec. 12-142. - Authority and duties. 
(a)  The airport authority is hereby granted authority to sue and be sued, contract and be contracted with, have an official seal, and the authority is hereby constituted and declared to be a body corporate. The airport authority shall have jurisdiction, control, supervision and management over the Melbourne International Airport, subject to reservations hereinafter set forth, including the power to rent or lease portions of the airport, including the buildings and hangars thereon, the granting of concessions upon such terms and conditions as to it shall seem proper, employment of necessary personnel, including a director of aviation.
