(b)  The authority herein granted to the airport authority shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, the following functions: 
(1)  To take charge of and manage for the city all airport flight operations at the international airport. 
(2)  To negotiate for the city the leasing of the property and facilities of the international airport. 
(3)  To work for and promote the industrial development of the international airport. 
(Code 1980, § 7-85; Code 1984, § 6-100; Ord. No. 97-2, § 3, 1-28-1997) 
Sec. 12-143. - Fiscal matters. 
(a)  The airport authority shall annually, at the same time as is required of the city, prepare and adopt by resolution a detailed budget of the estimated income and expenditures for operation and maintenance of the airport and aviation and other facilities of the airport during the succeeding fiscal year. Such budget shall be in such form and shall contain such content substantially as meets the requirements of the City Charter. Such budget in its final form shall be subject to approval by the city council. 
(b)  No expenditures for the operation and maintenance of such airport and aviation and other facilities of the airport shall be made in any fiscal year in excess of the amounts provided therefor in such budget without a written finding and recommendation by the general manager (who is aviation director) of such airport and aviation and other facilities of the airport or other duly authorized officer in charge thereof, which finding and recommendation shall state in detail the purpose of and necessity for such increased expenditure for the operation and maintenance of such airport and aviation and other facilities of the airport, and no such increased expenditures shall be made until the city council, after recommendation by the authority, shall have approved such finding and recommendation by a resolution duly adopted; and in the event such increased expenditures shall in any fiscal year exceed in the aggregate more than 15 percent of the amount provided for such operation and maintenance is such fiscal year, any further increased expenditures in such fiscal year for the operation and maintenance of the airport and aviation and other facilities of the airport shall only be made after the city obtains a certificate of the consulting engineers stating that such increased expenditures are necessary for the efficient and economical operation and maintenance of the airport and aviation and other facilities of the airport. 
(c)  Copies of such annual budget and all resolutions authorizing increasing expenditures shall be made available to any bond holders entitled to the same under the provisions of existing bond ordinances and resolutions of the city. 
(d)  The receipt and expenditure of all airport funds is controlled by existing bond ordinances and resolutions and which are contractual obligations of the city. All expenditures shall be made in strict compliance with the obligations as well as in compliance with any future resolutions or ordinances adopted by the city for the issuance of bonds or the borrowing of money for the benefit of the airport. 
(e)  The finance director of the city shall have custody of all airport funds as provided by the City Charter. All payments for outstanding bonds or interest thereon shall be paid and handled directly by the finance director. 
(f)  Expenditures of airport funds for operation, maintenance, renewal and replacement shall be under the supervision of the airport authority. Proposed expenditures shall be requested by the director of aviation and approved by the airport authority; such proposed expenditures shall then be processed in accordance with the general provisions of the City Charter. All books and records relating to the fiscal functions of the airport shall remain with and be under the control and supervision of the finance director of the city. All such records, accounts and budget items shall at all times be available to the airport authority. 
(g)  All airport funds shall be subject to audit and safeguards required of all other funds of the city. 
(h)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as granting to the airport authority the power to borrow money, or to issue bonds or certificates of indebtedness, all of such powers being strictly retained by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 7-86; Code 1984, § 6-101) 
Sec. 12-144. - Personnel. 
    Employees of the airport authority shall be deemed employees of the city to the same extent as all other employees of the city, subject to the same rules and regulations and entitled to all the privileges and benefits thereof. Travel will be approved by the airport authority executive director consistent with section 2-484. 
(Code 1980, § 7-87; Code 1984, § 6-102; Ord. No. 2013-03, § 3(6-102), 1-22-2013) 
Sec. 12-145. - Use of city services. 
    All proceeds from the operation of the airport shall be used for airport purposes. Where other departments of the city are used in the administration of airport matters, the city shall be entitled to payment from the airport for such services furnished on such pro rata basis as shall be fair and equitable and comparable to the cost of obtaining such services on a competitive basis. The airport authority shall, where feasible and when available, use other services from the city through its various departments for which compensation shall be paid. Request for such services shall be channeled and coordinated through the city manager who must approve the requests and who shall so direct the appropriate department heads. 
(Code 1980, § 7-88; Code 1984, § 6-103) 
Sec. 12-146. - Existing obligations. 
    The former City of Melbourne has existing obligations to the United States of America and to the holders of outstanding bonds issued for improvements to the airport and other existing obligations of the airport and recognizes generally its responsibility to the citizens of the city and the importance of the airport to its citizens and to the public generally. Among its obligations, the city recognizes its pledge that all proceeds from the operation of the airport or from the sale of any of the properties or other assets of the airport are obligated to be used for the maintenance and development and operation of the airport and for the payment of the outstanding indebtedness of said airport. The city further recognizes the interest of the public generally and tenants or prospective tenants of the Industrial Air Center of the airport in the continued maintenance, development and operation of the airport, including its Industrial Air Center, and hereby reaffirms the good faith of the city in fulfilling said obligations. 
(Code 1980, § 7-89; Code 1984, § 6-104) 
Sec. 12-147. - Provisions subordinate to certain obligations, ordinances, etc. 
    Anything in this article to the contrary notwithstanding, all duties or authority herein delegated shall be and are expressly subordinate to any of the obligations of the city to the United States of America, to the provisions of any ordinances or resolutions providing for the issuance of bonds or other obligations of the city in connection with the airport. 
(Code 1980, § 7-90; Code 1984, § 6-105) 
Secs. 12-148-12-177. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - EXERCISE OF FIRST AMENDMENT RIGHTS AT AIRPORT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Solicitation of funds within public transportation facilities, F.S. § 496.425. 

Sec. 12-178. - Purpose. 
    Any person or organization may use the airport as a forum to exercise the constitutional rights of free speech and freedom of religion, provided such activity does not interfere with the normal function of the facility and provided such activity complies with the provisions of this article which are declared necessary to accomplish the following objectives: 
(1)  To ensure the free and orderly flow of pedestrian traffic through the airport; 
(2)  To ensure that persons seeking to exercise constitutional freedoms of expression, including the right to solicit donations, can communicate effectively with other users of the airport; and 
(3)  To protect persons using the airport from unsought communications or encounters with solicitors which might constitute harassment, intimidation or fraud. 
(Code 1980, § 7-101; Code 1984, § 6-121) 
Sec. 12-179. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airport means Melbourne International Airport Terminal Building, including the surrounding parking lot and runway areas. 
    Director of aviation or director means the chief administrative official of the airport. 
    Permittee means a person or organization conducting a regulated activity with a permit issued under this article. 
    Regulated activity or activity means any conduct at the airport which requires a permit under this article, namely: 
(1)  Religious or other proselytism, including preaching, display of signs, advocacy of ideas, explanation of personal beliefs and similar conduct. 
(2)  Solicitation of donations for political, social or religious causes. 
(3)  Distribution of handbills, tracts and other literature. 
(Code 1980, § 7-102; Code 1984, § 6-122; Ord. No. 97-2, § 4, 1-28-1997) 
Sec. 12-180. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to engage in regulated activity at the airport without first obtaining permission from the director of aviation. To obtain a permit, an applicant must submit a written request, in a form prescribed by the director, signed by a person responsible for compliance with this article, and setting forth the following information: 
(1)  The full name, mailing address and telephone number of the person or organization sponsoring, promoting, or conducting the proposed activity; 
(2)  The full name, mailing address and telephone number of each person who will participate in the activity and of the person who will have supervision of and responsibility for the proposed activities; 
(3)  A description of the activity, indicating the type of communication planned; 
(4)  The dates on and the hours during which the activities are proposed to be carried out and the expected duration of the proposed activities; and 
(5)  The number of persons to be engaged in such activities. 
(Code 1980, § 7-103; Code 1984, § 6-123) 
State Law reference- Contents of application, F.S. § 496.425(2). 
Sec. 12-181. - Report required for solicitation of contributions. 
(a)  If the applicant intends to solicit contributions, he shall, in addition to completing a permit application, file with the director of aviation a financial report on a form as determined by the director of aviation, disclosing his past and prospective use of contributions and containing a statement that no person or organization participating in the solicitation has been convicted of a crime involving fraud within the two years immediately prior to filing the report. 
(b)  The information contained in the financial report shall relate to the applicant's most recent past calendar year, or in the alternative at his election, the most recent completed fiscal year. 
(c)  The director shall not issue a permit for activity involving the solicitation of contributions unless the financial report has been filed; however, the contents of the report may not be used as grounds for denial of a permit. 
(Code 1980, § 7-104; Code 1984, § 6-124) 
Sec. 12-182. - Public access to permit and report information. 
    All applications required under section 12-180 and financial reports required under section 12-181 shall be available for public inspection at the airport during the regular hours that the city is open to conduct business. 
(Code 1980, § 7-105; Code 1984, § 6-125) 
Sec. 12-183. - Issuance of permit. 
    After the receipt of a completed application, the director of aviation must issue the applicant a permit unless he finds one or more of the following facts to exist with regard to the application: 
(1)  That any material statement is incorrect, provided that the applicant has been given an opportunity to correct or amend his application. 
(2)  That the applicant or any named participant intending to solicit contributions has been convicted of a crime involving fraud within the past two years. 
(3)  That a financial report has not been submitted as required by section 12-181. 
(Code 1980, § 7-106; Code 1984, § 6-126) 
Sec. 12-184. - Denial of permit. 
    If the director finds an application to be in violation of section 12-183, he shall deny the applicant a permit, or, if one has been issued, he shall revoke it. 
(Code 1980, § 7-107; Code 1984, § 6-127) 
Sec. 12-185. - Restrictions on number of permittees. 
    Every person who is authorized to conduct regulated activities at the airport under a permit must register each day prior to commending activity. Registration will occur in the office of the director of aviation after 8:00 a.m. If more than one permittee seeks registration for the same location within the airport and for the same time period, the director will distribute available locations on a first-come, first-serve basis. He may further limit the time and space available to any permittee if necessary to provide equal access to others. No more than three persons may conduct regulated activity in a terminal building at the same time, regardless of the number of permits outstanding. 
(Code 1980, § 7-108; Code 1984, § 6-128) 
Sec. 12-186. - Restrictions on location. 
    Regulated activities may be conducted only on portions of the airport which are open to the general public for common use. However, no activity may be conducted at the following public use areas: 
(1)  On the side of the security check points where the gate positions of arriving and departing aircraft are located; 
(2)  Within ten feet of: 
a.  Security check points. 
b.  Information booths. 
c.  Another person conducting regulated activities. 
d.  Elevators, stairways and doorways. 
e.  Restaurants or coffee shops. 
f.  Snack bars, mobile pushcarts or bars. 
g.  Display cases or windows. 
h.  Any business establishment or office. 
i.  Any person waiting in line, such as at a ticket counter, information booth, concession stand or baggage claim area. 
(Code 1980, § 7-109; Code 1984, § 6-129) 
Sec. 12-187. - Restrictions on behavior. 
    In conducting regulated activity: 
(1)  Each permittee soliciting donations shall wear an identification badge in a form approved by the director of aviation, disclosing his name and the name of the organization, if any, which he represents. 
(2)  The following forms of expression are prohibited: 
a.  The use of sound or voice amplification systems, musical instruments, radio communication systems or other mechanical sound devices; 
b.  Singing, chanting or dancing. 
(3)  No permittee may obstruct the free movement of any other person, coerce or threaten any other person, or impede the conduct of any authorized business at the airport. 
(4)  No permittee may touch or pin a flower or other object upon a prospective donor or make similar physical contact unless that person either has consented to such contact or has already agreed to make a contribution. 
(5)  A permittee shall immediately cease all regulated activity directed toward any person who has indicated an unwillingness to listen, make a donation, or accept any literature or other gift offered to him. 
(Code 1980, § 7-110; Code 1984, § 6-130) 
Sec. 12-188. - Revocation of permit for violation of number, place and behavior restrictions. 
    The director of aviation shall revoke a permit after finding a violation of any restriction listed in sections 12-185 through 12-187. A permittee shall immediately cease all regulated activity upon notice that his permit is revoked. 
(Code 1980, § 7-111; Code 1984, § 6-131) 
Sec. 12-189. - Airport administrative hearing board. 
    There is hereby created a quasi-judicial body known as the airport administrative hearing board, composed of five members to be appointed by the chair of the city airport authority, each to serve a two-year term. One member shall be the airport attorney and the other four shall be members of the city airport authority. The board shall hear appeals from persons or organizations whose permits have been revoked by the director of aviation acting under the authority of section 12-188 or denied by the director of aviation acting under the authority of section 12-184. The board shall uphold, reverse or modify the director's ruling by written order supported by specific findings of fact based upon evidence received at a hearing. 
(Code 1980, § 7-112; Code 1984, § 6-132) 
Sec. 12-190. - Appeal to hearing board; hearing. 
(a)  Within ten days after receiving written notification that his permit is denied or revoked for conduct in violation of this article, the permittee may file with the office of the director of aviation a notice of appeal to the airport administrative hearing board. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a notice of appeal, the director of aviation shall set the matter for hearing before the board and give at least five days' notice to all parties of the scheduled time and place. 
(c)  At the hearing, testimony shall be taken upon oath or affirmation, first of witnesses in support of the revocation of the permit. The aggrieved permittee may then testify and present witnesses on his behalf. Any party may be represented by counsel. All matters of procedure, including the admission of testimony and other evidence, shall be determined by the board chair. 
(d)  A stenographic or taped record shall be made of the proceeding which will include a record of all evidence received, in addition to oral testimony. 
(e)  An order upholding the action of the director of aviation in revoking a permit shall be effective when served upon the permittee in person or by certified mail. 
(Code 1980, § 7-113; Code 1984, § 6-133) 
Sec. 12-191. - Reinstatement of permit. 
    The denial or revocation of a permit shall be effective for 90 days. The director of aviation will consider a new application submitted after the expiration of this period without regard for any previous denial or revocation pertaining to the airport. 
(Code 1980, § 7-114; Code 1984, § 6-134) 
Sec. 12-192. - Duration and renewal of permit. 
    All permits shall expire six months from the date of issue. A permit may be reinstated by filing a new application and, in the case of a solicitation permit, a revised financial report. 
(Code 1980, § 7-115; Code 1984, § 6-135) 
Secs. 12-193-12-222. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - AIRPORT SECURITY FORCE 

Sec. 12-223. - Established. 
    The city council, pursuant to the authority granted it under F.S. ch. 332, hereby establishes an airport security force at the Melbourne International Airport, to be known as the Melbourne International Airport Police Department, under the direction and supervision of the director of aviation. 
(Code 1984, § 6-151; Res. No. 1221, § 1, 7-24-1990; Ord. No. 97-2, § 5, 1-28-1997) 
Sec. 12-224. - Law enforcement powers. 
    The members of the Melbourne International Airport Police Department shall have law enforcement powers within and around the airport terminal building, air operations area and adjacent areas of the Melbourne International Airport, as marked on the attached Exhibit A, and shall have the authority to enforce all local, state, and federal laws, rules and regulations within such designated areas. 
(Code 1984, § 6-152; Res. No. 1221, § 2, 7-24-1990; Ord. No. 97-2, § 6, 1-28-1997) 
Editor's note- Exhibit A" as referenced in this section, is a map of the boundary of the Melbourne International Airport Police Department's primary and secondary jurisdiction and is available in the city clerk's office for review. 
Sec. 12-225. - Requirements for members. 
    All members of the Melbourne International Airport Police Department shall comply with all requirements for law enforcement officers imposed by F.S. ch. 943. 
(Code 1984, § 6-153; Res. No. 1221, § 3, 7-24-1990; Ord. No. 97-2, § 7, 1-28-1997) 
Sec. 12-226. - Retirement benefits. 
    Members of the Melbourne International Airport Police Department employed prior to January 1, 1996, shall be eligible to participate in the Florida Retirement System established pursuant to F.S. ch. 121. The city shall amend its contract with the state department of administration to permit such membership as special risk employees. Members of the Melbourne International Airport Police Department employed on or after January 1, 1996, shall participate in the City of Melbourne Special Risk Class Employees' Pension Plan. 
(Code 1984, § 6-154; Res. No. 1221, § 4, 7-24-1990; Ord. No. 97-2, § 8, 1-28-1997) 
Sec. 12-227. - Supervision and control. 
    The Melbourne International Airport Police Department established hereby shall be separate and distinct from the city police department and the members of said department shall be subject to the supervision and control of the city airport authority and the director of aviation of the Melbourne International Airport. 
(Code 1984, § 6-155; Res. No. 1221, § 5, 7-24-1990; Ord. No. 97-2, § 9, 1-28-1997) 
Chapter 14 - BOATS, BULKHEADS, MARINAS, AND WATERWAYS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Tidal lands and bulkheads, F.S. § 253.12 et seq.; boat registration and safety law, F.S. ch. 327 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Statutory authorization. 
    This chapter is adopted pursuant to the authority of inter alia, article VIII, section 2 of the state constitution of 1968 and F.S. §§ 166.021 and 327.60, and is subject to the limitations imposed therein and shall be construed to be supplemental to and not in conflict with the provisions of F.S. chs. 327 and 328. 
(Code 1984, § 7-1; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 14-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Houseboat means a vessel that is used primarily as a residence for at least 21 days during any 30-day period in a county of this state if such residential use of the vessel is to the preclusion of its use as a means of transportation. 
    Live-aboard vessel means: 
(1)  A vessel used solely as a residence and not for navigation; 
(2)  A vessel represented as a place of business or a professional or other commercial enterprise; or 
(3)  A vessel for which a declaration of domicile has been filed pursuant to F.S. § 222.17. 
A commercial fishing boat is expressly excluded from the term "live-aboard vessel." 
    Waters of the city includes all rivers, lakes, streams, ponds and canals within the territorial limits of the city and under its jurisdiction, except the Florida Intracoastal Waterway, as described in F.S. § 327.02, as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1984, § 7-2; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 327.02. 
Sec. 14-3. - Authority of city to regulate waterways. 
    The city shall have the right to regulate the use of all waters of the city and the conduct of all persons using same, consistent with and not in conflict with federal or state regulations. All ordinances of the city regulating the conduct of persons on land shall apply to persons using waterways, insofar as same are properly applicable. 
(Code 1984, § 7-3; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt regulations within certain limits, F.S. § 327.60. 
Sec. 14-4. - Authority to make safety inspections. 
    No officer shall board any vessel to make a safety inspection if the owner or operator is not aboard, unless the officer reasonably believes that such vessel has been abandoned. When the owner or operator is aboard, an officer may board a vessel with consent or when he has probable cause or knowledge to believe that a violation of a provision of this chapter or state law has occurred or is occurring. 
(Code 1984, § 7-4; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 14-5. - Commercial enterprises on water prohibited. 
    No commercial enterprise, defined as any person, partnership, corporation, joint venture, syndicate or other entity engaged in the sale, barter, trade, or production for sale, barter or trade of any goods or services, shall be operated from or upon any of the waters of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 7-5; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 14-6. - Throwing or discharging of trash, debris, etc., into navigable waters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, throw, discharge or deposit, or cause, suffer or procure to be placed, thrown, discharged or deposited, either from or out of any ship, barge, or other floating craft of any kind, or from the shore, wharf, or a manufacturing establishment of any kind, any trash, garbage, debris, acids, timber, logs, lumber, waste (human or animal), petroleum products, or refuse material of any kind or description whatsoever. It shall further be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause, suffer or procure to be deposited materials or matter of any such kind in any place on the bank of any navigable water or on the bank of any tributary of any navigable water or in any storm drainage facility where the same shall be liable to flow or be washed into such navigable water by either ordinary or high tide or by storms or floods or otherwise; provided that nothing herein contained shall extend to, apply to, or prohibit the deposit of any material upon a permit issued by the Secretary of Defense of the United States; or by the state department of environmental protection; nor shall this section be construed as prohibiting or declaring that to be unlawful which is permissible in accordance with any United States Code section or federal regulation now in existence and in effect relating to navigation or navigable waters. 
(Code 1984, § 7-6; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Florida litter law, F.S. § 403.413. 
Sec. 14-7. - Protection of manatees (trichechus manatus). 
    All waters of the city are hereby declared to be a manatee sanctuary. Except as may be authorized by terms of a valid state permit issued pursuant to F.S. § 370.12, as amended from time to time, and by terms of a valid federal and state permit, it shall be unlawful for any person at any time, by any means, or in any manner, intentionally or negligently, to annoy, molest, harass, or disturb or attempt to annoy, molest, harass, or disturb any manatee (trichechus manatus); injure or harm or attempt to injure or harm any manatee; capture or collect or attempt to capture or collect any manatee; pursue, hunt, wound, or kill or attempt to pursue, hunt, wound, or kill any manatee; or possess, literally or constructively, any manatee or any part of any manatee. 
(Code 1984, § 7-7; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Manatee protection, F.S. § 379.2432. 
Secs. 14-8-14-33. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOATS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Vessel safety law, F.S. § 327.01 et seq. 

Sec. 14-34. - Houseboats. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, no houseboat, as defined in subsection (b) of this section, moored to any private dock, wharf, pier, slip, seawall, or other structure or beach abutting any lot zoned for residential or commercial use in the waters embraced within the boundaries of the city shall be used as a dwelling. 
(b)  A houseboat is defined as any vessel of any design used as a dwelling, with living accommodations. 
(c)  The language of this section shall not be so construed as to prohibit any boat from occupying available space within the waterways of the city during a period of time reasonably necessary for protection of the boat from inclement weather conditions. 
(Code 1984, § 7-17; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate mooring or anchoring of live-aboard vessels, F.S. § 327.60(3). 
Sec. 14-35. - Live-aboard watercraft. 
    No person shall live aboard any type of watercraft, moored, docked or anchored within the waters of the city outside the marked boundaries of mooring fields permitted as provided in F.S. § 327.40; and no owner of any marina, dock, pier or dockage facility of any type shall allow a watercraft or vessel of any type to be moored in such facility and allow persons to live aboard as defined herein unless the marine sanitation devices are in compliance with state law. 
(Code 1984, § 7-19; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Marine sanitation requirements, F.S. § 327.53. 
Sec. 14-36. - Signage required. 
    All operators of marinas as defined in appendix B, article II shall post and display in a conspicuous place adjacent to the water, a sign at least one foot by two feet with one inch minimum letters containing the following statement: 
"IT IS UNLAWFUL TO DISCHARGE TRASH, SEWAGE, PETROLEUM PRODUCTS OR OTHER WASTE INTO ANY WATERS OF THE CITY. 
USE MARINA PUMPOUT FACILITIES TO EMPTY MARINE SANITATION DEVICES." 
(Code 1984, § 7-20; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 14-37. - Water skiing prohibited. 
    Water skiing is hereby prohibited on all waters of the city except the Indian River. For purposes of this section, the term "water skiing" is defined as the act whereby a person, either barefoot or upon water skis, aquaplanes, ultralight aircraft, kites, parachutes, or any similar devices or contrivances, is towed behind any type of watercraft in any manner whatsoever. 
(Code 1984, § 7-21; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 14-38. - Incapacity of operator. 
    It is unlawful for the owner of any vessel or any person having such in charge or in control to authorize or knowingly permit the same to be operated by any person who by reason of physical or mental disability is incapable of operating such vessel under the prevailing circumstances. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit operation of boats by paraplegics who are licensed to operate motor vehicles on the highways. 
(Code 1984, § 7-22; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 327.34. 
Sec. 14-39. - Mooring, beaching or placing of watercraft; where prohibited. 
(a)  No vessel or watercraft of any kind whatsoever shall moor to or tie up to a public or private seawall or dock or be beached upon public or private property within the city limits without the permission of the property owner thereof, except in an emergency where necessary to prevent harm to persons or property. No boat or watercraft shall be moored, abandoned, sunk or otherwise placed in such a manner as to impede, restrict or otherwise interfere with the use of private or public docks, launching ramps or other waterfront facilities except in an emergency where necessary to prevent harm to persons or property; however, in the case of an emergency as described in this section, such boat or vessel must be removed within 24 hours of the time said emergency has subsided. Any such craft in violation of this section may, upon request of the owner of the public or private seawall, dock, or property, or his agent, be subject to removal or impoundment. 
(b)  Any boat, vessel or other watercraft which, due to fire, explosion, accident, act of God or other disaster, or abandonment which constitutes a danger to life or property, or a hazard to navigation, shall be subject to removal or impoundment in the manner provided by state law. 
(c)  Any other wrecked or derelict boat having no value other than nominal salvage value, if any, which has been left abandoned and unprotected from the elements is to be disposed of as provided by state law. 
(Code 1984, § 7-23; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 1, 10-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Abandoned property, F.S. § 705.101 et seq.; abandoned vessels, F.S. § 823.11. 
Chapter 16 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Cemeteries and cemetery regulations, F.S. § 497.260 et seq. 

Sec. 16-1. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish a uniform set of regulations for the purchase, sale, use and maintenance of cemetery spaces in the city cemeteries, and to prescribe procedures for the administration of these cemeteries. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-1; Ord. No. 86-23, § 1, 4-8-1986) 
Sec. 16-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Block means a plot of land consisting of lots and spaces which is identified on the Eau Gallie and Melbourne cemetery plats filed with the city clerk. 
    Cemeteries means the municipal cemeteries identified as the Melbourne and Eau Gallie cemeteries owned and administered by the city. 
    Cemetery supervisor means that city employee who has responsibility for the day-to-day operation and supervision of the cemeteries. 
    Columbarium means a structure or building that is substantially exposed above the ground and that is intended to be used for the inurnment of cremated remains. 
    Columbarium niche means a space within the columbarium, which can accommodate two cremated remains. 
    Conveyance. All provisions herein referring to "conveyance," "sale," "transfer," "deeds," etc., mean the conveyance of a right to burial only in a space and shall not be deemed to convey fee simple title to the space. 
    Cremated or cremation means any mechanical or thermal process whereby a dead human body is reduced to ashes and bone fragments. The term "cremation" also includes any other mechanical or thermal process whereby human remains are pulverized, burned, recremated, or otherwise further reduced in size or quantity. 
    Cremated remains means the residue of a dead human body that has been cremated. 
    Direct disposal establishment means a place, licensed under F.S. ch. 497, where a direct disposer practices direct disposition. 
    Direct disposer means any person who is licensed in the state to practice direct disposition. 
    Direct disposition practice means the final disposition of a dead human body without preparation of the body of embalming and without any attendant services or rights such as funeral or graveside services. 
    Final disposition means the final disposal of a dead human body whether it be by, but not limited to, earth interment, above ground interment, cremation, burial at sea, or delivery to a medical institution for lawful dissection if the medical institution assumes responsibility for disposal. The term "final disposition" does not include the disposal or distribution of cremated remains and residue of cremated remains. 
    Funeral or funeral services means the observance, services, or ceremonies held to commemorate the life of a specific deceased human being and at which the human remains are present. 
    Funeral directing means the making of arrangements for, or directing the arrangements for, the preparation and transportation of dead human bodies for final disposition; or using, in connection with one's name, the term "funeral director," "licensed funeral director," "undertaker," or "mortician"; or offering or holding one's self out as offering such services. 
    Funeral director means any person licensed in the state to practice funeral directing. 
    Funeral establishment means a place, licensed under F.S. ch. 497, where a funeral director or embalmer practices his funeral directing or embalming. 
    Grantee means the person purchasing the space whose name shall appear on the cemetery deed of burial right. 
    Grave means the excavation on a lot for the final disposition of a dead human body. 
    Lot means a numbered plot of land consisting of one to ten spaces (and a part of a block) identified on the Eau Gallie and Melbourne cemetery plats filed with the city clerk. 
    Perpetual care means that the city agrees to perform all landscaping and ground maintenance at no additional cost, including, but not limited to, mowing, trimming, fertilization, pesticide applications, tree and shrub trimming and removal, debris and trash removal, renovations, and approved beautification projects. 
    Space means a lettered plot of land (and a part of a lot) identified on the Eau Gallie and Melbourne cemetery plats filed with the city clerk upon which the final disposition of deceased human beings is made. Space may also refer to a columbarium niche. 
    Vault means an underground or aboveground chamber for the final disposition of a dead human body. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-2; Ord. No. 86-23, § 2, 4-8-1986; Ord. No. 96-41, § 1, 7-23-1996; Ord. No. 2001-51, § 1, 10-9-2001; Ord. No. 2004-18, § 1, 3-23-2004) 
State Law reference- Definitions, F.S. § 497.005. 
Sec. 16-3. - Responsibility for cemetery operation and maintenance. 
    The general administration and maintenance of the cemeteries shall be the responsibility of a cemetery supervisor, who shall be an employee of the parks and recreation department. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-3; Ord. No. 86-23, § 3, 4-8-1986; Ord. No. 2014-69, 11-25-2014) 
Sec. 16-4. - Cemetery plats adopted. 
(a)  The plat of the Eau Gallie Cemetery to be used in conveying rights to burial is hereby adopted and ratified. Said plat is on file in the office of the cemetery supervisor. The plat of the Eau Gallie Cemetery shall consist of a one page drawing (revised from the original plat) surveyed by R.C. Gordon on January 21, 1926, and drawn by J.B. Gordon on June 30, 1928. 
(b)  The plat of the Melbourne Cemetery to be used in conveying rights to burial is hereby adopted and ratified. Said plat is on file in the office of the cemetery supervisor. The plat of the Melbourne Cemetery shall consist of a 63 page drawing entitled Record of Burials, Melbourne Cemetery. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-3.1; Ord. No. 96-41, § 2, 7-23-1996) 
Sec. 16-5. - Regulation for use of lots and spaces. 
    The following regulations shall apply to the use of lots and spaces: 
(1)  No enclosure of any nature such as copings, fences, hedges or ditches shall be allowed around any spaces. Grave mounds shall also not be allowed. 
(2)  No trees, plants or shrubs shall be planted, pruned or removed unless authorized by the cemetery supervisor. 
(3)  Artificial flowers may be used on spaces. Ceramic vases may be used for cut flowers. The use of fruit jars, glass vases, glass blocks, tin cans, milk cartons, paper cups or other such containers is not permitted. 
(4)  Small live plants in clay pots may be placed on spaces. 
(5)  All cemetery spaces will be allowed one monument or marker. Monuments and/or grave markers shall be of bronze, granite or marble; not more than four feet high. Foundations for monuments shall be adequately designed to prevent future settlement. Monuments shall be placed on a minimum of five inches of concrete with a perimeter reinforcement of #3 rebar. 
(6)  When footstones are used, such stones shall be aesthetically complimentary to the monuments on the space; shall not be of greater size than 12 inches by 24 inches; and shall be placed only under the direction of the cemetery supervisor. 
(7)  Urns placed on spaces will be of bronze, granite, marble or smooth-finish concrete and such urns will be kept planted at all times. 
(8)  The cemetery supervisor may remove, without notice, dead or dormant plants, faded or out-of-season artificial flowers or improper containers, as necessary. 
(9)  A nameplate for a columbarium niche must be purchased through the city to provide for uniformity and consistency on the columbarium. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-4; Ord. No. 86-23, § 4, 4-8-1986; Ord. No. 2001-51, § 2, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 16-6. - Sale of spaces. 
(a)  Spaces may only be sold to and purchased by residents of the city or persons who own a fee simple interest in real property within the city limits or who have previously purchased and continue to own spaces. The deed conveying the right to burial shall be issued to the purchaser by the city clerk's office. 
(b)  The cemetery supervisor shall be responsible for sales and shall keep a comprehensive records book reflecting the grantee, section, block, space, grave site number and monetary consideration paid for same. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-5; Ord. No. 86-23, § 5, 4-8-1986) 
Sec. 16-7. - Transfer of right to burial prohibited. 
(a)  Only the remains of the grantee or other person designated in the deed may be buried in a space. The grantee may not transfer the deed; however, the grantee may change the designation of a space by filing a written request with the city clerk. 
(b)  If a grantee determines that he no longer wishes to use the space, he may offer the space for sale back to the city. The city will repurchase a space at the following rate: 
(1)  Full adult space ..... $400.00 
(2)  One-third space for cremated remains .....  135.00 
(c)  The purchase price for a one-third space for cremated remains will apply only if the deed was issued for a "one-third" space. 
(d)  If a grantee has died and elected to not use his space, a representative of the estate of the deceased grantee may offer the space for sale back to the city or designate the space for someone else. A representative of a deceased grantee making such a request will be required to provide the following: 
(1)  Legal document showing the person is the court ordered representative of the deceased; 
(2)  Copy of a will that has been admitted to probate showing that the person making the request is the legal representative; or 
(3)  Notarized affidavit from the person making the request stating that he is the personal representative of the deceased and, as such, has the authority to sell the space to the city or designate the space. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-6; Ord. No. 86-23, § 6, 4-8-1986; Ord. No. 96-41, § 3, 7-23-1996) 
Sec. 16-8. - Cost of spaces. 
(a)  Full adult space. The purchase price of one full adult space is $1,200.00. At the time of purchase, a full adult space may be designated for either one body or six cremated remains. A maximum of six cremated remains shall be allowed per adult space. 
(b)  Second rite of interment. The grantee or legal representative of a grantee of one full adult space may consent to have one cremated remains buried in the same space at an additional cost of $500.00. 
(c)  Cremated remains space. The purchase price of a one-third space for cremated remains is $500.00. A one-third space may only be sold if there is something unique, which prohibits the full space from being sold. For example, a tree or utility line is located on a portion of the space. The grantee or legal representative of a grantee of a cremated remains space may consent to have one additional cremated remains buried in the same space at an additional cost of $500.00. A maximum of two cremated remains shall be allowed per cremated remains space. 
(d)  Columbarium niche. If a niche is for one cremated remains, the purchase price is $1,000.00 plus $200.00 for one nameplate. If a niche is for two cremated remains, the purchase price is $1,000.00 plus $400.00 for two nameplates. 
(e)  Perpetual care. Of the $1,200.00 cost for a full adult space, $600.00 will be used for funding perpetual care; of the $500.00 cost for one-third of a space for cremated remains, $250.00 will be used to fund perpetual care; and of the $1,000.00 cost for a columbarium niche, $500.00 will be used to fund perpetual care. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-7; Ord. No. 86-23, § 7, 4-8-1986; Ord. No. 96-41, § 4, 7-23-1996; Ord. No. 2004-18, § 2, 3-23-2004) 
Sec. 16-9. - Use of proceeds from sale of spaces. 
    Revenues designated from the sale of spaces shall be deposited in the city's general fund. Revenues designated for perpetual care shall be placed in trust, provided that the interest earned on such funds shall be deposited to the city's general fund. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-8; Ord. No. 86-23, § 8, 4-8-1986) 
Sec. 16-10. - Graves and vaults. 
    No burials above ground in vaults shall be permitted. Grave locations must be approved by the cemetery supervisor. The grave must be dug to a depth that leaves 18 inches of soil over the top of the vault. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-9; Ord. No. 86-23, § 9, 4-8-1986; Ord. No. 2001-51, § 3, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 16-11. - Burials and removals. 
(a)  No final disposition shall be made in the cemeteries without the purchase of a space or applicable portion thereof, and a securing of a burial permit issued by the cemetery supervisor. Funeral establishments and direct disposal establishments shall be responsible for arranging the opening and closing of graves at their expense. No graves may be dug or opened and no bodies may be removed without attendance by the cemetery supervisor or his designated representative. 
(b)  Removal of excess soil after burial or the filling of the gravesite with additional soil after settling shall be the responsibility of the funeral establishment/direct disposal establishment. Any excess soil must be removed the same day as the burial; and any filling needed as a result of settling must be accomplished within five days after burial. Upon failure to remove excess soil or to fill as required above, the cemetery supervisor may cause same to be accomplished with the costs thereof charged to the funeral establishment/direct disposal establishment, which cost shall be immediately due and payable. 
(c)  Any additional city services required due to failure by the applicable funeral establishment/direct disposal establishment to abide by this chapter, and any reasonable rules and regulations promulgated to effectuate this chapter, shall be charged to the funeral establishment/direct disposal establishment and be immediately due and payable. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-10; Ord. No. 86-23, § 10, 4-8-1986; Ord. No. 2001-51, § 4, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 16-12. - Easements. 
    An easement is reserved along all lot lines for installation of water lines as needed. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-11; Ord. No. 86-23, § 11, 4-8-1986) 
Sec. 16-13. - Rules and regulations. 
    The cemetery supervisor is hereby authorized to establish rules and regulations as may be necessary to provide for the effective and efficient operation of the cemeteries and to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public. Such rules and regulations shall be subject to the approval of the city manager, and shall not be inconsistent with any provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-13; Ord. No. 86-23, § 13, 4-8-1986) 
Sec. 16-14. - Deeds. 
    The form for the cemetery deed of burial right is available from the city clerk. All deeds to spaces in the cemeteries are hereby declared to incorporate and shall be subject to all rules, regulations and conditions contained in this chapter. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-14; Ord. No. 86-23, § 14, 4-8-1986; Ord. No. 96-41, § 6, 7-23-1996) 
Sec. 16-15. - Penalties and enforcement. 
    Any person, firm, corporation, business entity or any other entity violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be referred to the city code enforcement board for disposition. Upon the finding of a violation by the board, any funeral establishment or direct disposal establishment shall automatically be denied further access to the cemeteries until compliance has been established. 
(Code 1984, § 8.5-15; Ord. No. 86-23, § 15, 4-8-1986; Ord. No. 2001-51, § 5, 10-9-2001) 
Chapter 18 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Civil defense, rescue and disaster relief, § 3.23. 
State Law reference- Emergency management, F.S. § 252.31 et seq.; declaration of emergency and designation of local authority, F.S. §§ 870.041-870.048. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1-18-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency management, F.S. § 252.31 et seq. 

Sec. 18-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-56, § 1, adopted Aug. 23, 2016, repealed former § 18-19 which pertained to declaration of state of emergency, and derived from the 1980 Code, § 22-129; the 1984 Code, § 9-2; and Ord. No. 2002-55, § 1, adopted Aug. 13, 2002. 
Sec. 18-20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-56, § 1, adopted Aug. 23, 2016, repealed former § 18-20 which pertained to emergency measures; authority of city manager to declare, and derived from the 1980 Code, § 22-130; the 1984 Code, § 9-3; and Ord. No. 2002-55, § 1, adopted Aug. 13, 2002. 
Sec. 18-21. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-56, § 1, adopted Aug. 23, 2016, repealed former § 18-21 which pertained to designation of public shelters, and derived from the 1980 Code, § 22-134; the 1984 Code, § 9-7; and Ord. No. 2002-55, § 1, adopted Aug. 13, 2002. 
Sec. 18-22. - Intent; objectives. 
    Natural, technological and manmade disasters and other emergencies that occur in the city may threaten the life, health and safety of its people, damage and destroy property, disrupt services and everyday business and recreational activities and impede economic growth and development within the city. A state of emergency may be declared in emergencies to activate the emergency mitigation, response and recovery aspects of the state, local and interjurisdictional emergency management plans. It is the intent of this article to designate the city official authorized to declare a state of emergency and to provide the city manager with the authority to manage the event and expedite the recovery of the community affected by a disaster or other emergency. 
(Ord. No. 2016-56, § 2, 8-23-2016) 
Sec. 18-23. - Declaration of state of emergency based upon substantial harm. 
(a)  Intent. The purpose of the declaration of a state of emergency based upon substantial harm is to meet the dangers presented to the city and its people by emergencies pursuant to the terms of F.S. ch. 252, whether such emergency is declared by the city official or the governor of the state. 
(b)  Declaration by city official. The city manager, or in the city manager's absence the deputy city manager, is designated the city official that may declare that a state of emergency based upon substantial harm exists within the city or any part or parts thereof pursuant to F.S. § 252.38. The city official may declare that a state of emergency based upon substantial harm exists whenever the city official determines that: 
(1)  An emergency has been created by an occurrence whether natural, technological or manmade, that results in substantial injury or harm to the population or substantial damage to or loss of property; or 
(2)  An emergency has been created by an imminent threat of an occurrence, whether natural, technological or manmade, which may result in substantial injury or harm to the population or substantial damage to or loss of property. 
(c)  In the event of an emergency based upon substantial harm, the city manager shall take necessary steps for the protection of life and property and for the preservation of public peace and safety within the city, whether such emergency is declared by the city official or the governor of the state. A declaration of a state of emergency based upon substantial harm, whether declared by the city official pursuant to F.S. § 252.38 or the governor pursuant to F.S. § 252.36, shall activate the emergency plans to the extent applicable to the city and the nature of the emergency. 
(d)  Emergency measures. Upon declaration of a state of emergency based upon substantial harm, whether declared by the city official pursuant to F.S. § 252.38 or the governor pursuant to F.S. § 252.36, the following emergency measures apply: 
(1)  The city manager is authorized to order any appropriate emergency measures as set forth in section 18-26 of this article. 
(2)  If the declaration is made by the governor, the automatic tolling and extension of permits and other authorizations is effective within the geographic area for which the declaration applies as set forth in F.S. § 252.363. Such tolling includes but is not limited to extensions of development orders and building permits. Nothing herein is intended to limit any requirement to maintain and secure property. 
(e)  Duration and termination of city official declaration. A state of emergency based upon substantial harm declared by a city official pursuant to this section shall commence immediately upon the declaration of the emergency and shall terminate automatically after seven days. The city official may extend the duration of the state of emergency in increments of up to seven days. The city official may establish an early termination of the emergency period declared or extended by the city official. 
(f)  Nothing herein shall prohibit the concurrent declaration of a state of emergency based upon civil unrest pursuant to section 18-24 of City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2016-56, § 2, 8-23-2016) 
Sec. 18-24. - Declaration of state of emergency based upon civil unrest. 
(a)  Intent. The purpose of the declaration of a state of emergency based upon civil unrest is to protect citizens from a clear and present danger of violence pursuant to the terms of F.S. §§ 870.041-870.045. 
(b)  Declaration. The mayor, or in the mayor's absence the chief of police, is designated the city official that may declare that a state of emergency based upon civil unrest exists within the city or any part or parts thereof whenever said city official determines that: 
(1)  There has been an act of violence or a flagrant and substantial defiance of or resistance to, a lawful exercise of public authority; and 
(2)  Partly on account thereof, there is reason to believe that there exists (i) a clear and present danger of a riot or other general public disorder, (ii) widespread disobedience of the law, and (iii) substantial injury to persons or to property, all of which constitutes an imminent threat to public peace or order and to the general welfare of the city or a part or parts thereof. 
(c)  Emergency measures. Upon a declaration of a state of emergency based upon civil unrest pursuant to this section, the following emergency measures apply: 
(1)  The automatic restrictions regarding guns, firearms and ammunition as set forth in F.S. § 870.044 shall be effective throughout the entire city. 
(2)  The city manager is authorized to order any appropriate emergency measures as set forth in section 18-26 of this article. 
(d)  Duration and termination. A state of emergency based upon civil unrest declared pursuant to this section shall commence immediately upon the declaration of the emergency and shall terminate automatically after 72 hours. The city council may extend the 72-hour time limit by an appropriate resolution. If the city council fails to extend the state of emergency, the state of emergency is terminated after 72 hours. Either the city official or the city council may establish an early termination of any emergency period. 
(e)  Nothing herein shall prohibit the concurrent declaration of a state of emergency based upon substantial harm pursuant to section 18-23 of City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2016-56, § 2, 8-23-2016) 
Sec. 18-25. - Notice. 
(a)  Any emergency declaration or order issued under this article shall become effective immediately upon issuance and shall be reduced to writing as soon as practicable thereafter. Such emergency declaration and orders, upon being reduced to writing, shall state the nature of the emergency, the length of time such orders are to remain in effect, and shall call attention to the penalty for violation thereof. As soon as feasible after issuance, such emergency declaration and orders shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  As promptly as practical after issuance, such emergency declaration and orders shall be delivered to appropriate news media for publication and published by other appropriate means. 
(c)  The city manager shall report to the city council on actions authorized and taken under the provisions of this chapter in response to a declared state of emergency. 
(Ord. No. 2016-56, § 2, 8-23-2016) 
Sec. 18-26. - Other discretionary emergency measures of the city manager. 
(a)  The powers set forth herein may be exercised by the city manager after a state of emergency has been declared as referenced in section 18-23 or section 18-24 of City Code. 
(b)  Unless specifically limited by the declaration of the appropriate city official or the governor, as the case may be, said powers may be utilized and the city manager shall be authorized to issue, amend and rescind emergency orders in the interest of public safety and welfare, and, when appropriate or practicable, in coordination with the state and county, effective within the entire city or within such geographical areas as may be designated by the city manager. Said orders and powers include but are not limited to the following subjects: 
(1)  Governor's powers. Upon a declaration of a state of emergency by the governor based upon substantial harm as authorized pursuant to F.S. § 252.36, and subject thereto, the city manager is authorized to act on behalf of the city to effectuate and enforce said order of the governor, including but not limited to those emergency measures generally described as follows: 
a.  To suspend provisions of regulatory statute and related ordinances; 
b.  To utilize available state and city resources; 
c.  To direct and compel the evacuation of the population; 
d.  To control ingress and egress to and from an emergency area and the movement and occupation by persons within the area; 
e.  To suspend or limit the sale, dispensing, or transportation of alcoholic beverages, firearms, explosives and combustibles; 
f.  To make provision for temporary housing; 
g.  To limit utility services; 
h.  To establish a curfew; and 
i.  To extend the hours of solid waste disposal. 
(2)  Statutory powers. 
a.  Upon a declaration of a state of emergency based upon substantial harm, whether declared by the city official pursuant to F.S. § 252.38 or by the governor pursuant to F.S. § 252.36, and subject thereto, the city manager is authorized to order the discretionary emergency measures authorized to the city as set forth in F.S. § 252.38(3). Such orders shall have the force and effect of law. The powers include but are not limited to those generally described as follows: 
1.  To request state assistance; 
2.  To invoke emergency-related mutual-aid assistance; and 
3.  To waive the procedures and formalities otherwise required by state or local law pertaining to the following: 
¦ Performance of public work; 
¦ Entering into contracts; 
¦ Incurring obligations; 
¦ Employment of permanent and temporary workers; 
¦ Utilization of volunteer workers; 
¦ Rental of equipment; 
¦ Acquisition and distribution of supplies, materials and facilities; and 
¦ Appropriation and expenditure of public funds. 
b.  Upon a declaration of a state of emergency based upon civil unrest, the city manager is authorized to order the discretionary emergency measures during the period of the state of emergency as set forth in F.S. § 870.045, and generally described as follows: 
1.  To establish curfew; 
2.  To prohibit sale or distribution of alcohol; 
3.  To prohibit possession of alcohol in a public place; 
4.  To authorize closing of certain public places; 
5.  To prohibit sale or transfer of gas or other flammable or combustible liquids; and 
6.  To prohibit possession of portable containers of gas or other flammable or combustible liquids in a public place. 
(3)  Power to suspend city ordinances. Upon any declaration of a state of emergency, whether declared by the city official pursuant to F.S. § 252.38 or F.S. § 870.043 or by the governor pursuant to F.S. § 252.36, and subject thereto, the city manager is authorized to order discretionary emergency measures to suspend provisions of City Code as follows: 
a.  During the declared state of emergency, to require that portable signs, flags, and banners be removed during an emergency and providing for the circumstances for the aforesaid removal; 
b.  To temporarily provide for the waiving of fees and/deposits for city services or applications for building permits, comprehensive plan amendments, or land development regulations or permits; 
c.  During the declared state of emergency, to impose water or waste water use restrictions; 
d.  To temporarily suspend purchasing requirements set forth in chapter 2, article VI of this Code; 
e.  To provide a grace period for the replacement of fencing, vegetation and/or visual barriers; 
f.  To authorize temporary living quarters, including tents and recreational vehicles; 
g.  To remedy the condition of private streets, roads, and roadways, and other private property pursuant to section 18-27 of City Code; 
h.  To issue emergency regulations necessary for the protection of life and property, establishment of public order and control of adverse conditions affecting public welfare; 
i.  To provide for the health and safety of persons and property, including emergency assistance to the victims of any emergency. 
(4)  Power to suspend city policies and procedures. Upon any declaration of a state of emergency, whether declared by the city official pursuant to F.S. § 252.38 or F.S. § 870.043 or by the governor pursuant to F.S. § 252.36, and subject thereto, the city manager is authorized to waive the procedures and formalities otherwise required by City Code and administrative procedures as appropriate to expedite the recovery of the community affected by a disaster or other emergency, including but not limited to those emergency measures generally described as follows: 
a.  To suspend or temporarily modify the personnel policies and procedures previously adopted by city council; 
b.  To suspend or temporarily modify the administrative policies and procedures previously approved by the city manager, including the purchasing manual, check cashing for employees, city council policies. 
(c)  The city manager is authorized to delegate such powers as he may deem prudent. 
(d)  Nothing in this chapter shall be read to limit the authority of the city manager to take other emergency measures not set forth herein, including but not limited to abatement of any nuisance existing on public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 2016-56, § 2, 8-23-2016) 
Sec. 18-27. - Clearing of debris from private streets, roads, and roadways, and other private property after a declared emergency or disaster. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Debris means displaced, broken, or discarded building/construction materials, garbage, tree limbs, vegetative matter, spoiled or ruined household goods or materials, dead fish, or marine flotsam and jetsam. 
    Private property means all property that is not owned or controlled by a governmental entity. 
    Private streets, roads and roadways means the rights-of-way as well as the improved surface that are not owned or controlled by a governmental entity and which provide access to residential and commercial areas. 
(b)  The city may remove debris from private streets, roads, and roadways, and other private property when such debris is determined to be a public nuisance that poses an immediate threat and imperils the health, safety and welfare of the community. The city manager shall determine whether there is a sufficient immediate threat to the public health, safety, and welfare. The city council may adopt a resolution setting forth standards to determine whether there is a sufficient immediate threat to the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(c)  Commercial or other specific areas will be cleared if, in the opinion of the city manager, the clearance will significantly and substantially aid the city's recovery operations or significantly and substantially aid the health, safety, or welfare of the residents of the city. 
(d)  Prior to the city removing debris as contemplated herein from private property, when reasonably possible the city manager, or said manager's designee, shall contact the private property owner and have the property owner agree to indemnify and hold harmless to the maximum extent provided by law, the federal, state and local government and all contractors, employees, officers and agents of the city, connected with the rendering of such service. 
(e)  Nothing herein shall preclude a first response by the city to clear debris from all roadways (both public and private) as necessary for the movement of emergency vehicles including police, fire and ambulance within the first 72 hours after a declared emergency or a disaster. 
(f)  Nothing herein shall require the city to remove debris from private property as defined above except where the severity of the situation is of such magnitude or the debris is so widespread that it is determined by the city council to be a significant immediate serious threat to the health, safety and welfare of the city and in the overriding public interest of the city to remove debris from such areas. 
(Ord. No. 2016-56, § 2, 8-23-2016)

Sec. 20-41. - Definitions. 
    The definitions of terms as provided in F.S. § 163.340 are hereby adopted by reference whenever used or referred to in this article. 
(Code 1980, § 2-91; Code 1984, § 10-16) 
State Law reference- Definitions, F.S. § 163.340. 
Sec. 20-42. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to F.S. § 163.357, the city council hereby declares itself to be the community redevelopment agency in the city. All rights, powers, duties, privileges and immunities vested in a community redevelopment agency by F.S. § 163.330 et seq., are hereby vested in the city council subject to all responsibilities and liabilities imposed or incurred. 
(Code 1980, § 2-92; Code 1984, § 10-17) 
Sec. 20-43. - Exercise of powers. 
(a)  In the exercise of rights, powers, duties, privileges and immunities of a community redevelopment agency, the city council hereby authorizes, assigns, permits and directs its city manager, and all future incumbents to that office, to perform the following functions on behalf of the agency: 
(1)  Employ any agents or employees, permanent or temporary, as may be required, and determined their qualifications, duties and compensation; subject to the limitations on funding as specified in subsection (b) of this section. The city manager shall assign employees of the city to provide services required by the community redevelopment agency. 
(2)  Through the Melbourne Downtown Redevelopment Committee prepare community redevelopment plans and modifications thereof for community redevelopment projects in the designated community redevelopment areas. 
(3)  Work with private investors, other governmental agencies, its agents and consultants, employees and community groups and interests to foster the development and redevelopment of city properties identified in Resolution No. 775. 
(4)  Exercise the powers enumerated in F.S. §§ 163.370, 163.380 and 163.385, except as they may be limited by subsection (b) of this section. 
(5)  Comply with the reporting requirements and other requirements imposed on community redevelopment agencies by F.S. ch. 163, pt. III. 
(b)  The city council shall have sole power to: 
(1)  Determine an area to be a slum or blighted area, or combination thereof, to designate such area as appropriate for a community redevelopment project, and to hold any public hearings required with respect thereto. 
(2)  Grant final approval to community redevelopment plans and modifications thereof, after receiving recommendation of the city manager and the Melbourne Downtown Redevelopment Committee. 
(3)  Authorize the issuance of revenue bonds as set forth in F.S. § 163.385. 
(4)  Approve the acquisition, demolition, removal or disposition of property as provided in F.S. § 163.370 and the power to assume the responsibility to bear loss as provided in F.S. § 163.370. 
(5)  Appropriate funds deemed necessary for the administration expense and overhead of the agency. 
(6)  Establish a redevelopment trust fund as provided in F.S. § 163.387. 
(Code 1980, § 2-93; Code 1984, § 10-18) 
Sec. 20-44. - Redevelopment trust fund. 
(a)  Establishment of trust fund. There is hereby created the city community redevelopment trust fund pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 163.387 for the purpose of accepting and disbursing fees, appropriations, gifts, grants, and awards of monies made to the city, for the purpose of funding redevelopment projects as contemplated by the Community Redevelopment Act of 1969 as amended. 
(b)  Term of existence. The city community redevelopment trust fund shall be self-perpetuating and sustaining from year to year, unless specifically terminated by the city council; provided, however, that the downtown, northern expansion, and southern expansion areas of the Downtown Melbourne Community Redevelopment District, as described in section 20-40, shall terminate as the Downtown Melbourne Community Redevelopment Area and the Downtown Melbourne Community Redevelopment Agency at 11:59 p.m. on December 31, 2042. 
(c)  Trust assets. All trust assets shall be allocated, extended, utilized and disbursed in accordance with the Community Redevelopment Act of 1969, as amended, as F.S. ch. 163, pt. III (F.S. § 163.330 et seq.), the Act being hereby specifically incorporated by reference. 
(d)  Trust funding. Upon the enactment of this section, each taxing authority operating within the community redevelopment project area as designated by the city council, with the exception of school districts, shall annually appropriate to the trust fund herein created a sum, which is no less than the annual increment of ad valorem tax revenues accruing to the taxing authority. The annual tax increment shall be the difference between: 
(1)  The amount of ad valorem taxes levied each year by each taxing authority except school districts and other governmental agencies as described in F.S. § 163.387(2)(c), and exclusive of any amount from any debt service millage, on taxable real property contained within the geographic boundaries of the community redevelopment project area; and 
(2)  The amount of ad valorem taxes which would have been produced by the rate upon which the tax is levied each year by or for each taxing authority except school districts and other governmental agencies as described in F.S. § 163.387(2)(c), and exclusive of any amount from any debt service millage, upon the total of the assessed value of the taxable property in the community redevelopment project area involved as shown upon the most recent assessment roll used in connection with the taxation of such property by each taxing authority prior to the effective date of the ordinance approving the community redevelopment plan, or its expansion area as applicable, which governs the project involved. 
(e)  Disbursal of assets. No funds shall be disbursed from the city community redevelopment trust fund unless approved by the city council. The funds of the city community redevelopment trust fund shall be utilized in accordance with the provisions of the Community Redevelopment Act of 1969, as amended and embodied in F.S. ch. 163, pt. III (F.S. § 163.330 et seq.), and in accordance with community redevelopment plans as approved by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-94; Code 1984, § 10-19; Ord. No. 2006-23, § 7, 5-23-2006; Ord. No. 2011-36, § 3, 8-30-2011; Ord. No. 2016-52, § 1, 8-9-2016) 
State Law reference- Redevelopment trust fund, F.S. § 163.387. 
Secs. 20-45-20-62. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DOWNTOWN REDEVELOPMENT PLAN[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Community redevelopment plans, F.S. § 163.360. 

Sec. 20-63. - Findings. 
    In accordance with F.S. § 163.360, the city council makes the following findings with respect to the community redevelopment plan for the Melbourne Downtown Redevelopment Area: 
(1)  That the plan does not contemplate the relocation of any families in that the implementation of the plan will not cause any families to be displaced within the community redevelopment area. 
(2)  That the community redevelopment plan conforms to the general plan of the county and the city as a whole. 
(3)  That the community redevelopment plan gives due consideration to the provision of adequate park and recreational areas and facilities that may be desirable for neighborhood improvement, with special consideration for the health, safety and welfare of children residing in the general vicinity of the site covered by the plan. 
(4)  The community redevelopment plan will afford maximum opportunity consistent with the sound needs of the city as a whole for the rehabilitation or the redevelopment of the Melbourne Downtown Community Redevelopment Area by private enterprise. 
(Code 1980, § 11-3.2; Code 1984, § 10-101; Ord. No. 91-43, § 1, 8-27-1991; Ord. No. 92-07, § 1, 2-11-1992; Ord. No. 2001-11, § 1, 2-27-2001; Ord. No. 2003-97, § 1, 12-9-2003; Ord. No. 2006-23, § 8, 5-23-2006; Ord. No. 2007-15, § 1, 4-10-2007; Ord. No. 2011-36, § 3, 8-30-2011; Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 7-10-2012)
