(c)  The frequencies used, 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz, are generally accepted as being within the range of human hearing, but actually the human ear is most sensitive in the range of 20 Hz to 10,000 Hz. Because there is an almost infinite number of frequencies in this range, the A-weighted meter uses a geometric mean or center frequency to represent an octave frequency range. 
(d)  For any source of sound which emits a pure tone, the sound level limits set forth in Table 2 shall be reduced by five dB (A-wt). 
(e)  Impulsive sound shall not exceed the maximum sound levels contained in Table 5 without a variance as described in section 26-29. 
(Code 1984, § 20-27; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 2, 7-23-2002; Ord. No. 2010-50, § 2, 10-12-2010) 
Sec. 26-26. - Measurement of sound. 
    To show compliance with the sound level limits in this article, the sound shall be measured based on the following: 
(1)  Sound levels shall be measured on a sound level meter. 
(2)  The sound level shall be measured at a distance no closer to the point from which the sound in question is emanating than the property line of the real property from which the sound is emanating. 
(3)  A measurement period shall not be less than five minutes in duration. 
(4)  The sound being measured shall be representative of the sound which instigated the complaint. 
(5)  A measurement shall be recorded so as to secure and ensure an accurate representation of the sound. 
(6)  A measurement should be taken at approximately five feet above the ground or water surface away from any obstruction or reflecting surface. 
(7)  When necessary, a microphone windscreen shall be required to avoid wind noise biasing of a measurement. 
(8)  All manufacturer's directions on the operation of the sound level meter shall be followed (e.g., proper microphone angle). 
(9)  All sound level meters used for measurement shall be in conformance with ANSI section 1.4-1983. 
(10)  All octave and third octave band filter sets of the sound level meter shall be in conformance with ANSI S1.11-1976. 
(11)  Calibration of all instruments, components, and attachments shall conform to the latest ANSI standards. 
(12)  Measurements of sound shall be made by individuals trained in a noise measurement program approved by the city. 
(13)  When a code enforcement officer directs a person to briefly discontinue a noise that the code enforcement officer is measuring, it shall be a violation of this Code if that person fails to comply with the direction of the code enforcement officer. 
(Code 1984, § 20-28; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 2, 7-23-2002; Ord. No. 2010-50, § 3, 10-12-2010) 
Sec. 26-27. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of sections 26-28 and 26-29, no person shall produce, cause to be produced, or allow to be produced, by any means, any sound within any private or public property, including a right-of-way, which sound, when measured pursuant to section 26-26, exceeds the applicable sound level limits set forth in section 26-25. 
(b)  Subject to the provisions of sections 26-28 and 26-29, no person shall produce, cause to be produced, or allow to be produced, by any means, any vibration which is discernible at or beyond the property line of the parcel or lot from which the vibration is emanating. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 26-25 and 26-26, no person shall produce, cause to be produced, or allow to be produced, by any means, any sound which, because of its volume level, duration and character, annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, health, peace or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following day, unless such person is exempted from application of this article under section 26-28, or unless such person has obtained a variance as provided in section 26-29. 
(Code 1984, § 20-29; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 2, 7-23-2002) 
Sec. 26-28. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of section 26-27 shall not apply to the following sounds or vibrations: 
(1)  Railway locomotive or car activity conducted in accordance with federal laws and regulations. 
(2)  Household or farming tools, appliances and equipment meeting applicable manufacturer's specifications as to sound, from 7:00 a.m. until 10:00 p.m. 
(3)  Aircraft and airport activity conducted in accordance with federal laws and regulations. 
(4)  Law enforcement activities, including training. 
(5)  Emergency signals during emergencies. 
(6)  Emergency testing between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(7)  Motor vehicles operating on a public right-of-way subject to F.S. §§ 316.293 and 403.415, and applicable federal criteria. 
(8)  Refuse collection vehicles not exceeding 86 dB (A-wt). 
(9)  Construction activities for which a governmental entity has issued a development permit, as defined in F.S. § 163.3164, provided such activity occurs between 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(10)  Scheduled organized athletic contests and practices, including marching band practices, at a publicly owned or operated facility. 
(11)  The supervised public display of fireworks by fair associations, amusement parks, and other organizations or groups of individuals or other lawful use of fireworks. 
(12)  Any motor vehicle engaged in a professional or amateur sanctioned, competitive sports event for which admission or entry fee is charged, or practice or time trials for such event, at a facility being used for such purposes. 
(13)  Lawn mowing or maintenance activities conducted by the city. 
(14)  Emergency power generators operated at any time during periods of power outage caused by natural disaster, including storm, hurricane, flood, tidal wave, tornado or other disaster, resulting in a loss of electrical service. 
(15)  Operation or amplification of sound produced by a radio, tape player, or other mechanical soundmaking device or instrument within a motor vehicle on a street or highway as prohibited by F.S. § 316.3045, and further defined in Rule 15B-13.001, Florida Administrative Code. Nothing in this article shall be construed as limiting or curtailing the authority of law enforcement officers to enforce section F.S. § 316.3045, under the "plainly audible" standard as identified and defined therein. However, this article shall apply to motor vehicles used for business or political purposes, which, in the normal course of conducting such business, use soundmaking devices. 
(16)  Any matters specifically preempted by F.S. § 790.33. 
(Code 1984, § 20-30; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 2, 7-23-2002; Ord. No. 2004-76, § 1, 10-12-2004; Ord. No. 2011-46, § 6, 9-20-2011) 
Sec. 26-29. - Variances. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by application of this article may submit an application for a variance to the city's board of adjustment in accordance with the procedures in appendix B, article IX, section 7. 
(b)  All variance applications must demonstrate that bringing the sound or vibration for which the variance is sought into compliance with this article would constitute a practical difficulty for the applicant, community, or for other persons. At a minimum, the applicant shall provide the following information: 
(1)  Identification of applicant. 
(2)  Applicant's mailing address. 
(3)  Legal description of property from which the sound or vibration will emanate. 
(4)  Description of source of sound or vibration. 
(5)  Description of sound or vibration. 
(6)  Facts and reasons justifying a variance. 
(c)  At the hearing of the variance application, the applicant may submit any relevant evidence or testimony, including evidence or testimony demonstrating the applicant's efforts to reduce, contain or baffle the noise or vibration. In deciding whether to grant or deny the application, the board of adjustment shall balance the practical difficulty that will result to the applicant, the community, and other persons if the variance is not granted, versus the adverse impact on the health, safety, and general welfare of persons if the variance is granted. If the practical difficulty to the applicant, community and other persons outweighs the adverse impact on the health, safety or welfare of the public, the variance may be granted. No variance shall be granted unless it is the minimum variance that will make possible the applicant's reasonable use of the property from which the sound or vibration will emanate. In granting or denying a variance application, the board shall state in writing on the application the reasons for its decision. If its decision is to grant the application, the board shall set forth the terms and conditions of the variance, including the effective date of the variance, the period of the variance, the time of day the variance may be used, the location where the sound or vibration may be created or caused, and the sound or vibration level limits. 
(d)  No variance may exceed 365 days. 
(Code 1984, § 20-31; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 2, 7-23-2002; Ord. No. 2010-50, § 4, 10-12-2010) 
Sec. 26-30. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The police department or any other authorized code enforcement officer is empowered to investigate any situation where a person is alleged to be violating section 26-27. 
(b)  If a police officer or any other authorized code enforcement officer encounters a circumstance which reasonably indicates that a person is violating section 26-27(a), the officer shall measure the sound pressure level with a sound level meter to determine if the sound pressure level exceeds the level permitted under section 26-25. If the results of the test indicate that a violation of section 26-27(a) is occurring or has occurred in the presence of such an officer, the officer is thereupon authorized to issue a warning directing the person producing the sound to come into compliance with the sound pressure levels permitted under section 26-25. Failing immediate compliance, the officer is authorized to issue a notice to appear to, or arrest, the person producing, causing to be produced, or allowing to be produced, the sound. 
(c)  If a police officer or any other authorized code enforcement officer encounters a circumstance which reasonably indicates that a person is violating section 26-27(b), the officer shall determine if the vibration is discernible at or beyond the property line from which the vibration is emanating. If the officer determines that a violation of section 26-27(b) is occurring or has occurred in the presence of the officer, the officer is thereupon authorized to issue a warning directing the person producing the vibration to come into compliance with section 26-27(b). Failing immediate compliance, the officer is thereupon authorize to issue a notice to appear to, or arrest, the person producing, causing to be produced, or allowing to be produced, the vibration. 
(d)  If a police officer or any other authorized code enforcement officer encounters a circumstance which reasonably indicates that a person is violating section 26-27(a), (b) or (c) and that officer is unable to measure the sound or vibration in accordance with section 26-26, then that officer shall determine whether the sound or vibration being produced is of sufficient volume level, duration and character so as to annoy, disturb, injure or endanger the comfort, health, peace or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities. If the officer determines that a violation of section 26-27 is occurring or has occurred in the presence of the officer, the officer is thereupon authorized to issue a warning directing the person producing the sound or vibration to reduce the volume level, duration, and character of the sound and/or vibration to comply with section 26-27. Failing immediate compliance, the officer is thereupon authorized to issue a notice to appear, or arrest, or schedule a hearing before the code enforcement board, to the person producing, causing to be produced, or allowing to be produced, the sound or vibration. 
(Code 1984, § 20-32; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 2, 7-23-2002) 
Sec. 26-31. - Penalty. 
    A violation of section 26-27 shall be punished as provided in section 1-14, or F.S. ch. 162. 
(Code 1984, § 20-33; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 2, 7-23-2002) 
Sec. 26-32. - Other remedies. 
    The city council or any substantially affected person may bring suit in the circuit court of the county to restrain, enjoin or otherwise prevent the violation of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 20-34; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 2, 7-23-2002) 
Sec. 26-33. - Administration. 
    The city council may adopt such resolutions as are necessary to effectively administer this article. 
(Code 1984, § 20-35; Ord. No. 2002-52, § 2, 7-23-2002) 
Secs. 26-34-26-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARD CONTROL 

Sec. 26-55. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Environmental Standard Control Ordinance of the City of Melbourne." 
(Code 1984, § 20-105; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-56. - General requirements. 
(a)  Any use established or changed to, and any building, structure or land developed, constructed or used for any permitted principal use, or any use permissible as a conditional use, or any accessory use, shall comply with all the environmental standards herein set forth for the district involved. 
(b)  If any existing use or building or other structure is extended, enlarged, or reconstructed, the environmental standards for the district involved shall apply with respect to such extended, enlarged or reconstructed portions of such use, building, or other structure. 
(Code 1984, § 20-106; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-57. - Administration and enforcement of environmental standards. 
    Intent concerning determinations involved in administration and enforcement of environmental standards include: 
(1)  Determinations necessary for administration and enforcement of environmental standards set forth herein range from those that can be made with satisfactory accuracy by a reasonable person using normal senses and no mechanical equipment to those requiring great technical competence and complex equipment for precise measurement. It is the intent of this article that: 
a.  Where determination can be made by the building official, using equipment normally available to the city or obtainable without extraordinary expense, such determinations shall be so made before notice of violation issued. 
b.  Where technical complexity or extraordinary expense makes it unreasonable for the city to maintain the personnel or equipment necessary for making difficult or unusual determinations, the cost of proving to the building official that violations have not occurred shall rest with those responsible for the said violations. 
(2)  Applicable environmental standards. If the building official finds, after making determinations in the manner set forth in this article, that there is a violation of performance standards, he shall take or cause to be taken lawful action to cause correction to within the limits set by such environmental standards. 
(Code 1984, § 20-107; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-58. - Air pollution. 
    All buildings shall be constructed and maintained in a manner that meets the requirements of F.A.C. ch. 62-204, entitled "Air Pollution Control." 
(Code 1984, § 20-108; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-59. - Odor standards. 
    All uses shall be controlled to prevent the emission of odorous gases or other matter in such quantities as to be readily detectable or to produce a public nuisance or hazard at any point as measured along the lot lines. Detailed plans for the elimination of odorous matter may be required before the issuance of a building permit. 
(Code 1984, § 20-109; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-60. - Lighting. 
(a)  Lighting spillover standard. Any use, operation or activity on a lot must be conducted, operated and situated so that light spillover onto another lot used for residential purposes does not occur in excess of one footcandle. Lighting for parks from 6:00 a.m. until 12:00 midnight, public street lighting in the right-of-way at all times and residential security lights shall be exempt from this standard. 
(b)  Lighting spillover assessment. The light source will be measured with a light meter or photometer which measures light in footcandles. Measurement for compliance will be conducted by taking a sample measurement at or beyond any common lot (whether conforming or nonconforming) line at any vertical dimension not to exceed 20 feet without any light from the light source being investigated. This measurement shall be used to determine the amount of background light occurring. The light source being investigated shall then be measured at the same location and at the same vertical dimension. The first measurement shall then be subtracted from the second measurement to determine compliance or non-compliance with the standard of one footcandle. The first and second lighting measurements referred to herein shall be taken at substantially the same time of day. 
(c)  Measurements. In obtaining the measurement, the property owner shall, at the request of the building official or his designee, turn off the light source for such time as is necessary to complete the first measurement. Failure to comply with this request shall be prima facie evidence of violation of this section by the property owner. 
(Code 1984, § 20-110; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-61. - Glare. 
(a)  Direct glare standard. No light source on private property, regardless of zoning classification, shall be permitted to produce direct glare which results in visual discomfort for a normally located viewer on property in any abutting zoning district or on any public street or highway. 
(b)  Visual discomfort definition. As used in this section, the term "visual discomfort" shall refer to the viewing of a direct light source that is producing luminance which could cause annoyance, discomfort or loss in visual performance and visibility. 
(c)  Glare prohibited. Glare shall reflect away from abutting properties and shall not produce visual discomfort on abutting properties. The city may require the property owner of the site from which the offensive light source originates to illuminate all existing lights on the site during the site visit to make this determination. A violation of the direct glare standard shall be deemed a public nuisance and a violation of Code. 
(Code 1984, § 20-111; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 2015-45, § 4, 9-8-2015) 
Sec. 26-62. - Electromagnetic radiation. 
(a)  Requirements. All uses shall be controlled to prevent any source of electromagnetic radiation which does not comply with the current regulations of the Federal Communications Commission regulations regarding such sources of electromagnetic radiation. Further, any operation in compliance with the Federal Communications Commission regulations shall not be permitted if such radiation causes an abnormal degradation in performance of other electromagnetic radiators or receptors of quality and proper design because of proximity, primary field, blanketing, spurious reradiation conducted energy in power or telephone systems or harmonic content. 
(b)  Method of measurement. For the purposes of determining the level of radiated electromagnetic interference, standard field strength measuring techniques interference transmitted or conducted by power or telephone lines, a suitable, turntable peak reading, radio frequency volt-meter shall be used. This instrument shall, by means of appropriate isolation coupling, be alternately connected from line to line and from line to ground during the measurement. 
(c)  Determination of electromagnetic interference. The determination of "abnormal degradation in performance," and "quality and property design" shall be made in accordance with good engineering practices as defined in the latest principles and standards of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers, and the Radio Manufacturers Association. In case of any conflict between the latest standards and principles of the above groups, precedence in the interpretation shall be in the following order: 
(1)  Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers; and 
(2)  Radio Manufacturers Association. 
For the purposes of determining the maximum allowable level of radiated electromagnetic interference and electromagnetic interference transmitted or conducted by power or telephone line, maximum allowable levels will be adopted by the city council upon recommendation by the city engineer. 
(Code 1984, § 20-112; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-63. - Heat and humidity. 
    All buildings shall be constructed and maintained in a manner so that any use producing humidity in the form of steam or moist air, or producing heat, shall be carried on in such a manner that steam, humidity or heat is not perceptible at any lot line. 
(Code 1984, § 20-113; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-64. - Fire and explosion. 
    Each use shall be so operated as to minimize the danger from fire and explosion and to comply with the regulations of the fire department and/or code compliance division. 
(Code 1984, § 20-114; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-65. - Radiation hazards. 
    All buildings shall be constructed and maintained in a manner which meets the requirements of F.A.C. ch. 64E-5, entitled "Control of Radiation Hazards." 
(Code 1984, § 20-115; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 26-66. - Waste. 
    All buildings shall be constructed and maintained in a manner which provides for the storage and disposal of waste in compliance with chapters 48 and 58. 
(Code 1984, § 20-116; Ord. No. 2005-122, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Secs. 26-67-26-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HIGH-PRESSURE WELL STIMULATION PROHIBITED 

Sec. 26-77. - High-pressure well stimulation prohibited. 
    No person or entity may engage in any oil or gas exploration or production that utilizes high-pressure well stimulation. As used in this section, the term "well stimulation" shall mean a well intervention, exploration, operation, or maintenance procedure performed by injecting any fluid into a rock formation in order to increase production at an oil or gas well by improving the flow of hydrocarbons from the formation into the wellbore. Well stimulation does not include routine well cleaning that does not affect the integrity of the well or the formation. 
(Ord. No. 2016-34, § 1, 6-14-2016)

ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[3] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 28-44. - Adopted. 
    The Florida Fire Prevention Code, current edition as mandated by the state legislature and administered by the Department of Financial Services, Office of the State Fire Marshal, as published by the state fire marshal's office, shall be known as the "City of Melbourne Fire Prevention Code" and is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if fully set out. 
(Code 1984, § 12-8; Ord. No. 2002-23, § 1, 4-9-2002; Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 6-14-2005) 
State Law reference- Florida Fire Prevention Code, F.S. § 633.0215. 
Sec. 28-45. - Fire prevention board of adjustment and appeals; establishment. 
    In accordance with the Florida Fire Prevention Code, section 1-8, Board of Appeals, there is hereby established a board to be called the fire prevention board of adjustment and appeals. The fire prevention board of adjustment and appeals shall be comprised of the same members as the planning and zoning board. The same guidelines established for the planning and zoning board shall govern the fire prevention board of adjustment and appeals. 
(Code 1984, § 12-9; Ord. No. 2002-23, § 1, 4-9-2002; Ord. No. 2015-45, § 5, 9-8-2015) 
Sec. 28-46. - Plan review; fire prevention safety inspection and public education training fees. 
(a)  Plan review. A plan review fee equal to 25 percent) of the value of the building permit shall be paid for the review of plans for compliance with the Melbourne Fire Prevention Code and the standards set forth in this article. Such fee shall be in addition to any building permit fee assessed for a particular permit application. Said fee shall be paid at the time of the submittal of the plans for building permit review. 
(b)  Fire prevention safety inspection and public education training fees. The following fees shall be applied to those inspections and training practices as outlined herein: 
(1)  Adult living facility/adult congregate living facility, per hour or portion thereof ..... $50.00 
(2)  Group home/community residential home, per hour or portion thereof .....  50.00 
(3)  Day care center, per hour or portion thereof .....  50.00 
(4)  Medical facility, per hour or portion thereof .....  50.00 
(5)  Other requested inspections, per hour or portion thereof .....  50.00 
(6)  Review of evacuation plans, per plan .....  50.00 
(7)  Evacuation evaluation on-site, per hour, per inspector .....  50.00 
(8)  Fire extinguisher training: 
a.  Up to 25 persons .....  50.00 
b.  Each additional 25 persons or portion thereof .....  25.00 
(9)  Fire drill .....  50.00 
(10)  Reserved. 
(11)  Code required, permit, annual, school, college, or business tax receipt, per hour or portion thereof .....  50.00 
(12)  Fire hydrant test flow, per hour, per inspector .....  50.00 
(13)  Reinspection (second or consecutive) .....  15.00 
(Code 1984, § 12-10; Ord. No. 2002-23, § 1, 4-9-2002; Ord. No. 2008-20, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 2016-50, § 2, 8-9-2016) 
Sec. 28-47. - Open fires, incinerators, and commercial fireplaces. 
    In accordance with the Florida Fire Prevention Code, the following shall apply to open fires, incinerators, and commercial fireplaces: 
(1)  Permits are required for all outdoor fires, with the exception of cooking and small recreational fires. 
(2)  Permits will be issued by the fire chief or his designee. The fire chief shall have the authority to prohibit an open fire when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such a fire hazardous. 
(3)  Prior to issuance of a permit for an open fire, an applicant must meet the conditions outlined in the Florida Fire Prevention Code. 
(Code 1984, § 12-11; Ord. No. 2002-23, § 1, 4-9-2002) 
Sec. 28-48. - Fireworks; displays, use and storage. 
    In accordance with the Florida Fire Prevention Code, Chapter 65, Explosives, Fireworks, and Model Rocketry, the following shall apply to fireworks and displays: 
(1)  Applicants for fireworks and pyrotechnical special effects are required to obtain a permit from the fire chief or his designee through the special activity permitting process outlined in chapter 2. All displays must meet the requirements of the Fire Prevention Code along with any conditions imposed by the fire department. 
(2)  Permits shall not be required for use of sparklers that are on the current approved sparkler list issued by the Florida Division of the State Fire Marshal. 
(Code 1984, § 12-12; Ord. No. 2002-23, § 1, 4-9-2002) 
Chapter 30 - FRANCHISES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRIC FRANCHISE 

Sec. 30-19. - Franchise general provisions. 
(a)  Any individual, partnership, corporation or other legal entity (the "utility") desiring to construct, maintain, install, and operate in, under, along, over, and across present and future roads, streets, alleys, bridges, easements, public rights-of-way and other public places within the city shall apply for a franchise pursuant to this article. This issuance of a franchise pursuant to this article shall allow the franchisee to install, construct, maintain and operate in accordance with the National Electrical Safety Code and the utility's customary practices with respect to construction and maintenance, electric light and power facilities, including, without limitation, conduits, poles, wires, transmission and distribution lines, substations, foundations, supports, supporting and containing structures, and all other facilities installed in conjunction with or ancillary to all of the utility's operations (in this article called "facilities"), for the purpose of supplying electricity and other directly electric-related services to the city and its successors, the inhabitants thereof, and persons beyond the limits thereof. 
(b)  A written application shall be filed with the city for: 
(1)  A grant of a new franchise; 
(2)  A renewal of a franchise; 
(3)  A modification of a franchise agreement; 
(4)  A transfer of a franchise; or 
(5)  Any other relief from the city pursuant to this article or a franchise agreement. 
(c)  Each such application shall set forth, contain, or be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the utility. 
(2)  A detailed statement of the corporate or other business entity organization of the utility, including, but not limited to, the following: 
a.  The names and residence addresses of all general partners, managers or managing members, corporate officers or other officials of the utility's legal entity. 
b.  The names, residence addresses and business addresses of all persons and entities having, controlling, or being entitled to have or control 15 percent or more of the ownership of the applicant and the respective ownership share of each such person or entity. 
c.  The names and addresses of any parent or subsidiary of the utility and of any other business entity owning or controlling in whole or in part or owned or controlled in whole or in part by the utility. 
d.  A detailed description of all previous experience of the applicant in providing utility service or related or similar services. 
e.  A detailed and complete financial statement of the utility, prepared by a certified public accountant, for the fiscal year immediately preceding the date of the application hereunder; or a letter or other acceptable evidence in writing from a responsible lending institution or funding source, addressed to both the applicant and the city, setting forth a clear statement of its intent as a lending institution or funding source to provide whatever capital shall be required by the applicant to construct and operate the proposed system in the city. 
f.  A statement identifying, by place and date, any other utility franchises awarded or pending award to the utility, its parent or subsidiary; the status of said franchises with respect to completion thereof; the total cost of completion of such systems; and the amount of utility's and its parent's or subsidiary's resources committed to the completion thereof. 
(3)  A detailed description of the proposed plan of operation of the utility, which shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  A detailed map indicating all areas proposed to be served and a proposed time schedule for the installation of all equipment necessary to become operational throughout the entire area to be served. 
b.  A statement or schedule setting forth all proposed classifications of rates and charges to customers and all rates and charges as to each of any said classifications, including installation charges, service charges, special, extraordinary, or other charges. The purchase price, terms, and nature of any optional or required equipment, device, or other thing to be offered for sale to any customer shall be described and explained in detail. 
c.  A detailed statement describing the operational standards proposed by the utility. 
(4)  A copy of the form of any proposed agreement, understanding, or other instrument proposed to be entered into between the applicant and any customer. 
(5)  A detailed statement setting forth in its entirety any and all agreements and understandings, whether formal or informal, written, oral or implied, existing or proposed to exist between the utility and any person, firm or corporation which may affect control or operation of the system contrary to this article, as amended, or franchise agreement. 
(6)  A copy of any agreement covering the franchise area, if existing between the utility and any public utility providing for the use of any facilities of the public utility, including, but not limited to, poles, lines or conduits. 
(7)  Any other reasonable information which could materially affect the granting of the franchise and requested by the city. 
(8)  For a new franchise applicant, the city council shall determine if a consultant is needed to assist in the evaluation of the franchise application. Notice of the projected consultant costs shall be provided by the city manager by certified mail prior to commencing the evaluation process. The new franchise applicant shall submit a cashier's check in the specified amount no later than five days from receipt of said notice. If multiple applications are received for same franchise area, the costs shall be pro rated among the applicants. These application processing fees are over and above any construction, inspection, permit or franchise fees. Each franchise holder filing an application for expansion of its designated franchise area shall pay such application fee. 
(9)  Each original, renewal, transfer or modification application submitted for a franchise under the provisions of this article shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the amount of $5,000.00, unless otherwise determined by resolution of the city council. The purpose of the filing fee is to defray a portion of the city's cost on processing an application. The filing fee is therefore intended to be a charge incidental to the awarding or enforcing of a franchise, and may not be deducted from the franchise fee imposed in a franchise agreement. Such application fees are in addition to any costs for consultant services described above. 
(d)  Nonexclusive franchises may be awarded by the city council for all or any portion of the city to a utility upon a finding that such award is consistent with the public interest, furthers the goal of providing efficient electrical service to all residents of the city, is consistent with any regulatory requirements of federal or state electrical service regulatory agencies, including, but not limited to the Florida Public Service Commission, and does not result in material abuse of city streets, easements and rights-of-way. 
(e)  A franchise agreement shall be negotiated by the utility, the city manager, and the city attorney for presentation to the city council for consideration. At a minimum, the franchise agreement shall include adequate insurance provisions, including comprehensive general liability, automobile liability, and workers' compensation, to protect both the utility and the city; providing for removal or abandonment of the system at the utility's expense; holding harmless and indemnifying the city from liability; providing a term of the franchise which shall be for a reasonable period of time ranging between ten and 30 years. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-71; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-20. - Location of grantee's facilities; interpretation. 
(a)  As a condition of any franchise, the utility must agree that the facilities of the utility grantee shall be installed, located, removed or relocated so as to not unreasonably interfere with traffic over the public rights-of-way or with reasonable egress from and ingress to abutting property. It is the intent of the foregoing provision that all lanes of travel shall remain accessible for use by vehicular traffic. To avoid conflicts with traffic, the location or relocation of all facilities shall be made as representatives of the city may prescribe in accordance with the city's reasonable rules and regulations, as revised, repealed, or promulgated from time to time, with reference to placing and maintaining said facilities in, under, upon, along, over and across said public rights-of-way; provided, however, that such rules or regulations: 
(1)  Shall not prohibit the exercise of the utility's right to use said public rights-of-way for reasons other than unreasonable interference with motor vehicular traffic; 
(2)  Shall not unreasonably interfere with the utility's ability to furnish reasonably sufficient, adequate, safe, and efficient electric service to all of its customers; and 
(3)  Shall not require the relocation of any of the utility's facilities installed before or after the effective date hereof in public rights-of-way unless or until widening or other work changing the configuration of the paved portion of any public right-of-way used by motor vehicles causes such installed facilities to unreasonably interfere with motor vehicular traffic. 
(b)  The city grantor shall not be liable to the grantee for any cost or expense in connection with any relocation of the utility's facilities required under subsection (a)(3) of this section, except, however, the utility shall be entitled to reimbursement of its costs from others and as may be provided by law, as such laws may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-72; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-21. - City's liability. 
    The city shall in no way be liable or responsible for any accident, personal injury, property damage or any claim or damage that may occur in the construction, installation, operation, removal, repair, relocation, or maintenance by the utility, its employees, agents, contractors, subcontractors, sublessees or licensees of any of the utility's facilities or operations, or that may occur as the result of any omission to do any of the foregoing by the grantee, its employees, agents, contractors, subcontractors, sublessees or licensees, in connection with or relation to its facilities hereunder. The acceptance of the franchise granted pursuant to a franchise agreement by the utility shall be deemed an agreement on the part of the utility to indemnify the city, its officials, employees, and agents, all in their official and personal capacities, and hold it harmless against any and all liability, loss, cost, damage or expense which may accrue to the city by reason of the negligence, default or misconduct of the utility, its agents, employees, contractors, subcontractors sub-subcontractors, laborers, any of their respective materialmen, or other third party arising from the construction, installation, operation, removal, repair, or maintenance of its facilities hereunder. The city agrees that neither it nor its officers, employees, or agents, all in their official and personal capacities, shall be indemnified to the percentage of its or their fault in an accident or other occurrence that city or its officers, employees, agents, or volunteers, all in their official and personal capacities, is responsible for in any incident for damages or injuries (including, but not limited to, injury or death) arising from the gross negligence and wanton, willful, and intentional misconduct of the grantor or its officers, employees, agent, or volunteers. For an additional $10.00 paid to the utility, and for other good and valuable consideration, the receipt of which shall be acknowledged by the utility, the utility must acknowledge that it has received sufficient consideration for its agreement to indemnify the city as set forth above. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-73; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-22. - Consideration for franchise. 
(a)  As a consideration for a franchise applied for pursuant to section 30-19, the utility shall pay to the city, commencing 90 days after the effective date hereof, and each month thereafter for the remainder of the term of the franchise agreement, an amount which, when added to the amount of all licenses, excises, fees, charges and other impositions of any kind whatsoever (except ad valorem property taxes and non-ad valorem tax assessments on property) levied or imposed by the city against the utility's property, business or operations and those of its subsidiaries during the utility's monthly billing period ending 60 days prior to each such payment must be equal to or greater than 5.9 percent of the utility's billed revenues, less actual write-offs, from sales of electrical energy within the incorporated areas of the city for the monthly billing period ending 60 days prior to each such payment. The exact franchise fee rate shall be negotiated by the city manager and city attorney and the utility. 
(b)  If during the term of this franchise, the utility or company related to the utility enters into a franchise agreement with any other municipality located in the county or within any contiguous county to the county, where the number of the utility's active electrical customers is 100,000 or less than the number of utility's active electrical customers within the city, the terms of which provide for the payment of franchise fees by the utility at a rate greater than any rate negotiated in the franchise issued by or to be issued by the city of the grantee's residential, commercial and industrial revenues, under the same terms and conditions as specified in subsection (a) of this section, the utility shall notify the city, shall negotiate and enter into an amended franchise agreement with the city in which the percentage to be used in calculating monthly payments under subsection (a) of this section shall be equal to that percentage which the utility has agreed to use as a basis for the calculation of payments to such other municipality or other local government described above. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-75; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-23. - Repeal of certain Code provision not invalidating existing franchise agreements. 
    The repeal of sections 13.5-74 and 13.5-76 through 13.5-88 of the 1984 city Code of Ordinances does not and shall not be interpreted as repealing in or otherwise terminating or invalidating the existing franchise agreement between the city and Florida Power & Light Co. ("FPL"), adopted on September 11, 2007, by Ordinance No. 2007-67, or any "side letter" of concessions by FPL. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-89; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Secs. 30-24-30-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NATURAL GAS FRANCHISE 

Sec. 30-50. - Grant of franchise. 
(a)  Any individual, partnership, corporation or other legal entity (the "utility") desiring to construct, distribute, maintain, install, and operate in, under, along, over, and across present and future public roads, streets, alleys, bridges, easements, public rights-of-way and other public places within the city shall apply for a nonexclusive right, privilege and franchise (hereinafter called "franchise") pursuant to this article before commencing service with the city and its successor and assigns. The issuance of a franchise pursuant to this article shall allow the utility to install, distribute, construct, maintain and operate, for the purpose of supplying gas to the city and its successors and the inhabitants thereof, all in accordance with the established practice with respect to such construction and maintenance of facilities for the sale and distribution of gas, including conduits, mains, pipes, laterals and fixtures (in this article called "facilities"). 
(b)  A written application shall be filed with the city for: 
(1)  A grant of a new franchise; 
(2)  A renewal of a franchise; 
(3)  A modification of a franchise agreement; 
(4)  A transfer of a franchise; or 
(5)  Any other relief from the city pursuant to this article or a franchise agreement. 
(c)  Each such application shall set forth, contain, or be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the utility. 
(2)  A detailed statement of the corporate or other business entity organization of the utility, including, but not limited to, the following: 
a.  The names and residence addresses of all general partners, managers or managing members, corporate officers or other officials of the utility's legal entity. 
b.  The names, residence addresses and business addresses of all persons and entities having, controlling, or being entitled to have or control 15 percent or more of the ownership of the applicant and the respective ownership share of each such person or entity. 
c.  The names and addresses of any parent or subsidiary of the utility and of any other business entity owning or controlling in whole or in part or owned or controlled in whole or in part by the utility. 
d.  A detailed description of all previous experience of the applicant in providing utility service or related or similar services. 
e.  A detailed and complete financial statement of the utility, prepared by a certified public accountant, for the fiscal year immediately preceding the date of the application hereunder; or a letter or other acceptable evidence in writing from a responsible lending institution or funding source, addressed to both the applicant and the city, setting forth a clear statement of its intent as a lending institution or funding source to provide whatever capital shall be required by the applicant to construct and operate the proposed system in the city. 
f.  A statement identifying, by place and date, any other utility franchises awarded or pending award to the utility, its parent or subsidiary; the status of said franchises with respect to completion thereof; the total cost of completion of such systems; and the amount of utility's and its parent's or subsidiary's resources committed to the completion thereof. 
(3)  A detailed description of the proposed plan of operation of the utility, which shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  A detailed map indicating all areas proposed to be served and a proposed time schedule for the installation of all equipment necessary to become operational throughout the entire area to be served. 
b.  A statement or schedule setting forth all proposed classifications of rates and charges to customers and all rates and charges as to each of any said classifications, including installation charges, service charges, special, extraordinary, or other charges. The purchase price, terms, and nature of any optional or required equipment, device, or other thing to be offered for sale to any customer shall be described and explained in detail. 
c.  A detailed statement describing the operational standards proposed by the utility. 
(4)  A copy of the form of any proposed agreement, understanding, or other instrument proposed to be entered into between the applicant and any customer. 
(5)  A detailed statement setting forth in its entirety any and all agreements and understandings, whether formal or informal, written, oral or implied, existing or proposed to exist between the utility and any person, firm or corporation which may affect control or operation of the system contrary to this article, as amended, or franchise agreement. 
(6)  A copy of any agreement covering the franchise area, if existing between the utility and any public utility providing for the use of any facilities of the public utility, including, but not limited to, poles, lines or conduits. 
(7)  Any other reasonable information which could materially affect the granting of the franchise and requested by the city. 
(8)  For a new franchise applicant, the city council shall determine if a consultant is needed to assist in the evaluation of the franchise application. Notice of the projected consultant costs shall be provided by the city manager by certified mail prior to commencing the evaluation process. The new franchise applicant shall submit a cashier's check in the specified amount no later than five days from receipt of said notice. If multiple applications are received for same franchise area, the costs shall be pro rated among the applicants. These application processing fees are over and above any construction, inspection, permit or franchise fees. Each franchise holder filing an application for expansion of its designated franchise area shall pay such application fee. 
(9)  Each original, renewal, transfer or modification application submitted for a franchise under the provisions of this article shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the amount of $5,000.00, unless otherwise determined by resolution of the city council. The purpose of the filing fee is to defray a portion of the city's cost on processing an application. The filing fee is therefore intended to be a charge incidental to the awarding or enforcing of a franchise and may not be deducted from the franchise fee imposed in a franchise agreement. Such application fees are in addition to any costs for consultant services described above. 
(d)  Nonexclusive franchises may be awarded by the city council for all or any portion of the city to a utility upon a finding that such award is consistent with the public interest, furthers the goal of providing efficient electrical service to all residents of the city, is consistent with any regulatory requirements of federal or state electrical service regulatory agencies, including, but not limited to, the Florida Public Service Commission, and does not result in material abuse of city streets, easements and rights-of-way. 
(e)  A franchise agreement shall be negotiated by the utility, the city manager, and the city attorney for presentation to the city council for consideration. At a minimum, the franchise agreement shall include adequate insurance provisions, including comprehensive general liability, automobile liability, and workers compensation, to protect both the utility and the city; providing for removal or abandonment of the system at the utility's expense; holding harmless and indemnifying the city from liability; and providing a term of the franchise which shall be for a reasonable period of time ranging between ten and 30 years. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-102; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-51. - Filing of schedule of rates and charges. 
(a)  Prior to commencement of construction under this franchise, the utility shall file with the city clerk a schedule of its rates and charges. All authority and rights of the utility, its successors and assigns with respect to its rates and charges shall at all times be subject to all lawful power, authority and jurisdiction now or hereafter possessed by the public service commission. After the effective date of this franchise, the utility shall file with the city clerk all amendments to its schedules of rates and charges within 30 days of approval of such amendments by the public service commission. 
(b)  In the event that the public service commission should be deprived of the authority to make rules and regulations governing the utility, then the city council, or other governing body of the city, shall have the right to fix reasonable and compensatory rates to be paid for gas by consumers, and to provide for the extension, repair and maintenance of mains, conduits and pipes, and the installing and testing of meters and other appurtenances, and to regulate the quality and pressure of the gas, and to provide such other and further regulations as shall be reasonably necessary and proper to provide adequate service to consumers and to protect their interests. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-103; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-52. - Filing of plans and specifications; construction requirements. 
(a)  All plans and specifications for the location or relocation of all gas facilities constructed pursuant to this franchise shall be approved by the city engineer prior to commencement of any construction. The facilities shall be so located or relocated and so erected or installed as not to obstruct or interfere with any water pipes, sewers, storm drains, or other utilities or structures already installed or hereafter to be installed; and interfere as little as possible with traffic over said streets, avenues, alleys, bridges and public places, and with reasonable egress from and ingress to abutting property, subject at all times to the lawful police power of the city. The utility company shall not unnecessarily or unreasonably obstruct the use of or damage any sidewalk, driveway, curb, street, avenue, alley, bridges, easements or other public places or ways of the city which shall have been opened by the utility for the purpose of laying, placing or repairing its gas mains or service; and the utility shall, upon completion of such construction or repair, restore the construction site to as good condition as it was at the time of excavation. Such restoration shall be maintained in an approved condition for a period of one year after its completion. Any unreasonable obstruction of any street, avenue, alley, bridge, easement or other public place or way of the city not removed by the utility after proper notice of not more than 24 hours by the city demanding removal thereof, and any such public way or place of the city not repaired by the utility after its excavation thereof, may be removed or repaired, as the case may be, by the city. The reasonable cost of removal or repair of said unreasonable obstructions plus 25 percent of such cost for administration and engineering expenses shall be charged against the utility, shall be paid by the utility, and shall be collectible by the city in any lawful manner, together with attorney's fees and costs of collection. 
(b)  In the event that at any time during the period of this franchise the city shall elect to alter, repair, or change any street, alley, easement or other public way requiring the relocation of the facilities of the utility, then the utility shall, upon reasonable written notice by the city, remove, relocate or take any other action required by the city to accommodate such alteration, repair or change to its mains or service pipes, manholes and other gas fixtures at its own expense and in accordance with specifications provided by the city. 
(c)  The utility shall at all times comply with and be subject to any ordinance and all ordinances of the city, now or hereafter in existence, relating to the use of the streets, avenues, alleys, sidewalks, highways, bridges, easements and other public ways and places, not inconsistent with this franchise. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-104; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-53. - Insurance. 
(a)  Prior to the effective date of this franchise, the utility shall file with the city clerk and shall keep in full force and effect at all times during the effective period hereof, insurance policy declaration evidencing a liability insurance policy or policies, the terms and conditions whereof shall be such as to provide for the protection and indemnification of the city with respect to any and all legally valid claims of any persons suffering injury, loss, or damage to person or property by reason of the construction or operation of a gas distribution system within the territorial limits of the city. 
(b)  Such insurance policies shall be subject to the acceptance of and approval by the city manager. Each such policy shall be issued by a company licensed to conduct insurance business in the state, Florida Insurance Commissioner, or successor office, and having a financial rating in Best's Insurance Guide of VII;A+ or better, or a similar rating by its successor. Any excess policy used must be issued by underwriters acceptable to the city. Such policies shall aggregate, as a minimum, the sum of $5,000,000.00 combined single limit for bodily injury, or death, and/or property damage resulting from any one accident or occurrence, and such aggregate minimum sums shall remain in full force and shall be undiminished during the effective period of the franchise. Such policy shall have a deductible of not more than $25,000.00, and the policy shall be an occurrence based policy. A claims made policy shall not be acceptable. 
(c)  Every such insurance policy shall contain a provision whereby every insurance company executing the same shall obligate itself to notify the city manager in writing, at least 30 days before any material alteration or modification, or before cancellation of such policy is to become effective. 
(d)  In the event that any suit is filed or action brought against the city, either severally or jointly with the company, by any person seeking to recover damages resulting from or attributable to any act or omission of the utility within the territorial limits of the city, the insurance company shall, upon receipt of written notice by the city, defend said suit or action and, in the event any final judgment therein should be rendered against the city resulting from or attributable to any act or omission of the utility for which the utility shall be adjudged liable by the court, the insurance company shall promptly pay the final judgment, together with all costs and attorneys' fees relating thereto; the insurance company being allowed, however, to require at its sole discretion an appeal to the appropriate court from the judgment rendered in any such suit or action upon the filing of such supersedeas bond as shall be required to prevent levy of judgments against the city during such appeal. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-111; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-54. - Hold harmless and indemnification. 
    The city shall in no way be liable or responsible for any accident or damage that may occur in the construction, operation, distribution, or maintenance by the utility of or through its facilities hereunder, and the acceptance of this article shall be deemed an agreement on the part of the utility to indemnify the city and hold it harmless, together with its employees, officers, volunteers, and agents, both in their official and personal capacities, against any and all claims, liability, loss, cost, damage or expense, of any type or nature whatsoever, including attorney's fees and court costs, which may arise in any way from or out of the construction, operation, distribution, or maintenance of or through the utility's facilities hereunder. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-112; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-55. - Compliance with city regulations. 
    This franchise, and all work that may be done hereunder, shall be subject to valid, reasonable regulations, rules, laws and ordinances as may be in force or which may hereafter be enacted or adopted for the regulation and use of the streets and highways of the city, and for the general welfare and safety of its citizens and protection and safeguarding of their lives and property. The right is hereby reserved to the city to adopt, in addition to the provisions herein contained in existing applicable ordinances, such additional regulations as it shall find necessary in the exercise of the police powers, provided that such regulations by ordinance, specification, or otherwise shall not be in conflict with the laws of any other governing body or agency. It is not intended hereby that the city shall have the right of unilaterally modifying the terms of this franchise other than as herein provided. It is also expressly recognized that the authority of the city is subject to preemption by the state by and through the public service commission and by the United States government. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-113; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-56. - Prohibition of discriminatory practices. 
    The utility shall not, as to rates, charges, service facilities, rules, regulations, or in any other respect, make or grant preference or advantage to any person, nor subject any person to any prejudice or disadvantage, provided that nothing in this franchise shall be deemed to prohibit the establishment of a graduated scale of charges and classified rate schedules to which any customer coming within such classification would be entitled. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-115; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-57. - Franchise fee. 
    Within 30 days after the end of each calendar month beginning with the calendar month in which the franchise fee commencement date (as defined below) occurs, the utility/franchisee, or its successors and assigns, shall pay to the city or its successors a franchise fee in an amount which shall equal six percent of the utility's gross revenue from the sale or transportation of gas to residential and commercial customers located within the corporate limits of the city during such calendar month (the "franchise fee"). 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-116; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-58. - City access to company records. 
    The city shall have access to all of the utility's plans, contracts, and engineering, accounting, finance, statistical, customer and service records relating to the property and the operations of the utility pertaining to the city at all reasonable hours. The following records and reports shall be filed with the city and in the local office of the company: 
(1)  Utility rules and regulations. Copies of such rules, regulations, terms and conditions adopted by it for the conduct of its business. 
(2)  Total billings. An annual summary report showing total billings received by the utility from its operations within the city during the preceding year and such other information as the city shall request with respect to properties, and expenses related to the utility's service within the city. 
(3)  Audits. The duly authorized agent of the city shall have the right, power and authority to inspect and audit the current records of gross revenue of the utility for any annual period at any reasonable time within five years after the expiration of such annual anniversary. The gross revenue records of the utility for any annual period shall be closed to the city after five years from the said annual anniversary. In the event the city audits the franchise fees paid by the utility to the city and said audit reveals that said fees have been underpaid to the city by more than five percent in any monthly time period, the costs of the audit, including administrative costs associated with said audit, will be paid by the utility to the city. Any underpayment of the franchise fee revealed by an audit shall be immediately paid to the city. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-117; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-59. - Approval of transfer. 
    The utility shall not sell or transfer its plant or system to another, nor transfer any rights under this franchise to another, without city council approval; provided that no sale or transfer shall be effective until the vendee, assignee or lessee has filed in the office of the city clerk an instrument, duly executed, reciting the facts of such sale, assignment or lease accepting the terms of this franchise and agreeing to perform all the conditions thereof. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-118; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-60. - Right to purchase. 
    The city hereby reserves the right at and after the expiration of this franchise, or, in the event of the utility's forfeiture, of any of the terms, conditions, and provisions of this franchise, to purchase the utility's franchise interests and the physical property of the utility used under this franchise at a valuation determined in accordance with the provisions of the general law now in effect. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-121; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 30-61. - Repeal of certain code provision not invalidating existing franchise agreements. 
    The repeal of sections 13.5-101, 13.5-105 through 13.5-110, 13.5-114, 13.5-119 through 13.5-120, and 13.5-122 through 13.5-126 of the 1984 city Code of Ordinances does not and shall not be interpreted as repealing in or otherwise terminating or invalidating the existing franchise agreement between the city and NUI Corporation, a New Jersey Corporation, or Florida City Gas, adopted on June 8, 1993, by Ordinance No. 93-24, and amended on January 14, 2003, by Ordinance No. 2002-85. NUI Corporation is now known as Pivotal Utilities, Inc., a New Jersey Corporation, d/b/a City Gas Company of Florida. 
(Code 1984, § 13.5-127; Ord. No. 2007-67, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Chapter 32 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Public health, F.S. ch. 381 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - City manager-General sanitation powers. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to investigate health and sanitation nuisances and hazards. The city manager, or his designee, shall be entitled to enter upon private property for the purpose of conducting such investigations. He also shall have the power and authority to order the abatement of nuisances or health hazards when such nuisances or hazards constitute a menace to the health and safety of the occupants. The city manager shall notify the owners and occupants of such premises of the charges, the changes that are required, and the time allowed to place the premises in a sanitary and safe condition. 
(Code 1980, § 18-1; Code 1984, § 15-1; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 1, 8-22-2000) 
Sec. 32-2. - Same-Designated health officer. 
    The city manager is hereby designated as city health officer. He may appoint an assistant health officer and a city physician and delegate such duties to them as he deems appropriate and necessary to the preservation of the health and sanitation of the city and its occupants. 
(Code 1980, § 18-2; Code 1984, § 15-2) 
Sec. 32-3. - Additional health powers. 
    For health and sanitation purposes and to carry out the intent of the City Charter, the city manager is hereby vested with all powers, authority, responsibility and duties applicable to the city which are exercisable under state statutes. The statutes shall be enforced as city ordinances and as a part of this chapter as if they were fully incorporated and set out in full herein. 
(Code 1980, § 18-3; Code 1984, § 15-3; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 1, 8-22-2000) 
Sec. 32-4. - Records. 
    The director of finance shall keep complete records relating to the amount payable on liens described in article II of this chapter. Any action taken pursuant to this chapter in regard to the disposal, abatement or removal of the conditions herein declared public nuisances shall be considered cumulative and in addition to penalties and other remedies provide elsewhere in this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 18-22; Code 1984, § 15-6; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 1, 8-22-2000) 
Secs. 32-5-32-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LOT, JUNK, GARBAGE AND TRASH CLEARING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Abatement of nuisances by injunction, F.S. § 60.05; nuisances injurious to health, F.S. ch. 386; public nuisances, F.S. ch. 823. 

Sec. 32-54. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the "City of Melbourne Lot, Junk, Garbage and Trash Clearing Ordinance" and shall be applicable in the incorporated areas of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 18-16; Code 1984, § 15-21) 
Sec. 32-55. - Declaration of legislative intent. 
    City council finds and determines that the rapid, continuous growth and development of the incorporated areas of this city require the reasonable and effective control and regulation of excessive growth and accumulation of weeds, undergrowth and other plant life to the extent and in such manner as to cause infestation by rodents and other wild animals, the breeding of mosquitoes and vermin, or to threaten or endanger the public health, or adversely affect and impair the economic welfare of adjacent property. Further, the city council finds and determines that the accumulation of garbage and trash in violation of chapter 48, and the accumulation, storage or maintenance of junk or trash in violation of section 48-29, requires reasonable and effective controls to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the community. 
(Code 1980, § 18-17; Code 1984, § 15-22) 
Sec. 32-56. - Public nuisances prohibited. 
    The excessive accumulation or untended growth of weeds, undergrowth or other dead or living plant life over 12 inches in height, or an open and/or unprotected pit, upon any parcel of land, improved or unimproved, within 100 feet of the boundary line or any improved property within the incorporated areas of this city to the extent and in the manner that such parcel of land is or may reasonably become infested or inhabited by rodents, vermin, or wild animals, or may furnish a breading place for mosquitoes, or threatens or endangers the public health, safety or welfare, or may reasonably cause disease, or adversely affects and impairs the economic welfare of adjacent property, is hereby prohibited and declared to be a public nuisance. Further the accumulation of garbage and trash in violation of chapter 48, and the accumulation, storage or maintenance of junk, abandoned vehicles, or trash, except for compost piles, in violation of sections 48-29 and 48-30, is hereby prohibited and declared to be a public nuisance. Further, having an attractive nuisance in violation of sections 32-104 and 32-105 is hereby prohibited and declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1980, § 18-18; Code 1984, § 15-23; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 1, 8-22-2000; Ord. No. 2009-05, § 1, 2-10-2009) 
Sec. 32-57. - Notice. 
(a)  If the code enforcement official finds and determines that a public nuisance, as described and declared in section 32-56, exists, he shall so notify the owner of record of the offending property in writing and require that the condition be remedied. The notice shall be given by registered or certified mail, addressed to the owners of the property described, as their names and addresses are shown upon the record of the county property appraiser, and shall be deemed complete and sufficient when so addressed and deposited in the United States mail with proper postage prepaid. 
(b)  Simultaneous with mailing the notice, the property shall be posted with a notice in substantially the following form: 
NOTICE OF PUBLIC NUISANCE 
Name of owner: ___________ 
Address of owner: ___________ 
Our records indicate that you are the owner(s) of the following property in the City of Melbourne, Florida: 
(describe property) 
An inspection of this property reveals that a public nuisance exists and constitutes a violation of the City of Melbourne Lot, Junk, Garbage and Trash Clearing Ordinance in that: 
(describe here the condition which places the property in violation) 
You are hereby notified that unless the condition above-described is remedied so that it is no longer in violation of the City Code within 10 days from the date of this notice, the City of Melbourne will proceed to remedy this condition and the cost of the work, including advertising costs and other expenses, will be imposed as a lien on the property if not otherwise paid within 30 days after receipt of billing. 
(Code 1980, § 18-19; Code 1984, § 15-24; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 1, 8-22-2000) 
Sec. 32-58. - Hearing. 
(a)  Within ten days after the mailing of the notice to the property owner and the posting of the property, the owner of the property may make written request to the city manager for a hearing before him or his designee to show that the condition alleged in the notice does not exist or that such condition does not constitute a public nuisance. 
(b)  At the hearing, the city and the property owner may introduce such evidence as is deemed necessary. The city manager shall establish rules and regulations for the hearing procedure. Following a review by the city manager, the owner will have exhausted his administrative remedies. 
(Code 1980, § 18-20; Code 1984, § 15-25; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 1, 8-22-2000) 
Sec. 32-59. - Condition may be remedied by city. 
(a)  If within ten days after mailing of the notice, no hearing has been requested, or if the property owner has been found in violation at a hearing, and the condition described in the notice has not been remedied within three days of the finding, the condition will be remedied by the city at the expense of the property owner. 
(b)  After causing the condition to be remedied, the city manager or his designee shall certify to the director of finance the expense incurred in remedying the condition and shall include a copy of the notice above-described and a copy of the decision, if any, by the city manager. If the expense is not paid within 30 days, a special assessment lien and charge will be made upon the property, which shall be payable with interest at the rate of eight percent per annum from the date of such certification until paid. Such lien shall be enforceable in the same manner as a tax lien in favor of the city and may be satisfied at any time by payment thereof including accrued interest. Such lien shall be recorded in the public records of the county. Upon payment of a lien, the satisfaction and cancellation of such lien shall be recorded in the public records of the county. 
(Code 1980, § 18-21; Code 1984, § 15-26; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 1, 8-22-2000) 
Secs. 32-60-32-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MOSQUITO CONTROL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Mosquito control districts, F.S. ch. 388. 

Sec. 32-77. - Breeding places for mosquitoes prohibited. 
    No person shall have, keep, maintain, cause or permit any collection of standing or flowing water in which any mosquitoes breed, or are likely to breed, unless such collection of water is treated so as to effectively prevent such breeding. The foregoing shall apply to every type of container, depression or place where water might collect, whether natural or manmade. 
(Code 1980, § 18-41; Code 1984, § 15-41; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 1, 8-22-2000) 
Sec. 32-78. - Evidence of breeding places. 
    The natural presence of mosquito larvae in standing or running water shall be prima facie evidence that mosquitoes are breeding. 
(Code 1980, § 18-42; Code 1984, § 15-42; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 1, 8-22-2000) 
Sec. 32-79. - Treatment of breeding places. 
    Collections of water in which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed shall be treated by one or more of the methods set out herein, as approved by the county mosquito control director. Such methods are as follows: 
(1)  Screening with wire netting of at least 16 meshes to the inch each way, or any other materials which will effectively prevent the ingress or egress of mosquitoes. 
(2)  Complete emptying every seven days of unscreened containers, together with their thorough drying and cleaning. 
(3)  Use of a larvicide approved and applied under the direction of such mosquito control director. 
(4)  Completely covering the surface of the water with kerosene, petroleum or paraffin oil once every seven days. 
(5)  Cleaning and keeping sufficiently free of vegetable growth and other obstructions, and stocking with mosquito-destroying fish. 
(6)  Filling or draining to the satisfaction of such mosquito control director. 
(7)  Proper disposal by removal or destruction of broken or empty containers likely to hold water. 
(Code 1980, § 18-43; Code 1984, § 15-43) 
Sec. 32-80. - Violation. 
(a)  Any person responsible for the condition of premises on which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed shall take necessary measures to prevent their breeding within three days after written notice by the city, or within such longer time which may be specified in the notice. 
(b)  Abatement of such breeding places may be made through declaring them a nuisance and proceeding under the provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 18-44; Code 1984, § 15-44) 
Secs. 32-81-32-103. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ATTRACTIVE NUISANCE CONDITION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Nuisance abatement, F.S. § 60.05; swimming pools as attractive nuisances, F.S. § 515.21 et seq.; public nuisances, F.S. § 823.01 et seq. 

Sec. 32-104. - Attractive nuisance conditions prohibited. 
    No person shall have, keep, maintain, cause or permit an attractive nuisance condition on any parcel of land within this city. As used in this article, the term "attractive nuisance" shall be construed to mean any artificial condition, whether in a building, on the premises of a building or upon an unoccupied job site, which by its nature, location or character would tend to attract and substantially endanger the safety of any minor person. This includes, but is not limited to, unsecured swimming pools, abandoned wells or shafts; excavations; abandoned refrigerators/freezers with doors or motor vehicles with unlocked doors; any structurally unsound fences or structures; lumber, trash/debris, or any other materials which may provide a hazard; or any condition which is determined to be a life safety violation. A "life safety violation" includes: 
(1)  A violation of the Florida Fire Prevention Code, as adopted pursuant to Rule 69A-60.002(3), Florida Administrative Code, which includes the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 101, Life Safety Code and National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 1, Life Safety Code; or 
(2)  A violation of the Preston de Ibern/McKenzie Residential Swimming Pool Act, F.S. § 515.21 et seq., and, in particular, F.S. § 515.27(1)(a) and F.S. § 515.29. 
(Code 1984, § 15-61; Ord. No. 2009-05, § 2, 2-10-2009) 
State Law reference- Residential swimming pool safety, F.S. § 515.27. 
Sec. 32-105. - Attractive nuisance condition violation. 
(a)  If an attractive nuisance condition is found to exist, notice to the property owner and mortgagee, if the mortgagee is registered pursuant to section 36-38, shall be given pursuant to section 32-57. Any person responsible for the attractive nuisance condition of premises shall take necessary measures to remedy the attractive nuisance condition within three days after written notice by the city, or within such reasonable time as may be specified in the notice. The owner, or the mortgagee if the mortgagee is registered pursuant to section 36-38, may request a hearing pursuant to section 32-58 if the owner or mortgagee believes that the alleged attractive nuisance condition does not exist. 
(b)  If the attractive nuisance condition is not remedied after notice from the city and an opportunity to correct the violation is extended, as provided in subsection (a) of this section, abatement of such attractive nuisance condition, including, but not limited to, temporary repairs, may be made by the city by declaring the condition a public nuisance and proceeding under the provisions of article II of this chapter. If no hearing is requested, or upon a determination after a hearing that the alleged condition does exist and must be remedied, code compliance officials of the city may undertake repairs and secure the property as provided in section 32-59, and charges shall be made and a lien shall exist and be enforced as provided therein. 
(c)  Should the condition to be abated be deemed an emergency condition necessitating immediate action to preserve the health, safety or welfare of the surrounding citizens of the city, the city shall abate the nuisance as provided in this section absent written notice but after it has attempted reasonable means of notifying the owner of the property and mortgagee, if the property is registered pursuant to section 36-38. As soon as practicable after abatement if the property is registered, notice of the action taken shall be sent to said owner and mortgagee and a lien shall be recorded as provided in section 32-59. Upon the giving of said notice, the owner or mortgagee shall have a right to appeal the determination that the alleged nuisance condition existed pursuant to section 32-58.
