ARTICLE II. - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS AND PROPERTY 

Sec. 52-33. - System established; incorporation of map. 
    A uniform system of numbering properties and principal buildings, as shown on the map identified by the title, "Property Numbering Grid Map," which is filed in the office of the city engineer, is hereby adopted for use in the city. This map and all explanatory matter thereon is hereby adopted and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 29-17; Code 1984, § 28-21; Ord. No. 2002-34, § 1, 5-28-2002) 
Sec. 52-34. - Administration. 
(a)  The city engineer shall be responsible for maintaining the numbering system adopted by this article. 
(b)  The city engineer shall duly record all numbers assigned under section 52-33. 
(c)  The city engineer shall assign to any property owner in the city or its immediate environs upon request and without charge a property number for each principal building or separate front entrance to such building. However, the city engineer may issue additional property numbers in accordance with the official numbering system whenever a property has been subdivided, a new front entrance opened, or undue hardship has been worked on any property owner. 
(Code 1980, § 29-18; Code 1984, § 28-22) 
Sec. 52-35. - Assignment of numbers. 
(a)  All properties or parcels of land within the city shall be identified by reference to the uniform numbering system adopted in this article. 
(b)  Each principal building shall have its own unique address number. Address numbers shall be assigned in accordance with the numbering system adopted in this article. 
(c)  Address numbers shall be consistent with all even number on the west and north side of each street and all odd numbers on the south and east side of each street. Babcock Street shall be the boundary line for east and west and Brevard Drive shall be the boundary line for north and south. Odd/even numbers shall not be changed when the street direction curves or changes. 
(d)  Corner lot address numbers shall be assigned on the street where the structure faces, if accessible to that street. 
(e)  Street names should not contain a directional reference (north, south, east and west) unless they cross the boundary line or change zip code. 
(Code 1980, § 29-19; Code 1984, § 28-23; Ord. No. 2002-34, § 1, 5-28-2002) 
Sec. 52-36. - Numbering multiple-family structures. 
    Each principal building shall bear the number assigned to the frontage on which the front entrance is located. A principal building with four or more units shall be assigned one property address number and shall have unique unit numbers for each unit. Unit numbers (not letters) should increase consistently with the address grid. For example, multiple story buildings should have unit numbers of 100-199 on the first habitable floor, 200-299 on the second habitable floor, etc. 
(Code 1980, § 29-21; Code 1984, § 28-25; Ord. No. 2002-34, § 1, 5-28-2002) 
Sec. 52-37. - Numerals to be posted; dimensions; coloration. 
(a)  Numerals indicating the official numbers for each principal building or each front entrance to such building shall be posted in a manner as to be clearly visible and distinguishable from the street on which the property is located. Such numerals shall be a minimum of six inches in height on commercial buildings and a minimum of three inches in height on all other buildings, at least one-half inch in width, and of a contrasting color with the building. 
(b)  If the building is not clearly visible and/or the number not legible from the public or private way, an additional building number must be placed in a manner easily visible from a public or private way. 
(Code 1980, § 29-22; Code 1984, § 28-26; Ord. No. 85-62, § 1, 8-27-1985; Ord. No. 2002-34, § 1, 5-28-2002) 
Secs. 52-38-52-64. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CROSSING SIDEWALK OR CURB WHERE NO DRIVEWAY EXISTS 

Sec. 52-65. - Permit required. 
    No person shall operate any vehicle of any kind or character on or over any sidewalk or curb within the city except at such places as driveways exist without first obtaining a permit from the building official and a right-of-way use permit from the city engineer. 
(Code 1980, § 29-23; Code 1984, § 28-81; Ord. No. 2002-34, § 1, 5-28-2002) 
Sec. 52-66. - Application for permit. 
    In case any person desires to operate any vehicle on or over any sidewalk or curb at any place except at a driveway, he shall make application to the building official therefor. The application shall specify the place involved, the duration of time for which such permit is desired and the kind of vehicles desired to be operated on or over the place specified. 
(Code 1980, § 29-24; Code 1984, § 28-82; Ord. No. 2002-34, § 1, 5-28-2002) 
Sec. 52-67. - Term of permit. 
    Permits issued pursuant to section 52-65 shall not be valid for a period of longer than 60 days. 
(Code 1980, § 29-27; Code 1984, § 28-85) 
Secs. 52-68-52-92. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ABANDONMENT OF PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY AND EASEMENTS 

Sec. 52-93. - Power to open, straighten, divert, widen, narrow or vacate public ways. 
    The city council may, upon its own motion or upon the request of any agency of the state, or of the federal government, or upon the written petition of any person owning property abutting any public street or alley located within the city limits or within the territory lying within the jurisdiction of the city, cause any street, alley or public highway to be opened, straightened, diverted, widened, narrowed or vacated. 
(Code 1984, ch. 28, art. V(intro.); Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 52-94. - Purposes and methods. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish a uniform procedure for applications to the city for the vacation and abandonment of city streets, alleys, special purpose easements and other non-fee interests of the city; to provide a method for the city to vacate and abandon its fee interest in the public right-of-way; to designate the appropriate departments of the city that shall be responsible for the processing of such applications; and to provide procedures and standards that shall govern such processing. The process and act of vacating, abandoning, or terminating the city's and public's rights in a right-of-way or platted easement is quasi-judicial in nature. This article relates solely to the vacating, abandonment, and termination of the city's and public's rights in a right-of-way, or easement, which has been dedicated usually through the act of platting. 
(Code 1984, § 28-101; Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 52-95. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandon or vacate means to renounce or disclaim all interest of the city and of the public in and to any land dedicated for transportation or travel by the public or to an easement dedicated for public use. 
    Abutting property means and refers to any parcel of real property whose boundary, or any part thereof, also serves as the boundary, or any part thereof, of the petition site. 
    Affected property means and refers to any parcel of real property, or portion thereof, which lies within 500 feet of the boundaries of the petition site. 
    City or public right-of-way means and refers to any right-of-way acquired by the city or the public by virtue of dedication to the public or the city on a plat, by separate instrument of conveyance, by eminent domain or by prescription. 
    Easement means and refers to any strip of land or body of water created by an owner or subdivider for public or private travel, access, utilities, drainage, sanitation or other specified uses having limitations, the fee title to which shall remain in the name of the property owner subject to the right of use designated in the document granting the easement. 
    Lead review department means and refers to the department within the city that is designated by the city manager as having the responsibility to administer the petition for abandonment. 
    Owner means and refers to the person, governmental entity or other entity that is the fee simple title holder of real property as shown on the current tax rolls of the county property appraiser, unless the city has actual knowledge that a person or entity other than the person or entity shown on the tax roll is the actual owner. 
    Petition for abandonment or petition means and refers to the form prescribed by the lead review department, which requests the abandonment of a right-of-way or public easement pursuant to this article. 
    Petition site means and refers to the portion of a right-of-way or easement that is the subject of a petition for abandonment, or a petition for release of interest or a petition for vacation pursuant to this article. 
    Petitioner means and refers to the person, governmental entity or other entity submitting a petition for vacation pursuant to this article. 
    Plat means any drawing of real property made and recorded pursuant to F.S. ch. 177. 
    Private easement or interest dedicated by separate instrument means and refers to any road, street, alleyway, utility, drainage, pedestrian, air, light, access, ingress or egress, flowage or similar easement or interest that is dedicated by separate instrument to any person or entity other than the federal government, the state government or any of its subdivisions or agencies, pursuant to requirements of the city. 
    Private right-of-way means and refers to any right-of-way dedicated or deeded to an owners' association or the owner of the abutting property or which is dedicated as a right-of-way and is the perpetual maintenance obligation of any owners' association or the owner of abutting property. 
    Public easement means and refers to any utility, maintenance or drainage easement that is dedicated by plat in perpetuity for utility or drainage purposes, or which is conveyed by a separate instrument approved by the city. The term "public easement" shall not include instruments of conveyances or dedications made to specifically named utility companies, owners' associations, or other governmental entities. 
    Reviewing department means and refers to the departments within the city that shall participate in the review of the petition for abandonment. 
    Right-of-way means and refers to land dedicated, deeded, used or to be used for a boulevard, road, street, alley, walkway, drainage facility, access for ingress and egress, or other purposes by the public, certain designated individuals or governing bodies. The term "right-of-way" shall apply to city rights-of-way whether dedicated by plat or separate instrument. 
(Code 1984, § 28-102; Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 52-96. - Filing fee. 
    Every application or petition filed with the city for the vacating or narrowing of a right-of-way or an easement shall be in writing and shall be accompanied by a filing fee as set out in section 2-507. Such fee shall be used for the costs incidental in processing of said application or petition. 
(Code 1984, § 28-103; Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 52-97. - Petition application procedures. 
    Applications may be filed by the owners of record of property abutting or bounding the right-of-way or easement sought to be vacated. All requests for vacation, termination, abandonment, and permanent closure of rights-of-way or easements shall be made in petition form upon an application furnished by the lead review department, which shall be signed by all owners of property abutting the portion of the right-of-way or easement sought to be vacated, and shall require the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the petitioners. 
(2)  Evidence of the petitioners' ownership or interest in the petition site. 
(3)  A general description of the right-of-way or easement that petitioners seek to have abandoned, vacated, terminated, or permanently closed and the location of same. 
(4)  Type of petition. The petition shall identify the type of petition as being for abandonment of: 
a.  A city right-of-way. 
b.  A public easement. 
c.  The public's interest in a private right-of-way. 
(5)  Justification. Petitioners' relevant reasons in support of the request to abandon and vacate the right-of-way or easement. 
(6)  A survey of any existing structures, buildings, fences or other encroachments contained on the petition site, which are related to the reason that the request is being made, where applicable. 
(7)  The petition shall be signed by the legal property owners of all lands abutting the petition site that agree or consent to the vacation. 
(Code 1984, § 28-104; Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 52-98. - Review procedure. 
(a)  Each application shall be reviewed for sufficiency by the lead review department. 
(b)  Following a determination that the application is complete, the lead review department shall distribute the application, accompanied by maps, survey drawings and any other pertinent information, to the reviewing departments, utilities, and applicable agencies. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the petition, each reviewing department shall submit a written response containing its finding and recommendations to the lead review department. Upon receipt of all written findings and utility input, the lead review department shall review the application and reports and shall notify the petitioners in writing of any conditions to be performed prior to making a recommendation to the city manager for action by the city council. 
(d)  Within 60 days of receipt of the lead review department's notification, the petitioners shall either comply with, agree and commit in writing to the conditions, or disagree in writing to the conditions. Failure to respond to the lead review department's notification may result in a recommendation to deny the petition by the lead review department. 
(e)  After expiration of the 60-day period of this section, or sooner, if conditions are not imposed, or if imposed are responded to by the petitioner in the manner set forth in this section, the lead review department shall forward the petition, together with its findings and recommendations of same, in the form of a report to the city manager for subsequent action by the city council. 
(Code 1984, § 28-105; Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 52-99. - Review criteria. 
    Following a determination that the application is sufficient for consideration, the lead review department shall make a recommendation that addresses the following factors, if applicable: 
(1)  Applications for vacation of rights-of-way or easements shall be reviewed to determine whether there is any future likelihood that the right-of-way or easement may be needed by the city, county, state, or utility. 
(2)  Such application shall be analyzed to ensure that the convenient access of property owners on adjoining street rights-of-way will not be adversely affected. 
(3)  No right-of-way or public easement giving access to any publicly accessible waters in the city shall be closed, vacated or abandoned except in those instances wherein the petitioners offer to trade or give to the city comparable land for a right-of-way or public easement that provide access to the same body of water. Such access shall not create a hardship on the users. A determination on this, as well as the distance and comparable land being offered, shall be left to the discretion of the city council. 
(4)  The lead review department shall obtain written approval or consent of affected utilities to the abandonment of a right-of-way or easement. 
(5)  If existing utilities or improvements are located in the petition site, any provisions for the utilities or improvements to be relocated shall be defined in writing by the affected utility. 
(6)  Written consent of the utility if a new utility easement will be created within or over the original petition site for existing or planned utility equipment located in the right-of-way that is being considered for vacation. 
(7)  A determination whether any geographic areas within 2,500 feet may be impacted by the proposed action and the nature and degree of impact. 
(8)  A determination of what other additional property, easements, utility relocations, agreements or other actions may also be required to accommodate the proposed action. The petitioners may be required to provide an alternative right-of-way or easement. 
(9)  Identification and evaluation of the nature and degree of any impacts that the proposed action might have on the delivery and provision of service by public service vehicles. 
(10)  Identification and evaluation of any impacts the proposed action might have on the surrounding public street system. 
(11)  The results of any applicable traffic study. 
(12)  A complete list of all owners of abutting and affected property within 500 feet. 
(13)  Location map. A drawing, measuring not larger than 8.5 inches by 14 inches, which clearly and legibly identifies the location of the petition site in relation to the nearest public right-of-way, excluding the petition site, and all affected properties. The location map may be located on the survey in a separate block. 
(14)  Abutting property and affected property. The petition shall include a map that identifies the boundaries of abutting properties. 
(15)  Survey. A certified land survey measuring not larger than 8.5 inches by 14 inches shall be prepared by a state registered land surveyor in accordance with the minimum technical standards of F.S. § 472.027, and F.A.C. ch. 21HH-6, and attached as an exhibit to the petition. The survey shall also contain or depict the following information: 
a.  An accurate drawing of the petition site. 
b.  The boundaries of abutting properties. 
(Code 1984, § 28-106; Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 52-100. - Public hearing; notice. 
(a)  Before narrowing or vacating any street, alley, public highway, or portion thereof, the city council shall first hold a public hearing. At least ten days prior to first reading of the ordinance, the city shall mail a notice to all property owners within 500 feet of the portion of the street affected by the proposed vacating or narrowing, the giving of said notice being a courtesy notice. The notice shall be mailed to each property owner at his last known address as listed on the county property appraiser's most current tax roll as displayed in the internet at the time of submission of the petition or from such other source as the lead review department deems reliable. The lead review department shall provide proof of such mailing by affidavit filed with the lead review department, provided that failure to mail the notice or the mailing of the notice to an erroneous address or wrong property owner shall not invalidate any proceedings hereunder. Notice of the time and place of such public hearing shall also be given by publication once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least ten days prior to the date of the public hearing. The notice shall describe the street, alley or public highway to be narrowed, or vacated and such service by publication shall be verified by the affidavit of the publisher and filed with the city clerk. In the event an easement is requested to be narrowed or vacated, the abutting property owners shall be notified and the procedures for publication as hereinabove stated for vacating public streets and alleys shall be followed. 
(b)  No right-of-way or easement, or the public rights therein, shall be determined to be vacated, terminated, abandoned or permanently closed by the city council until the city council has applied the review criteria in section 52-99 and it has been determined that: 
(1)  The right-of-way or easement, or rights of the public therein, to the extent requested to be vacated, terminated, abandoned, or permanently closed, is no longer needed. 
(2)  The public health, safety, welfare, aesthetics, and economic order of the community will not be compromised by the vacation, termination, abandonment or permanent closure of the right-of-way or easement, or rights of the public therein, to the extent requested to be vacated, terminated, abandoned, or permanently closed. 
(3)  The rights or anticipated and likely future needs of utilities, including, but not limited to, electric, gas, water, wastewater, telephone, and cable television, to use the right-of-way or easement will not be compromised, or acceptable and adequate alternatives have been provided. 
(4)  All properties abutting and utilizing the portion of the right-of-way or easement to be vacated, abandoned, terminated, or permanently closed will have adequate alternative right-of-way or easement available to serve said abutting properties. 
(c)  When determined by the city council, a vacation, termination, abandonment, or permanent closure may be approved conditioned upon certain conditions precedent occurring. 
(Code 1984, § 28-107; Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 52-101. - City council action evidenced by ordinance. 
    After the public hearing has been held pursuant to section 52-100, the city council may, by ordinance, provide for the vacation, termination, abandonment and permanent closure of all rights of the public in the right-of-way or easement. Any action of the city council shall be evidenced by an ordinance duly adopted and entered upon the minutes of the city council. 
(Code 1984, § 28-108; Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Sec. 52-102. - Recordation; effective date of vacation. 
    The ordinance shall be recorded in the public records of the county. The vacation, termination, abandonment, and permanent closure of all rights of the public in the right-of-way or easement described in the ordinance shall not become effective until the ordinance has been recorded. 
(Code 1984, § 28-109; Ord. No. 2007-66, § 1, 9-11-2007) 
Secs. 52-103-52-132. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NEWSRACKS 

Sec. 52-133. - Intent; official charged with administrative responsibility; exemptions. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to promote the public health, safety, welfare, economic order, and aesthetics through the regulations of the placement, appearance, servicing, and ensuring of newsracks on public rights-of-way so as to: 
(1)  Make the downtown redevelopment area an active and attractive pedestrian environment; 
(2)  Provide the opportunity for creative, colorful, pedestrian-focused commercial activities; 
(3)  Promote land conservation and redevelopment; 
(4)  Provide for pedestrian and driving safety and convenience; 
(5)  Restrict the unreasonable interference with the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including ingress into or egress from any residence or place of business, or from the street to the sidewalk by persons exiting or entering parked or standing vehicles; 
(6)  Provide reasonable access for the use and maintenance of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes, and access to locations used for public transportation purposes; 
(7)  Provide for proper access to sidewalks; 
(8)  Encourage well designed and aesthetically compatible newsracks; 
(9)  Reduce unnecessary exposure of the city to personal injury or property damage claims; 
(10)  Provide for and maintain the freedom of speech for newspapers, news or other periodicals or advertising circulars using newsracks for distribution purposes; 
(11)  Improve the economic order of the community; and 
(12)  Ensure safe, orderly sidewalks that are not blocked by the disorderly or cluttered placement of newsracks for use by wheelchair-bound citizens. 
(b)  The building official shall administer the provisions of this article and of newsracks that constitute "abandoned property" or "lost property" pursuant to F.S. ch. 705. Code enforcement officers subject to the supervision of the building official are authorized, subject to supervision by the building official, to enforce this article and enforce the provisions of F.S. ch. 705, with regard to newsracks that constitute "abandoned property" or "lost property" as defined in said statute. 
(c)  The following newsracks shall be exempt from regulation pursuant to this article: 
(1)  Newsracks located wholly on private, non-governmental property; and 
(2)  Newsracks located outside the downtown redevelopment area. 
(Code 1984, § 28-120; Ord. No. 94-39, § 1, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 52-134. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned property means all tangible personal property which does not have an identifiable owner and which has been disposed of on public property in a wrecked, inoperative, or partially dismantled condition or which has no apparent intrinsic value to the rightful owner. 
    Advertising circular means any publication that contains only advertising and no news reports. 
    Bike path means that portion of a right-of-way improved, designed, or ordinarily used by bicycle traffic. For the purposes of this article no sidewalk shall be construed to be a bike path. 
    Building official means the city building official, or said official's designee. 
    Distributor means the person responsible for placing and maintaining a newsrack, the owner or other person having a possessory or other ownership interest in the newsrack, or the publisher of the newspaper or other periodical or advertising circular vended from a newsrack regulated by this article. 
    Downtown redevelopment area means that area of the city as defined by section 20-40, as may be amended from time to time. 
    Downtown redevelopment plan means that plan as specified in section 20-64, as may be amended from time to time. 
    Lost property means all tangible personal property which does not have an identifiable owner and which has been mislaid on public property in a substantially operable, functioning condition or which has an apparent intrinsic value to the rightful owner. 
    Newsrack means any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used, or maintained for the display, sale, or distribution of newspapers, other periodicals, or advertising circulars. 
    Public agency means the city, county, or the state. 
    Right-of-way means all that area dedicated to public use or otherwise owned by a public agency for public street purposes and shall include, but is not limited to, roadways, swales, bike paths and sidewalks. 
    Roadway means that portion of a right-of-way improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Sidewalk means any surface within a right-of-way provided for the primary use of pedestrians. 
    Swale means any area within a right-of-way which is a drainage pathway, curb and gutter of a sidewalk, or is used for water retention or detention. 
(Code 1984, § 28-121; Ord. No. 94-39, § 2, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 52-135. - Newsracks on public rights-of-way-Standards for maintenance and installation. 
(a)  Any newsrack which in whole or in part is attached to or rests upon any public right-of-way shall comply with the standards set forth in this section. 
(b)  Each coin-operated newsrack, except where the newspaper or periodical is distributed free, shall be equipped with a coin-return mechanism to permit a person using the machine to secure an immediate refund in the event he is unable to open the newsrack. The coin-return mechanisms shall be maintained by the distributor in good working order. 
(c)  The distributor is charged with the duty of ensuring that each newsrack shall have affixed to it in a readily visible place, so as to be seen by anyone using the newsrack, the telephone number of a working telephone service to call to report a malfunction, or to secure a refund in the event of a malfunction of the coin-return mechanism, and shall feature clearly on its face the name and address of the distributor to give the notices provided for in this article. 
(d)  Each newsrack shall be maintained by the distributor in a neat and clean condition and in good repair at all times at the sole cost of the distributor. 
(e)  Each newsrack shall be maintained by the distributor in accordance with the terms of this article. 
(f)  The distributor shall be responsible for any damage or repairs caused by the removal or installation of their newsracks. 
(Code 1984, § 28-122; Ord. No. 94-39, § 3, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 52-136. - Same-Location and placement of newsracks. 
(a)  Any newsrack which is attached to or rests in whole or in part upon, or on any portion of, a right-of-way or which projects onto, into, or over any part of a right-of-way, shall be located in accordance with the standards set forth in this section. 
(b)  No newsrack shall be used or maintained which projects onto, into, or over any part of any roadway or bike path, or which rests, wholly or in part, upon or over any portion of any roadway or bike bath. 
(c)  No newsrack shall be located upon, in or over any swale or sidewalk when such: 
(1)  Installation, use or maintenance poses an imminent threat to the safety of persons or property; 
(2)  Newsrack obstructs the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic; or 
(3)  The newsrack placement or location violates state law. 
(d)  No newsrack shall be located: 
(1)  Within two feet of any kiosk, bench, trash receptacle, drinking fountain, bicycle rack, mailbox, post, pole or any area planted with grass, shrubs, flowers or trees; 
(2)  Within the triangular shaped real property at the intersection of two public rights-of-way described as running away from the intersection and along the edge of the right-of-way lines with a line joining points on those lines, said points being 25 feet from the intersection; 
(3)  Within the triangular shaped real property at the intersection of a public right-of-way and a private driveway described as running away from the aforesaid intersection and along the edge of the right-of-way line and the driveway with a line joining points on those lines, said points being 25 feet from said intersection; 
(4)  So as to reduce the clear, continuous sidewalk width to less than four feet in the C-3 zoning district of the downtown redevelopment area; 
(5)  Within five feet of any fire hydrant; 
(6)  Within five feet of any driveway or alley; 
(7)  Within five feet ahead of, and 20 feet to the rear of any sign marking a designated bus stop; 
(8)  Within four feet of a display window or building entrance; 
(9)  Within two feet of the curb face; or 
(10)  In such manner that pedestrian traffic at any time would be substantially blocked, disrupted, or slowed. 
(e)  Newsracks shall be placed together in groupings consisting of one to six individual newsrack dispenser boxes. Each grouping of newsracks shall be separated by a distance of not less than ten feet. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event there is parallel parking or head-in parking provided along a roadway, then no newsracks shall be placed so as to block, interfere or impair operators of vehicles from exiting their vehicles onto or through to the sidewalks, curbs or rights-of-way adjoining said roadways. Each newsrack within a group shall be separated by no more than two feet from the nearest newsrack. 
(f)  No newsrack may be chained, bolted or otherwise attached to any fixture located in the right-of-way. 
(Code 1984, § 28-123; Ord. No. 94-39, § 4, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 52-137. - Newsracks constituting abandoned or lost property; when newsrack does not have an identifiable owner. 
(a)  When a newsrack does not have an identifiable owner and constitutes abandoned property, disposition of said newsrack shall be pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 705.103, relating to "abandoned property," as therein defined. 
(b)  When a newsrack does not have an identifiable owner and constitutes lost property, disposition of said newsrack shall be pursuant to "lost property," as therein defined. 
(Code 1984, § 28-124; Ord. No. 94-39, § 5, 7-12-1994) 
Sec. 52-138. - Orders to correct chapter violations; stay upon appeal; when newsrack has an identifiable owner. 
(a)  Notice. 
(1)  If the building official is able to ascertain the owner/distributor of a newsrack, upon determination by the building official that a newsrack has been installed, used or maintained in violation of the provisions of this article; that the newsrack does not have a proper decal as provided in section 52-135 to identify the distributor; or that the decal does not properly identify the distributor of the newsrack, an order to correct the offending condition may be issued by the building official to the distributor of the newsrack. Said order shall be mailed, postage prepaid, by U.S. certified mail, return receipt requested, to the distributor. The order shall describe the offending condition and suggest action necessary to correct the condition. The order shall reference any pedestrian and vehicular traffic study containing data that may have been utilized to ascertain the offending condition. The order shall also describe the manner in which a distributor may appeal the order pursuant to subsection (c) of this section. 
(2)  Additionally, the building official shall cause a notice, which cannot be easily removed, to be posted for at least 20 days on the newsrack determined to be installed, used or maintained in violation of this article. Such notice shall not be less than eight inches by ten inches and shall be sufficiently weatherproofed to withstand normal exposure to the elements. 
(3)  The building official shall keep a record noting the date of posting of the notice on the newsrack and the date of mailing of the order to the distributor of the newsrack determined to be in violation of this article. 
(b)  If the offending newsrack is not removed from the public right-of-way or the newsrack is not brought into compliance with the provisions of this article within 20 days after receipt of the mailed notice or the posting date of the order, whichever event is later in time, said newsrack shall be declared by the building official to be lost property, pursuant to F.S. ch. 705. A notice of intent to remove the property shall thereupon be posted on the newsrack pursuant to F.S. § 705.103(2). The newsrack may later be taken into custody by the city pursuant to F.S. § 705.103(2)(b). 
(c)  The distributor may appeal an order or declaration issued pursuant to subsections (a) or (b) of this section. Such appeal must be made prior to title to the newsrack vesting in the city pursuant to F.S. § 705.104. An appeal is initiated by filing with the building official a formal letter advising that the distributor wishes to appeal the order. The letter shall constitute a notice of appeal. In the event the distributor of the newsrack files an appeal, then the determination that the newsrack is lost property or the order to correct the offending condition shall be stayed pending final disposition of the appeal, which final disposition shall include all judicial review. 
(d)  Appeals. Upon receipt of a notice of appeal, the building official shall provide such notice to the board of adjustment. A de novo hearing shall be held with regard to the appeal within a reasonable period of time after receipt of the notice of appeal. The appellant shall be given at least five days' notice of the time, date, and place of the hearing. The board shall give the appellant, and any other interested party, a reasonable opportunity to be heard. At the conclusion of the hearing, the board shall make a final determination. The determination shall be reduced to writing, signed by the chair, and filed in the office of the building official. The building official shall record on the order, the date upon which the order was filed in the building official's records. A copy of the order shall be personally delivered or mailed, by first class U.S. mail, postage prepaid, by the building official to the appellant. The decision of the board shall be effective when filed with the building official. 
(Code 1984, § 28-125; Ord. No. 94-39, § 6, 7-12-1994; Ord. No. 2002-34, § 1, 5-28-2002)

ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC SERVICE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Public service tax, F.S. §§ 166.231, 166.232. 

Sec. 54-19. - Levied. 
    There is hereby levied by the city within the corporate limits of the city on each sale of electricity and metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, a tax on the charge made by the seller thereof, which tax in every case shall be paid by the purchaser for the use of said city, at the time of paying the charge therefor. Said tax shall be computed on the basis of ten percent of the total charge made by the seller to the purchaser for said services. 
(Code 1980, § 32-52; Code 1984, § 30-16; Ord. No. 83-27, § 1, 10-11-1983; Ord. No. 85-22, § 1, 4-9-1985; Ord. No. 85-69, art. I, § 1, 11-12-1985; Ord. No. 86-69, § 1, 10-14-1986; Ord. No. 87-20, § 1, 5-26-1987; Ord. No. 89-09, § 1, 3-14-1989; Ord. No. 89-54, § 1, 10-10-1989; Ord. No. 91-53, § 1, 9-24-1991) 
State Law reference- Authority to levy, F.S. § 166.231. 
Sec. 54-20. - Collection required; paying over of monies. 
    It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity or metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, to collect from the purchaser for the use of the city, the tax levied by this article at the time of collecting the selling price charged for each transaction. All such taxes levied and collected during the preceding month shall be reported and paid over on or before the 15th day of each calendar month to the director of finance of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 32-53; Code 1984, § 30-17; Ord. No. 85-69, art. I, § 2, 11-12-1985) 
Sec. 54-21. - Method of collecting utility tax on electricity and metered or bottled gas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any seller to collect the price of any purchase of electricity or metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, without, at the same time, collecting the tax levied by this article in respect to such purchase unless such seller shall elect to assume and pay such tax without collecting such tax from the purchaser. 
(Code 1980, § 32-54; Code 1984, § 30-18; Ord. No. 85-69, art. I, § 3, 11-12-1985) 
Sec. 54-22. - Liability for failure to collect. 
    Any seller failing to collect taxes levied pursuant to this article at the time of collecting the price of any purchase where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax in like manner as if the same had been actually paid to the seller. The city manager shall cause to be brought all suits and actions and take all proceedings in the name of the city as may be necessary for the recovery of said tax. The seller, however, shall not be liable for the payment of such tax upon uncollected charges. 
(Code 1980, § 32-55; Code 1984, § 30-19) 
Sec. 54-23. - Discontinuance of service for nonpayment. 
    If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay to the seller the seller's charge and the tax hereby imposed and as hereby required on account of the purchase for which the charge is made, or either, the seller shall have and is hereby vested with the right, power and authority immediately to discontinue further service to such purchaser until the tax and the seller's bill shall have been paid in full. 
(Code 1980, § 32-56; Code 1984, § 30-20) 
Sec. 54-24. - Keeping of records. 
    Every seller of electricity or metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, shall keep complete records showing all purchases in the city of such commodities or services, which records shall show the price charged upon each purchase, the date thereof, and the records shall be kept for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city during business hours on all business days. The duly authorized agents of the city shall have the right, power and authority to make such transcripts thereof during such times as they may desire. 
(Code 1980, § 32-57; Code 1984, § 30-21; Ord. No. 85-69, art. I, § 4, 11-12-1985) 
State Law reference- Administrative and auditing procedures, F.S. § 166.234. 
Sec. 54-25. - Exemption from tax. 
    The United States of America, the state, and the political subdivisions and agencies, boards, commissions and authorities thereof, and any recognized church in this state for use exclusively for church purposes are hereby exempted from payment of the tax levied by this article. 
(Code 1980, § 32-58; Code 1984, § 30-22; Ord. No. 86-76, § 1, 10-28-1986) 
State Law reference- -Municipalities; public service tax, F.S. § 166.231(5). 
Sec. 54-26. - Separate purchases. 
    Each metered or measured service of electricity or metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, shall constitute a separate purchase. 
(Code 1980, § 32-60; Code 1984, § 30-24) 
Secs. 54-27-54-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMMUNICATIONS SERVICES TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Communications services tax simplification, F.S. § 201.10 et seq. 

Sec. 54-56. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of the city to impose a local communications services tax upon the sales price of private communications services provided within the city in accordance with F.S. ch. 202. 
(Code 1984, § 30-25; Ord. No. 85-69, art. II, § 1, 11-12-1985; Ord. No. 86-76, § 2, 10-28-1986; Ord. No. 2003-62, §§ 1, 2, 8-26-2003) 
Sec. 54-57. - Tax levied. 
    Effective January 1, 2003, the local communications services tax in the city shall be 5.97 percent. Effective January 1, 2004, the local communications services tax in the city shall be decreased to 5.81 percent. 
(Code 1984, § 30-26; Ord. No. 85-69, art. II, § 2, 11-12-1985; Ord. No. 86-76, § 3, 10-28-1986; Ord. No. 2003-62, §§ 1, 2, 8-26-2003) 
Sec. 54-58. - No permit fees assessed; additional tax imposed. 
    The city hereby elects not to require the imposition and collection of permit fees from providers of communications services to use or occupy the city's road or rights-of-way for the installation of communication services as defined in the Communications Services Tax Simplification Law. The city does hereby impose in lieu of the collection of permit fees, the sum or rate of 0.12 percent of additional tax added to the total rate for the local communications services tax as computed pursuant to F.S. § 202.20. 
(Code 1984, § 30-27; Ord. No. 85-69, art. II, § 3, 11-12-1985; Ord. No. 2003-62, §§ 1, 2, 8-26-2003)

ARTICLE IV. - PROPERTY INSURANCE PREMIUM TAX[4] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 54-90. - Purpose of tax levy. 
    The tax levied by this article is in fulfillment of the desire of the city to put into full force and effect the provisions of the firefighters' pension trust fund, F.S. ch. 175. 
(Code 1980, § 32-71; Code 1984, § 30-41) 
Sec. 54-91. - Firefighters' pension trust fund created. 
    There is hereby created a special fund to be known as the municipal firefighters' pension trust fund. All funds received by the city under the provisions of this article shall be paid immediately into the municipal firefighters' pension trust fund, which shall be administered in accordance with the provisions of F.S. ch. 175. 
(Code 1980, § 32-72; Code 1984, § 30-42) 
State Law reference- Municipal firefighters' pension trust fund, F.S. § 174.041. 
Sec. 54-92. - Levy of tax. 
    There is hereby assessed, imposed and levied on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer now engaged in or carrying on, or who shall hereafter engage in or carry on, the business of property insurance as shown by the records of the state office of insurance regulation of the financial services commission, an excise tax in addition to any lawful license or excise tax now levied by the city. The additional tax shall be in the amount of 1.85 percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policy holders on all premiums collected on property insurance policies covering property within the city. In the case of multiple-peril policies with a single premium for both the property and casualty coverages in such policies, 70 percent of the premium shall be used as the basis for the 1.85 percent tax. 
(Code 1980, § 32-73; Code 1984, § 30-43) 
State Law reference- Authority to levy tax, F.S. § 175.101. 
Sec. 54-93. - When payable. 
    The excise tax levied by this article shall be payable annually on March 1 of each year in the manner specified in F.S. § 624.509. Funds shall be paid by the state to the city in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 32-74; Code 1984, § 30-44; Ord. No. 89-03, § 1, 2-28-1989) 
State Law reference- When payable, F.S. § 175.101(3).
