ARTICLE II. - EXTENSIONS OF WATER AND SEWER SYSTEM[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Extension of utilities, F.S. §§ 180.03, 180.04. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-34. - Approval of city council required. 
    No water distribution lines or sewer collection lines shall be extended at the cost of the city without first obtaining approval of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 36-31; Code 1984, § 32-26) 
Sec. 58-35. - Application; contract. 
    Any person desiring the extension of the water distribution line or sewer collection line shall make application to the city manager, who is hereby authorized to enter into a contract with the person so desiring the extension of water distribution or sewer collection lines, and the city manager shall be authorized to sign a contract with the person and the person shall deposit with the city sufficient cost to cover the construction and engineering thereof unless the same is authorized by the city council as set out in section 58-34. 
(Code 1980, § 36-32; Code 1984, § 32-27) 
Sec. 58-36. - Form of contract. 
    The following shall constitute the form of the water and sewer extension contract as required by this article: 
CONTRACT 
This agreement made and entered into this _____ day of _______, _____, by and between the CITY OF MELBOURNE, a duly constituted municipal corporation of the State of Florida, hereinafter referred to as THE CITY, and, _______ a _______ hereinafter referred to as THE CUSTOMER, 
WITNESSETH THAT: 
For and in consideration of the mutual covenants and agreements herein set forth, and for other good and valuable consideration by each of the parties hereto, it is contracted, covenanted and agreed as follows: 
THE CITY hereby agrees to plan, construct, or accept a water main extension from _______ to _______, for an estimated cost _____ DOLLARS and _____ CENTS, ($_____), to be paid in full by the CUSTOMER by deposit with the CITY for said water main extension. 
THE CITY also agrees to refund, upon completion and acceptance by the CITY and the Florida Department of Environmental Protection of the said water main extension, any moneys so deposited by said CUSTOMER with the CITY in excess of the actual construction and engineering costs. 
THE CITY hereby further agrees to require any additional customers who may desire and receive water service from said water main extension between the points of beginning and ending above described to pay, as a connection fee, the pro rata per foot cost of the construction of the water main extension extending across, or the length of, or the width of, any additional customers' real property. The pro rata per foot costs so collected by the CITY from additional customers to the above described water main extension will be refunded to the CUSTOMER as received, to defray the cost of said water main extension. 
The term of this contract shall be for five (5) years from the date hereof, and is not to be construed to be a contingent liability upon the revenues from water sales, sewer revenue, bonded indentures, or water and sewer deposit moneys received by the water fund of the City of Melbourne, Florida. 
(Code 1980, § 36-33; Code 1984, § 32-28; Ord. No. 2001-36, § 4, 7-24-2001) 
Sec. 58-37. - Refund by subsequent connectors. 
    Any person who shall bear the expense for the extension of water distribution lines or sewer collection lines shall be reimbursed on a front foot cost by any person desiring to connect to that portion which has been extended within a five-year period after extension. 
(Code 1980, § 36-34; Code 1984, § 32-29) 
Secs. 58-38-58-62. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POLICIES, RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 58-63. - General policy. 
(a)  Extensions to the water distribution and wastewater collection system shall be made only on the basis of the rules and regulations established herein and with the final approval of the city council. This division does not supersede or alter in any way the provisions for tapping and meter installation for individual services or the charge therefor. 
(b)  As a condition of the issuance of a development order for a site plan, a preliminary development plan, a preliminary subdivision plat, a final subdivision plat, or for endorsement of an Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP) permit application for a waterline extension, the applicant shall pay, at the time of issuance of the development order a nonrefundable capacity reservation fee, as defined in appendix D, chapter 3, for water and sewer service. 
(c)  No water or sewer line extension and no metered water service will be made to any property lying beyond the city limits that is within the Melbourne Urban Service Area as defined in the 2001 Joint Planning Agreement and April 2006 First Amendment, between the city and county unless a petition for annexation is presented to the city council by the owner of contiguous property, or, if noncontiguous, a pre-annexation agreement is executed by the owner and city. Notwithstanding the foregoing provision, water connections in some areas that are urban service plan areas outside the city will not be permitted, even with a pre-annexation agreement, despite contiguity of the parcels or areas because of special circumstances, which may limit their compactness under special conditions. Such circumstances occur where an election could be called in the foreseeable future for the addition of the area to join the city; where the actual service delivery area and/or boundary adjustment would result in the creation of an illegal enclave, or noncompact area otherwise prohibited by state law; or where the service provision is otherwise inconsistent with the city and county utility service provisions for uniform and consistent planning and boundary adjustment. 
(d)  Platted lots within the Melbourne Urban Service Area that are in subdivisions having existing water or sewer service provided under a utility agreement between the subdivision developer and the city shall be exempt from the annexation and pre-annexation requirements. 
(Code 1980, § 36-36; Code 1984, § 32-41; Ord. No. 91-17, § 1, 3-12-1991; Ord. No. 2003-98, § 1, 1-13-2004; Ord. No. 2006-100, § 1, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 58-64. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any individual, partnership, corporation, owner, developer, subdivider, or builder who requests an extension of water and/or wastewater disposal service for any property, area, development or subdivision. 
    City's engineer means the city engineer and/or the city's consulting engineers for the water and sewer system. 
    Development has the meaning given it in F.S. § 380.04. 
    Development order means any order granting, denying, or granting with conditions an application for a development permit. 
    Development permit includes any building permit, fire protection permit, zoning permit, subdivision approval, rezoning certification, construction plan approval, special exception or conditional use, variance, or any other official action of local government having the effect of permitting the development of land. 
    Installation cost or construction cost means the cost of materials, labor, engineering supervision, equipment, and other incidentals necessary for complete water and/or wastewater disposal service extension. 
    Rendition means and refers to the issuance of a letter of determination or order by the community development director, public works and utilities director, city engineer, board, city council, or other decision-maker, the date of execution of which shall be presumed to have been the date set forth in said letter of determination or order. The letter of determination or other order shall be executed by the decision-maker and filed in the records of the clerk or secretary of the community development director, public works and utilities director, city engineer, board, city council, or other decision-maker's office or department. Said clerk or secretary shall record on the letter of determination or other order the date on which said letter of determination or order was filed in the records of the clerk or the secretary. 
    Wastewater disposal service extension and sewer main extension means all necessary gravity and pressure sewer mains, wastewater pumping stations, manholes, valves, fittings, and appurtenances, service laterals from the sewer main to the property line, and any other miscellaneous items which may be involved in, or required by, the wastewater collection system. 
    Water service extension and main extension means all necessary water mains and lines, valves, fittings, hydrants and appurtenances, exclusive of individual service laterals, except when such term pertains to the water service extensions into new subdivisions; in which case, the cost of service laterals from the main to the property line, exclusive of meters, shall be included in the above definition of costs. 
(Code 1980, § 36-37; Code 1984, § 32-42; Ord. No. 2001-36, § 5, 7-24-2001; Ord. No. 2006-100, § 2, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 58-65. - General rules. 
(a)  Applicability. The general rules for the extension of water and sewer mains as hereinafter set forth shall apply to all extensions of the municipal water and/or wastewater collection and disposal systems within and without the city, and without respect to whether the extension is for the benefit of an individual consumer or a new subdivision development. 
(b)  Application. Application for the extension of water and/or wastewater disposal service shall be made in writing on a standard form provided by the city. The executed form shall constitute a binding agreement setting forth the terms and conditions under which the service shall be extended. 
(c)  Economic feasibility. Except as later modified herein, all proposed water and sewer main extensions will be analyzed from the standpoint of sound business practices, and all such extensions must conform to the city's economic feasibility test, in order not to impose a burden upon existing customers which would necessitate future rate increases. An extension will be considered economically feasible if the revenue produced by the connection, or connections to the proposed extension, based on anticipated average daily water consumption and, where applicable, wastewater flows as established by the city's engineer, will equal or exceed the cost of operation and maintenance of the system, plus 150 percent of the principal and interest cost of the extension project, based on a 30-year period of time at the then-usual interest rate. An additional 25 percent of the total cost as established above shall be added to the computed cost to determine the cost of providing service to areas beyond the corporate limits of the city. 
(d)  Customer participation. Where anticipated revenue from the sale of water and wastewater disposal service is insufficient to economically warrant a main extension by the city, main extensions may be considered provided the applicant contributes construction funds in an amount sufficient to make the extension economically feasible under the city's feasibility test. 
(e)  Location and installation. Water and sewer mains will be extended and located only in public rights-of-way, or in easements acceptable to the city. In new subdivisions, water and wastewater facilities may be installed only in streets, alleys or other rights-of-way where the finished grade has been established and approved by the appropriate governmental agency. Further, the extension may not be installed until the street, alley or other rights-of-way have been constructed to at least finished subgrade. 
(1)  Inspection and testing of water distribution and wastewater collection system extensions for acceptance shall not be made until the grading, storm sewers, and street improvements are substantially completed. The final inspection for acceptance will be made only from certified as-built drawings, four sets of which shall be furnished to the city upon completion of the installation. 
(2)  A construction permit, issued by the city, will be required prior to starting work. At that time the applicant desiring a permit must show evidence that he has the approved plans from which to construct the work; and also at which time the inspection cost to the applicant, as established in section 58-68 and all other applicant contributions for the cost of construction as set forth in this subsection (e), shall be paid. 
(3)  A 48-hour notice of intent to start work shall be given to the city water and sewer department, at which time all required construction materials, exclusive of brass fittings, shall be on the job site for inspection. 
(f)  Construction standards. All materials, construction procedures, and installation shall be in strict accordance with the applicable sections of the latest revised edition of the Technical Provisions for Construction of Water Distribution Systems, Technical Provisions for Construction of Sanitary Sewer Systems, Technical Provisions for Construction of Sanitary Sewer Lift Stations, and Technical Provisions for Construction of Reclaimed Water Distribution Systems on file with the city's engineer, and subject to the approval and inspection of the city's engineer at all times. Any material, equipment or installation which may be required and is not covered by the city's specifications shall be approved by the city's engineer prior to the start of construction. 
(g)  Ownership. The ownership of any extension and appurtenances laid in accordance with any application shall at all times remain in the city, and an agreement shall be executed to this effect prior to the start of construction. 
(h)  City's rights reserved. No agreement to extend the city's water or wastewater disposal systems under the provisions of this article shall restrict the city's right to make further extensions nor incur any additional obligation to any original participant should the city subsequently extend any original extension. 
(Code 1980, § 36-38; Code 1984, § 32-43; Ord. No. 2001-36, § 6, 7-24-2001; Ord. No. 2006-100, § 3, 10-24-2006) 
Sec. 58-66. - Extension of service for individual property owners within corporate limits. 
(a)  No water or wastewater disposal service extension will be accomplished to platted areas of the city unless it is determined by the city's engineer that the city's participation is financially feasible. In order to be nondiscriminatory and not to impose a burden upon existing customers by necessitating future increased rates, each extension should be self-sustaining. In instances in which the feasibility test indicates that the extension will not be economically self-sustaining, a determination will be made by the city council with due consideration being given to public need, public health, ecology and other pertinent considerations and shall govern the manner and extent of individual property owner or applicant participation. 
(b)  If required, participation shall be paid for at the time of application for water meter installation or sewer service lateral connection and shall be in addition to the usual connection charge. 
(c)  Deferred payments. 
(1)  The cost for such extension may be paid in installments of principal over a period of five years and amount owed shall constitute service charges benefiting the subject property subject to F.S. §§ 159.17 and 159.18. If the benefiting property owner opts to make monthly installments, the property owner shall pay an administrative charge of $250.00 and the property owner must enter into an agreement in form and substance acceptable to the city, which shall be recorded in the public records and shall also constitute a lien against the property until said extension fee has been paid in full. Failure to pay the installments when due shall result, at the city's sole discretion, in acceleration of the entire principal with interest and penalties. 
(2)  Upon failure to pay the extension fee when due, the city may enforce its interests: 
a.  As a statutory lien for failure to pay a delinquent service charge pursuant to F.S. § 159.17; 
b.  By means of termination of utility services for failure to pay a delinquent service charge pursuant to F.S. § 159.18; and 
c.  By means of any other remedy permitted by federal, state, local or other law. 
(d)  In certain cases where public health and welfare may be endangered by the absence of water and wastewater disposal service, the city council may, in the interest of the public, waive the test for financial feasibility and approve the construction of the required extensions using funds which may then be available in appropriate account of the city's water and sewer system. 
(e)  In cases where the city is providing a municipal service to a newly annexed area by making a water service extension, the property owners who wish to become water customers shall, prior to installation of the connection to the water main, pay an extension fee to defray the cost of the water service extension. 
(1)  For property owners who request capacity within 365 days after the date the new water service extension is cleared for service, the extension fee shall be determined as follows: 
a.  To serve a property having frontage of 100 feet or less on the public right-of-way in which the new water extension is constructed, the extension fee shall be $1,000.00. 
b.  To serve a property having frontage greater than 100 feet on the public right-of-way in which the new water extension is constructed, the extension fee shall be $1,000.00 for the first 100 feet of frontage plus $500.00 for each additional 50 feet of frontage or increment thereof. 
(2)  For property owners within a newly annexed area who do not request capacity within 365 days after the new water extension is cleared for service, the extension fee shall be determined as follows: 
a.  To serve a property having frontage of 100 feet or less on the public right-of-way in which the new water extension is constructed, the extension fee shall be $2,000.00. 
b.  To serve a property having frontage greater than 100 feet on the public right-of-way in which the new water extension is constructed, the extension fee shall be $2,000.00 for the first 100 feet of frontage plus $1,000.00 for each additional 50 feet of frontage or increment thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 36-39; Code 1984, § 32-44; Ord. No. 2002-43, § 1, 6-25-2002; Ord. No. 2005-67, § 5, 6-14-2005; Ord. No. 2006-100, § 4, 10-24-2006; Ord. No. 2012-29, § 1, 7-24-2012) 
Sec. 58-67. - Extension of service for individual property owners outside corporate limits. 
(a)  Generally. No water or wastewater disposal service extension will be accomplished unless it is determined by the city manager that the city's participation is financially feasible. In order to be nondiscriminatory and not to impose a burden upon existing customers by necessitating future increased rates, each extension should be self-sustaining. 
(b)  Conditions of city will construct. If it is determined that the city is to construct the water and/or wastewater service extension, the charge or project cost for extending the system will be based on the current construction costs for labor and materials (including piping, valves, fixtures, etc.), which is deemed necessary by the city's engineer for proper water supply or wastewater disposal service to the applicant's designated area. The cost of engineering design and inspection services, where required, will be added to the construction cost. Amounts advanced for water and/or wastewater system extensions, as noted in this section, may be refunded to the applicant in accordance with the terms of the agreement with the city. In no way will the applicant receive more than he originally advanced for the extension of the water and/or wastewater system extension; nor does the city guarantee full payment to the applicant for his original advancement. All refund contracts shall expire five years from the date of their signing. For each new water and/or wastewater customer who connects directly to the aforementioned systems, as previously noted, a prorated front-foot dollar amount based on the total length of property footage served by the system, along the line for the full street frontage of the customer's property, shall be charged to the customer. The prorated charge will be derived from the original project costs experienced by the applicant for extending the system. The amount refunded to the applicant will be a yearly return totaling the number of new water customers that connect to the water and/or wastewater disposal systems financed by the applicant during the aforementioned five-year period. This amount will be refunded not more than 30 days after the city's closing book audit. Collections made by the city after the five-year period will not be refunded. The conditions and provisions outlined under this subsection will not apply to water and/or wastewater system extensions for developers in new subdivisions. 
(c)  Deferred payments. 
(1)  The cost for such extension may be paid in 60 equal, monthly installments of principal over a period of five years and amount owed shall constitute service charges benefiting the subject property subject to F.S. §§ 159.17 and 159.18. If the benefiting property owner opts to make monthly installments, the property owner shall pay an administrative charge of $250.00 and the property owner must enter into an agreement in form and substance acceptable to the city, which shall be recorded in the public records and shall also constitute a lien against the property until said extension fee has been paid in full. Failure to pay the installments when due shall result, at the city's sole discretion, in acceleration of the entire principal with interest and penalties. 
(2)  Upon failure to pay the extension fee when due, the city may enforce its interests: 
a.  As a statutory lien for failure to pay a delinquent service charge pursuant to F.S. § 159.17; 
b.  By means of termination of utility services for failure to pay a delinquent service charge pursuant to F.S. § 159.18; and 
c.  By means of any other remedy permitted by federal, state, local or other law. 
(d)  Conditions if applicant constructs or has constructed by a private company. Should it be determined that the applicant desires to construct the extended line or employs a private company, partnership or individual to construct and extend the water and/or wastewater system extension to his property, he will comply as follows: 
(1)  All construction and costs experienced in extending the water and/or wastewater system will be at the expense of the applicant. 
(2)  All work in extending and developing the water and/or wastewater disposal system within the development shall be to the satisfaction of the city's engineer. 
(3)  Upon completion of extending and developing the water and/or wastewater disposal system extension, up to and within the development, any extension and appurtenances laid throughout the development shall be deeded by the applicant to the city free and clear of all liens, in accordance with the city's standard contract. 
(4)  Section 58-68, regarding extension of water and/or wastewater disposal services for developers, shall be complied with. 
(Code 1980, § 36-40; Code 1984, § 32-45; Ord. No. 86-83, § 1, 11-11-1986; Ord. No. 2002-43, § 2, 6-25-2002; Ord. No. 2012-29, § 2, 7-24-2012) 
State Law reference- Revenue Bond Act, F.S. § 159.01 et seq. 
Sec. 58-68. - Extension of system service for developers. 
(a)  Applicability. Where applications for extensions are made by individuals, partnerships or corporations interested primarily in the development and sale of land and/or homes, and/or where applications are made for extensions to serve commercial or industrial water and/or wastewater disposal system users, the rules in the following subsections apply. 
(b)  Preliminary planning. Preliminary plans and cost estimates shall be prepared by the applicant's engineer. All extensions of the water and waste cater disposal system shall be planned, designed and supervised by a professional engineer registered in the state. 
(c)  Final construction planning. The applicant shall have the engineering services for final construction planning performed by an engineering firm selected by the applicant. The applicant's engineering design, plans, specifications and cost estimate must be reviewed and approved by the city's engineer. Approval of the plans and specifications must be issued by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection and the approved plans received by the city before construction is started. In the event that construction is not started within the period of one year after the date of the department of environmental protection's approval, resubmission will be required. Upon the completion of construction the applicant's engineer shall submit to both the Florida Department of Environmental Protection and to the city, certified as-built drawings of the final construction. 
(d)  Requirements. The city's engineer shall determine the actual pipe sizes and basic grid layout of the water and wastewater mains and other facilities necessary to extend the city's water distribution and/or wastewater disposal system from the limits of the existing system to the area of development for which service is requested by the applicant. Water mains larger than those required to serve only the areas or developments for which service is requested by the applicant may be required by the city in the interest of future expansion, development and economy. However, the applicant shall be required to pay for the cost of water and sewer mains and other facilities of sufficient size to serve the applicant's development, but in no case less than six-inch pipe for water mains and eight-inch pipe for gravity sewer mains inside the development. Water supply main extensions in general shall be six-inch and eight-inch minimum, and the city shall pay the additional cost for any larger mains required. The city's engineer shall, in the interest of fairness to all concerned, determine the proportionate part of the installation costs to be paid by the applicant and the city, in the event mains larger than required by the specific area or development are to be installed. The minimum size water main shall be six inches and the minimum size gravity sewer mains shall be eight inches. Water and sewer main installations and other related facilities shall be in accordance with the most recent edition of the city's "Detailed Specifications for Materials and Workmanship, Water Distribution System and Sanitary Sewer Lines." The city's engineer shall determine the contribution required by the applicant in all cases requiring city participation in costs. No water or sewer main extensions or subdivision water and/or wastewater disposal system shall be connected to the city's systems until the requirements of this division are met, nor shall such connection be made until an agreement is executed conveying such extensions and systems to the city free and clear of any liens or encumbrances. 
(e)  Deposits for installations. In the event that the installation of water and/or wastewater disposal service is to be accomplished by the city, either by city forces or under contract by the city, the applicant shall deposit with the city his share of the total estimated project costs of the water and wastewater disposal service extension before construction is begun or contract is awarded. The amount of the deposit shall be increased or decreased as required when the actual construction cost of the service extension is determined. 
(1)  In the event the installation of the water service is handled by the applicant through his engineer or contractor, the applicant shall construct and have completed the water distribution and/or wastewater disposal system in his subdivision prior to the award of a contract by the city to make a water or wastewater disposal service extension to the subdivision. In addition, a maintenance and warranty bond shall be furnished to the city and shall remain in effect for one year from the date the system is placed in service and until all work and materials are satisfactory to the city's engineer, and until the applicant furnishes satisfactory evidence that no liens or claims for unpaid bills against the water distribution and/or wastewater disposal system extension exist. If the installation is made by the applicant's contractor, all work will be done under city inspection. Cost of this inspection will be paid for by the applicant. 
(2)  The cost to the developer for city inspection shall be based on the estimated construction, and the inspection fee shall be as set out in section 2-507. 
(Code 1980, § 36-41; Code 1984, § 32-46; Ord. No. 2001-36, § 7, 7-24-2001) 
Sec. 58-69. - Right to decline extensions unless additional guarantees made. 
    Even though the conditions set forth in section 58-68 may be satisfied, some water and/or wastewater disposal system extensions may impose a burden on the city that would be too great to be permanently supported. Therefore, the city reserves the right to decline to construct any extension which it deems uneconomical unless the city is provided additional guarantees, in addition to the contribution and guarantees for the cost of the extension provided for in this article. Such additional guarantees shall be determined by the city's engineer and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 36-42; Code 1984, § 32-47) 
Sec. 58-70. - Disposition of funds received. 
    The city shall not be obligated to pay interest on any advance made to it. All sums advanced to the city under the terms of this article for extension of water and/or wastewater disposal systems shall be deposited by the city to the credit of the city according to appropriate existing resolutions. 
(Code 1980, § 36-43; Code 1984, § 32-48) 
Sec. 58-71. - Supplementary regulations concerning certain areas. 
(a)  Wickham Road. 
(1)  Reimbursement to the city's water and sewer system for the cost of making water service available shall be required when a water service connection is made to the water main in Wickham Road from any location within the following areas: 
a.  East side of Wickham Road right-of-way. Begin at the south rights-of-way line of the Pineda Causeway and run south along the easterly rights-of-way of Wickham Road to the north line of Living Homes Estate, Phase 5, as recorded in Plat Book 25, Page 67, of the public records of Brevard County, Florida, for a total distance of 8,580 feet. 
b.  West side of Wickham Road right-of-way. Begin at a point 250 feet south from the intersection of westerly extension of the south rights-of-way line of the Pineda Causeway and the westerly rights-of-way line of Wickham Road and run south along the westerly right-of-way of Wickham Road to the north rights-of-way line of Post Road, excepting therefrom the frontages of the Brevard County property (660 feet, more or less) and the First Baptist Church of South Brevard property (660 feet more or less) for a net total distance of 9,585 feet. 
(2)  The city's engineer shall determine the amount of reimbursement due the city's water and sewer system pursuant to the terms of this subsection (a). The formula listed below which produces the greatest amount of revenue shall be used by the city's engineer in determining reimbursement due: 
a.  $12.44 per front foot, multiplied by the frontage of the parcel served, but not less than 100 feet. 
b.  $245.94 per gallon per minute (gpm) multiplied by the estimated flow requirements (gpm) of the parcel to be served by the connection. 
(b)  U.S. 192 between John Rodes Boulevard and Brandywine Lane. 
(1)  Reimbursement to the city's water and sewer system for the cost of making water service available shall be required when a water service connection is made to the 20-inch water main located in U.S. 192, between John Rodes Boulevard and Brandywine Lane, or to other water mains which may be extended from the 20-inch main from any location within the following described area or from any other area where service is obtained from the 20-inch main:

Thence southerly along the west boundary line of said section to the southwest corner of said section; thence easterly along the south boundary line of said section to the intersection of the southerly extension of the west boundary line of Parcel 758.1 with the south section line; thence northerly along the west boundary line of Parcel 758.1 to the northwest corner of Parcel 758.1; thence westerly along the westerly extension of the north boundary line of Parcel 758.1 to the southeast corner of Parcel 757; thence northerly along the east boundary line of Parcel 757 to the northeast corner of Parcel 757; thence westerly along the north boundary line of Parcels 757 and 756 to the northwest corner of Parcel 756; thence northerly along the west boundary line of Parcels 751 and 753 to the south right-of-way line of State Road No. 500 (U.S. 192); thence easterly along the south right-of-way line of U.S. 192 to the intersection point with the east right-of-way line of Brandywine; thence northerly to the southwest corner of Parcel 8; thence easterly and northerly along the northerly and westerly right-of-way line of S.R. 500 (U.S. 192) and State Road No. 9 (1-95) to the intersection point with the north boundary line of Section 3, Township 28 South, Range 36 East; thence westerly along the north boundary line of said section to the northwest corner of said section and the point of beginning. 
b.  East of 1-95. Commencing at the intersection of the east right-of-way line of State Road No. 9 (1-95) with the south boundary line of Section 3, Township 28 South, Range 36 East, Brevard County, Florida, said point also being the point of beginning. Thence easterly along the south boundary line of said section to the southeast corner of said section; thence continuing easterly along the south boundary line of Section 2, Township 28 South, Range 36 East, to the intersection point with the southerly extension of the west boundary line of the National Police Home Foundation Inc., Subdivision No. 51, Second Addition (PB 20-112) Block B; thence northerly along the west boundary line of said subdivision to the northwest corner of Lot 20 of said subdivision; thence easterly along the north boundary of said subdivision to the intersection with the southerly extension of the east boundary line of Parcel 503; thence northerly along the east boundary line of Parcel 503 to the intersection with the south right-of-way line of S.R. 500 (U.S. 192); thence westerly along the south right-of-way line of S.R. 500 (U.S. 192) to the northeast corner of Parcel 551; thence southerly along the east boundary line of Parcel 551 to the southeast corner of said parcel; thence westerly along the south boundary line of parcel 551 to the southwest corner of said parcel; thence northerly along the west boundary line of Parcel 551 to the southeast corner of Parcel 552; thence westerly along the south boundary line of parcel 552 to the southwest corner of said parcel; thence northerly along the west boundary line at Parcel 552 to the intersection with the south right-of-way line of S.R. 500 (U.S. 192); thence westerly and southerly along the south right-of-way line of S.R. 500 (U.S. 192) and the east right-of-way line of State Road No. 9 (1-95) to the intersection point with the south section line of Section 3, Township 28 South, Range 36 East, and the point of beginning. 
(2)  The requirements of this subsection (b) shall not apply to any properties which are subject to the city's agreement with Brandywine Estates, Limited, dated May 15, 1985. The city engineer shall calculate the amount of reimbursement due the city's water and sewer system pursuant to the terms of this subsection (b). The fee used to calculate the reimbursement shall be based on $0.98 per gallon per day multiplied by the estimated flow requirements as measured by gallons, per day, of the user connecting to the system. 
(c)  Dairy Road.

Said water connection may be for metered service, fire protection line, or for water main extension.

Secs. 58-72-58-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 58-101-58-128. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 58-129. - Penalty for nonpayment of deposit. 
    Any consumer who fails to pay the required water security deposit shall be terminated as a customer and the supply of water to such customer immediately turned off. 
(Code 1980, § 36-4; Code 1984, § 32-68) 
Sec. 58-130. - Prerequisite for commencement of water service. 
    No water shall be supplied or furnished to new or future consumers of utility service unless and until such consumers shall have first made a request to the city, provided an executed lease agreement or proof of ownership, and established the required security deposit. 
(Code 1980, § 36-45; Code 1984, § 32-70; Ord. No. 2012-19, § 6, 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 58-131. - Water impact fees. 
(a)  Service to properties or customers. Each customer requesting potable water capacity from the city's water system shall, prior to the installation of the connection to the water main, pay the following amounts to provide service to properties or customers and to all customers presently connected to the city's water system when additional development, structural changes, additions or changes in permitted use shall result in an additional impact to the city's water system. Water impact fees shall not be transferable from one property to another property. 
(1)  Single-family residence. All development which is considered an individually metered residential unit shall be considered one equivalent residential connection ERC). The water impact fee per one ERC shall be $1,540.00. 
(2)  Multiple-family, condominium, mobile home trailer and motor home parks, including all related facilities not having individual water meter connections, or other multiple living units or developments of mobile-type homes. The water impact fees for each living unit served by a master meter shall be determined in accordance with the following schedule. If the development served by the master meter includes individually metered nonresidential use, then the water impact fee for such individually metered nonresidential use will be determined in addition to the applicable water impact fees as shown below for this customer designation. 
ERC 
Factor 
per Living 
Unit Water 
Impact 
Fee Duplex (1 or 2 bedrooms) 0.833 $1,283.00 Duplex (3 or more bedrooms) 1.000 $1,540.00 Multifamily (1 bedroom) 0.583 $898.00 Multifamily (efficiency less than 500 square feet) 0.500 $770.00 Multifamily (2 bedrooms) 0.833 $1,283.00 Multifamily (3 or more bedrooms) 1.000 $1,540.00 Mobile home (1 or 2 bedrooms) 0.667 $1,027.00 Mobile home (3 or more bedrooms) 0.833 $1,283.00  
(3)  Hotels and motels not having individual water connections. The water impact fees for each unit that is not individually metered shall be considered as 0.75 ERCs per unit. The water impact fee per each unit shall be $1,155.00 per unit. 
(4)  Housing for older persons not having individual water connections. The water impact fees for each unit of housing as defined by F.S. § 760.29, as amended from time to time, that is not individually metered shall be considered as 0.75 ERCs per unit. The water impact fee per unit of housing shall be $1,155.00 per unit. 
(5)  Commercial connections. 
a.  For all commercial and nonresidential connections not specifically identified in one of the classifications listed above, the water impact fees shall be based on the average dependable daily capacity for the development of property identified by the applicant and as certified for the applicant by a registered state professional engineer using the city's potable water concurrency standards in appendix D, article IV, chapter 3, section 3.46, and as approved by the city expressed on a gallons per day basis multiplied by $6.417 per gallon of capacity. In no event will the water impact fee charged to a commercial customer property be less than $1,540.00. For each commercial customer that is presently connected to the city's water system that constructs structural changes, additions, or changes in permitted use of such property that shall result in an additional capacity impact to the city's water system, the water impact fee shall be based on the net increase in the average dependable daily capacity for the structural changes, additions, or changes in permitted use as determined above expressed on a gallons per day basis multiplied by $6.417 per gallon of capacity. 
b.  To the extent that the average daily flow for a commercial connection during any consecutive 12-month period is greater than the average dependable daily capacity for which water impact fees have been paid, an additional water impact fee shall be assessed for the excess flow calculated in accordance with this section. No refund or credit shall be afforded to the owner of the property in the event that diminution of use occurs. 
(6)  Meter size. The city reserves the right to determine the meter size that will be required for the service requested. 
(b)  Payment of fees. 
(1)  Applicants within the city limits. All owners or applicants for water service to serve a development within the city shall pay in full the water impact fees in effect at the time, and as a condition, of issuance of building permit or other final development order. 
(2)  Deferral of payment. An owner or applicant for a nonresidential or mixed use project within the city may request to defer the payment of these fees until the issuance of the certificate of occupancy, if such project will create jobs. 
a.  The creation of jobs may be temporary construction jobs and at least two permanent jobs that would be located within the new development. 
b.  The request to defer payment shall be administered by the community development director, or designee, upon receipt of a statement indicating the number of permanent and temporary jobs created. 
(3)  Applicants outside the city limits. All owners or applicants for water service to serve a development project not in the city shall pay in full the water impact fees in effect at the time and as a condition of clearance of the waterline for service. 
(4)  Any owners or developers of individual development projects not requiring a Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP) permit or other approval and requiring only metered service shall pay in full the water impact fees in effect at the time and as a condition of installation of the connection to the water main. The aforesaid payment shall apply except as otherwise provided in an agreement between the city and a property owner or developer, or as otherwise provided in a development order stipulated to by the property owner or developer. 
(5)  Any capacity reservation fees previously paid per appendix D, chapter 3, shall be applied toward the amount of water impact fees owed at the time of payment of the then-applicable impact fee. 
(c)  Use of monies. 
(1)  The city hereby confirms the establishment of a separate capital account for water impact fees collected and shall recognize such account separate and apart from all other accounts of the city. All such water impact fees received by the city shall be deposited in such capital account immediately upon receipt. 
(2)  The monies deposited in the water impact fee capital account shall be used solely for the purpose of providing the necessary utility facilities and improvements required by new development and growth of the water service area and shall include, but not be limited to, the following expenditures: 
a.  Design or construction plan preparation; 
b.  Permitting and related fees; 
c.  Land acquisition, including any costs of acquisition or condemnation; 
d.  Construction of water system buildings, facilities, structures, or improvements and additions thereto; 
e.  Relocating utilities required by the construction of buildings, facilities, structures, or improvements and additions thereto; 
f.  Cost of construction management, inspection, or both; 
g.  Surveying, soils and material testing, and the evaluation and development of raw water resources and supplies; 
h.  Acquisition of plant or equipment necessary or convenient to expand the water system; and 
i.  Payment of principal and interest, reserves and cost of issuance under any bonds or other indebtedness issued by the city to fund growth impacted improvements, and additions to the water system. 
(3)  Funds on deposit in the water impact fee account shall not be used for any expenditure that would be classified as routine maintenance, operation or repair expenses. 
(4)  The monies deposited in the water impact fee account shall be used solely to provide improvements and additions to the water system required by growth or new development which will be provided water service by the city either on a wholesale or retail basis. 
(5)  Any funds on deposit, which are not immediately necessary for expenditure, may be invested by the city. All income and earnings derived from such investments shall be deposited in the water impact fee account and be used as provided herein. 
(Code 1980, § 36-46; Code 1984, § 32-71; Ord. No. 86-38, §§ 1, 2, 6-10-1986; Ord. No. 87-48, § 2, 9-8-1987; Ord. No. 89-29, § 1, 7-25-1989; Ord. No. 91-32, §§ 1, 2, 5-28-1991; Ord. No. 91-48, §§ 4, 5, 10-8-1991; Ord. No. 93-7, § 1, 2-9-1993; Ord. No. 95-30, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 97-42, § 1, 8-26-1997; Ord. No. 99-14, §§ 1, 2, 4-13-1999; Ord. No. 2001-36, § 9, 7-24-2001; Ord. No. 2003-99, § 1, 1-13-2004; Ord. No. 2005-67, § 7, 6-14-2005; Ord. No. 2006-100, § 5, 10-24-2006; Ord. No. 2009-20, § 1, 5-26-2009, eff. 10-1-2009; Ord. No. 2011-52, § 1, 11-8-2011; Ord. No. 2012-19, § 7(32-71), 5-22-2012)

Sec. 58-133. - Water service rates. 
(a)  Description of rate structure. 
(1)  The rate charged for potable water service to each customer shall consist of a monthly service charge based on the number of equivalent residential connections (ERCs) determined by the city periodically for the premises or point of connection, which shall serve as the minimum bill, and a gallonage charge for each unit of 1,000 gallons or portion thereof as metered at the premises or point of connection. Such charges shall be due and payable on a monthly basis. The property owner for the premises that receives the potable water service from the city shall be the customer except during such time that service is requested by a tenant customer, located at such premises, as allowed by the property owner. The rates for potable water service are charged based on the customer's location. Customers located within the city limits are charged the inside city rate. Customers located outside the city limits are charged the outside city rate. 
(2)  As long as service is provided to the premises of the property owner, the property owner shall be considered as the customer, except as noted above. Service shall be considered as being provided to the premises if there is installed a water meter available to measure potable water service to such premises. The temporary discontinuance of service at the request of a customer, whether the property owner or new owner/tenant customer, does not render a customer inactive from service availability and billing basis and shall not be considered as the discontinuance of service to such premises and the customer shall be responsible for all monthly charges due for the provision of service. 
(b)  Monthly service charge. 
(1)  Each customer connected to the city's potable water system shall pay a monthly service charge based on the number of equivalent residential connections (ERCs) and the effective rate per ERC being served at such connection as determined by the city for each potable water customer as defined in the following table: 
Rate per ERC - All Customers Effective

(2)  The determination of the ERCs shall be calculated as follows: 
a.  Individually metered residential service customers includes all connections for individually metered dwelling units as defined by appendix D, article IV, chapter 3, section 3.46. Each such individually metered residential unit shall equate to one equivalent residential connection or ERC for the application of the monthly service charge. One ERC shall represent an average daily potable water flow of 240 gallons per day. 
b.  All other customers not classified as individually metered residential service customers shall be calculated individually for the determination of the number of ERCs applicable at a metered premises. 
For existing customers classified under this customer designation, the determination of the total ERCs shall be based on the greater of:

Sec. 58-134. - Capacity reservation. 
    All owners or applicants for water service to serve a development project located outside the city shall comply with the Melbourne Concurrency Code, appendix D, chapter 3, article I and article IV, regarding potable water, except that the city's capacity reservation period timeframes and the city's capacity reservation fee schedules of payment shall not be modified by development orders issued by other jurisdictions without the express written consent of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 32-74.1; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 6-14-2011) 
Sec. 58-135. - Free service; connection to comply with article. 
(a)  No free service or service not in accordance with the established rate schedule shall be furnished. In the event water service or related services are requested in a form which is not covered by this Code, the city manager or his designate shall negotiate or establish a service charge which will be in accordance with the city's covenants with bond holders. 
(b)  No person shall make or cause to be made a connection to the water system except as provided herein. 
(Code 1980, § 36-53; Code 1984, § 32-77) 
Sec. 58-136. - Construction water sales. 
    A customer may tap a fire hydrant with permission of the city and for construction use only upon placing a meter deposit and paying for the water used based upon the volume registered by the meter calculated using the then applicable inside city rate plus a monthly service charge based on an ERC value of eight. The construction water sales security deposit shall be based upon meter size as set forth in the schedule below:
